HEADLINE: Cuomo's Plan to Divert School Aid Comes Under Fire

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposal to divert state aid from wealthy to poor school districts came under attack today from officials in New York City's suburbs, which would bear the brunt of the cuts needed to make the plan work.
In Nassau, Suffolk, Rockland and Westchester Counties, where about 80 percent of the school districts would lose aid under the plan, school officials predicted that Mr. Cuomo's proposal would lead to teacher layoffs, larger classes, fewer courses and higher property taxes. 
 And the cuts were not reserved for affluent areas. In several districts with large pockets of poverty, including Hempstead and Yonkers, the new formula would reduce aid.
 
'Devastating' Reductions
 "This would be devastating," said Eddy Bayardelle, superintendent of the Hempstead School District in Nassau County. The school system would lose $1.9 million under the plan, or 9 percent of its state aid, even though about half of its students are so poor they qualify for a free lunch program. "You're looking at one of the neediest school districts, not just in Long Island, but in the entire state," he said.
Under Mr. Cuomo's plan, poor districts would receive up to $1,400 for each student enrolled in free lunch programs, a standard measure of poverty. The plan would do that, in part, by taking money from wealthy districts with low tax rates.
There is little question that the plan faces an uphill battle in the Legislature. Even in the best of economic times, state education aid is a thorny issue, and legislators are wont to fight for every penny they can get for their local schools.
But Mr. Cuomo, by his own admission, has chosen a particularly difficult time to make his proposal. Not only does he want to change the way the state divides its pot of school aid, he wants to shrink the pot itself by $130 million.
 
A Double Hit
 As a result, wealthier districts would, in effect, take a double hit -- first from the diversion to poorer districts, and second from the budget cut. Under the plan, about 70 percent of the $130 million cut would be shouldered by Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland Counties.
And on the flip side, because there is little money available in the state education pot, even those districts that stand to gain from the new formula will not gain a great deal. New York City, for instance, would receive an additional $6.2 million, an increase of 0.2 percent.
The fact that deep cuts would hit districts represented by Democrats as well as Republicans is likely to cause strong bipartisan opposition to Mr. Cuomo's proposal.
Reflecting the uncertainty that the plan faces in the Legislature, Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin, Democrat from Queens, declined to comment on it today. "It's very complicated," said Steven A. Greenberg, Mr. Weprin's spokesman. "We can't look at it in three or four hours and respond."
 
Republicans Critical
 But among Republicans, response to the plan was critical and swift. "Under the guise of reform, the Governor pits region against region, school district against school district, in an effort to unfairly manipulate the school aid formula," said Senator Ralph J. Marino, Republican from Oyster Bay and the Senate majority leader.
The proposal is based in part on the findings of a commission appointed by the Governor and the Legislature in 1988 that recommended that the state provide more aid to poor districts and to regions where the cost of living is high.
Mr. Cuomo's plan would do that in several ways. Districts with large numbers of children who receive free lunches -- which are available only to low-income families -- would receive millions more in aid. The proposal would also reduce aid to wealthy districts that have low local tax rates and increase aid to poor districts with high tax rates.
The plan would also increase aid to districts where teacher salaries and construction costs are high, a measure that would benefit both New York City and its suburbs. The plan also is designed to make districts cut costs, particularly for transportation, Mr. Cuomo's aides said.
As details about how the plan would affect each of the state's 700 school districts became public today, many officials said they were stunned by the depth and breadth of the cuts.
 
'One More Time'
 In the Plainview-Old Bethpage School District in Nassau County, which would lose $690,000, or 10 percent of its state aid, officials recalled how, just two years ago, they had laid off 35 teachers and eliminated several advanced placement courses after receiving a $6 million cut in state aid.
"I have a major problem biting the bullet one more time, one more time, one more time," said Henry L. Grishman, the school superintendent.
In East Islip in Suffolk County, which has joined other school districts in a lawsuit to force the state to distribute more aid to poorer districts, school officials said they had expected to benefit from Mr. Cuomo's plan. Instead, they face a $2.1 million cut in aid.
"There are a number of wealthier districts who had lower cuts," said Mike Griffin, the school superintendent. "On its face, this doesn't appear to achieve what the Governor says it will."
 
Mixed Impact
 In several districts, the proposed formula would have a mixed impact. Yonkers and Hempstead, for instance, would receive additional aid based on the fact that many of their students receive free lunches because their parents' incomes are low.
But on balance, both districts would lose aid because the proposed formula calculates a district's wealth in a new way, basing it more on the income of residents than on the value of their property. Because Yonkers and Hempstead are above the state average in per capita income, they would lose aid.
Mr. Cuomo has acknowledged that his proposal comes at a time when the depth of cuts is likely to cost him substantial political support.
"It's going to be difficult to explain to people in Nassau County that you have had the benefit for years of an unfair formula," Mr. Cuomo said Tuesday when he presented his proposal. "The ideal time to do it would be a time when you have so much money that no one gets hurt. My judgment was: if you don't do it now, you'll be left not doing it at all."

HEADLINE: More Donors to Neediest Honor a Slain Principal

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
The life and death of Patrick Daly, the elementary school principal who inspired thousands of children in the Brooklyn neighborhood of Red Hook, continues to weigh heavily on the minds of contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Since The Times published an article last month on people who donated to the fund in his memory, dozens of others have followed suit.
Members of the Kaufman family of Wilton, Conn., said they were deeply moved by the story of Mr. Daly, who had dedicated his career to the troubled neighborhood before he was shot on Dec. 17 when he walked into the crossfire of what the police said was a drug dispute. 
 "In his own unassuming way, he was a most remarkable man who quite literally gave his life for what he believed in," the Kaufmans wrote. "Our lives are enriched just by knowing of Mr. Daly." They gave $200 to the Neediest Cases.
Jean Robl of Monroeville, Pa., sent $20, noting that "as a former elementary school art teacher, I know how crucial the principal is to any elementary school." Michael and Margaret Buckner of Manhattan gave $100, and Bernard and Irene Murphy of Gainesville, Fla., contributed $15 in memory of Mr. Daly.
 
'Inner Light'
 In a letter to the fund with his $100 donation, Jonathan B. Leonard of Manhattan said he felt as if all of New York City was mourning Mr. Daly. He wrote that the principal was "a man of compassion and vision whose inner light shone bright amid the turbulence and chaos of our times."
"May his memory lead us all to a place of greater understanding, mercy and grace," he said.
Since the early years of this century, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has supported charities that help thousands of people free themselves from poverty. The campaign is facing a drop in donations while social-service agencies report a decline in government aid and a surge in demand because of the recession.
The Times pays the expenses for the fund's campaign, so all contributions go directly to the charities. This year's appeal, the 81st, ends on Feb. 28.
Besides giving in memory of Mr. Daly, many of these contributors also dedicated their donations to neighborhoods like Red Hook, where residents are struggling against a tide of drugs and guns. They asked that the money be used for counseling, after-school programs and other services for children.
Judith Block of Manhattan gave $35. Mr. Daly's "life was taken suddenly, unfairly and horribly," she wrote. "I hope this money will be used to help unfortunate children."
Christopher J. Weeks of Providence, R.I., sent $25. "The world needs more people with his courage and conviction to make a difference," Mr. Weeks wrote.

HEADLINE: Letterman's No. 1 Question: Where?;
New York City and Los Angeles Are Weighed for New Show

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
If this were a late-night talk show and we had limped through the monologue and the first commercial and it was time for the top 10 list, the No. 1 question would be (drum roll, please): Now that David Letterman has decided to switch networks, will he also switch cities?
Boosters on both coasts are already debating whether Mr. Letterman -- whose frantic, neurotic humor has had an unmistakable New York City flavor since he went on the air 11 years ago -- would be as funny if he packed up and headed for Los Angeles.
 
10. Earthquakes!

 He wouldn't have a lot of his biggest running gags. No car-swallowing potholes, no "radioactive steam" billowing from city streets (or from a pipe behind his desk), no Connecticut state police to hand out "greeting cards" that look suspiciously like speeding tickets, no "shoulderless" Merritt Parkway on which to hand them out, no Donald J. Trump to lay carpet in his Rockefeller Center office when NBC dawdled. 
 "The show has something in New York that you can't get in Los Angeles," said the Amazing Kreskin, who calls himself a "mentalist," does not use a first name and has done card tricks and word-guessing games in his occasional appearances on Mr. Letterman's show. "The New York audience is the dream of the live performer or entertainer."
 
9. Cher Lives There
 But apparently the New York audience is not the most important dream of everyone on Mr. Letterman's staff. One of his co-executive producers, Peter Lassally, worked on the "Tonight" show before taking his current assignment last year. Mr. Lassally still has a house in California and has said in the past that he would like to go back.
Mr. Letterman's other co-executive producer, Robert Morton, is said to favor keeping the show in New York City once it moves to CBS from NBC later in the year.
And Mr. Letterman? He has houses on both coasts: one in Connecticut, the other in Malibu, Calif.
 
8. N.Y. Has More Stupid Pets
 The conventional show business wisdom is that New York City offers better audiences, Los Angeles better guests. This may be an important consideration in the war with Jay Leno and NBC's "Tonight." Or it may not.
 
7. No Skyscraper Backdrops
 "In my own case, it didn't matter," said Steve Allen, who did "Tonight" from New York City in the 1950's and a syndicated talk show from Los Angeles in the 1960's. "I was born in New York, but I love the whole planet. What is more important to me is the kind of theater you get into, the physical setup. Some studios are good for comedy, others are not. I like to do stunts and unusual things, and if he isn't required to work in the CBS building, he might consider looking over other studios."
 
6. I <heart> N.Y. (Really)

 Which is what Mr. Letterman's staff has been doing. Ann L. Morfogen, a vice president and spokeswoman for CBS, said they had inspected the Ed Sullivan Theater, on Broadway at 54th Street, where its stiff-shouldered namesake presided over "a really big shue" until the 1970's. They have also toured studios at the CBS Broadcast Center on West 57th Street between 11th and 12th Avenues, where Ms. Morfogen said Geraldo Rivera tapes his talk show.
 
5. What Speed Limits?
 Geraldo Rivera? What more could Mr. Letterman, who used to drop in on Phil Donahue at NBC, want?
But his staff is also studio-shopping in Los Angeles, Ms. Morfogen said. "No decision has been made," she said, "and I don't think anyone could take a read on which way they are leaning at this point."
 
 4. No Leggy Rockettes
 Mr. Letterman said last week that he was "leaning toward staying in New York."
Determined to prevent him from leaning the other way, Richard Brick, the director the city's Office of Film, Theatre and Broadcasting, met with Mr. Letterman's producers to discuss what incentives, if any, the city could offer to keep the show here.
 
3. Ocean on Wrong Side
 The Dinkins administration has not yet prepared a package of incentives, which often include tax credits and other financial benefits, because it does not know what the Letterman show might need, said Jennifer Kimball, a spokeswoman for Barry F. Sullivan, the Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development.
The concern about not losing Mr. Letterman comes on the heels of a report that found that a long boycott by Hollywood film producers growing out of a labor dispute in 1991 had caused a lasting talent drain in New York City. Even though fewer than 200 jobs are at stake, city officials appear to be courting Mr. Letterman as assiduously as they would court a Wall Street power broker or a garment-district ready-to-wear mogul. That may be because losing "Late Night With David Letterman" would be more about prestige and New York City's self perception than about money.
 
2. Paul Would Burn, Not Tan
 New York? Los Angeles? Either way, Mr. Letterman is sure to leave NBC's Rockefeller Center studio.
For viewers, that probably means no more Meg Parsont. From time to time, Mr. Letterman dials her phone number, and she waves out her window across the street from NBC. One night Mr. Letterman sent over a justice of the peace to perform a marriage ceremony for a couple who wanted to marry on either "Star Trek" or "Late Night." For her birthday, he arranged for a marching band to high-step its way down 49th Street.
 
1. One Word: Buttafuoco
 "I will miss having him as my neighbor," she said. "Maybe he felt like they needed to get out of a rut, though I thought the rut was working pretty well."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Lower And Gold Prices Advance

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mostly lower in moderate trading on world currency markets yesterday.
Gold prices advanced across the board. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $329.90 an ounce, up $1.30 from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank said gold added 85 cents an ounce to a late bid price of $329.65. 
 The dollar declined in foreign trading and continued to lose ground against most currencies when trading shifted to domestic markets. Analysts said dealers were sidetracked by the inauguration of President Bill Clinton.
"People want to consolidate their positions while they see what a new regime will bring," said Randolph Donney, director of research at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
Meanwhile, he said, there is growing skepticism about how strong the economy will prove to be in the first quarter. "People are worried that we may see a little bit of a lull after the good showings in the third and fourth quarters last year," Mr. Donney said.
After opening their wallets and spending heartily around Christmas, consumers may be more frugal in the early part of the year, traders are reckoning.
Separately, the British pound was hit hard following a report showing that British retail sales fell in December, in contrast to an expected increase. In London the pound fell to $1.5410, from $1.5470 late Tuesday. In New York it cost $1.5440 to buy one pound, less expensive than Tuesday's $1.5465.
Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 125.39 Japanese yen, from 125.46 yen on Tuesday. Later in London, it fell to 124.94 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 124.63 yen, down from 125.50 yen on Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.6038 German marks, down from 1.6110; 1.4685 Swiss francs, down from 1.4725; 5.4190 French francs, down from 5.4500; 1,464.00 Italian lire, down from 1,472.00, and 1.2814 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2784.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.6060 German marks, down from 1.6105; 1.4712 Swiss francs, down from 1.4739; 5.4275 French francs, down from 5.4490; 1.8050 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8120; 1,466.75 Italian lire, down from 1,478.00, and 1.2799 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2768.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Market Funds Slow Their Fall in Latest Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered by tax-exempt and taxable money market funds were down in the latest reporting week, but the declines were not as severe as those posted a week earlier.
The latest survey by The Money Fund Report shows tax-exempt yields down sharply for the week that ended Tuesday, affected by money flowing into funds from recent huge redemptions of municipal bonds. 
 Walter S. Frank, the publication's chief economist, noted that investors might not be willing to risk moving money out of tax-exempt funds merely to gain a percentage point or two in taxables over the short run. The end-of-season pressures brought on by tax strategies and other portfolio shifts may be only a couple weeks off, Mr. Frank said, and yields could head to levels higher than present ones.
Assets of tax-exempt funds for the week declined $777 million, to a total of $103.1 billion. The average number of days left to maturity of securities held in tax-free fund portfolios held at 55, analysts said.
The seven-day average compounded yield for tax-exempt funds dropped 22 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 1.73 percent. The average seven-day simple yield dropped by 21 basis points, to 1.72 percent. Statisticians for the publication calculate that over a 30-day period the compounded yield is averaging 2.32 percent, and the simple yield is 2.30 percent.
Not assuming state taxes, the taxable equivalent of the average seven-day compounded yield this week for taxpayers in the 28 percent bracket is about 2.40 percent. For those in the 31 percent bracket, it is about 2.51 percent.
Among tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million surveyed by The Money Fund Report, the Strong Municipal Money Market fund had the highest yield, at 2.42 percent. The fund is distributed by Strong/Corneliuson Capital Management in Milwaukee.
 
Taxable Yield: 2.81%
 Assets of taxable money market funds rose by $1 billion, to a total $482.2 billion. Total assets of institutional funds fell by $200 million, while retail fund assets grew by $1.2 billion.
Analysts said the average days left to maturity of securities in taxable money market portfolios rose to 59 from 58.
The seven-day average compounded yield for taxable funds dropped 6 basis points, to 2.81 percent. The average seven-day simple yield dropped by 6 basis points, to 2.77 percent.
Olde Premium Plus Money Market Series, distributed by Olde Asset Management Inc. in Detroit, had the best return for the week, yielding 3.75 percent.
For comparative purposes, banks adjusted their yields down a basis point in the week, to 2.74 percent.

HEADLINE: Market Place

BYLINE: By Agis Salpukas

 BODY:
IN December, the airline industry seemed to have turned the corner from a period of low traffic, unstable pricing and rising fuel prices. A series of fare increases raised prices by about 10 to 15 percent, and there were signs that more people were flying.
Last week, however, the industry seemed again to be in disarray as several carriers battled each other to get people out of January ruts and flying to sunny islands or snowy ski slopes. 
 Northwest Airlines began the tussle when it announced a long-term restructuring of its lowest discount fares by offering discounts of 20 percent for two people traveling together, 30 percent for three and 40 percent for four or more.
Two days later, Delta Air Lines tore into Northwest's effort by offering cuts of 30 to 40 percent without the requirement of having passengers fly together. The move forced Northwest to back off and suspend the cuts.
Thus Delta was able to head off a long-term lowering of discount fares by putting into effect deep, but short-term, cuts.
On the surface, the industry still seems unable to build a long-term pricing structure that is both stable and simple -- something that Robert L. Crandall, the chairman of American, tried to do last March. That effort was torn apart by a promotion by Northwest, which American answered with huge reductions of its own.
But there are some signs that the industry is nearing a better balance between the number of seats and the number of fliers.
 Capacity grew about 4 percent a year during the last decade, but jumped last year for the Big Three -- American, United and Delta -- which had a huge increase in the number of new planes being delivered. The 14 percent increase in the number of seats of the Big Three was partly offset, however, by the disappearance of some carriers, including Pan Am and Midway, which kept the overall industry capacity growth at 4 percent.
But that was still high at a time when the recession cut traffic growth.
Paul Karos, airline analyst for First Boston, estimated that capacity growth this year would only be about 3 percent, and that by 1994 there could be a big reduction as recent cancellations and postponements of new planes by the weakening major carriers begin to take effect.
He said he expects the carriers struggling under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, like America West and Trans World Airlines, to survive because they have good cash positions.
But the need of these carriers to fill seats could force them to continue to undercut the fares of healthier carriers, making it more difficult for the industry to keep prices firm.
There are also some new carriers that have begun to fly, like Kiwi International, operating from Newark, and Reno Air of Nevada. And this week another new carrier, Ultrair, began flying out of Houston.
But the track record of start-ups has been poor. As they grow and challenge the large established carriers, they often do not have the financial staying power to last through protracted battles to stay in major markets.
Thus the coming year could be the time when the industry, which has shrunk to five huge dominant carriers, may be able to begin using restraint on fare discounting and agree on a pricing structure that reflects their dominance of the nation's route system.
This could mean bad news to consumers in terms of rising fares but good news to investors, who could see airlines recovering from two years of huge losses.

HEADLINE: Circle in the Square Struggling to Survive

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
The Circle in the Square Theater, spiritual parent to the Off Broadway movement and progenitor of New York's growing nonprofit theater boom, is struggling for survival. Its season, which was supposed to start in November, has now been postponed until April, amid speculation in the theater industry that its doors will not reopen at all.
Officials at the Circle insist that the company is merely going through a difficult stretch. Yet with a deficit of $1.5 million, a subscriber list that has shrunk to 8,533 from 22,000 over the last two decades and financial losseson two of its last three productions, the Circle in the Square is clearly experiencing more than the difficulties afflicting other companies in the recession. 
 Emblematic of its predicament, the dusty sets for "Anna Karenina," its last production, which closed nearly four months ago, still occupy the Circle's theater at 254 West 50th Street. For now, the company is so starved for cash that it is saving the $12,000 cost of striking the sets.
 
A Resignation and a Cancellation
 Robert A. Buckley, the managing director since 1990, publicly announced his resignation two weeks ago, saying he needed "a sabbatical, since I've been working nonstop for 25 years." Mr. Buckley, who is 43, will be replaced on Feb. 1 by George A. Elmer, a 52-year-old producer and general manager, who managed the current "Ruthless" and "Remembrance" on Off Broadway and "Other People's Money" and "The Rothschilds."
Last week the Circle, as it is generally known, announced the cancellation of "Reflected Glory," a comedy by Ronald Harwood that was to have opened the season in February.
Theodore Mann, the 68-year-old artistic director, said he was trying to bring in a replacement play, in a co-production arrangement. But since tickets would have to be provided to the Circle's patient subscribers -- who have already paid $75 for a three-play season that has yet to begin -- the incentive for other producers is limited, said executives at other theater companies.
Recently the fortunes of the Circle have declined critically as well. Two of last year's productions, "On Borrowed Time," with Nathan Lane and George C. Scott, and Howard Korder's "Search and Destroy," received mixed reviews. "Anna Karenina" was roundly pummeled by critics.
Asked why he was leaving at such a critical time, Mr. Buckley said he had planned to leave sooner but delayed his departure "because I was afraid that people would think I was leaving because of the difficulties the company is going through." Both he and Mr. Mann denied that creative or financial disagreements led to his departure.
Theater producers and managers, as well as former staff members of the Circle, who agreed to speak only on condition of anonymity, said the company's budgetary problems seemed insurmountable. But Mr. Mann emphatically denied that his theater was in danger of closing permanently.
 
'The Season Will Go On'
 "As Mark Twain said, the reports of our death are greatly exaggerated," he said, adding that "we have survived many worse crises than this."
"I guarantee our subscribers that the season will go on," he said.
He insisted that the actor Brian Bedford would star in two Moliere comedies in April, and said he had lined up four to six other productions for the 1993-94 season.
Mr. Elmer, the incoming managing director, said he would not have taken the job if he did not think the company would survive. He said he had "looked at all the financials and read the letters," meaning expressions of interest from potential donors. "The fiscal condition of the company is not daunting," he concluded.
Nonetheless, the company has suffered losses on recent productions. "Anna Karenina" cost $515,000, said Paul Libin, the theater's consulting producer, and the operating loss was $10,000 a week, or nearly $80,000 during the course of the run. And Mr. Elmer said "the real killer was 'Search and Destroy,' which lost more than $350,000."
The theater had expected to earn a surplus of $400,000 during the eight weeks of Al Pacino's star turn in two plays, "Salome" and "Chinese Coffee" last year. But because of throat problems Mr. Pacino had to cut back the number of performances, to six a week from eight, reducing the show's profitability. The Circle made only $200,000, according to Mr. Buckley, before operational overhead was deducted. "We broke even, certainly, but we had counted on a bigger surplus," he said.
 
'Every Week Was Treachery'
 Mr. Libin, who was the managing director and later the producing director at the Circle from 1963 to 1990,said of keeping the theater going: "Every week was treachery, taking money from one place and putting it in another, hustling up grant money to pay back our loans. It's a constant balancing act." He left to become producing director at Jujamcyn Theaters, though he retains a consulting capacity at the Circle.
Although the Circle in the Square was able to reduce its deficit by several hundred thousand dollars last season, the current accumulated deficit is about $1.5 million, according to Mr. Libin. This figure is nearly the same as it was in 1991 -- $1,581,721 -- according to the organization's most recent tax return filed with the New York State Attorney General, for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1991.
The company's current lease runs until 2001; the deed stipulates that the space must be used as a theater, a result of efforts in the John V. Lindsay administration to revitalize Broadway by offering concessions to builders if they included theaters in new office towers. The builder, Harold D. Uris, got 10 additional floors of space thanks to the two theaters in the building: the 681-seat theater occupied by the Circle and the 1,933-seat Gershwin Theater, which was originally called the Uris.
The Circle in the Square moved uptown to its current location from Greenwich Village to Broadway in the fall of 1972, into a new horseshoe-shaped space that was intended to recapture the environmental intimacy of the Circle's Bleecker Street theater. But from the outset, some criticized it as awkward. Mr. Mann says the space "enables audiences to focus on the language," but some actors and directors had said it limited staging options and caused sight-line problems for the audience.
These days, aside from readings, student productions and a benefit starring Vanessa Redgrave on Monday to aid Holocaust-research efforts in the Soviet Union, the principal sign of activity at the Circle is its theater-school operation, which is a major source of revenue. According to Mr. Libin, the school, with 350 acting students, has brought in about $900,000 this season.
"Right now, they're living off the school," said a former employee of the Circle who spoke only on condition of anonymity.
 
Borrowing From Itself
 Mr. Buckley said this year's revenues from subscribers had been "commingled," meaning that they were used to cover current expenses. In effect, the Circle has been borrowing from itself against anticipated income.
Income from subscribers is often used in this way at institutional theaters, Mr. Elmer said. Executives at other nonprofits confirmed this, though several used the word "dangerous" to describe the practice, since it leaves a company without funds earmarked to meet its subscriber obligations.
"Without commenting specifically about the Circle in the Square," said Richard Barr, a spokesman for the New York State Attorney General's Office, "it is the view of our office that subscribers should get what they paid for." He said there were no complaints against the Circle and that it was not under investigation.
The Circle in the Square began in 1951, so its longevity exceeds that of the New York Shakespeare Festival, the La Mama Experimental Theater Company and most of the city's other theater perennials. In recent years, it has been facing relentless competition for audiences, financing and media attention from other nonprofit companies like Lincoln Center Theater, the Manhattan Theater Club, the National Actors Theater, Playwrights Horizons and the Roundabout Theater, companies that owe a measure of their success in part to the subscription-based institutional theater concept the Circle helped pioneer.
 
Some Early Successes
 In 1952 the company's first hit production, Tennessee Williams' "Summer and Smoke," starring Geraldine Page, brought many critics and theatergoers to performances in downtown Manhattan for the first time, and was an impetus to the development of the Off Broadway movement. The success of the Circle's 1956 production of "The Iceman Cometh" helped re-establish the reputation of Eugene O'Neill.
Although the Circle has received glowing notices for some of its revivals and experimentation with new works, in recent years productions have been inconsistent, and some critics said the value of the work seemed less dependent on institutional continuity than on the quality of the directors and actors in individual productions.
Mr. Mann, the bearded, sleepy-voiced artistic director, who was a young lawyer when he helped found the theater in 1951, is the link with the institution's past and is now its staunchest defender. He stated that he was not ready to step down, though he added that "for some time now I have been thinking about a successor."
Several managers at other subscription theaters criticized the Circle's 16-member board, which will have to find much of the money to mount the three new productions promised to subscribers, and has hired a new developmental consultant to do so. The board has a number of relatively inactive members, including Lucille Lortel, who said in an interview that she fully supported Mr. Mann but that "for a long time I haven't gone to any of the board meetings."
John C. Russell, the chairman, said, "The board has been active, but we're trying to get the board to increase its activity."
Mr. Russell said flatly that the company "will mount a season," adding, "We continue to have confidence in Ted and Paul."

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
As Rock Beat Fades, Clinton's Presidency Opens on a Soft Note

BYLINE: By JON PARELES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
"We march to the music of our time," President Clinton said today in his Inaugural Address. But the rock-and-roll Presidency that some feared and others hoped for has already begun to look like what radio stations call "adult contemporary" or "lite" rock, sticking to plush, cautious tunes that wouldn't risk anything like excitement, much less rudeness.
On cable television on Sunday, the Clinton media brain trust came close to hipness, booking the rapper L. L. Cool J. for may be history's first pre-Presidential rap. But on network television, in "An American Reunion," the CBS-TV variety show on Tuesday night, it was back to musical diversions direct from the Jimmy Carter era. None other than Barry Manilow, unhipness incarnate, was the first big star trotted out for a program that featured ballads, ballads, ballads. It made the average Grammy Awards telecast sound avant-garde. 
 On Tuesday night, except for jazz from a vigorous all-star group and rock-and-roll from Chuck Berry and Little Richard -- both segments brutally truncated for commercials -- the show brought music for cocooning rather than dancing, music that would rather soothe than inspire. Barbra Streisand unveiled a lounge-act version of "God Bless America" that caressed the word "sweet" as if America were a sleepy, beloved child. The first musical trend of the Clinton era is the recasting of patriotic flag-wavers as lullabies. So long, Kate Smith, and hello, Raffi.
The second trend is the willingness of rockers and rappers to take up praise songs, like African griots extolling their patrons and chiefs. In contrast to its predecessors, the Clinton Administration seems relatively hospitable to rock music, and rockers aren't wasting any time in showing their gratitude. L. L. Cool J. on Sunday, then Chuck Berry on Tuesday -- singing "Bill's gonna get this country straight" -- hailed the new chief, as if suggesting that rap and rock, already co-opted for soundtracks and commercials, are ready to line up behind the new powers instead of hurling spitballs from the sidelines. During the finale, Mr. Clinton pumped Little Richard's hand and came back to trade high-fives with him, as if welcoming rock's anarchic spirit to the team.
But the welcome seems halfhearted; schmaltz, not rock, was the official musical choice, offering reassurance rather than any jarring change. Even Fleetwood Mac's uptempo "Don't Stop," the campaign theme and the show's finale, came from "Rumours," the 1977 album that marked the commercial peak of soft rock. The Clintons (and the Gores) came of age in the 1960's, a time of psychedelia and turbulence and generational divisions, but their heart doesn't seem to be in that era. Where the two previous Republican Administrations strove to roll back the 60's, the emerging Clinton style is simply to say, as Fleetwood Mac did in 1977, "yesterday's gone."
The new Administration would clearly prefer that voters connect it to the comparatively settled 1970's, through a nostalgic haze that forgets how much the 70's extended the indulgences of the 60's. With Michael Bolton singing Bill Withers's "Lean on Me" and Ms. Streisand crooning "Evergreen," the network special steered away from the 70's of Eric Clapton's hit "Cocaine" or the Eagles' "Life in the Fast Lane," or any of rock's other tales of hedonism unto decadence, away from the 70's of Studio 54 and Plato's Retreat. After the increasingly sober, pleasure-fearing 1980's, the Clinton revue offered the 70's as a cozy remembered era of everlasting love and devotion.
In the 1990's, that coziness segues naturally to thoughts of compassion, preferably toward innocent and uncontroversial victims. Before Michael Jackson sang "Gone Too Soon" on Tuesday night, he urged the new President to "commit the resources necessary to eliminate" AIDS; he dedicated the song to the hemophilic AIDS victim Ryan White, taking pains to describe him as "very normal" (an odd word for Mr. Jackson to use). Ms. Streisand, performing Stephen Sondheim's "Children Will Listen," stumped for prevention of child abuse. Family, health and environmental consciousness are home-front issues like the economy, all about retaining (or bringing back) a sense of well-being instead of shaking things up.
For the moment, it seems as if the Presidential esthetic has skipped a musical generation, moving directly from pre-rock, Tin Pan Alley tastes to soft-rock ballads, the La-Z-Boy recliners of popular music. Maybe the idea is to ease America into a time of change. But as Americans grow ever more suspicious of photo-opportunity poses with little to back them up, it was hardly reassuring to notice that when Michael Jackson sang "Heal the World" for the new Administration, he was apparently lip-synching.

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
Laughs That Mask the Fears of Gay Manhattan

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
Jeffrey, the title character of Paul Rudnick's wildly funny new comedy at the WPA Theater, is a gay man in his mid-30's who, exhausted from negotiating safe sex, decides to become celibate. It's not that he hasn't had his share of adventure. Jeffrey estimates he has had 5,000 sexual encounters but remained H.I.V. negative.
"I'm not promiscuous," he declares. "It's such an ugly word. I'm cheap." 
 A mostly unemployed actor, he makes his living as a freelance "cater-waiter" for fancy services with names like Arugula With Attitude. Wearing spotless uniforms and serving large numbers of people in tents, he says, "is like being in the gay National Guard."
For all its fun, "Jeffrey" captures the strained social tenor of Manhattan life as it is lived right now perhaps more acutely than any play since John Guare's "Six Degrees of Separation." The desperate, brittle tone of the hilarity underscores the ghastly sense of the absurd that the AIDS epidemic has brought to hypersophisticated Manhattan society.
Beneath its playful surface, "Jeffrey" wrestles with questions of life, death and erotic partnership that thousands are facing every day. In the sexually supercharged milieu of gay New York, the playwright asks, what are the practical implications of celibacy? And if abstinence is an emotionally and spiritually self-punishing response to AIDS, what is the wisest approach to seeking erotic fulfillment?
Mr. Rudnick's comedy is packed with bon mots that fly so profusely from the stage that the laughter rarely flags. Many of the best one-liners are delivered by Jeffrey's best friend, Sterling (Edward Hibbert), a waspish interior decorator who resembles a much younger Quentin Crisp and who defines a boyfriend as "a pet that can feed and walk itself."
Sterling's lover, Darius (Bryan Batt), in fact dresses like a pet. A sweet-natured, not-very-bright cast member of the Broadway musical "Cats," he rarely bothers to change out of his feline costume.
The play's other significant character, Steve (Tom Hewitt), is a handsome bartender whom Jeffrey meets in a gym and who could be his Mr. Right except for one impediment. Steve has been H.I.V. positive for five years, and Jeffrey is terrified of getting involved with someone he fears could get sick and die at any moment.
Short satirical sketches depict Jeffrey's visits to a gym filled with voyeurs, a safe-sex club that is all talk and no action and a meeting of Sexual Compulsives Anonymous. He attends a lecture by a sharp-tongued, double-talking new-age guru (Harriet Harris), who is apparently a caricature of Marianne Williamson, and visits St. Patrick's Cathedral, where he is importuned by a lustful priest.
A bit too digressive, the play sometimes threatens to become a disconnected series of sketches satirizing gay New York. A gay-bashing scene in which Jeffrey is attacked by toughs on Christopher Street seems inserted more to cover the political spectrum of gay issues than to advance the story.
Where Mr. Rudnick, who wrote last season's Broadway comedy "I Hate Hamlet," succeeds is in being completely up to the minute and traditional at the same time. The predicament of true love thwarted by obstacles is as old as comedy itself. But in "Jeffrey," the stumbling block isn't a disapproving parent or an inconvenient partner but a deadly retrovirus. The denouement that Mr. Rudnick has concocted is at once touching and wonderfully right.
"Jeffrey" has been brilliantly brought to the stage by Christopher Ashley, the young director who oversaw Anna Deavere Smith's "Fires in the Mirror" at the Joseph Papp Public Theater. In the production, which uses slides and a few props to evoke interiors, an ensemble of eight actors delivers Mr. Rudnick's epigrams with a seamless consistency of tone.
While Mr. Higgins and Mr. Hewitt make an appealing pair of sparring partners, the show is almost stolen by Ms. Harris. Playing eight small roles, she displays a gift for caricature that is as far-reaching as it is subtle.
"Jeffrey" is just the sort of play that Oscar Wilde might have written had he lived in 1990's Manhattan and taken aim at an epidemic that was decimating his circle of friends.

HEADLINE: Mr. Cuomo's Welcome Austerity

 BODY:
In his proposed budget, Gov. Mario Cuomo tries to make up for past fiscal sins by going straight, or mostly straight. He tries fewer gimmicks and makes more stringent cuts. He wants a fairer allocation of school aid, and if there's no income tax cut, there's no income tax increase either.
The Governor's welcome overall answer to years of mismanagement in New York State -- his own and the Legislature's -- is to get more serious than ever about reforms and the need for intelligent ways to tighten the belt. Several of his proposals can't be assessed without more information and study; others sound sensible and worth pursuing. 
 Clearly, the state should close underused mental hospitals and modernize the Department of Motor Vehicles to make it more efficient. Those and other measures would trim 4,700 jobs from the state work force.
Whether or not his plan to cut $130 million out of school aid goes too far, he deserves strong support for this latest proposal to allocate education funds more equitably.
He would give less to wealthy districts and more to poor districts like New York City that are denied their fair share of state funding now because suburban legislators in the Republican-dominated State Senate block reallocation.
This time, events outside Albany's control may make the issue harder for the Senate to duck, like the well-publicized brouhaha over a Long Island school official's outlandish pension and strong efforts to reform education funding in neighboring Connecticut.
Other aspects of the plan raise legitimate questions. The Governor proposes to take $516 million in petroleum business taxes from the so-called "locked box" for transportation and use it instead to help plug an anticipated budget gap of $3.7 billion. Is that the best use of the money?
And it's possible that the budget inflicts undue damage on the weakest and poorest of New Yorkers. Do the deep Medicaid cuts -- including new limits on home care and eliminating reimbursement for such items as walkers -- go too far? Is it really necessary to cut back on scholarships for new college students? Can local governments sustain state aid cuts without suffering?
New Yorkers may also reasonably ask whether the budget provides adequate funding for mass transit, whether raising the cigarette tax from 39 to 60 cents a pack could backfire by encouraging massive bootlegging, and whether it is wise or realistic to increase the state's reliance on gambling by creating a new keno game.
But these questions need to be asked in fair context: Mr. Cuomo presented an austere budget because he had to. The state is in financial difficulty and the economy has yet to rebound.
Given those woeful circumstances, he presented a budget plan that acknowledges fiscal reality and for the most part deals with it responsibly. Now it's up to the Legislature to do the same.

HEADLINE: THE INAUGURATION;
CLINTON TAKES OATH AS 42D PRESIDENT, URGING SACRIFICE TO 'RENEW AMERICA'

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
William Jefferson Clinton became the 42d President of the United States today, and in an Inaugural Address striking in its appeal for sacrifice, he told Americans that if they assume greater responsibility for their country's future, "there is nothing wrong with America that cannot be cured by what is right with America."
The 46-year-old Governor of Arkansas, virtually unknown to most Americans 18 months ago and a long shot for the White House, took the oath of office under a stunningly blue sky from Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist. President George Herbert Walker Bush, who once seemed sure to win a second term, watched stoically from his seat on the Capitol steps. 
 Under Mr. Clinton's left hand, his wife, Hillary, held a King James Bible given to Mr. Clinton by his grandmother. His 12-year-old daughter, Chelsea, stood at his right as he uttered the traditional oath at 11:58 A.M. Eastern time. He then spoke for 14 minutes to a sea of people, flowing down from the flag-draped Western facade of the Capitol to the Washington Monument.
 
'What America Does Best'
 "We must do what America does best: offer more opportunity to all and demand more responsibility from all," Mr. Clinton declared in an echo of John F. Kennedy's Inaugural Address. "It is time to break the bad habit of expecting something for nothing, from our Government or from each other. Let us all take more responsibility, not only for ourselves and our families but for our communities and our country."
In a speech with the recurring theme of renewal, Mr. Clinton implored at one point: "To renew America we must be bold. We must do what no generation has had to do before." [Transcript, page A15.]
Washington never looked better, or felt better. Cheerful chaos reigned on the streets, in a subway system that is usually weirdly sedate and on the Mall, in front of the Capitol, where something like a quarter of a million people endured mobs and metal detectors and midwinter chill. Schools and Federal offices had a quadrennial holiday, so natives joined tourists beneath a Capitol that was dressed for the day in gowns of red, white and blue, and glittered in the January sun.
 
Walk Through the Crowd
 In a day of ceremonies intended to be casual and intimate -- with lots of Presidential bear hugs for friends and a conscious assertion of the passing of power to the post-World War II generation -- the Clintons walked the last few blocks down Pennsylvania Avenue from the Capitol to the White House. Before the Clintons decided to get out of their new armor-plated Cadillac, the crowds along the route were chanting: "Walk! Walk!"
From the viewing stand in front of the White House's iron gates, the Clintons watched a politically inclusive parade, encompassing everyone from Arkansas bands to gay groups to Elvis impersonators -- like the rest of the inaugural as meticulously scripted as any Hollywood production. Throughout, Mr. Clinton wore the amazed grin of a man whose lifelong dream had just come true.
The flag-waving crowds along the parade route were striking both for their enthusiasm and their racial diversity. The upbeat mood of the well-wishers seemed on track with that of recent national polls -- one of guarded optimism about Mr. Clinton's prospects, coupled with a strong desire to give the new President a chance.
 
Short, Informal Speech
 Mr. Clinton's Inaugural Address, far more compact than the lengthy oratory of his long 1988 Democratic National Convention speech, was informal and almost conversational.
It was typical of the New Age political style that helped him win the highest office in the land. While Mr. Clinton paid homage to many of the themes that won him the election -- the need for renewal, health-care reform, economic revival and political reform -- his address was not an agenda for action, but rather a call to service.
"You, my fellow Americans, have forced the spring," he said. "Now we must do the work the season demands."
The address was at times brutally frank in its assessment of the decline of the country under Mr. Bush and in its chastising of an aloof and self-absorbed Congress, as well as an apathetic American public.
"We know we have to face hard truths and take strong steps. But we have not done so," said Mr. Clinton, who wore a dark blue suit and no top coat as he spoke on the chilly winter day. "Instead, we have drifted, and that drifting has eroded our resources, fractured our economy, and shaken our confidence.
"Thomas Jefferson believed that to preserve the very foundations of our nation, we would need dramatic change from time to time. Well, my fellow Americans, this is our time. Let us embrace it. Our democracy must be not only the envy of the world but the engine of our own renewal. There is nothing wrong with America that cannot be cured by what is right with America."
In the age of satellite communications, which Mr. Clinton put to such good use during the campaign, the new President used his address to speak not only to the hundreds of thousands gathered before him, but also to America's allies and enemies over the horizon. He signaled the world in general, and President Saddam Hussein of Iraq in particular, that while America renewed itself at home it would not abandon its responsibilities abroad.
"Together with our friends and allies, we will work to shape change, lest it engulf us," said Mr. Clinton, speaking behind a shield of bullet-proof glass. "When our vital interests are challenged, or the will and conscience of the international community is defied, we will act, with peaceful diplomacy whenever possible, with force when necessary."
 
Transfer of Power
 A moment after being sworn in, Mr. Clinton turned and shook hands with Mr. Bush. Their eyes locked for three seconds as they pumped each other's hands in what appeared in many ways to be the real passing of authority. At that moment, Mr. Bush's military aide carrying the locked briefcase of nuclear-warfare codes, and standing on the podium behind him, began taking orders from a new Commander in Chief.
While every inauguration celebrates the peaceful transfer of power that is the hallmark of American democracy, in the case of Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton that transfer is all the more amazing. Eighteen months ago, Mr. Bush was at the peak of his political power, the victorious commander of a successful and unusually painless war in the Persian Gulf, riding the crest of polls with 80 percent approval ratings. Most serious Democrat did not believe there was any sense in even trying to challenge him.
Mr. Clinton was then Governor of one of the nation's poorest states, worrying about getting a one-cent sales tax through his legislature, but also burning with enough ambition to set off against Mr. Bush when more cautious Democrats hesitated.
Mr. Clinton got his reward today. About 1 P.M., he and his wife waved from the Capitol steps as Mr. Bush and his wife, Barbara, flew off by helicopter to an early retirement in Houston -- while a United Van Lines trailer with Arkansas license plates was backing into the White House driveway to move in the Clintons' belongings.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton had to work closely during the transition to deal with foreign-policy crises in Haiti and Iraq, and it may have left them with a measure of mutual respect undetectable in their bitter election campaign, when Mr. Bush once dismissed Mr. Clinton as a "bozo" who knew less about foreign affairs than Millie, the Bushes' dog.
 
Salute to Bush
 At the top of his address Mr. Clinton hailed Mr. Bush, saying: "On behalf of our nation, I salute my predecessor, President Bush, for his half-century of service to America."
Mr. Clinton's inauguration represents not only a change in Presidents and parties but also of generations. The generation symbolized by President Bush was shaped by the patriotism of World War II, sobered by the deprivations of the Great Depression and serenaded by the music of Frank Sinatra.
It now gives way to a fortysomething crowd who were born into politics during the idealistic, prosperous era of John F. Kennedy, but forged their identities singing along with Bob Dylan through the troublesome seasons of Vietnam, Watergate and acid rain.
For the first time America has a President and Vice President younger than the Beatles. At age 46, Mr. Clinton is the third youngest President. Only his idol John F. Kennedy, who took office in 1961 at 43, and Theodore Roosevelt, who took office at 42, were younger.
Mr. Clinton's fellow baby-boomer and now Vice President, Al Gore, the 44-year-old former Senator from Tennessee, was sworn in by Justice Byron R. White, as his wife, Tipper, and his four children crowded around. Mr. Gore had chosen the retired Justice Thurgood Marshall, but Mr. Marshall was too ill and had to beg off at the last minute.
There were 14 official balls and who knows how many unofficial ones tonight, including an "Inaugural Ball for the Not Well Connected" and an affair sponsored by MTV, the only one where women showed up with bats tatooed on their bare backs.
"Everybody here knows that MTV had a lot to do with the Clinton-Gore victory," Mr. Clinton told the rock-loving crowd, where attire ranged from prom dresses to ripped jeans.
The MTV crowd greeted the Clintons like celebrities, surging forward with enthusiasm when they appeared. But Tipper Gore, who has opposed violent and sexually suggestive rock lyrics, was visibly shaken when she was booed as she approached a microphone.
Presidential reserve was thrown to the winds at a ball with fellow Arkansans. The new President grabbed a saxophone from the rhythm and blues musician Ben E. King and played a solo, then topped of a little speech with the Arkansas football holler, "Soooooweeeee, Razorbacks."
In his speech in the afternoon, Mr. Clinton said, "Today, a generation raised in the shadows of the cold war assumes new responsibilities in a world warmed by the sunshine of freedom but threatened still by ancient hatreds and new plagues. Raised in unrivaled prosperity, we inherit an economy that is still the world's strongest, but weakened by business failures, stagnant wages, increasing inequality and deep divisions among our own people."
In a line that appeared directed most at the politically reform-minded supporters of Ross Perot, Mr. Clinton included in his address a swipe at the politicians, lobbyists and political forces that he said had made Washington a city synonymous with corruption.
"This beautiful capital, like every capital since the dawn of civilization, is often a place of intrigue and calculation," Mr. Clinton said, with Senators and Congressmen gathered on the Capitol steps behind him. "Powerful people maneuver for position and worry endlessly about who is in and who is out, who is up and who is down, forgetting those people whose toil and sweat sends us here and pays our way. Americans deserve better."
 
Biblical Flourish
 Mr. Clinton then closed with a rhetorical flourish, that blended the Biblical with the political: "From this joyful mountaintop of celebration, we hear a call to service in the valley. We have heard the trumpets. We have changed the guard. And now, each in our own way, and with God's help, we must answer the call."
Mr. Clinton's first official act was to sign an executive order imposing his new, much stricter ethical standards on senior officials in his Administration, and another order proclaiming Friday as a "national day of fellowship and hope." He also signed nominating papers for his Cabinet appointees.
Republicans, wary of being drowned in what they see as a reservoir of goodwill greeting Mr. Clinton's inauguration, despite his occasionally rocky transition to power, pledged their cooperation.
"I think he is going to have a lot of good will," said Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, who just returned from a Florida vacation. "I was running on the beach and I saw a lot of people and they would shout at me: 'Give him a chance, give him a chance.' So this is Clinton's moment and we won't do anything to interfere with it."
Mr. Clinton's day began, as his term begins, with a focus not on the domestic issues which got him elected but on the foreign crises which threaten to divert his attention. He was briefed at Blair House, one last time, by Brent Scowcroft, President Bush's national security adviser, on the state of the world he is about to inherit.
Mr. Clinton walked out of Blair House, gripping a mug of decaffeinated coffee, for the short drive to the Metropolitan African Methodist Episcopal Church, a prominent black Baptist church in downtown Washington.
 
A Laugh and a Tear
 While the chorus gave a rousing rendition of the hymns "Holy Ground" and "Precious Lord Take My Hand," Mr. Clinton laughed, nodded, and sang along, dabbing a tear on his left cheek.
President Bush began his last day in the White House by making a solitary walk around the South Lawn and then returning to the Oval Office to write a note to leave behind for Mr. Clinton, as Ronald Reagan had done with Mr. Bush.
Mr. Reagan's note said: "Don't let the Turkeys get you down." Mr. Bush would not say what his note said.
Mr. Clinton's inauguration was closed by a poem read by his favorite poet, Maya Angelou, who wrote "On the Pulse of Morning" to celebrate Mr. Clinton's inauguration as the dawn of a new era of national unity. It ended with the verses:
Here, on the pulse of this new day
You may have the grace to look up and out
And into your sister's eyes, and into
Your brother's face, your country
And say simply
Very simply
With hope --
Good morning.

An article yesterday about the inauguration of President Clinton referred incorrectly to the church where Mr. Clinton attended a morning prayer service. It is African Methodist Episcopal.

HEADLINE: THE INAUGURATION;
A Change of Power, but Barely a Break in Stride

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Today was the day of Bill Clinton's dreams, the day he and his party finished the arduous climb to a "joyful mountaintop of celebration," but like all Inauguration Days, it was more than that.
It was a day when the nation committed itself once more, with the recital of a simple 18th-century oath, to what the new President felicitously termed "the mystery of American renewal." The solemn magic of the moment, in this most telling of national rituals, lies in what it symbolizes: the unquestioned acceptance by victor, vanquished and public alike of the continuity and legitimacy of governance. 
 The United States crowns no kings. But as he stood before the Capitol and spoke the words George Washington first uttered in lower Manhattan on April 30, 1789, Mr. Clinton embodied this nation's unity, in something of the way a monarch embodies Britain's at the hour of coronation in Westminster Abbey.
Jack Valenti, who worked in the White House three decades ago, calls the man in the Oval Office "the keeper of the national integrity and the steward of our civic virtue."
As such, Mr. Clinton starts with the good wishes of most Americans. But he is the leader of a Government as well as an icon of nationhood, and in that capacity he begins with less than universal acceptance. He won the votes, after all, of only 43 percent of those who cast ballots last November, and since then, he has excited wariness as well as enthusiasm in the country.
 
Bitter Democratic Memories
 Few will take exception to his message of hope and rebirth, but it is far less certain that he will carry the country with him in his appeal to "face hard truths and take strong steps" in a spirit of shared sacrifice. That will depend not only upon who is asked to give up what, and how fair the apportionment seems, but also upon Mr. Clinton's ability to stir a citizenry that has been more preoccupied with "me" than with "us" for much of the last two decades.
The Old Guard in his party remembers all too well the self-immolation of the last two Democratic Administrations, those headed by Lyndon B. Johnson and Jimmy Carter, and prays that the rule of three will not apply in this case. But many have been perturbed by a rocky transition period.
"Lyndon used to say that the President proposes and the country disposes," said Walter Shorenstein, the San Francisco financier and fund-raiser, "and in his case it disposed of him. No matter how smart the Clinton people are, there are lots of bumps in the road ahead, and I hope they remember that."
Even at their moment of triumph, many of the Clinton people seem acutely aware that their margin for error, never great, has been reduced by the conflict, the disorganization and the resultant tardiness that marred the transition. When a reporter complained this week to George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, that his answers to her questions were flat and unilluminating, he replied, "I can't afford to be colorful."
At the beginning and end of his Inaugural Address, especially, the new President showed that he can find the language of exaltation that a President needs. Many in his audience were moved by the Biblical cadences so beloved of Southern orators. The length of the speech as well, only 14 minutes, showed a new discipline in a man who has often proven embarrassingly prolix.
He brings other strengths to the task of coping with economic dilemmas at home and the "ancient hatreds and new plagues" of the world -- not only his intelligence and mastery of policy detail, not only his determination and stamina, his youth and idealism, but also his membership in a fresh generation. Only four years ago, Ronald Reagan, who was born before World War I, sat in the White House; the new occupant was born after World War II, "in the shadows of the cold war," as Mr. Clinton put it.
The prospect of new departures has produced a new if guarded optimism among voters across the country who found the Bush Administration old and tired. The prospect of power has galvanized Democrats eminent and humble, from Pamela Harriman, the Georgetown hostess and power broker, who pronounced herself "thrilled" after the swearing-in, to the thousands who lined up early to cheer the Monarch Band from Papillon, Neb., and a double-dozen others.
 
A Need to Buy Some Time
 Yet Mr. Clinton has not yet shown the country that he himself can make the tough choices that will be needed -- between cutting the deficit and investing in new infrastructure or new governmental programs, say, or between allowing the slaughter of innocents in Bosnia to continue or risking a prolonged and draining American involvement.
He will try to buy time on some thorny issues, like homosexuality in the military, where he is proposing a two-step approach, or meeting with Boris N. Yeltsin, on which he is just plain stalling so as not to lose his focus on domestic affairs. But he promised a lot, and he will have to deliver something soon.
The problems experienced by the Clinton team during the transition may prove to be transitory, the product of inexperience. If a President does well in his first few months, the transition is soon forgotten. But problems may persist. As Carl M. Brauer writes in "Presidential Transitions" (Oxford University Press): "Transitions are the shadow of the man who heads them. They silhouette his past experience and future goals, strengths and weaknesses."
Some profess to see in Mr. Clinton's promises of a Government that "looks like America," to cut the deficit by a quarter in four years, to produce wonders in his first 100 days, and so on, a tendency to give hostages to fortune. Certainly they have caused him embarrassment during the transition, as has his habit of talking casually about complex foreign-policy issues.
Others worry that he is too eager to please, too loath to say no.
 
Fragile Covenant
 After a campaign that focused on questions of character, the President will be judged mostly on what he accomplishes and what he does not, at least at first. No one expects him to accomplish everything he promised to. But if he seems to make a habit of trimming, if he gains a reputation for evasion, as he did for a time during the campaign, he will quickly dissipate the advantage that accrued to him as he stood today, bright as a new penny in a city and a nation that love new things, in the thin winter sunshine of the capital.
It will happen quickly because the covenant between President and people has become a fragile one, worn thin by the lies of Vietnam and Watergate and the suspicions about politicians and institutions that linger, and also because of the awesome speed and impact of the modern media of communication.
But Bill Clinton's advantage is this: The nation is tired of gridlock and cynicism. It longs to believe again. Tonight he is there at the center, in the White House, after such a long and unlikely journey from Hope, Ark.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 22, 1993, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A news analysis article yesterday about the transfer of power in Washington described one of President Clinton's campaign pledges incorrectly in some editions. He promised to cut the budget deficit in four years by half, not by one-quarter.

LENGTH: 823 words

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Primary Dealer Records a Big Loss

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The last three years have been banner ones for the 39 primary dealers that are the heart of the $2.3 trillion Government securities market.
According to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, the dealers as a whole made about $800 million in profits in 1990 and a record $1 billion in 1991. Moreover, they accumulated profits of $900 million through September and could be looking to another record year. 
 Still, the business is not as easy as rolling off a log. And for those that get it right, there are are those who get it wrong.
The Discount Corporation of New York, one of smaller primary dealers without the backing of a large parent company, is one of the firms that have got it wrong.
Discount yesterday reported a surprising fourth-quarter after-tax loss of $26.3 million and an after-tax loss of $24.5 million for all of 1992. Of the fourth- quarter loss, close to $20 million may have been from trading losses, since that is the company's main business.
 
 
Stock Plunges
 Trading of the company's stock on the New York Stock Exchange was halted before the announcement. When trading resumed, the shares fell -- ending the day down 30 percent, or $3.125, at $7.375.
Raphael de la Gueronniere, the chairman who took over the troubled primary dealership in mid-1991, would not comment on the losses.
Other players in the primary dealer business said the loss was amazing, but could not say what wrong bets Discount might have made in a year that had been pretty good for most of the other dealers. According to the Federal Reserve, about 87 percent -- or 34 of the 39 dealers -- had reported profits though September.
Possibly unfortunately for Discount, because it is not owned by a larger company, its profits and its losses from trading are easily identified, making it one of the few clear examples of the ups and downs possible in the Government securities markets. The fate of most of the other primary dealers are mixed with the profits and losses of a larger company.
Discount is still going through a major revamping, including the sale of subsidiary businesses, as the company refocuses on its core business, the primary dealership. It had reported losses for four of the last five quarters. The $8.8 million operating profit made in the fourth quarter of 1991 was wiped out by a one-time $11.95 million charge to pay for the revamping of the firm.
The company's futures trading subsidiary was closed in the fourth quarter and since new management took over a year and half ago, the firm's work force had been cut from 400 people to 125.
The loss in the fourth quarter includes one-time charges that total about $5.7 million, including $2 million for the closing of the futures business and $4.5 million for a further write-down of the value of the firm's headquarters in New York City. There is also a $1.2 million credit from adjustment of pension liabilities because of the layoff of so many employees.
 
Treasury Market
 Bill Clinton was inaugurated as President yesterday but the bond market did not have much to say about it. Prices were little changed except for an 11/32 -point fall in the price of the 30-year bond. But that was more of a correction after a hearty rally rather than any statement on the new Administration, traders said.
But Jay Goldinger, a trader at Capital Insight in Los Angeles, noted with a chuckle that the price of the 30-year bond hit its high for the day just at the time that Mr. Clinton finished his oath as President.
Traders noted there were no details of any portion of the new President's economic program in his first speech to the nation as President.
John Costas, a managing director at the First Boston Corporation, said that traders and investors seemed to steep back as the yields on both shorter maturities and the 30-year bond approached recent lows. For the two-year note that yield is 4.25 percent and for the 30-year bond it is 7.25 percent.
Yesterday, the yield on the 30-year bond ended at 7.33 percent, up from 7.3 percent Tuesday. The yield on the two-year note dipped to 4.35 percent, down from 4.37 percent the day before but up from 4.29 percent at the end of last week.
Mr. Costas said that "4.25 percent and 7.25 percent are proving to be difficult resistance levels for the market."
One of the forces that has been moving the market up and down recently, according to Mr. Costas, has been traders moving in and out of what are called curve trades. When traders think that the spread between the yields on the two-year note and the 30-year bond is widening they sell long maturities and buy short ones. When the spread is narrowing, they sell short maturities and buy long ones.
Views of what position to take, Mr. Costas said, change with the view of the economy. When people think it is getting stronger they shift into the flattening trade; when they think it is getting weaker, they short to the steepening trade.

HEADLINE: SETTLING IN: AROUND THE NATION;
Much Outrage, Little Sympathy On Main Street

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Friday, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Behind the counter at a pet store in a middle-class Washington suburb, Carolyn Williford had drawn herself up in outrage at the notion that Zoe Baird might become Attorney General after hiring illegal immigrants to care for her toddler.
"She thought she could do something illegal and get away with it," said the 45-year-old assistant manager at Doctor's Pet Center in Hyattsville, Md. "I don't think it's fair. I raised my kids while I was working. I worked days. My husband worked nights at the post office. Our in-laws filled in when they had to. This makes me mad." 
 Ms. Baird removed herself from consideration as Attorney General early this morning, amid swelling opposition to her nomination. Ms. Baird's household arrangements, and her failure to pay Social Security taxes for her Peruvian employees, had struck a nerve on Capitol Hill as well as across America. Her defenders had insisted that hers was a sin of good intentions motivated by nothing more sinister than a desire for good child care -- a venial transgression for which a sincere apology and penalty payments should have been sufficient atonement. But Main Street seemed impatient with moral relativism.
 
The Sounds of Anger
 The anger across the country had come in varied tones, like a musical chord. The dominant note was one of class, of resentment over what seemed like a double standard that favored the rich.
But other notes filled out the theme: the anger of well-to-do people who wrestled quarterly with the Internal Revenue Service household tax forms that one person called "infuriating and outrageous"; the anger of people who thought that "she was just being greedy" and not paying her workers enough, whatever their legal status; the conviction of some people that she should have let President Clinton begin his Administration without having to defend her.
And while voices were raised in her defense, questioning the law or the country's preoccupation with moral purity, the major women's groups were largely silent, leaving unanswered the angry chorus that finally drowned out support for the first woman ever nominated to be Attorney General.
In a recent poll by the Gallup Organization, a majority of the public had expressed some concern when told "that Bill Clinton's nominee for Attorney General, Zoe Baird, hired illegal aliens to work in her home in violation of the law." Fifty-one percent of the 754 adults interviewed Monday and Tuesday said that was a "major concern" to them.
Another 33 percent had said it was a "minor concern," while 15 percent had said it was "not a concern at all." The national telephone poll, which Gallup conducted for CNN and USA Today, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
Diane Rehm, hostess of "The Diane Rehm Show" on WAMU-FM in Washington, said a solid majority of callers had asked Ms. Baird to step aside. "There were feelings that the people did not want Mr. Clinton to start his new Administration with this as a potential problem hanging around his neck," she said.
"There were also feelings that this was a so-called 'yuppie crime.' That people in positions of power and money were feeling that they could do whatever they wanted, and to hell with the rest of the country. And that surely, surely, if this woman is as bright as they say she is, she should have known better.
"There was very little sympathy for her," she added. "Very little sympathy."
In San Diego County this week, an attorney for a woman accused in Federal Court of transporting illegal aliens moved for dismissal on the basis of selective prosecution. The grounds: Zoe Baird had not been prosecuted.
 
Some Can Understand
 Yet a sympathetic strain arose, from suburban Delaware to downtown San Francisco. While many people viewed the issue as a simple matter of right and wrong, others reacted with dismissive forgiveness.
Audrey Scott, a 30-year-old computer programmer who had just bought seedless grapes at Stiles market on Ninth Avenue in Manhattan, said she had children and had found it difficult to find help. "I don't think Zoe Baird did anything wrong," she said. "She gave some people a job."
Papusa Molina, 41, single, director of the University of Iowa's Women's Resource Action Center, said: "I'm sure hundreds of thousands of 'regular' citizens end up employing undocumented immigrants. She wasn't so out of line. It's something many middle- and upper-middle-class citizens do.
"Perhaps I'm cynical," said the Mexican-born woman, who earns $33,000 a year, "but in Mexico we believe no one is a saint. Private lives here become such an issue when a person enters public life. If everyone's background was so scrutinized, we wouldn't be able to elect anybody to public office."
 
Some Sawee No Excuse
 Shirley Ellis, a 54-year-old laborer in Chicago, said that, as the mother of three children, she empathized with Ms. Baird. "I don't like to wink at things that are truly illegal, but I think she probably put the priority of her child first," Ms. Ellis said. "I can't condemn her for that."
But the murmurs of sympathy by Ms. Ellis, Ms. Molina, Ms. Scott and others were drowned out by the cries of outrage. The sin a Wall Street Journal headline called "Boomer Blind Spot" may be widespread, but it is not publicly condoned.
Shelley Gates, an associate director at a women's organization in Chicago and the mother of two small children, said Ms. Baird's action's were inexcusable.
"Average working mothers don't make nearly what she makes, and yet we are obligated to follow the law," Ms. Gates said. "It's kind of unfair. This certainly diminishes her credibility."
 
Above the Law?
 Daniel Williams, a Philadelphia computer programmer with four children said that the issue was that Ms. Baird wanted to represent the law of the land, but that she had knowingly broken that law.
"If you don't like the law, you should work to get it changed," Mr. Williams said. "She had the contacts and the wherewithal to do that. I respect her talents, her experience, and I think her appointment would have been great, but I'm very uncomfortable with her placing herself above the law she is sworn to represent."
And James Rogers, an economist and investor in Manhattan who said he lived by the book, said, "Having had to fill out lots of forms, infuriating and outrageous forms, I don't know why I had to do it and she didn't."
But while the anger was palpable, both random interviews and the rate of mail into Congressional offices made Ms. Baird's case seem different from other high-profile character examinations in Washington.
While mail and phone calls ran heavily against Ms. Baird in Congressional offices, the overall volume of reaction did not compare with the reactions provoked by the October 1991 hearings on Judge Clarence Thomas's nomination to the Supreme Court, and his confrontation with Anita F. Hill, or the 1987 confirmation hearings on Robert H. Bork's nomination to the High Court.
True, some radio hosts were deluged with calls when they raised the issue. But others, like Jan Mickelson, who has a morning show on WHO in Des Moines, got little reaction.
James Blackburn, 47, a computer manager for an aircraft-leasing firm from San Francisco, said he felt that Ms. Baird's difficulties during the hearings "reflect badly on the Administration. I believe we should have more women in government. They contribute a fresh approach, but I don't think we should sacrifice principles or the rule of law to get them."
Back in Hyattsville, one of Mrs. Williford's co-workers in the pet store was puzzled at the outrage that preceded Ms. Baird's withdrawal. Michelle Reaves, 23, whose 2-year-old daughter is cared for by her grandmother, said: "I know the law is the law. But sometimes you have to bend it."
