HEADLINE: CHRISTOPHER LEERY OF BOSNIA ACCORD

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher said today that he doubted that the international mediation effort to end the fighting in Bosnia and Herzegovina would succeed, his spokesman said.
Mr. Christopher's spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, said at the State Department briefing this morning that although the Clinton Administration generally supports the negotiations, Mr. Christopher "expressed doubts about whether it can realistically be achieved, whether they can, in fact, find an agreement, find a solution that's peaceful that the parties would, in fact, agree to." 
 Mr. Christopher's remarks have put the Administration in the awkward position of publicly supporting a negotiating process while criticizing -- and perhaps undermining -- the particular plan that is on the table.
 
Settlement 'That Will Stick'
 Mr. Boucher, who is a holdover from the Bush Administration, pointed to two obstacles: the fact that the parties engaged in the Geneva-based talks have broken their commitments to agreements in the past, and that the fighting and atrocities have been "so horrible" that it is very difficult to bring the parties together.
"Obviously, it's a very difficult task to bring them to a political settlement that will stick and that will actually solve the situation with the agreement of different parties," Mr. Boucher said. The new Administration has found it particularly difficult to formulate a position on the peace plan advanced by the United Nations-European Community mediation team, which would establish a Bosnian confederation of 10 autonomous regions, most with strong majorities of one of the three main national groups.
 
Experience Under Vance
 For example, even as Mr. Boucher was expressing doubts about the feasibility of the plan, twice during the briefing he said that the new Administration supported the negotiations led by Cyrus R. Vance, the special United Nations envoy, and Lord Owen, the European Community representative.
Complicating matters is the broad spectrum of opinion within Mr. Clinton's foreign-policy team on the peace plan, ranging from cautious support of it as an imperfect but potential means of ending the bloodshed, to strong criticism because the settlement could be perceived as appeasement of the Serbs, who have made most of the gains in the fighting, and would rely too much on their goodwill when they have repeatedly broken promises in the past.
Another problem is that a number of Mr. Clinton's senior foreign-policy advisers worked for Mr. Vance when he was Secretary of State in the Carter Administration.
Mr. Christopher was Mr. Vance's Deputy Secretary, and the national security adviser, W. Anthony Lake, and his deputy, Samuel R. Berger, held key positions in the Carter-era State Department. One senior Administration official called discussion of the peace plan "agonizing" because of the deep respect felt for Mr. Vance.
But Mr. Christopher has sought to distance himself from his former boss, and appeared to align himself with the more skeptical Administration view during his Senate confirmation hearings last week. Senator Joseph R. Biden, the Delaware Democrat, said he found it a "bit bizarre" that some of the Serbs involved in the negotiations are people the United States has labeled as suspected war criminals, and asked Mr. Christopher whether he was concerned that a map drawn up under the Geneva peace plan "ratified the atrocites of ethnic cleansing," the forcible expulsion of other ethnic groups from areas seized by the Serbs.
"I do have a personal concern along these lines," Mr. Christopher replied, but added that the United States was not a party to those negotiations.
Mr. Boucher declined to say today whether the Clinton Administration believed the Vance-Owen plan ratified ethnic cleansing.
Within the department, those who support the Vance-Owen approach argue that if the primary parties engaged in the talks -- the Bosnian Serbs, the Bosnian Croats and the Bosnian Muslims -- agree on a settlement, then it is not up to the United States to stand in their way.
Opposing them are officials who question the wisdom of negotiating with Radovan Karadzic, president of the self-proclaimed Serbian Republic of Bosnia, and Slobodan Milosevic, President of the Serbian republic, who were on the Bush Administration's list of possible war criminals.
 
Clinton Team's Options
 Mr. Vance said in an interview in Geneva this week that Mr. Christopher personally backed his negotiations. Senior Administration officials did not dispute that Mr. Christopher generally supported the negotiating process, but cautioned that he had made no commitments on the plan. When the two men spoke by telephone several days ago, Mr. Christopher agreed to take a "hard look" at the plan, but "rendered no judgments or comments," a senior official said.
The new Administration regards the crisis in the Balkans as the most difficult foreign-policy problem it will have to address immediately. In her confirmation hearings today as chief United States representative to the United Nations, Madeleine Albright called the crisis in the Balkans "clearly the highest priority of the President in the National Security Council's agenda," adding that the N.S.C. would meet very soon to discuss the matter.
Mr. Clinton has ruled out the use of American ground troops in Bosnia, and Ms. Albright reiterated his support for speedy enforcement of a United Nations-mandated ban on flights by the three Bosnian factions and called for the creation of an international tribunal to try war criminals.
Other Administration officials said they are studying other options. Among those under consideration: a campaign to selectively lift the United Nations-imposed arms embargo, which now favors the better-armed Serbs; a further tightening of the economic sanctions; a plan for guaranteeing and enforcing any peace settlement so that it could not be misused by Serbs as a ploy to avoid outside military intervention, and a more aggressive plan through the United Nations to deliver relief aid throughout Bosnia, even if it required military intervention.

Companies

The Economy
The Sematech chip-making consortium accomplished its goal of using American-made equipment to produce a chip with ultra-thin circuitry. It met the goal on time and on budget. [D4.]
Zoe Baird withdrew her name as President Clinton's nominee to be Attorney General. [A1.] The Senate confirmed Ronald H. Brown as Commerce Secretary, Robert B. Reich as Labor Secretary and Leon E. Panetta as director of the Office of Management and Budget. [A13.]
The economy except in California continues to improve, with gains in retailing, construction and factories, the Federal Reserve said. But job growth continues to lag. [A16.]
 
International
Japanese companies are losing their grip on the computer memory chip market. High costs and sharp competition have caused many to curb production of widely used D-RAM's, their mainstay product since the 1980's. [D1.]

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Dell to Sell Computers Directly in Japan

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 21

 BODY:
A personal-computer price war heated up here today, with the Dell Computer Corporation announcing that it would sell low-priced computers directly to Japanese customers.
Dell, based in Austin, Tex., said it would sell personal computers at prices sharply lower than those announced earlier this week by the NEC Corporation, which controls more than half the Japanese market. 
 NEC announced its price cuts in response to new lower-priced computers introduced by Compaq, I.B.M., Apple and other American makers. Dell, which pioneered direct marketing of PC's in the United States, plans to avoid Japan's difficult distribution system by selling directly.
But the decision is something of a gamble, since many Japanese are used to personalized service and are not accustomed to ordering expensive goods by mail or phone. It also comes as Japan's computer industry faces hard times in the recession.
The managing director of Dell's new Japanese subsidiary, Katsumi Iizuka, said the bad economic conditions gave the company an advantage, in light of the lower prices and efficient marketing methods.
The company's cheapest computer in Japan with a 486 chip will be priced at 152,000 yen -- a little more than $1,200 -- while NEC's cheapest lists for 218,000 yen, or $1,745. But NEC's products are frequently discounted by dealers.
Dell said it would welcome orders from individuals but would focus on business customers. As in the United States, it will provide free technical support by telephone, along with a year of on-site servicing through a Japanese company.

HEADLINE: SETTLING IN: Presidential Appointees;
14 Major Clinton Nominees Are Confirmed by Senate

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
The Senate today approved 14 major appointments by President Clinton, including Ronald H. Brown as Commerce Secretary after he agreed to sever all ties to his former law firm and to remove himself from all decisions that might give the appearance of a conflict of interest.
Among the others confirmed today were Donna E. Shalala as Secretary of Health and Human Services, Robert B. Reich as Labor Secretary, Federico F. Pena as Transportation Secretary and Leon E. Panetta as director of the Office of Management and Budget. 
 The full Senate voted to approve Mr. Brown just hours after the Senate Commerce Committee unanimously voted to send his name to the floor. Mr. Brown's confirmation left only one other Cabinet nominee bogged down in controversy, that of Zoe Baird to be Attorney General. Several Senators urged Ms. Baird, who admitted knowingly breaking the law by employing two illegal aliens as domestic servants, to withdraw.
 
Critic Backs Brown
 Senator Trent Lott, the Mississippi Republican who had led criticism that Mr. Brown's initial policy on conflicts of interest was too narrow, said today that he was satisfied with Mr. Brown's pledge on Wednesday not to discuss with his former colleagues at Patton, Boggs & Blow any matter before the Commerce Department or likely to come before the department.
Senator Lauch Faircloth, a North Carolina Republican, cast the sole vote against Mr. Brown.
Mr. Brown, the former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, presented a more narrow conflict-of-interest policy when he appeared before the Commerce Committee on Jan. 6 in the first Congressional hearing for a nominee to the Clinton Cabinet. Nominees with later hearings, including Mickey Kantor as the United States Trade Representative, tended to adopt broader conflict-of-interest policies.
The Senate confirmed Mr. Kantor today, as well as Mike Espy as Agriculture Secretary, Richard W. Riley as Education Secretary and Jesse Brown as Secretary of Veterans Affairs. Also confirmed were Henry G. Cisneros as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and Hazel R. O'Leary as Energy Secretary.
Also confirmed today were Carol M. Browner as Director of the Environmental Protection Agency, Roger C. Altman as Deputy Treasury Secretary and Alice M. Rivln as Deputy Budget Director.
 
Tough Questions for Babbitt
 In his second day before the Senate Energy Committee, former Gov. Bruce Babbitt of Arizona faced tough questioning from Western senators about his views on Federal lands and his links to environmental groups.
Mr. Babbitt, who was later confirmed as Interior Secretary, said he would take a balanced approach to the use of Federal lands, saying he could "accommodate both resource development and resource conservation."
Mr. Babbitt said he backed the Endangered Species Act, which calls on the Government to preserve threatened species and plants. Business and labor have often criticized the act for preventing logging in parts of the Northwest to protect the spotted owl.
Mr. Babbitt said the act's concept was "sound," asserting that with "thoughtful administration" such "collisions can be avoided."
 
Focusing on Job Growth
 In a confirmation hearing today, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, Mr. Clinton's nominee to be chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said one of the Administration's priorities would be to fulfill the President's goal of creating eight million jobs over four years.
She signaled that the Administration was seriously considering a short-term stimulus package, including increased deficit spending in the first year, to speed up job growth, which has been anemic despite months of economic recovery.
"This is a modest recovery," she said. "It's not creating jobs as fast as previous recoveries."
She predicted that the nation's trade deficit might deteriorate as Europe's and Japan's economies flounder, causing them to import fewer American goods. She said the Government should work to insure that American companies have full access to European and Japanese markets, asserting that she favored open trade and was not, as some critics contend, a protectionist.
 
Specialist in Trade Issues
 Ms. Tyson, a professor at the University of California at Berkeley, told the Senate Banking Committee that the trade deficit was evidence that the nation's economic competitiveness had eroded. A specialist in trade issues, Ms. Tyson noted that American companies have lost market share abroad in computers, commercial aircraft and telecommunications.
She denied that she favored having the Government decide which industries have the best chance to be successful in the future and then aiding those industries. Instead she said the Government should encourage increased investment, research and job training for all industries.
Ms. Tyson said that to make more loans available to small business, the new Administration was studying whether to help arrange for financial institutions to package and sell such loans to outside investors, as is done with home mortgages. This would help reduce the risk for financial institutions that make such loans.
In another confirmation hearing, Madeleine K. Albright, the nominee for Ambassador to the United Nations, told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that the fighting in Bosnia was "clearly the highest priority of the President in the National Security Council's agenda." Ms. Albright, a professor at Georgetown University's School of Foreign Service, urged enforcement of the United Nations' ban on Serbian warplanes flying over Bosnia.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, who was confirmed on Wednesday along with Warren M. Christopher as Secretary of State and Les Aspin as Secretary of Defense, announced today that Lawrence H. Summers was being nominated as Under Secretary for International Affairs and Frank N. Newman as Under Secretary for Domestic Finance.
Mr. Summers is an economics professor at Harvard University and Mr. Newman is vice chairman of the board and chief financial officer of the BankAmerica Corporation, the California-based banking company.
Mr. Bentsen also announced that Eugene A. Ludwig, a lawyer at Covington & Burling in Washington, was his nominee for Comptroller of the Currency.

HEADLINE: SETTLING IN: The Pentagon;
Aspin Moves In With Much Unsettled

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
The mundane collided with the sublime at the Pentagon today as Defense Secretary Les Aspin and his staff began moving into their new quarters and immediately faced issues ranging from combat in Iraq to jockeying over Pentagon parking spaces.
Unlike most of President Clinton's incoming Cabinet secretaries, Mr. Aspin, a former Pentagon analyst and chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, is no stranger to the department he now heads. Senior aides said that Mr. Aspin would soon give Mr. Clinton a reorganization plan for the civilian side of the agency. 
 But the Administration has been slow to fill senior civilian positions, to the point that the line of succession has left Adm. Frank B. Kelso 2d, the chief of naval operations, as acting Secretary of the Navy, a position that is supposed to be held by a civilian.
 
Phones, Locks and Parking
 A flurry of activity engulfed Mr. Aspin's third-floor offices along the Pentagon's outer ring of power suites. Aides in pin-striped suits, scurried between meetings, dickered for office space, negotiated a new telephone system and waited for Pentagon security passes. Locksmiths were called to change locks on doors and office safes. It was not until late afternoon that the traditional ceremonial sentry who stands at attention outside the Defense Secretary's office found his way to Mr. Aspin's quarters.
Telephone calls for former Defense Secretary Dick Cheney were being referred to his new employer, the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative research group in Washington.
"It's probably less chaotic than it seems to us," said one harried aide to Mr. Aspin. "But people were coming back from lunch today, hoping their offices were still there and no one new had moved in."
 
Nominates 49 Generals
 In other parts of the Pentagon, it was unusually quiet, despite an attack by two American F-16's on an Iraqi missile battery. Motorized carts scooted around the corridors picking up shredder-bound brown paper sacks filled with discarded files of departed political appointees.
Mr. Aspin, who in his new job gets a raise to $148,400 from his $129,500 salary as a member of the House of Representatives, spent most of the day in meetings and listening to job-seekers. One of his first official acts was to announce the nominations of 49 Air Force and Air National Guard officers to be generals.
The new Defense Secretary also met for two hours with the joint chiefs of staff, where the discussion was dominated almost completely by Mr. Clinton's campaign pledge to lift the ban on homosexuals in the military.
 
Post-Cold-War Organization
 Mr. Aspin and his aides have been finishing a reorganization plan for the Defense Department that will soon be submitted for Mr. Clinton's approval, senior aides said.
Under the proposal, Mr. Aspin and the Deputy Defense Secretary will preside over the civilian side of the Defense Department whose activities, now organized into two major groups, would be reorganized along four functional lines: policy, financial management, personnel and readiness, and acquisition.
Financial, personnel and acquisition activities would be carried on roughly as before, but the policy branch would be reorganized. Instead of concentrating largely on the Soviet threat, as it did during the cold war, the branch would address five emerging threats to national security: regional conflicts, arms proliferation, economic conversion, reversal of reforms in the former Soviet republics, and strategy and resources. The Administration has not formally named any senior Pentagon officials except Mr. Aspin. But Pentagon aides said that a handful of senior positions had been filled. William J. Perry, a former Under Secretary of Defense for Research and Engineering in the Carter Administration, will be the Deputy Defense Secretary. He currently heads Technology Strategies and Alliances, a consulting company in Menlo Park, Calif.
Frank G. Wisner, Under Secretary of State for International Security Affairs, will replace Paul D. Wolfowitz as Under Secretary of Defense for Policy. Among those expected to join Mr. Wisner in the policy branch are Walter B. Slocombe, a former Defense Department official in the Carter Administration and an expert on strategic forces, and Jock Covey, a Middle East expert who serves in the Bush Administration's State Department.
 
The Aspin Contingent
 Mr. Aspin is bringing along many members of his former staff from the House Armed Services Committee. Rudy F. de Leon, the committee's staff director, will become a special assistant to Mr. Aspin. Larry K. Smith, the committee's counsel, will become a counsel to the Defense Secretary. Vernon A. Guidry, Jr., a committee staff member, will replace Pete Williams as the Pentagon spokesman.
The departures of Mr. Cheney and 39 other appointees of Mr. Bush have left vacancies at the highest civilian levels of the Defense Department.
The Clinton Administration asked the following five other Bush appointees to stay for a time to help with the transition: John Shannon, Under Secretary of the Army; Martin C. Faga, Assistant Secretary of the Air Force for Space; Michael B. Donley, Assistant Secretary of the Air Force for Financial Management and Comptroller; James R. Locher 3d, Assistant Secretary of Defense for Special Operations and Low Intensity Conflict; and Victor H. Reis, Director of Defense Research and Engineering.
Clinton transition aides approached Barbara S. Pope, Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Manpower and Reserve Affairs, and Robert C. McCormack, the Navy Comptroller, to help with the Navy transition, but both declined for personal reasons, Navy officials said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Talk of a Smaller Issue Lifts Bonds

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Treasury prices inched higher yesterday as traders and investors continued to wait to see what the new Clinton Administration would do to stimulate the economy and cut the record Federal budget deficit.
More speculation about a Treasury move to reduce the issuance of 30-year bonds helped lift their price by 12/32 and lower the yield to 7.30 percent, from 7.33 percent Wednesday. 
 The prices of Treasury notes were also up a little as yields declined. And the discount rates on Treasury bills fell several basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.
Michael H. Strauss, the chief economist at Yamaichi International, said the fact that the economy seemed to be doing "a little backing and filling" was also helping support the market both at the short and long ends. "The spending at Christmas is being offset by less spending in the beginning of the year," he said.
 
Reduction of Issue Denied

 
 Early in the day there was a rumor that Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bensten would hold a news conference to announce that the Treasury would not reduce the amount of 30-year bonds scheduled for sale in its quarterly auction next month. That pushed the price lower. But the Treasury denied the rumor.
Then during her confirmation hearing before the Senate Banking Committee, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the nominee to head the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said that the Administration was indeed considering cutting back the sales of 30-year bonds. That comment sent the price of the bond higher in generally light trading.
Analysts and economists are split over the impact of cutting the issuance of 30-year bonds. Some argue that the Government could both cut its borrowing costs and bring long-term interest rates down a little. But achieving these benefits would require a cut in issuance probably much larger than the new Treasury staff is even considering. In addition, others argue that the Treasury could wind up with no savings in borrowing costs and little impact on interest rates.
The Treasury announced yesterday that it would auction $15.25 billion of two-year notes on Tuesday and $11.5 billion of five-year notes on Wednesday. The $15.25 billion for the two-year note was $250 million less than the last auction in November while the $11.50 billion for the five-year note was $250 million higher.
The reduction in the size of the two-year auction, Mr. Strauss said, helped lift the price of the current two-year note late in the day. It was up 3/32 to yield 4.30 percent, down from 4.35 percent Wednesday.
In the pre-auction, or when-issued, market yesterday, the two-year note was trading at a yield of 4.37 percent while the five-year note was at a yield of 5.82 percent. Both yields are several basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, higher than the yields on the current Treasury security for each maturity.
 
High Yield Bonds
 In the high-yield or junk-bond market, an issue by Overhead Door Corporation, a Dallas-based manufacturer of doors used in construction, issued $85 million of notes due in 2000 at a yield of 12.25 percent. The lead underwriter was the First Boston Corporation.
Edward H. D'Alelio, chief investment officer of the high-yield bond group at the Putnam Companies in Boston, said that this deal was an example of the smaller companies that are becoming regular issuers in the junk-bond market.
He said the demand was so strong that there were about $300 million of bids for the $85 million issue.
Mr. D'Alelio said that the junk bond market was generally being helped by the economy's slow recovery and the purchase of better-rated high- yield bonds by institutions and funds that usually purchase only investment-grade corporate bonds. He said the low yields on other securities and the improvement of prospects of many companies selling high-yield bonds were enticing these normally more conservative buyers.
According to Salomon Brothers, the secondary market for junk bonds was up 6 cents yesterday, led by gains in the bonds of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and USAir Group. USAir announced that British Airways would pump $300 million into the American carrier.
 
Money Supply
 The regular Thursday report from the Federal Reserve on the nation's money supply will not be released until today because of the observance of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday and the holiday for the Inauguration in Washington Wednesday.

HEADLINE: But Does Punishment Fit the Budget?

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
With spending on corrections quadrupling in the 1980's and continuing to rise sharply, the North Carolina Legislature this week began considering a plan that would reduce the average criminal sentence in the state by 80 percent and send nonviolent criminals to community programs for supervision, treatment and work.
The Arkansas Legislature began considering a similar proposal this week, and Kansas has just started remodeling its sentencing policies and punishment programs. Criminal justice experts say other states, including Pennsylvania, Delaware, Florida, Tennessee, Louisiana, Texas and Ohio, are also slowly moving in a similar direction. 
 Pressed by rising costs for health care and other programs, the experts say, legislators and governors around the nation have begun reconsidering the merits of stringent anti-crime laws and mandatory minimum sentences that nearly all states enacted in recent years without regard to future costs. As more such laws come under review, they expect a number of states to overhaul or scrap their criminal justice systems.
 
Big Budget Item
 For a decade, corrections spending has been the fastest- or second-fastest growing part of state budgets, after health care. This year, states have allocated $2 billion to build prisons and $15 billion more to operate corrections departments. At the same time, many states have been ordered by Federal courts to relieve prison overcrowding by creating additional space in prisons or by releasing inmates, adding to their financial responsibilities. Those pressures, as well as the recession, have forced deep reductions in education and other programs.
It is a time of reckoning for the states -- and perhaps for the entire country. President Clinton, who as Governor of Arkansas created that state's commission to plan the remodeling of its criminal laws, may appoint a national crime commission to do the same thing at the Federal level, say criminal justice experts who served on his transition team.
"We're at a point of change," said Kenneth F. Schoen, a transition team leader who is director of criminal justice programs at the Edna McConnell Clark Foundation, a New York philanthropy. "We're seeing a wide awareness of the failures of the current get-tough laws that most states passed, and we're seeing an almost universal interest -- motivated entirely by the cost of prisons -- in exploring the cost-effective alternatives."
Such plans will be studied by penal experts and elected officials from around the nation as they gather in Winston-Salem, N.C., on Friday at the National Association of Counties annual conference on justice and public safety. A primary focus of the meeting will be North Carolina's proposed overhaul of its punishment system, and conference leaders say they will be sharing plans to promote similar efforts in other states.
Lynn S. Branham, who will give the conference's main speech, said, "It's time to say that the emperor has no clothes, that with all these tough new laws we are not safer and we're going broke." Ms. Branham is a law professor at the Thomas Cooley Law School in Lansing, Mich., and a former chairman of the American Bar Association's committee on corrections policy.
 
3 States Are Models
 The reorganization in Kansas and the plans under consideration in North Carolina and Arkansas are far from novel or experimental ideas. They are modeled on existing criminal laws and policies in Minnesota, Washington and Oregon, which began pioneering these ideas as far back as 1980.
Even in the last few years, for example, when Minnesota got caught up in a national trend of enacting tough anti-crime laws, a special commission on corrections policy is heading off higher costs associated with proposals before the State Legislature. In one instance, the legislature defeated a plan to stiffen sentences for first-time drug offenders after the commission determined that it would require 1,300 new prison beds and a $32 million annual operating budget.
The state sends nonviolent offenders to community programs, which are 20 percent to 50 percent less expensive than prison and which experts say hold more promise for rehabilitating offenders. The experts say that more states might adopt such approaches were it not for the highly emotional arguments that arise over anti-crime legislation.
"Crime is a very emotional issue and it's difficult to create a rational policy in such an emotional area," said Debra L. Dailey, executive director of the state's panel, the Minnesota Sentencing Guidelines Commission. But fiscal experts also say budget concerns may overcome resistance in other states.
 
Reasons for Overcrowding
 As in most other states, North Carolina's increased efforts to enforce drug laws, population changes and the legislature's enactment of severe anti-crime laws in the 1980's have contributed to prison overcrowding, state officials say. North Carolina now faces a staggering 9 percent annual increase in felony convictions. The state increased its prison capacity by 50 percent in the 1980's. But because of its inability to build prisons fast enough, the state has been releasing prisoners early to comply with a 1987 Federal order that requires it to reduce overcrowding.
To cope with the system's needs and the court order, the North Carolina commission issued a report this week recommending a complete restructuring of the way the state sentences and punishes criminals. The commission recommends reducing prison sentences by an average of 80 percent, to reflect the time inmates actually serve, and publicly acknowledging the state's limited capacity to imprison offenders.
The commission also recommends reserving prison cells only for violent offenders and scattering other convicts to an expanded network of less costly, and possibly more effective, halfway houses, treatment programs, supervised probation and victim-restitution programs.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
McDonnell's Earnings Off 61.9% in '92

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 21

 BODY:
The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that its earnings fell 61.9 percent in 1992, as a result of heavy losses from its C-17 cargo plane and continued declines in its commercial aircraft division. These results excluded the effects of a one-time accounting change that gave the company a net loss for the year.
Moreover, the company's fourth-quarter earnings, also excluding the one-time accounting change, declined 59.2 percent. 
 St. Louis-based McDonnell, which is the nation's largest weapons contractor, said it earned $161 million, or $4.15 a share, compared with $423 million, or $11.03 a share, in 1991. Revenues also declined in 1992, to $17.38 billion from $18.07 billion in 1991.
But McDonnell said that it took a charge of $942 million, or $24.25 a share, in 1992 to adopt new accounting rules for retiree health benefits that many United States companies are undertaking. The charge, which has no impact on the company's cash flow, resulted in a net loss of $781 million, or $20.10 a share, for 1992, McDonnell said.
For the fourth quarter, excluding the accounting change, McDonnell had earnings of $86 million, or $2.20 a share, compared with $211 million, or $5.50 a share, in the 1991 fourth quarter. But including the longer-term effect of the new accounting rules, the company posted net income of $762 million for the quarter.
The fourth-quarter results, excluding that one-time accounting item, were far below securities analysts' estimates and reflect continued weakness at the beleaguered aerospace company. Still, McDonnell Douglas shares rose $2.50 today, to $56.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Operating income for the commercial aircraft segment declined 48 percent, to $151 million, in 1992, compared with $291 million in 1991, because of overall softness in the airline market, lower margins on the MD-11 trijet, and higher research and development costs, the company said.
McDonnell Douglas, which has a shrinking backlog and few new orders on the horizon, has not been competitive with its rivals in the commercial aircraft industry, the Boeing Company and the European Airbus Industrie. Analysts have said that McDonnell needs to broaden its product line, but the company lacks the finances to do so.
The military aircraft division earned $77 million in 1992, compared with $404 million the year before. The drop was due mainly to heavy losses in the C-17 military transport program. The C-17 wing buckled and was damaged during an Oct. 1 stress test. McDonnell said that it loss about $470 million on the C-17 in 1992.
But the chief financial officer, Herbert Lanese, said that the company had now put the worst behind it and that 1993 would "be a pivotal year" for McDonnell. Mr. Lanese predicted that the C-17 would be profitable this year and that McDonnell would generate about $1 billion in cash that it will use to reduce debt. About half the $1 billion will come from improved operations and the other half from the sale of assets, Mr. Lanese said.
Mr. Lanese also noted that operating profit was about 10 percent on most weapons programs last year and that he expected the company to earn more than the $8.15 a share average predicted by analysts for 1993.

HEADLINE: Uncovered Short Sales Decline 8% on Big Board

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
Reversing a 10-month trend, the number of shares sold short and not yet covered on the New York Stock Exchange fell almost 8 percent in the period from mid-December to mid-January, the Big Board reported yesterday.
At the end of the period on Jan. 15, short interest fell sharply to 931.8 million shares. That was the lowest level since September. In the previous period, short interest surpassed the billion mark for the first time. 
 The figures on short interest are closely watched on Wall Street as a gauge of investor sentiment, since they reflect the activities of professional traders who specialize in ferreting out companies whose stock price they believe is in for a fall. The sellers borrow shares of these companies and sell them, betting that they will be able to buy the shares back at a lower price and profit from the difference.
 
Amex Also Down
 The number of shares sold short on the American Stock Exchange also dropped in the period to 66.9 million shares from 69.5 million.
While the drop in short interest could reflect a belief that the market is heading up, professional traders said yesterday that the reason for the retrenchment was more basic: Many short-sellers have been making poor bets for the last two years and are now operating with less capital and are becoming less aggressive in their bets.
The raging bull market in small- capitalization stocks has been particularly damaging to short-sellers, many of whom have seen stock prices of some of these small companies rise even as negative news emerges.
"The stocks have been pushed up to these incredible levels, and people are now covering massive positions," one trader said.
Indeed, the trading has gotten so difficult that many money managers who had used short-selling in their trading strategy are backing away.
"A lot of people who thought they could use short-selling to be in a market neutral position and achieve great returns have found that they are wrong," said Steve Kibbey of Centurion Capital in La Jolla, Calif. "The lesson of the last two years is that if someone is going to manage money on the short side, they must have some market sensitivity."
One of the worst investments for short-sellers in the period was shares of Wells Fargo & Company. The stock price of the bank company has been steadily rising since October, and gained almost a dollar a day in the last 10 days of the period, closing at $85.25 on Jan. 15, the end of the current reporting period.
That grew even worse for short- sellers in the last few days, after Wells Fargo announced strong earnings. The company shares have since gone as high as $100.875, and closed yesterday at $98.25, up $1.
The short interest in Wells Fargo was huge in the period, standing at 2.3 million shares.

Short Sales Tables Explained
 These tables show issues with a short interest position in the current month of at least 250,000 shares or a change up or down from the previous month of at least 108,894 shares.
 Cover ratio represents the number of days, at average volume level, that it would take to purchase the number of shares sold short.
A -- American Stock Exchange.
 N -- New York Stock Exchange.
 N.L. -- Not listed.
 + -- Stock split.
 * (American Stock Exchange only.) May have been affected by arbitrage transactions resulting from any one or more of the following: proposed or pending acquisitions; convertible securities of the same company; rights offerings; stock splits or distributions; tenders; other special situations.
 Short interest may also be affected by options positions.
 <check> Indicates a change of 75 percent or more from the previous month.

HEADLINE: Upturn Continues in Most Areas, Fed Reports

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
With the notable exception of California, the economy showed continued improvement in December and early January, with sizable gains in retail sales augmented by better activity in factories and residential construction, a survey published today by the Federal Reserve Board said.
But the survey found that over all employers were moving slowly in adding to payrolls as they tried to squeeze still more productivity from current workers. The cost of health benefits was repeatedly cited as a deterrent to hiring. 
 The Fed's survey, compiled largely from anecdotal reports collected in its 12 districts, is used in the deliberations of the Federal Open Market Committee, its chief policy-making body.
 
A Look at the Year Ahead
 The committee's next session, beginning Feb. 2, is to produce a fairly detailed statement of the Fed's expectations for the economy this year and the monetary strategy to be associated with it. The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, is scheduled to present it to the Senate Banking Committee on Feb. 18.
Although today's survey, which included information gathered through Jan. 11, did not indicate a sharp acceleration of activity, it did seem to show some broadening improvement. Early in December, the Fed found the economy "improving modestly but unevenly," while five weeks earlier the improvement was "slow and uneven."
Even in the still-slumping market for commercial real estate, the survey found "some positive signs here and there."
Reports from the Fed's districts "indicate continued improvement in economic conditions across much of the nation," said the Kansas City unit, which coordinated the poll this time.
It called retail sales during the recent holiday season significantly better than in 1991 in most districts and factory activity "steady to increasing moderately in nearly all districts." Residential real estate also gained, with "some glimmers of hope" for multiple-family dwellings. Atlanta and Dallas reported higher occupancy rates and firming rent levels.
But house prices weakened further in Southern California, and in the state as a whole, persistent weakness, with continued contraction in manufacturing, offset moderate growth elsewhere in the district.
Banks reported a further slight increase in demand for loans in most districts, but there was little expectation of higher interest rates. The survey found little evidence of production bottlenecks or other potential sources of revived inflation.
Retailing strength in New England was concentrated in the Boston area, the survey indicated, with various merchants elsewhere not sharing in the holiday gains. And half the factories there reported recent sales to be flat, compared with levels a year earlier.
The New York district reported solid gains for apparel of all kinds. It said that office leasing ran at a "fairly good pace" in midtown Manhattan but remained sluggish downtown. Buffalo posted the first decline in its rate of office vacancies in four years.
 
Good News From Atlanta
 Elsewhere, one-third of factories in the Philadelphia district expect to step up hiring and increase working hours over the next six months, and Atlanta reported double-digit gains in holiday sales and strong tourism, especially from abroad.
Many of those responding to the survey in the St. Louis district complained of a lack of qualified workers, even as many small businesses "worry about the rising cost of health care."
Minneapolis reported a strong winter recreation business in northern Michigan and strong home construction throughout the district.
The Dallas bank said that Austin had become the district's first major metropolitan area in a decade to show office vacancy rates below the national average.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises as Economies In Europe Show Weakness

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled higher in moderate trading yesterday on worsening economic conditions in Europe.
Gold prices fell in United States trading, but advanced on overseas markets. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $329.20 a troy ounce, off 70 cents from Wednesday. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid of $329.30, down 35 cents. 
 The dollar rose in European trading, spurred by the British Government's announcement of a two-tenths of a percent rise in unemployment in December to 10.5 percent. That news, in addition to anticipation of further interest rate cuts by the Bank of England, continued to set the tone when trading shifted to domestic markets, analysts said.
 
Profit Taking Seen
 "It was a day of dollar gains, mostly concentrated at sterling's expense because of the bad economic figures," said Mike Faust, a foreign exchange analyst at MMS International. "The dollar had been under pressure for the past few days and saw some relief today."
Ronald Holzer, chief currency trader at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago, said, "Prospects for lower European rates and weaker economies prompted profit taking at the lower dollar levels."
The market also appeared to focus on Europe because of a dearth of significant domestic economic news. The Federal Reserve provided a rosy economic outlook in its latest report on business activity, but this gave the dollar only minor support, traders said.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 124.68 yen, down from 125.39 at Wednesday's close. Later in London, the dollar rose to 125.04 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 124.90 yen, up from 124.625 yen on Wednesday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.5180, from $1.5410 late Wednesday. In New York, it cost $1.5225 to buy one pound, less expensive than Wednesday's $1.5440.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.6135 German marks, up from 1.60375; 1.4795 Swiss francs, up from 1.4685; 5.4530 French francs, up from 5.4190; 1,477.00 Italian lire, up from 1,464.00, and 1.28515 Canadian dollars, up from 1.28135.

HEADLINE: Figure Skating;
Reunited U.S. Pair Captures Crown

BYLINE: By FILIP BONDY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHOENIX, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Calla Urbanski didn't mean to call him a toad.
Rocky Marval was sorry he didn't practice his triples. 
 Apologies behind them, a great American figure-skating story resumed. Urbanski and Marval, a team again, won the pairs competition Thursday night at the United States championships. Perhaps more surprising they are on speaking terms.
"I was just a temporary toad," said Marval, the quiet trucker from New Egypt, N.J., born Rocco Marvaldi.
"His work habits are better," said Urbanski, who is 32 years old and still waits on tables for one week every month at Kid Shelleen's in Wilmington, Del.
Romeo and Juliet on ice they are not. There is still creative tension in the air when these two perform their synchronous double axels. But with a fresh start and a Winter Olympics to aim at just one year away in Lillehammer, Norway, Urbanski and Marval hope their past differences can work, quickly, in their favor.
 
'It Was Like Walking on Glass'
 "I don't want to harp on the split," Urbanski said. "For a while after we got back together, it was like walking on glass. Everything was very fragile. But now, we're more friends on the ice. My patience is better. Rocky knows my frustration, and it's new for him to reach out and explain things."
After finishing a disappointing seventh last year at the Albertville Olympics and 10th at the world championships in Oakland, Calif., Urbanski decided in June that Marval was not working hard enough and that she would look for another partner.
"I have to kiss a few toads before I find a prince," she said at the time.
Urbanski tried her luck skating with Scott Kurttila, a former singles skater who was 27 years old, the same age as Marval. Kurttila displeased Urbanski even more than Marval.
In July, Marval tried out a new partner of his own, Natasha Kuchiki. That didn't work well, either, and tough economic times forced him to sell five of the nine trucks in his Marvaldi Trucking Inc. fleet in New Jersey.
Then, less than two months after they had broken up, Urbanski called.
"It was her initiative at the beginning, and her initiative at the end," Marval said.
"Rocky's anguish was public; mine was unseen," Urbanski said. "I became the evil one."
Together again, the skaters face logistical and injury problems that have nothing to do with their stormy relationship. The pair divide their training between Wilmington, where they work with a coach, Ron Ludington, and a choreographer, Phillip Mills, and Monsey, N.Y., where they are coached by Peter Burrows.
They both spend a lot of time on the New Jersey Turnpike. Urbanski drives around while watching a small television in her car, and has rented a condo near Seton Hall University, in South Orange, as a geographical center.
"It's a place where I can relax, bring my fan mail, and just think about my skating," Urbanski said.
 
Injuries Become a Problem
 Urbanski has other troubles, not so easily solved. A muscle is torn away from the bone in her right leg. Another muscle in the same leg is strained. After years of topflight competition and several partners, Urbanski might be running low on time, and princes.
"I'm not 100 percent, but we know what's at stake," Urbanski said. "We're both looking to have a career out of this."
On Wednesday night at the America West Arena, the odd couple skated a strong technical program in campy silvery outfits. They had wanted to wear body suits with designer muscles, but had been discouraged from doing so by conservative judges at Skate America in Atlanta.
On Thursday night their physically demanding long program placed them first, ahead of another good pair with a bumpy history, Jenni Meno and Todd Sand. Meno and Sand dumped their respective pairs partners, Scott Wendland and Kuchiki, after romance blossomed between Meno and Sand in the Olympic Village in Albertville last February.
 
Coaching Not Always Easy
 "Right away, I was in a state of shock," said John Nicks, who coached both Meno-Wendland and Sand-Kuchiki. "Rational arguments, pro and con, were falling on deaf ears. I was wasting my time and breath."
It took months before Meno and Sand got their timing right, but Thursday night they earned the second of two berths for the for the world championships at Prague in March. Once there, an American team will need to place among the top five to earn a third pairs berth in the 1994 Olympics at Lillehammer.
"This hasn't always been easy," Urbanski said. "But we have to peak at the worlds."
 
ICE CHIPS
 BRIAN BOITANO, much talked about in absentia, was expected to arrive Thursday night to scout the men's competition on Friday and Saturday. . . . RENEE ROCA and GORSHA SUR won the original dance program Thursday night and led the ice-dancing event going into Friday night's final free-dance program. HEADLINE: The Art Market;
New Mood at Antiques Show

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL

 BODY:
COMPETITION is healthy. At least it seems to have made a difference at this year's Winter Antiques Show, which opens to the public tomorrow at the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan and runs through Jan. 31. For most of its 39 years, the event has been something of an institution on the antiques circuit, but in recent seasons this decidedly American show had become overridden with boring brown furniture, banal objects and works of dubious provenance.
Then the arrival of the fall International Antiques Show at the armory four years ago changed things. And for the better. For starters, the quality controls at the Winter Antiques Show became stricter. They had to. Since the International Show is vetted, a practice common in Europe but still relatively new in the United States, the Winter Show felt it had to follow. Dealers at the Winter Show have always been required to offer customers a certificate of authenticity for every purchase, but this year, in addition to the guarantees, a committee made up of more than 70 dealers, scholars and art experts toured the armory, reviewing the objects in every booth. Anything they found questionable was removed. 
 "It has certainly made the show more expensive to produce, since we've had to take the armory for an extra day in order to give the vetting committee time," said Betty Sherrill, the chairwoman of the show, which benefits the East Side House Settlement, a century-old community service organization that sponsors programs for children, teen-agers and the elderly in the South Bronx. "There's always been pressure to vet. I guess the fact that the International Show is vetted has had a lot to do with it."
Penny Jones, the show's organizer, added that vetting was an important "comfort factor" in troubled economic times, especially for the new collector.
Still, many of the old-time dealers don't like the idea. "I'm not a believer in vetting," said Allan S. Chait, president of Ralph M. Chait Galleries in Manhattan, who has participated in the Winter Antiques Show for 34 years. "I suppose it's keeping up with the times, but things still slip through the cracks."
Other seasoned dealers expressed concern that vetting would raise the standards of the show, thereby raising prices, which in turn would discourage business. Of the two major antiques shows in Manhattan, the Winter Antiques Show has always been the bigger commercial success. Less forbidding than the more proper International Show, it plays to a larger audience and has made its reputation by featuring more decorative pieces and fewer museum-quality objects.
"Just because a show is vetted doesn't mean it has to be dull," said Thomas K. Woodard, co-owner of the Madison Avenue gallery that bears his name. The centerpiece at his booth this weekend is a 17-foot-long, late-19th-century English work of fairground art called the Charioteer. Made of intricately carved gilded wood, it depicts a pair of horses with the figure of Perseus in the center. The piece was originally designed to attract attention at the entrance to a fairground.
The $325,000 work makes quite a spectacle, but it's not exactly an easy sell for someone looking to furnish a Park Avenue living room. "It was designed to make a pitch to sell the show, and that's exactly what we are doing," said Mr. Woodard. "I hear Donald Trump is building an amusement park. Wouldn't this be perfect for the entrance?"
 
Eyecatchers Abound
 As unusual as the Charioteer is, it will be in the company of a host of other exotic antiques in an extraordinary range of offerings from the eccentric to the mundane. "People will be especially fascinated by the unusual forms and shapes at this year's show," said Mrs. Jones. "Dealers have brought eye-catching, show-stopping things."
Michael Goedhuis, a London dealer who has taken part in the Winter Antiques Show for 10 years, is highlighting a pair of Japanese bronze lions 5 feet long and 45 inches high. Originally temple guardians, the lions came from Langley Park, England, just outside of Windsor. "I haven't seen any of this scale and quality," Mr. Goedhuis said, adding that the pair was priced at $475,000.
Hardly a bargain, but then dealers seem undaunted by the high price tags that are ubiquitious at this year's show. This attitude is, in fact, quite a change from three months ago, when the recession was on everyone's mind at the International Antiques Show and dealers made an extra effort to show affordable, useful pieces.
 
'Feeling of Optimism'
 Among the 67 dealers in the Winter Antiques Show, the mood seems far more upbeat than it was in the fall. "Business has been terrific," said Stuart Feld, who runs Hirschl & Adler Galleries in Manhattan. "There's a tremendous feeling of optimism."
Edward Munves Jr., the president of the James Robinson gallery on East 57th Street, said he had noticed that "everyone wants to feel good." He suggested that the high prices in evidence were a reflection of the rising cost of rare, top-quality pieces. "The best things won't go down in price," he said. "There's just not enough supply."
Another Manhattan dealer, Leigh Keno, said he had seen a lot of interest in this weekend's opening, far more than last year. "There's real excitement," he said. "Collectors have been calling to ask about opening night. As dealers are feeling better about the market, they are bringing things they might not have brought last season when the mood was more somber."
This being Presidential Inauguration week in Washington, some objects in the show make an appropriate nod to patriotism. Mr. Keno, for example, is featuring a miniature portrait of George Washington by William Russell Birch. "It's certainly the right season," the dealer said. He added that Birch had chosen to make the enamel miniature from two Gilbert Stuart portraits of Washington, even though Washington had offered to sit for him. Birch sold the miniature to James McHenry, Washington's Secretary of War; Mr. Keno said he bought it from a descendant of McHenry. The portrait costs $55,000.
Other patriotic pieces can be seen at Fred B. Nadler Antiques, where a green-and-white porcelain cut-corner bowl and serving dish (circa 1800) in a pattern known as Green Fitzhugh, features an eagle in the center. The Green Room at the White House has the same pattern, acquired during the Nixon Administration, Mr. Nadler said.
 
Dollhouse From George III Period
 There are also objects at the show that boast a royal provenance. A doll's house, beautifully outfitted with tiny furniture and objects and on view at the Kentshire Galleries booth, was made by the children of King George III and given to the children of Sir George Grey, who was the captain of the King's flagship. The gallery bought it at a small English country auction. "This is my third year doing the show and it seems we're all making a special effort," said Fred Imberman, an owner of the Manhattan gallery. "The competition has really forced us to try to improve the show."
Of the eight new dealers participating, two joined the show because of the success they had at the International Show in October. "This show is supposed to be more commercial, and I thought it would be good to try it," said Peter Finer, a dealer from Warwickshire, England. "I've got some inexpensive items, ranging from $5,000 to $10,000." But the star piece in his booth is a $125,000 sword carried by Napoleon.
Mark Jacoby, a director of Philip Colleck, a Manhattan gallery that specializes in English 18th-century furniture and objects, is another first-time participant. Because he is the new kid in the show, he said, he purposely filled his booth with a wide range of furniture and objects: "It's our way of introducing ourselves." Among his selections are a Victorian settee with its original needlepoint upholstery, a miniature coromandel screen, and a Queen Anne over-the-mantel mirror.
 
Hard Acts to Follow
 Seasoned dealers who have done both shows for four years now concede that it gets harder each season to fill their booths with exciting objects. "The two shows are too close together," said Mr. Chait. "Playing to a house that has already seen your act once is difficult." Complaining that he must find new things to take to each show, Mr. Chait explained: "I have to. Real collectors have too good a memory."

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN

 BODY:
There's the Rhodes scholar connection, the Yale connection, the Little Rock connection. And now, it seems, there's also a Carnegie foundation connection that leads right to the top of the Clinton Administration.
The foundation, known formally as the Carnegie Corporation of New York, is losing 3 of its 17 trustees to President Clinton's Cabinet or other high posts. WARREN M. CHRISTOPHER, until now chairman of the foundation, is now Secretary of State; ROBERT E. RUBIN, chairman of the its finance committee, was chosen to be chairman of the National Economic Council, and DONNA E. SHALALA is Secretary of Health and Human Services. 
"Donna Shalala was just appointed to the board and never even got to a meeting," Dr. DAVID HAMBURG, president of the Carnegie Corporation, said yesterday.
The Clinton transition team didn't limit itself to trustees, but tapped others from influential posts at the foundation as well. RICHARD RILEY, the former South Carolina Governor who is the new Secretary of Education, was chairman of a foundation task force on "Meeting the Needs of Very Young Children," which is expected to issue its report by the end of the year.
"We are hoping he will pay close attention to it," Dr. Hamburg said.
And then there was a task force that issued a report in 1990 called "Turning Points: Preparing American Youth for the 21st Century," including recommendations for the overhaul of junior high and middle schools. Among its members: Gov. BILL CLINTON of Arkansas.
"He made a major contribution to it and was the principal spokesman explaining it on national television," Dr. Hamburg said.
Faced with the prospect of replacing so many people, he said: "To lose a chairman and a finance committee chairman at one time is significant for any foundation. But needless to say we are proud. And we'll adapt."
In fact, the foundation coped with losses to Republican administrations, too, he said, citing the departures of John C. Whitehead, Deputy Secretary of State under Ronald Reagan, and James D. Watkins, Secretary of Energy in the Bush Administration. Thomas H. Kean left, too, when he was elected Governor of New Jersey.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
The Clinton Doctrine?

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
The classic reason for the use of American military force has been to protect our vital interests. In one pregnant sentence of his Inaugural Address, President Clinton added another.
"When our vital interests are challenged," he said, "or the will and conscience of the international community is defied, we will act, with peaceful diplomacy whenever possible, with force when necessary." (Emphasis added.) 
 If that important new doctrine is to have any meaning -- if it is to be respected as the Clinton Doctrine -- the place to apply it is at hand in Bosnia. And the time is now.
That Serbian aggression in Bosnia defies the conscience of the international community cannot be in doubt. Not unless at the end of the 20th century the world accepts mass murder, rape and terror directed at one ethnic group.
"It borders on genocide," Patricia Diaz Dennis, Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights, said of Serbian behavior as she released the annual State Department report on human rights around the world. The Serbs' "ethnic cleansing," the report said, was "on a scale that dwarfs anything seen in Europe since Nazi times."
What can and should President Clinton do to stop the horror? He may be tempted to postpone the hard decisions because Cyrus Vance and Lord Owen are seeming to make progress in their negotiations on Bosnia. But that would be a disastrous mistake, morally and politically.
The singular fact about the Vance-Owen effort is that while it has gone on, over many months, the Serbs have continued their killing. They are still besieging Sarajevo and other cities, lobbing shells at civilians. And they will go right on, as things look now.
The Bosnian Serbs' "assembly" voted this week to accept the Vance-Owen plan for a Bosnia with 10 autonomous provinces. But the Serbs, though that plan would reward their aggression, insisted that they would keep working for their ultimate aim: a Bosnian Serb republic.
Even if all the parties sincerely accepted the Vance-Owen principles -- a huge if -- the borders of the autonomous provinces still have to be negotiated. And while that difficult business goes on, the Vance-Owen approach allows the Serbs to continue their slaughter.
To earn any respect, this "peace process" would at a minimum require that the Serbs immediately stop their siege of Sarajevo and other Bosnian cities. Even under their own aggressive theories, what possible excuse do the Serbs have for shelling and starving a capital that has never been a Serbian city?
That is where President Clinton must act: to stop the killing while peace negotiations go on. He can do so with great effect by speaking directly and strongly to the warring parties in Bosnia. These are some of the things he should say:
* The siege of Sarajevo must end at once.
* Aid to civilians elsewhere must get through. Any further interruptions of relief convoys will not be tolerated.
* Military attacks on civilians must stop.
President Clinton would of course work with our European allies and with the United Nations. But if there was at last some forceful American leadership, it would quickly have its effect. For one thing, he could urge on the British and French, and the United Nations, a change in the rules for their peacekeeping forces on the scene allowing them to use their weapons if there are any further attempts to block relief convoys.
Moreover, the President would have many ways to signal the Serbs that he means business. He could act to tighten the economic embargo, for example. He could reduce the number of U.S. diplomats in Belgrade.
And he could prepare to act militarily. After 14 months of American dithering and evasion on the Serbian attacks, military action is more difficult. But at a minimum the United States could join in setting up and protecting safe havens for the Bosnian Muslim population now threatened with genocide.
The stakes are high: for Bill Clinton's credibility abroad as a decisive President, and more broadly for the world's safety. Continued appeasement of the worst calculated atrocities in Europe since the Nazis would exact a terrible price.

LENGTH: 694 words

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
What's in It for Us?

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The ruler of a great power had shown kindness and friendship to a new nation. So its leader wrote a letter of appreciation, and of his country's realities.
"Within our territories there are no mines either of gold or silver, and this young nation, just recovering from the waste and desolation of a long war, have not, as yet, had time to acquire riches by agriculture and commerce. 
 "But our soil is bountiful, and our people industrious, and we have reason to flatter ourselves that we shall gradually become useful to our friends."
At the inauguration of the 42d President, those words from a letter by George Washington to Sultan Mohammed III of Morocco in 1789 were in my pocket and mind.
They possess those qualities Americans would most like to distinguish their nation and Presidents, and occasionally even do: common sense, dignity, candor, a decent modesty joined to a comfortable sense of self-worth, and, in world affairs, loyalty and faith.
At inaugurals, each of us listens for a word that touches our own sense of national purpose. Most people at the Capitol saw President Clinton as a dot. But each had a clear, unobstructed view of himself.
The passage I hoped for came toward the end. The President spoke of America's greatest strength -- the power of "our ideas" -- and said: "Our hopes, our hearts, our hands are with those on every continent who are building democracy and freedom. Their cause is America's cause."
Hellbent for brevity, Mr. Clinton did not explain just why freedom's causes have to be ours. What's in it for us?
At least in part he has explained it in other talks. Democracies do not go around slaughtering each other, a fact that tends to increase American longevity. The more democracies that exist, the less American blood is likely to be spilled abroad.
Also, the American system prospers economically and politically in concert with other free nations, even if sometimes we threaten not to drink their white wine.
Dictatorships can be good customers for awhile, particularly for arms. But the stronger the tyranny becomes the quicker it presents a political price the U.S. cannot pay -- Imperial Japan, Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, or Saddamite Iraq. Why we expect Communist China, with its burgeoning military might, to be different is a puzzle, unless we again put cash register ahead of international security and individual freedom.
Political freedom may not be "our" idea and certainly was not during slavery. But Mr. Clinton was right: it is our greatest strength abroad.
I have lived in nations oppressed by Communist despotism and nations oppressed by poverty. Almost every day, the longing for the freedom America represented could be touched. Poles threw roses in the path of Richard Nixon because he was the Vice President of the United States. In India, college students filled lecture halls to hear almost every visiting American, roses of attention.
The hopes of and for America often had cost to those who held them. In every war, every crisis, the U.S. asked the help of other peoples. It was given in belief that political freedom was transferable and that the U.S. would be its conduit. Without that trust, for most of the world the U.S. would be just real estate.
American "pragmatists" warn that democratic idealism will make us the world policeman. Not if we have any judgment it won't. Sometimes American armed power is necessary -- with or without the U.N., which is supposed to expand freedom's boundaries, not confine them.
But mostly freedom fighters plead not for U.S. troops but for food, medicine, a political arm around them.
To Mr. Clinton and his chief of staff Thomas McLarty: Freedom's causes need supporters in the Administration. The transition has squeezed most of them out -- a dangerous invitation to cynicism.
To journalists: We are the last people who can justify becoming automatic cynics. The whole beauty of journalism is that every day we get another crack at the story, to get more information, assuage cruelties, adjust our heads, correct mistakes.
Maybe Bill Clinton can make that the whole beauty of being President, who knows?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

INDUSTRY: SIC2329 MEN'S & BOYS' CLOTHING, NEC (70%); 

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (98%); MOROCCO (79%); CHINA (79%); JAPAN (79%); IRAQ (79%); GERMANY (51%);

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
May Stores Moving Merchandise Staff to St. Louis

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
The May Department Stores Company announced yesterday that it would move its New York merchandising office to its headquarters in St. Louis.
The company said all 430 employees of the May Merchandising Company would be offered jobs in St. Louis. It said it would retain its office on the Avenue of the Americas in Manhattan to give its buyers and executives a place to hold meetings when they are in New York.
 
Closer to the Stores
 David C. Farrell, the company's chairman and chief executive, said the relocation would bring May's trend-spotters and style arbiters closer to their counterparts in each of May's department store chains, including Lord & Taylor, Filene's and Hecht's. The move will be completed June 14. 
 "We believe this relocation will make the company more coordinated and cohesive and give us more agility in being able to respond to what's happening in the market," Mr. Farrell said in a telephone interview.
In a separate announcement yesterday, Conran's Habitat, the chain of specialty housewares stores recently purchased by a group of investors headed by Marvin Traub, the former Bloomingdale's chairman, said it would move its headquarters from White Plains to Manhattan, bringing in 46 jobs.
Over the last few years, May has merged its various regional department store divisions and mercilessly shut or sold unprofitable stores. But Mr. Farrell stressed that May Merchandising was not being moved to pare costs. The company took a $30 million charge in the third quarter to cover relocation costs. "Future cost savings associated with the move are likely to be minimal," indicating it is a strategic decision, said Jeffrey M. Feiner, a retail analyst with Salomon Brothers.
May is the second department store company to move its merchandising operations out of New York. The Mercantile Stores Company moved its buying and merchandising office to Fairfield, Ohio, in April.
Barry F. Sullivan, New York's Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development, said that because May was relocating for business reasons and not to escape a heavy tax burden or high rents, the city had no incentives to offer the company to stay. He noted that May still had a presence in New York in Lord & Taylor and Payless Shoe Source, its budget shoe stores, and that it could open more stores.
May also announced that Anthony J. Torcasio, chief executive and president of Famous-Barr, the company's department store chain based in St. Louis, would become president and chief executive of May Merchandising, replacing Kenneth Folker, 69, who is retiring. May will announce Mr. Torcasio's replacement soon.
John L. Dunham, chairman of the G. Fox chain, will become chairman of the merchandising unit, succeeding Kenneth B. Winfield Jr., 59, who is retiring.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 26, 1993, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Friday about the relocation of the May Department Stores Company's merchandising unit misidentified the chief executive of May Merchandising, who has since retired. He was Kenneth Kolker.

HEADLINE: SETTLING IN: Presidential Appointees;
14 Major Clinton Nominees Are Confirmed by Senate

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
The Senate today approved 14 major appointments by President Clinton, including Ronald H. Brown as Commerce Secretary after he agreed to sever all ties to his former law firm and to remove himself from all decisions that might give the appearance of a conflict of interest.
Among the others confirmed today were Donna E. Shalala as Secretary of Health and Human Services, Robert B. Reich as Labor Secretary, Federico F. Pena as Transportation Secretary and Leon E. Panetta as director of the Office of Management and Budget. 
 The full Senate voted to approve Mr. Brown just hours after the Senate Commerce Committee unanimously voted to send his name to the floor. Mr. Brown's confirmation left only one other Cabinet nominee bogged down in controversy, that of Zoe Baird to be Attorney General. Several Senators urged Ms. Baird, who admitted knowingly breaking the law by employing two illegal aliens as domestic servants, to withdraw.
 
Critic Backs Brown
 Senator Trent Lott, the Mississippi Republican who had led criticism that Mr. Brown's initial policy on conflicts of interest was too narrow, said today that he was satisfied with Mr. Brown's pledge on Wednesday not to discuss with his former colleagues at Patton, Boggs & Blow any matter before the Commerce Department or likely to come before the department.
Senator Lauch Faircloth, a North Carolina Republican, cast the sole vote against Mr. Brown.
Mr. Brown, the former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, presented a more narrow conflict-of-interest policy when he appeared before the Commerce Committee on Jan. 6 in the first Congressional hearing for a nominee to the Clinton Cabinet. Nominees with later hearings, including Mickey Kantor as the United States Trade Representative, tended to adopt broader conflict-of-interest policies.
The Senate confirmed Mr. Kantor today, as well as Mike Espy as Agriculture Secretary, Richard W. Riley as Education Secretary and Jesse Brown as Secretary of Veterans Affairs. Also confirmed were Henry G. Cisneros as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and Hazel R. O'Leary as Energy Secretary.
Also confirmed today were Carol M. Browner as Director of the Environmental Protection Agency, Roger C. Altman as Deputy Treasury Secretary and Alice M. Rivln as Deputy Budget Director.
 
Tough Questions for Babbitt
 In his second day before the Senate Energy Committee, former Gov. Bruce Babbitt of Arizona faced tough questioning from Western senators about his views on Federal lands and his links to environmental groups.
Mr. Babbitt, who was later confirmed as Interior Secretary, said he would take a balanced approach to the use of Federal lands, saying he could "accommodate both resource development and resource conservation."
Mr. Babbitt said he backed the Endangered Species Act, which calls on the Government to preserve threatened species and plants. Business and labor have often criticized the act for preventing logging in parts of the Northwest to protect the spotted owl.
Mr. Babbitt said the act's concept was "sound," asserting that with "thoughtful administration" such "collisions can be avoided."
 
Focusing on Job Growth
 In a confirmation hearing today, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, Mr. Clinton's nominee to be chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said one of the Administration's priorities would be to fulfill the President's goal of creating eight million jobs over four years.
She signaled that the Administration was seriously considering a short-term stimulus package, including increased deficit spending in the first year, to speed up job growth, which has been anemic despite months of economic recovery.
"This is a modest recovery," she said. "It's not creating jobs as fast as previous recoveries."
She predicted that the nation's trade deficit might deteriorate as Europe's and Japan's economies flounder, causing them to import fewer American goods. She said the Government should work to insure that American companies have full access to European and Japanese markets, asserting that she favored open trade and was not, as some critics contend, a protectionist.
 
Specialist in Trade Issues
 Ms. Tyson, a professor at the University of California at Berkeley, told the Senate Banking Committee that the trade deficit was evidence that the nation's economic competitiveness had eroded. A specialist in trade issues, Ms. Tyson noted that American companies have lost market share abroad in computers, commercial aircraft and telecommunications.
She denied that she favored having the Government decide which industries have the best chance to be successful in the future and then aiding those industries. Instead she said the Government should encourage increased investment, research and job training for all industries.
Ms. Tyson said that to make more loans available to small business, the new Administration was studying whether to help arrange for financial institutions to package and sell such loans to outside investors, as is done with home mortgages. This would help reduce the risk for financial institutions that make such loans.
In another confirmation hearing, Madeleine K. Albright, the nominee for Ambassador to the United Nations, told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that the fighting in Bosnia was "clearly the highest priority of the President in the National Security Council's agenda." Ms. Albright, a professor at Georgetown University's School of Foreign Service, urged enforcement of the United Nations' ban on Serbian warplanes flying over Bosnia.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, who was confirmed on Wednesday along with Warren M. Christopher as Secretary of State and Les Aspin as Secretary of Defense, announced today that Lawrence H. Summers was being nominated as Under Secretary for International Affairs and Frank N. Newman as Under Secretary for Domestic Finance.
Mr. Summers is an economics professor at Harvard University and Mr. Newman is vice chairman of the board and chief financial officer of the BankAmerica Corporation, the California-based banking company.
Mr. Bentsen also announced that Eugene A. Ludwig, a lawyer at Covington & Burling in Washington, was his nominee for Comptroller of the Currency.
