HEADLINE: SETTLING IN: Easing Abortion Policy;
CLINTON ORDERS REVERSAL OF ABORTION RESTRICTIONS LEFT BY REAGAN AND BUSH

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Signaling a sea change in domestic policy, President Clinton moved today to reverse a decade of Republican edicts on abortion and other issues, including a repeal of the ban on abortion counseling at federally financed clinics.
Mr. Clinton signed five abortion-related memorandums on the 20th anniversary of Roe v. Wade, the Supreme Court decision that established a constitutional right to abortion. 
 As he signed the documents, a crowd that the Park Police estimated at 75,000 rallied against abortion in the nation's capital and pledged to fight on.
In addition to lifting the ban on counseling, Mr. Clinton lifted restrictions on Federal financing of research that uses fetal tissue, eased the policy on abortions in military hospitals, and reversed a Reagan Administration prohibition on aid to international family-planning programs that are involved in abortion-related activities.
 
'Safe and Legal but Rare'
 He also called for a review of the ban on the importation of the French abortion drug, RU-486, for personal use.
In a ceremony at the White House this afternoon, Mr. Clinton reiterated the carefully nuanced position on abortion he had maintained in the campaign, calling for "an America where abortion is safe and legal but rare."
Outside, angry abortion opponents protested his moves. John Cardinal O'Connor, the Archbishop of New York, was one of many religious and political leaders who addressed the annual March for Life in the nation's capital. He told the marchers: "Your presence here makes very clear that we will not be intimidated, we will not be ignored, and we will not be treated with contempt. We have only just begun."
 
180-Degree Turns
 On its third day, the Clinton Administration busily set about putting its mark on domestic policy. As Mr. Clinton erased years of Federal abortion policies with five signatures, other Administration officials were announcing 180-degree turns on two other issues that loomed large in the Bush years.
Just hours after he was sworn in as director of the Office of Management and Budget, Leon E. Panetta rescinded scores of proposed Federal regulations issued by the Bush Administration in its final weeks, effecting areas like the environment and banking. [Page 10.]
Vice President Al Gore said the Administration had abolished the Council on Competitiveness, a Cabinet-level group that had led the Bush Administration's assault on environmental regulations it considered too costly.
And Mr. Clinton's new Labor Secretary, Robert B. Reich, gave a full-throated endorsement to legislation that would require employers to give workers time off for childbirth or family illness, insuring quick approval of a bill twice vetoed by Mr. Bush.
Mr. Clinton's memorandums on abortion, which were roundly cheered by abortion-rights supporters, repealed one of the most hotly debated Bush Administration regulations, the ban on counseling about abortion in family-planning clinics that receive Federal money.
Mr. Clinton declared today: "This dangerous restriction censors the medical information and advice that health-care professionals can give their patients. As a result of today's action, every woman will be able to receive medical advice and referrals that will not be censored or distorted by ideological arguments that should not be a part of medicine."
 
Allows Fetal-Tissue Research
 In reversing the ban on fetal research, Mr. Clinton declared, "This moratorium has significantly hampered the development of possible treatments for individuals afflicted with serious diseases and disorders, such as Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease, diabetes and leukemia."
The result of another memorandum will be that military hospitals will be allowed to perform abortions, "provided the procedure is paid for entirely with private funds."
Mr. Clinton took one of his more far-reaching steps by reversing the policy established in 1984 by the Reagan Administration that cut off aid to international family-planning programs that were involved in abortion counseling or other abortion-related activities, including lobbying efforts to have abortion legalized. His action would open the way to restoring contributions to United Nations population programs.
While much of abortion policy is enshrined in legislation and thus not able to be changed quickly, Mr. Clinton asserted today that his actions "will go a long way toward protecting vital medical and health decisions from ideological and political debate."
Kate Michelman, President of the National Abortion Rights Action League, hailed him for "swiftly and decisively fulfilling his vow to revoke dangerous Bush-Reagan anti-choice policies."
Although Mr. Clinton's moves had been widely expected, leaders of the anti-abortion movement reacted with outrage. Roger Cardinal Mahony, Archbishop of Los Angeles and chairman of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops' Committee for Prolife Activities, declared today that Mr. Clinton was not fulfilling his vow to make abortion "safe, legal and rare."
"Surely you cannot reduce abortion by promoting abortion as just another method of birth control," the Cardinal said. "You cannot reduce abortion by fueling a market for the tiny dead bodies of unborn children. You cannot reduce abortion by exporting abortion to the poor in the Third World."
Senator Jesse Helms, addressing the March for Life today, put his message to Mr. Clinton more simply: "I say to him, shame! shame!" Mr. Helms declared to a crowd that sprawled across a muddy Ellipse still marked from Mr. Clinton's inaugural celebrations.
The protesters, who in other years had received telephoned messages of support from Presidents Reagan and Bush, vowed that the change in Administrations would not cause them to flag. March organizers estimated the size of the crowd at 250,000, although United States Park Police put it at less than a third of that.
While some of the signs in the crowd were bitterly partisan, most were not. People wore stickers that read, "In Your Heart You Know It's Wrong," and "The Natural Choice is Life," and they carried banners from scores of small towns, schools, churches and parishes. Some of the speakers, noting Mr. Clinton's education by the Jesuits at Georgetown, said they would pray that he would see the error of his ways.
Again and again, the speakers declared that this was a spiritual battle, and that they were in it for the long haul.
 
 
 
CHANGING RULES ON ABORTION
COUNSELING
Rebublican Policy: Counseling women on the option of having an abortion was prohibited in 4,000 family planning clinics that receive Federal financing.This "gag rule" was imposed by Ronald Reagan in February 1988.
Clinton Action: No immediate effect because courts have blocked the ban.
 
INTERNATIONAL PROGRAMS
Rebublican Policy: Cut off all money to family planning programs of the United Nations or other international groups that provide abortions or abortion counseling as any part of their work. United States policy declares that rising population is not an important factor in economic development (this position, established in 1984 by Mr. Reagan, reversed decades of policy).
Clinton Action: Opens the way to restore Unites States financing to United States population programs if Congress appropriates the money.
 
MILITARY HOSPITALS
Rebublican Policy: Banned abortions in military hospitals overseas. Extended a 1980 ban on Federal financing for military abortions.
Clinton Action: Will permit abortions if women pay the operations themselves. Would not permit Federal payment for military abortions, which would require Congressional action.
 
FETAL TISSUE
Rebublican Policy: A ban imposed by Mr. Reagan in 1988 blocked transplant research using organs from aborted fetuses. Research into an area considered promising by scientists -- transplantion of unformed fetal cells into adult brains to replace neural cell damaged by disease -- was stopped.
Clinton Action: Allows research to go forward.
 
RU 486
Rebublican Policy: Banned import of the French abortion pill into the country by individuals for personal use.
Clinton Action: Directs Federal regulators reassess whether RU 486 is safe and effective and should be available in this country.

HEADLINE: Paying for Health, The German Way -- A special report.;
Medical Care in Germany: With Choices, and for All

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Jan. 22

 BODY:
If the most critical problem in providing national health care is getting control over rapidly rising costs, as President Clinton has often said, he may find some intriguing ideas in the German health care system, which offers coverage to all at a much lower price than Americans pay.
Germany's much-admired system of health care, provided through nonprofit but private "sickness funds" that are legally mandatory for nearly 90 percent of the population, leaves patients with freedom to choose their own doctors and their own hospitals, and freedom from almost all medical bills. 
 Germans spend only about half as much per person on health care as Americans do, $1,486 in 1990 for Germany, compared with $2,566 for the United States. As a percentage of gross national product, however, it was 14 percent for the United States in 1992 and a little more than 8 percent for Germany. In 1990, the G.N.P. comparisons were 12.1 percent for the United States and 8.1 percent for Germany.
American health experts and politicians have flocked here in recent years to try to learn how they could apply at home what they see here. But they have found little that could simply be copied from a country with different cultural traditions.
Visiting a German doctor's office or hospital is much like visiting a good one in the United States. Many German hospitals are regarded as among the best in the world, and few have the crowded emergency rooms and waiting areas that are common in urban American hospitals because people have no other source of medical care. Neither do they have to increase bills for insured patients to cover those who cannot pay, because in Germany insurance covers virtually everybody, including foreign workers and asylum-seekers.
For years, the German Government has tried to keep medical expenditures from growing faster than the economy as a whole, not so much by limiting benefits as by pressing drug makers, doctors and hospitals to contain fees, an approach that has worked fairly well.
The biggest savings have come from Government-mandated programs that brought down the prices of German pharmaceutical products, once the highest in Europe, by ordering insurance funds to pay only what generic drugs cost.
Doctors administer their own payments from the health insurance system, and since 1985 they have agreed to annual caps on total payments, which they share depending on the number of treatments performed.
In another effort to curb costs, and to counter what is generally seen as a surplus of physicians, doctors have been told that from now on they would have to retire, as far as the sickness funds were concerned, at age 68. New practices can only be set up in localities where the Government agrees there is a need for them.
The restrictions have stirred some unhappiness among doctors. German general practitioners earn an average of $95,565 before taxes, which puts them among the country's highest earners, but their incomes have not risen as fast as average wages over the last two decades.
"Many people go into the medical profession with expectations that are too high," said Dr. Karsten Vilmar, head of the national physicians' association in Cologne. "But these kinds of limitations seem to us to violate the constitutional guarantees on professional freedom."
Another factor in keeping costs down is that malpractice suits are less common in Germany than in the United States, and so are extraordinary life-prolonging measures for patients judged to be terminally ill. "If an elderly patient is clearly dying of natural causes, I treat her at home," said Dr. Ursula Friedrichs, who like most of her colleagues still makes house calls. "I know a hospital stay wouldn't do any good."
According to a recent study by John K. Iglehart in The New England Journal of Medicine, "On the average, German hospitals have fewer pieces of high-technology equipment than most big urban hospitals in the United States." But Germany concentrates its most expensive medical technology in teaching hospitals like the University Hospital in Bonn, where the basic daily room rate can be as high as $400 -- but remains far below American rates.
 
A Mounting Demand
 Still, with a mounting demand for medical services, costs have been soaring here too, putting the insurance funds billions of dollars in the red last year. To try to bring costs under control the Government, with a determination worthy of Otto von Bismarck, the Chancellor who expanded the sickness fund system in Prussia 110 years ago to keep the Socialists at bay, has recently run roughshod over the lobbies of doctors, dentists, hospital administrators and drug manufacturers, all of which are seemingly far less powerful here than they are in Washington. A law that went into effect Jan. 1 imposed more across-the-board reductions in the price of most medicines, tightened the caps on doctors' fees, and changed the way hospitals are paid in ways devised to encourage efficiency and lower costs.
 
How Things Work
Some Choices, Some Limits
 Germany's system bears little resemblance to the state-run system of cradle-to-grave national health care the British adopted after World War II. It is also very different from the American health-insurance system, which leaves some 35 million people uncovered.
The main difference between the German system and the American one is that most Germans have no choice about whether to join a health insurance plan, and no problem finding coverage, either. Unless they are either very poor or pretty well off, the law requires them to become members of one of 1,147 "sickness funds" in the country. Some of the funds are connected to private employers, while others are quasi-public institutions.
The funds are supposed to break even, and each one sets a monthly premium rate as a percentage of a wage-earner's monthly salary. The rates among the funds now vary between 8 percent and 16.8 percent of salary, and have reached a historically high national average of 13.1 percent. The premiums are shared equally by employer and employee and paid by payroll deduction. The rate is the same for single and married wage-earners, with or without dependents, in any given sickness fund.
"Everybody knows exactly how much health insurance costs, and when the figure climbed above 13 percent, everybody in the system knew they had to get costs under control or the public would be after them," said Uwe E. Reinhardt of Princeton University, an economist who is an expert on the German system.
Nearly all employers are required to participate, including small businesses and low-wage industries, which in the United States often say they cannot afford to offer health benefits.
The funds cover not only workers and employees but retirees and people on welfare. Government agencies pay the premiums for the elderly and the indigent, as well as for the three million Germans now out of work. Changing jobs, or losing them, does not mean losing insurance coverage, even for a minute.
 
Never See a Bill
 Germans who have the basic, mandatory insurance never see their doctor or hospital bills. Starting this year, most of them have to pay more for medicine, but only up to a maximum of 7 marks -- less than $4.50 -- every time a prescription is filled.
Hospital patients must pay only $6.80 a day in western Germany, and $6.25 in the formerly Communist eastern part, and only for the first 14 days -- after that, even this charge is dropped.
"All I had to do was fill out a health care coupon from my sickness fund and present it to the doctor," said Mrs. Marianne Wettlauffer, 68, who had a slight heart attack several years ago and also spent six weeks in a rehabilitation cure in the Black Forest. All but a nominal amount was paid for by her sickness fund.
Her husband, Hellmut, 68, also had a heart attack 10 years ago, while he was a Government employee. His current care, too, costs him nothing out of pocket, though he supplements his Government pension plan with an inexpensive private policy that provides additional benefits like private hospital rooms.
Their physician, Dr. Friedrichs, has a small second-floor practice in a modern building in Bad Godesberg. From the small waiting room to the two consulting rooms, every room is white and antiseptically modern. Dr. Friedrichs takes privately insured patients as well as those in the sickness funds.
The private patients bring in bigger fees, but the funds provide the bread and butter, with a minimum of administrative headache, she said. "I get the payment automatically when I turn in the coupon, with the services performed marked on it," she said.
Germans who earn more than $40,000 a year ($29,450 this year in the formerly Communist eastern part of Germany, where wages and salaries are still lower) are not required to buy health insurance, but almost all of them -- about 6.3 million people -- purchase it anyway.
Because 88 percent of the population is covered by the sickness funds, risk is more evenly distributed among them than in the United States, and private insurance is also relatively cheap by American standards.
 
Containing Costs
Price Rollbacks And Limits on Fees
 How to reduce waste and inefficiency has been a preoccupation of German Governments since the mid-1970's. Three years ago, changes were put into effect that were supposed to put the health system on a secure financial basis for the next century. Sickness funds were ordered to pay for generic drugs only wherever possible, dental benefits were curtailed and hospitals were directed to increase efficiency.
But costs kept rising anyway, much faster than the rate of inflation or the funds' income from premiums. Either the rates had to be raised or costs had to be cut. And for German politicians, raising health premiums was about as desirable as raising taxes.
Since the system is set up to be self-financing, the German Government did not bail out the funds with taxpayers' money. Instead, it enacted a draconian new law that went into effect on Jan. 1, with the backing of all the major political parties.
Among other new controls on the pharmaceutical industry, the law mandates an across-the-board reduction of 5 percent in the price of most nongeneric medicines sold in the western part of the country this year, and a price freeze through 1994. In the poorer east, the law requires all medicine to be sold at a 20 percent discount.
The law also reduces orthodontists' fees by 10 percent, mandates that hospital fees rise during the next two years no faster than incomes, and bars clinics or private practices from buying expensive new "major equipment" without Government approval.
 
Charges for Weekends
 The law eliminates the traditional practice of reimbursing hospitals' costs and letting them bill the funds at a daily rate -- a practice that, many doctors concede, often led to admissions on Fridays, so hospitals could collect fees over the weekends even though no treatment was given, and discharge 10 days later on Mondays for operations that need only have taken a few days.
By 1996, German hospitals and physicians are to work out new fees based on the procedure, not the length of stay.
To hold down doctors' fees, the new law provides that reimbursements from the sickness funds rise only as fast as income from premiums. The funds pay doctors by the number of services they perform at a rate negotiated with the sickness funds, so by limiting the total "pot," the payments can be limited too.
 
What the Future Holds
Changing Needs In Aging Population
 In all, the Government says that the new law will save $6.5 billion this year and that premiums will not have to rise faster than inflation.
Government and health officials all insist that they do not want to be forced to delay care, the way the British National Health Service does for "elective" operations like hip replacements and heart transplants, with waiting lists that can delay them for years. Nor can they understand why Americans accept a system with what they see as Darwinian traits.
"We are not entitled, particularly with our German past, to decide who is entitled to survival and who is not," said Dr. Vilmar, who heads the national physicians' association. "All we have to ask ourselves is whether we really need a system that provides 100 percent coverage to everybody. There should be a system of perceptible cost-sharing."
He is among the critics of the new law who question if providers of medical care will ever have a strong reason to keep costs under control as long as most consumers never have to even think about how much their care costs.
Regardless of the new law, serious challenges will remain. As in the United States, for example, there is debate about how to cover the costs of long-term care like nursing homes for the growing population of disabled elderly.
Nursing care for the elderly at home is partly covered under the German system, but only up to four weeks and only if it is connected with an illness or accident.
Nursing homes cost about as much here as they do in the United States, and those who cannot pay usually have to sign over their assets or rely on help from welfare. Children with incomes can also be required to pay for nursing home care for their invalid parents.
The Labor Minister, Norbert Blum, has proposed a new state-run old age insurance plan to cover nursing home care, to be paid for by payroll deductions and by eliminating one national paid holiday. But opposition from churches as well as labor unions makes it doubtful whether the plan will become law by 1996, as Mr. Blum wanted.
Only one thing seems sure: with a rapidly aging population -- the proportion of those over 60 will grow by 19 percent by the end of the century, while the segment between 20 and 40 is shrinking by more than 12 percent -- the pressure from medical costs will continue to mount.

HEADLINE: SETTLING IN: An Angry Public;
Fueled by Radio and TV, Outcry Became Uproar

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 22

 BODY:
By Sunday, most of official Washington and the news media had already dismissed the problems with Zoe Baird's nomination as Attorney General. But anyone listening that morning to Susan Estrich's talk show here on KABC radio knew the nomination was in deep trouble over Ms. Baird's hiring of illegal aliens as household help.
"The phones went crazy," said Ms. Estrich, who was the Presidential campaign manager for Michael S. Dukakis in 1988 and now teaches law at the University of Southern California. "That's the only thing people wanted to talk about. I found a fire already raging, just looking for a house to burn down." 
 Over the next few days, as Washington insiders scratched their heads in bafflement, public fury over Ms. Baird reached a boil -- on radio-talk shows from Boston to San Diego, in bars in New Orleans, in the remote reaches of West Texas. "The more exposure she got, people would say, 'Look at this,' " said Roy Markey, owner of Markey's Bar in the working-class Lower Ninth Ward of New Orleans.
 
Isolation of Washington
 By early today, the uproar forced President Clinton to withdraw the nomination -- demonstrating both that there is often an enormous gulf in political sensibilities between Washington and the general populace and that a new means of communications are giving new political power to the public. The anger rose on a crest carried by a new generation of talk shows, cable television and other programs that Mr. Clinton used to win election but that has now come back to haunt him. These media have made for the direct exchange of ideas and emotions, short-cutting traditional news outlets.
It was also, to be sure, an issue that resonated powerfully in families searching for solutions to the problem of raising children and earning a living. And it hit particularly hard here in economically battered California, where illegal aliens are increasingly perceived as a drag on state and local government services and as taking jobs away from legal residents.
For 57-year-old Shirley E. Roth of Fountain Valley in Orange County the blood began to heat a week ago Thursday when she first read in The Orange County Register that Ms. Baird had hired a Peruvian couple who were in this country illegally. Anger turned to outrage in the next two days when that newspaper and The Los Angeles Times endorsed Ms. Baird's nomination.
 
Taking Jobs Away
 Ms. Roth, who moved here from Rochester with her husband, an engineer, and four children 17 years ago, wrote letters to the editor of The Register, to her Congressman and the Senators from California, Dianne Feinstein and Barbara Boxer, both Democrats.
"Our concern was that she was taking meaningful employment away from American citizens," Ms. Roth said today. "Citizens can't compete with illegals for a living wage, and that makes for a volatile environment, especially here in California."
The telephone lines at the local offices of Senators Feinstein and Boxer were overwhelmed on Thursday by callers who complained that Ms. Baird broke the law and that illegal aliens were taking away jobs.
The Senate hearings shown on cable television fueled the complaints. John De Roo Jr., a 72-year-old retired school administrator who lives in the upper-middle-class Granada Hills area of the San Fernando Valley, watched senators questoin Ms. Baird on Thursday. He said he was struck that Ms. Baird did not seem to grasp what was wrong with hiring illegal aliens.
"We're facing tremendous problems in Southern California," he said. "Dianne Feinstein pointed that out in her questioning yesterday that she didn't seem even aware that this was such a tremendous problem."
Like many who watched the hearing, Muriel North of Hackettstown, N.J., felt that the Senators on the Judiciary Committee were not sufficiently tough on Ms. Baird, a corporate lawyer who had failed to pay the Social Security taxes of the Peruvian couple, then dismissed them after the Clinton victory.
"I got so upset over the hearings and I thought they were missing the point," said Mrs. North, 90, who called her Representative, Marge Roukema, a Republican. "I was watching the whole day getting madder and madder. No one was saying the big thing, which was that she was very unethical. She is probably brilliant and capable, but to live in a democracy you've got to be honest and ethical."
In Garden City, Kan., Roberta Renick, a retired drug-store owner, called the office of Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, a Republican. She complained that the Senators were too "generous" to the nominee. Mrs. Renick said she had never hired anyone without paying for Social Security. "I think everyone should do it if that's the law and she knew what was right and what was wrong," she said.
At KPRC-AM in Houston, Jon Matthews's talk show has been swamped with calls about Ms. Baird. "There was not great sympathy for her," he said. "People were perplexed. Here's someone with half a million in income who has no problems. It's hard to identify with somebody who has that type of income and assets breaking the law. People read a lot of arrogance into that."
Hundreds of miles west, in the ranch country of West Texas, where Mexican immigrants have long been employed and exploited, there was consternation, too. Bill Young, a retired Air Force master sergeant in San Angelo, complained to his Congressman, Lamar Smith, a Republican. "I'm tired of people being so darn greedy and grabbing," he said in an interview today. "We're the ones at home sacrificing to keep them up there."
The mood was no different half a continent away in politically liberal Boston, where callers would talk of nothing else on Marjorie Clapprood's morning talk show on WHDH. "This is a big reaction," said Ms. Clapprood, who likened the furor to that over the testimony of Prof. Anita F. Hill at the Clarence Thomas hearings. "It really touched a chord. I think two-thirds of my calls were from women who've been through the rigorous process of finding day care -- and they were having none of it."
At the Harvard Medical School, Patricia Thomas, editor of The Harvard Health Letter, said that sentiment turned against Ms. Baird as her all-female staff listened to the hearings. "This is an office where everyone wore buttons that said, 'Vote for Hillary's Husband,' " she said. "First people were saying, 'What woman doesn't have problems with child care?' But then as time went on, people thought, 'If this woman is such a good lawyer and her husband is a constitutional law expert why did they knowingly do something against the law?' '

HEADLINE: Russia and Partners Meet, But Unity Still Eludes Them

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Leaders of the Commonwealth of Independent States met today in the Belarus capital, Minsk, for a summit meeting that once again failed to give real shape or purpose to the association that emerged 13 months ago as the successor to the Soviet Union.
The meeting, which was delayed three times, ended without resolving a quarrel between the commonwealth's two largest members, Russia and Ukraine, over the control of strategic nuclear weapons. 
 But it also left unanswered more fundamental questions about whether the commonwealth has any function other than to gather together its 10 disparate members, from Europe's edge to the steppes of Central Asia, for periodic high-level meetings.
At the end of the daylong meeting, the leaders agreed to sign a memorandum that lays out the principles of the commonwealth while allowing individual members more time to consider a more substantive charter defining the range of the commonwealth's authority. Seven of the 10 members are apparently ready to sign the charter, but Ukraine, Turkmenistan and Moldova, fearing the surrender of their new sovereignty, held back.
"I think by joint mental effort we found a decision that suits everybody and does not create problems within the national interest of individual states," President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia said at a news conference after the meeting.
 
Ownership at Issue
 On the eve of the meeting, Russia proposed to take control over the former Soviet Union's strategic nuclear forces, including weapons in Ukraine, Belarus and Kazakhstan scheduled to be transferred to Russia for dismantling under recent arms control agreements with the United States.
Although its Parliament has yet to ratify the first Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, known as Start I, Ukraine has not backed away from its commitment to become a nonnuclear country. But it insists that the 176 intercontinental missiles on its territory are legally Ukrainian property.
The meeting did produce a few agreements, including the creation of an interstate bank that will serve to resolve conflicts over money transfers and currency issues. According to an initial draft approved by the commonwealth's Prime Ministers, the ruble will serve as the bank's single currency and Russia's Central Bank will keep control over the issuing of credits.
But the members were divided over a proposed charter that would more closely coordinate defense and economic policies among the commonwealth's members. They now include the Central Asian states of Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, Kyryzstan and Uzbekistan, as well as Kazakhstan, Armenia, Moldova, Russia and Ukraine, with Azerbaijan taking part as an observer.
Ukraine, together with Turkmenistan and Moldova, has had reservations about signing the charter. Several days ago, the Ukrainian President, Leonid M. Kravchuk, told reporters in Kiev that he "will not allow the Commonwealth of Independent States to be turned into a supranational body subject to international law."
Unable to resolve their disagreement over the nature of their relationship, the commonwealth leaders today prepared two documents -- one, a charter, that would promote greater integration, and another, called a memorandum, that calls for a looser cooperation. To preserve the appearance of unity, the leaders decided to sign the memorandum jointly, leaving open the option of a more definitive charter, which requires ratification by local parliaments.
The uncertain status of the commonwealth's armed forces is one reason why Russia this week proposed to claim jurisdiction over nuclear weapons outside its territory. Under the original agreement reached between Russia and the three other "nuclear" states, strategic nuclear forces were to remain under the command of the Commonwealth Armed Forces.
But as Marshal Yevgeny I. Shaposhnikov, commander of the armed forces, noted recently, this did not resolve the issue of which state has legal jurisdiction over them. This right, he said, should belong to Russia, the only one of the former Soviet republics that will remain a nuclear power and the one that has pledged to undertake the dismantlement of nuclear weapons.
According to reports from Minsk, Belarus and Kazakhstan are ready to consider Russia's position. But Ukraine insists that it is the legal heir to the nuclear weapons on its territory.

HEADLINE: London Journal;
Labor's Problem: Must Beliefs Be Whitewashed?

BYLINE: By JOHN DARNTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Among the thousands who gathered on Wednesday under red, white and blue flags in the Dorchester Hotel ballroom to raise a long-distance toast to Bill Clinton's inauguration were more than a smattering of Labor Party leaders, members and sympathizers. They could be forgiven for what they were thinking: we could have been winners, too.
Nowhere are the changeover to a new Administration in Washington and the lessons of the Democratic victory in November being studied more closely than in Britain, where Labor has been wandering in the desert during 13 years of Conservative rule. 
 The questions bouncing around the ballroom -- before the hard realities of governing set in -- were simple: what was the secret of Mr. Clinton's magic in getting elected, and could it be made to work on this side of the Atlantic?
"The first lesson we learned is to keep your eye on the ball, which is the economy," said Tony Banks, a dapper East Ender who represents a London district in Parliament. "That's the same over here."
 
Praises Clinton's Stand
 As he spoke he stared up awe-struck at a fuzzy screen where a 20-foot-tall President Clinton waved his arms in triumph.
Mr. Banks continued: "Then there's the populist way it was done, very good. The way Clinton appealed to the broadest spread -- you don't win elections by narrowing your appeal. Course, I don't think one should go overboard."
Mr. Banks was hedging his observations advisedly, for the Labor Party, so hungry for power that at times it seems weak with starvation, is undergoing a rift over how far it should proceed with what is called "Clintonization."
On the one side are the "modernizers," who believe that the party should soften its class-conflict militancy and position itself more in the mainstream of British life in the way that Mr. Clinton, as Governor of Arkansas, helped create a more conservative and popular wing of the Democratic Party.
These Young Turks, who mostly joined Parliament in the elections of 1983 and 1987, want to build on and expand the changes instituted by the former Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock. Mr. Kinnock rescued the party from near oblivion after it took a far-left detour in the 1980's but resigned as leader after the humiliating loss to John Major's Tories in April, the party's fourth straight defeat.
On the other side are the traditionalists, who fear that the party is in danger of watering down its beliefs, moving away from its working-class and trade union origins, and in short losing its soul in a Faustian bargain to gain a majority of seats in four years.
Presiding over it all and standing above the fray is the new leader, John Smith, a broad-browed, square-jawed Scottish lawyer who has been very sphinxlike. Most assume he will carry on in the Kinnock tradition, trying to nudge along reforms in both party and electoral procedures while trying hard not to offend believers in the old-time religion of collective egalitarianism.
But so far he has not made any dramatic moves or articulated a hard-driving philosophy. In fact he plays his cards so close to the chest that no one can say for certain which path he might take. As a headline in the Conservative Daily Telegraph put it: "Smith: Lost for Words or Just Quietly Confident?"
 
Devastating Series of Events
 While the fortunes of the Major Government have fallen low, those of the opposition have not risen correspondingly high. Over recent months, the Government has been hit by a devastating succession of events: an abrupt decision to pull the pound out of the European Exchange Rate Mechanism, thus effectively devaluing it; the announced closing of 31 coal mines that would put 30,000 miners out of work that was hastily reversed for cooler consideration, and even some long-running personal scandals among Cabinet ministers that forced one to step down.
Above all, after three years of recession, there has been a continuing stream of bad economic news. While some Government officials squinted hard and said they saw ahead the first signs of a slight upturn, figures released on Thursday showed that unemployment had jumped up to reach nearly three million, the highest level in six years.
 
Creating an Acceptable Vision
 But for whatever reason Labor has not been able to exploit these woes. In debates in the House of Commons, Mr. Smith can throw punches at Prime Minister Major but, so far at least, he has not managed to deck him. Some weeks back, private polls were showing Labor running ahead by some 20 points but more recently the gap is said to have narrowed.
The lack of headway feeds the arguments of those who look across the Atlantic for inspiration, like Anthony Blair, Labor's shadow Home Secretary and a man sometimes touted as Mr. Smith's heir apparent. "Clinton presented the Democrats in a different way to the American people, and that certainly has application for us here," he said.
Along with figures like Gordon Brown, the shadow Chancellor of the Exchequer, he gives the vision an acceptable slant by promoting it as a "new radicalism." Among other things, it represents a loosening of ties with the trade unions that control party congresses through a system of bloc voting, revisions in the scheme of universal benefits, a shift away from a "tax and spend" reputation and a slightly more pro-European tilt.
But at heart it is an attempt to capture the non-unionized workers in the private sector -- the middle-class consumers as well as the assembly-line producers -- in much the same way that Mr. Clinton recovered the Democrats' traditional blue-collar constituency.
The approach was detailed in a conference here two weeks ago at which some Clinton poll takers and advisers told an audience of Labor and trade unionists how the victory was achieved.
 
A Warning for the Future
 The "traditionalists," on the other hand, believe in shoring up the party's base in the working class and retaining the pervasive role of the unions, the party's founders. They shrink from the idea of debating the sanctity of "Clause 4" in the party's constitution, which holds out the shimmering and ever-distant promise of full nationalization.
In learning about Mr. Clinton, most traditionalists were scandalized to discover that he favored capital punishment.
"Let's go back to being proud of our roots" is the battle cry of John Prescott, shadow Transportation Minister, who is a leader of this faction. Like others in the group, he harbors a distrust for image makers and sophisticated campaign techniques. In a recent interview with the BBC, he warned the "Clintonizers" of the risks of having the party fall under the domination of poll takers, advisers and public relations executives.
Both sides share one reaction to the new Clinton Presidency. An editorial in The Independent summed it up: "On this side of the Atlantic we may be forgiven a powerful twinge of envy for the cleansing of the Augean stables that is taking place across the water."

HEADLINE: New Appeals to Pocketbook Patriots

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ABINGTON, Pa.

 BODY:
By the standards of respectable economic thinking, people like William Lynott are dismissed as well-meaning but misguided eccentrics whose ideas come from the Rush Limbaugh-Patrick Buchanan school of economics.
Mr. Lynott is the president of the year-old Buy America Foundation here, one of a handful of organizations that have sprung up in recent years to urge consumers to wield their wallets like patriots and buy American-made goods. 
 And they are finding a growing audience for their message. Marketing surveys show that more Americans have qualms about buying imported products and are increasingly looking for the "Made in U.S.A." label. The shift in sentiment is apparently linked to concerns about American jobs and a belief that the economy has deep-seated problems, a chord struck so effectively by Bill Clinton during the Presidential election campaign.
But most economists and academics say the Buy America movement's appeals to pocketbook jingoism are simple-minded and wrong in today's global economy, which muddles the geographic lineage of products because companies shop around the world for low-cost components.
"Absurd on the face of it" is the verdict of Louis W. Stern, a professor at the J. L. Kellogg Graduate School of Management at Northwestern University.
The Buy America advocates, if heeded, could actually hurt the American economy, argues Robert Z. Lawrence, a professor of international trade at Harvard University. Nationalistic consumers, he says, violate a basic tenet of economics -- namely, that everyone is better off if each nation produces what it is best at making and free trade allows consumers to buy from the most efficient producer. This "theory of comparative advantage," first advanced in the early 19th century by an English economist, David Ricardo, is regarded today as "a fundamental insight into the way the world ought to work," Mr. Lawrence said.
Yet in its annual survey of consumer attitudes, completed in November of each year, Yankelovich Partners Inc. found in 1992 that 61 percent of Americans said they "feel guilty when purchasing non-American products," up from 49 percent in 1989.
Demand Factors Inc., a research firm in St. Louis that conducts market surveys for domestic clothing and textile makers, found in December that 38 percent of women under 35 years old checked labels for the country of origin when shopping for clothes, up from 23 percent in 1985. Of those who look for the Made in U.S.A. label, about 90 percent buy American-made goods.
Frank Schapiro of Demand Factors says the interest of the under-35 crowd is significant, because in the mid-80's, when he began the research, it was mainly consumers aged 50 and older with blue-collar backgrounds who noticed where goods were made.
"In the past few years, there has been a massive increase in the interest of young people and higher-income people in the country of origin of the products they buy," he said.
Yet it is unclear whether consumer misgivings about buying imports can be translated into changed buying habits. The Buy America campaigners speak of forging a new "consumer ethos" and point to the environmental movement, with its promotion of recyclable and natural products.
 
 
Wrapped in the Flag
 To be sure, more American marketers are sounding patriotic themes these days, like the "Heartbeat of America" slogan of the Chevrolet division of General Motors. And no company has wrapped itself in the flag as blatantly as the nation's leading retailer, Wal-Mart Stores Inc. The company asserts that its "Buy America" program, begun in 1985, now supports more than 100,000 United States jobs through orders Wal-Mart has shifted from foreign suppliers.
Wal-Mart's stores today are adorned with stars-and-stripes motifs and "Made in the U.S.A." signs. Still, a drawback of being so closely identified with the Buy America theme was seen last month when the weekly news program "Dateline NBC" asserted that Wal-Mart had placed "Made in the U.S.A." signs over imported goods. The company conceded that goods had been improperly marked, but said that the mistakes had been made in only a couple of its 2,000 stores.
Market researchers say that appeals to patriotism can influence buying habits, but only if the price and quality of domestic goods equal that of the imports. "All things being equal, people will choose American products today," said James A. Taylor, the managing partner of Yankelovich Partners. "But things aren't equal often enough."
A new book, "The Patriotic Consumer: How to Buy American," illustrates both the interest in buying American-made products and the challenge of doing so. Since the $6.95 paperback was published in November by Andrews & McMeel of Kansas City, it has sold briskly, nearly 50,000 copies so far. The book provides a guide to every room in the house from the bedroom to the garage, with charts that detail the origins of several hundred products.
Brand names, it seems, offer little help to the patriotic consumer. Take a product as simple as deodorant. Old Spice Stick, for example, is classified as 100 percent American made and owned, while Old Spice Anti-Perspirant uses less than 50 percent American ingredients or labor.
"The whole idea of how you buy American in a global economy can be incredibly difficult," said Anne Grant, co-author with Web Burrell of "The Patriotic Consumer."
There are heavyweight groups trying to jump-start the Buy America movement. The Crafted With Pride in U.S.A. Council, founded in 1984, is backed by big textile and apparel producers; its television advertising budget was about $15 million last year. The Made in the USA Foundation, begun in 1989, supports a lobbying affiliate as well as the foundation, with more than 50,000 individual, corporate and union members, and a yearly budget of roughly $10 million.
 Mr. Lynott's Buy America Foundation is a leaner operation. "Say hello to my staff," he said, gesturing toward the fish in an aquarium in the paneled office behind his garage here. He answers the phone, replies to letters and empties the trash himself. He is the reporter, writer and editor of the Buy America newsletter, which he sends free to anyone who asks for it. He receives no salary from the nonprofit foundation.
Less than two years ago, Mr. Lynott was ready to settle into a comfortable early retirement. A former executive at Sears, Roebuck & Company, he had a consulting practice and rarely gave much thought to where the goods he bought were made.
But after watching a public-television documentary on how the Japanese conquered America's consumer electronics market, Mr. Lynott began reading up on international business issues. A fascination, fed by selective study, developed into some fervently held beliefs.
In his view, America's chronic trade deficit is a disturbing symptom of the erosion of the nation's manufacturing sector, which cannot be replaced by service businesses.
A dapper 64-year-old, dressed in a tweed jacket, his necktie never loosened, Mr. Lynott is no zealot. His newsletter is packed with straightforward accounts of American products that are mentioned favorably in magazines like Consumer Reports and Motor Trend, and summaries of newspaper reports on trade issues.
"We don't lecture people on trade issues," he explained. "It's not an extremist approach. You turn off thinking people with extremism."
Mr. Lynott started the foundation last year with $4,000 of his own money. Since then, enough donations have come in to pay for his modest operation, with the average donation at $18 and about 30 percent of his readers contributing. The newsletter has grown to 10,000 copies and he hopes to double its circulation this year, and perhaps increase its frequency (it is now published quarterly) and hire a full-time staff member.
"I know that distinguished economists very often dismiss the Buy America movement as simplistic," Mr. Lynott said. "But I believe that it does matter where goods are made and who owns the company."
He added, "And if you walk into a store and U.S.-made goods are of equal or better quality than the imports, you owe it to yourself and your kids to buy it."

HEADLINE: Trenton Tries to End $2.2 Billion Budget Gap

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Faced with a projected $2.2 billion budget gap in an election year, New Jersey officials have begun negotiations on a range of revenue sources that they hope will allow them to close the gap with "minimal pain" to voters.
But the proposals are based on projections that the economy will grow significantly and that New Jersey residents will have a large appetite for a new lottery game. And one proposal is largely dependent on the Florio administration's ability to get the Federal Government to reimburse it for Medicaid bills it has refused to pay. 
 Among other things, budget officials are pinning their hopes on an 8 percent increase in revenues, an increase in Department of Motor Vehicles fees, a new Keno lottery game, a commuter tax mainly on New York residents and an early retirement plan for state employees. Those proposals would help raise about $1.9 billion.
Legislators and Florio administration officials say the money is needed to help offset a $900 million increase in spending and a $1 billion structural deficit left from last year, when officials used an $800 million pension revaluation and other one-time sources of revenue to close a similar gap in the 1992-93 fiscal budget. An additional $250 million is being sought as a surplus to help improve the state's bond rating.
 
Counting On U.S. Help
 According to a preliminary budget plan being circulated in the Legislature, administration planners are also counting on a large part of a $450 million in retroactive Medicaid reimbursements, which the state claims the Federal Government owes, for care at state psychiatric hospitals.
Without those reimbursements, the state would be left with at least a $200 million shortfall. Legislators and the Florio administration believe that they can bridge that gap with fee increases and other revenue enhancements without layoffs.
"If the administration also receives the $300-$400 million in Medicaid money from the Federal Government that the state is owed," according to the budget plan, "then the fiscal '94 budget will be balanced with minimal pain."
The disputed Medicaid reimbursement was the cause of a fractious budget battle last year. Gov. Jim Florio first included the money in his proposed 1992-93 fiscal budget. He yanked it out at the last minute, telling angry Republicans that the money would not be forthcoming. The move forced huge last-minute cuts.
The emerging budget, which is expected to be $15.2 billion to $15.5 billion and will be presented by Mr. Florio on Feb. 8, tries to thread a narrow course between two political minefields: raising taxes and cutting services or forcing more layoffs. The current budget is $14.7 billion.
Although the proposals outlined include raising the minimum tax on corporations and increasing the fees on such things as motor vehicles, the budget proposals largely skirt big cuts in services or employment, and impose no big new taxes.
The state has already eliminated some 5,000 state employees through early retirements and layoffs, cutting the work force to 65,000, from 71,000 when Mr. Florio took office in January 1990. And last year the Republican Legislature cut Mr. Florio's budget from $15.7 billion to $14.6 billion, incurring widespread criticism for cutting the Governor's popular Homestead Rebate program. The reductions in the work force and the budget cuts already made will make it difficult to make further cuts to achieve a balanced budget.
But Assembly Speaker Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian said that once the Governor proposes his budget, "We'll go through it line by line just as we did this year, and if cutting is necessary, we will do it."
The proposals being discussed today represent a new-found spirit of co-operation between Mr. Florio's Democratic administration and the overwhelmingly Republican Legislature. Republican leaders do not want to give voters the impression of partisan gridlock, which held up several issues last year. The Governor and all 120 members of the Legislature are up for election in November.
The anticipated $2.2 billion budget shortfall, according to budget officials in the Legislature and in the Florio administration, comes basically from the use of "one-shot" revenues to close last year's budget gap, including $800 million from the pension revaluation and $100 million from early collection of the utilities tax.
Although neither will be available this year, the state must allow for increases in school aid spending, Medicaid costs and outlays for prisons and prison personnel.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Steel Prices Rise, and Industry Sees Profitability

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Buoyed by the economic recovery and the possibility of new duties to protect them from foreign competition, the nation's large steel companies have announced price increases that could help the industry return to profitability this year.
The USX-U.S. Steel Group, the nation's largest steel company, said today that it would match increases announced Thursday by the LTV Corporation, the third-largest steel company, of $20 a ton for most sheet steel, a rise of from 4 percent to 5 percent. The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the second-largest producer, and several smaller steel companies said that they were studying the increases and would make announcements next week. 
 The increases, if the industry can force customers to accept them, might be enough for most of the major companies to return to profitability in 1993 after two years of heavy losses. The increases affect spot prices and will have no near-term impact on much of the steel used by major manufacturers with long-term contracts.
The increases came on top of price rises earlier this month, which were the first the industry managed to maintain after more than a year of failures. But even the earlier increases were not a complete success. They held for cold-rolled steel but have been only partly enforced for hot-rolled products and failed completely in zinc-coated, or galvanized, steel.
The new increases, effective in April, apply only to hot and cold-rolled steel. But U.S. Steel said today that it also intended to impose changes in transaction costs that in effect would enforce this month's price increase for galvanized steel.
Some analysts noted that the increases did nothing to solve the industry's fundamental problem of overcapacity. Although the economy has been recovering since last spring, factory utilization has only recently nudged past 80 percent and several new highly efficient mini-mills are scheduled to open in the next few years. Some on Wall Street also fear that any gains from the price increases will be lost to unions in coming negotiations.
Still, investors responded positively, with the share prices of LTV, USX, Bethlehem, and Inland Steel Industries rising smartly in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Stocks Show Gains
 LTV rose 37.5 cents today, to $1.125; USX climbed $2.75, to $37.75; Bethlehem was up $1.75, to $19.25, and Inland finished up 87.5 cents, to $24.125. The increases continued a rebound for the sector that began last October, when big investors switched from drug stocks into steel and other cyclical industries expected to benefit from economic recovery.
Much of the industry's pricing optimism is hitched to the success it has enjoyed in Washington with its complaints against foreign steelmakers aimed at getting duties or quotas imposed on various types of steel imports.
The industry is anticipating one of its biggest victories yet next week when the Commerce Department is expected to find that major producers in a number of countries have been selling flat-rolled steel in the United States at prices below cost, a practice known as dumping.
 
Heavy Duties Seen
 Flat-rolled steel, used in the automobile and appliance industries, is the single largest segment of the industry. The Commerce Department is expected to call for duties of up to 25 percent.
The ruling would be a preliminary one subject to further action by both the Commerce Department and the International Trade Commission, but industry sources say that a number of foreign steelmakers have already slowed shipments to the United States to avoid some of the liabilities they face in fighting it.
Experts say the import share of the market is likely to fall from about 17 percent last year to 15 percent this year.
The decline in foreign competition comes at the same time demand is picking up from auto makers and other major steel users. "Orders are definitely coming in more strongly than a few months ago," said Robert Lefley, a spokesman for Inland Steel.

HEADLINE: Japanese Trade Surplus Leaps to a Record

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Japan said today that its trade surplus with the United States jumped 14 percent last year, as its surplus with the entire world reached a record high.
It was the second consecutive yearly increase in the surplus with the United States after several years of declines. That trend may pose a challenge to President Clinton, who is facing calls in Congress for a tougher stance on the Japanese trade issue that could include retaliatory measures. 
 The amount by which Japanese exports to the United States exceeded imports rose from $38.22 billion in 1991 to $43.67 billion last year, still below the record of $52.09 billion in 1987.
But Japan's Ministry of Finance said the overall worldwide merchandise trade surplus soared 37.6 percent in 1992 to a new record. The total excess of exports over imports reached $107.06 billion in 1992, compared with $77.79 billion in 1991 and well beyond the record $82.74 billion in 1986.
[In Washington Friday, the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, said in a statement that the Japanese trade surplus was "a call for action, an end to the policies of the past and a move to a results-oriented trade policy."
[Mr. Gephardt said the scale of Japan's trade surpluses with many countries, and not just the United States, showed that Japanese leaders "need to understand, as today's figures show, that this isn't just a bilateral problem, it's a global problem."]
President Clinton and some of his Cabinet members and advisers have vowed to take a tougher stance on Japanese trade, and the new figures could give them one more justification.
In a policy speech today, Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa said he hoped to address bilateral economic issues "expeditiously and properly." He called Japan's economic situation "very grim."
Economists said the main reason for the rising Japanese trade surplus was a recession that reduced imports by 1.7 percent in 1992, to $232.70 billion. At the same time, Japanese companies, with their home market slumping, continued to increase their exports, which rose 8 percent, to $339.76 billion.
Those conditions are likely to persist into 1993. Indeed, the fact that the American economy appears to be recovering faster than the Japanese economy could further enlarge the surplus because it will lead to a spurt of Japanese exports without an equivalent rise in imports.
Another reason for the rise in the surplus, Japanese officials said, is the strengthening of the yen. That means exports valued in yen are converted into a higher dollar figure when the trade figures are calculated.
Still, the figures are considered embarrassing for Japan, which has long pledged to convert its economy to one that relies more on domestic consumption and less on exports. Japan made progress in that direction during the speculative "bubble" economy of the late 1980's, but that movement is now reversing.
Japan's trade surplus is also causing political problems with the European Community and with the rest of Asia, both of which also have large and growing deficits with Japan.
The Japanese trade surplus with the European Community rose 14 percent, to $31.18 billion, and with Asia 32 percent, to a record $41.76 billion.
Japanese officials have said that the best way to reduce the surplus is to improve the domestic economy. The Government last year enacted an $86 billion economic stimulus program centered on increased spending for public works. And reports are circulating that the Bank of Japan would soon cut the discount rate, which now stands at 3.25 percent, as a way to stimulate the economy.
It is likely that another stimulatory package will be enacted this year, although there is debate about how far it should go. Some business executives favor an income-tax cut to spur consumer spending, even if it means a national budget deficit. But the Ministry of Finance is strongly opposed to a budget deficit.
The trade figures released today are on a customs-cleared basis and differ from the balance of payments method used by the International Monetary Fund. Under that measurement, Japan's trade surplus might reach about $130 billion in 1992.

HEADLINE: Island of Lost Souls? No, but the Talk of the Mall.;
Spate of Highly Publicized Crimes Leaves Many Asking What's Got Into Long Island

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SMITHTOWN, L.I.

 BODY:
On Long Island, in the same suburbs that for decades have been considered prototypes of security, wealth and tranquillity, now comes the macabre.
"I suppose the question for a lot of people is how this all could have happened on our quiet, tree-lined streets," said Louis Simpson, the poet and a Long Island resident for more than 20 years. 
 "It is strange, but I think it is just coincidental," he said in a burst of defensiveness shared by many here. "I mean, really! You could have three mass murders in Indianapolis."
 
No Mass Murders, at Least
 Mass murders, thank goodness, have not been the problem. But perhaps few crimes would have attracted such relentless publicity as those popping up on Long Island.
They include the case of Katie Beers, the 10-year-old held captive in a subterranean Bay Shore bunker; the sordid story of Sol Wachtler, the former chief judge of the State Court of Appeals, arrested in November on charges of threatening his former mistress and now under house arrest in Manhasset, and the tawdry tale of Amy Fisher, the Merrick 18-year-old who has become known, through three made-for-TV movies and more media attention than is normally allotted to a small war, as the "Long Island Lolita."
It has all unfolded here, prompting many to raise an all-but-imponderable question: Why here? One jibe is that there must be something strange in the Island's drinking water.
Some are asking if the recession has been so deep and long that it is pushing Long Islanders over the brink into violence.
But to most people here, the cases of Katie Beers, Amy Fisher and Sol Wachtler are aberrations, strung together only by coincidence of geography and timing, and yield no deep secrets about life on the Island.
Still, Long Island has gained the unwanted distinction of being a national center of scandal and crime. And therein lies a problem that may linger after the headlines.
"Obviously, this has all been negative for the Island," said the Rev. Tom Hartman, a Catholic priest and director of radio and television for the Diocese of Rockville Centre.
"There are a lot of people around the country that already view us as being an extension of New York City -- hard nosed, insensitive and money driven. "These stories just underscore that perception," he added.
"I do worry," said Mr. Simpson, a retired professor of literature at the State University of New York at Stony Brook and a recipient of the Pulitzer Prize for poetry. "People in the suburbs watch a lot of television, and it has a degrading effect. They get an exaggerated sense of violence, and they lose proportion. Now, with these stories, it is all real, and suddenly it is right on top of them."
 
Repelled and Attracted
 The emotional response in schools, churches and synagogues, around dinner tables and in parking lots, has been complex and sometimes conflicting. While many say they resent the media coverage, others admit to a strong tug of fascination.
"It may be voyeurism," said Ron Craddock, manager of the Smith Haven shopping mall here, which was itself drawn briefly into the media blitz when Miss Fisher, on the day before her sentencing for shooting Mary Jo Buttafuoco, came shopping for a new outfit, reporters in tow.
"I didn't know she was here at the time," Mr. Craddock said. But with a smile and a slight blush, he added: "If I had, I would probably have wanted her autograph."
Many Long Islanders now have personal stories of coming close to celebrity, or scandal.
"You know, I've seen him many times at the diner," said Sylvia Sones of Massapequa, who was plodding through the mall here with her husband, Lou, and their friends Ted and Esther Zuckerman.
To most people in Massapequa, Mrs. Sones's reference to "him" would be obvious -- he is Joseph Buttafuoco, the man Amy Fisher says was her lover.
Some are angry, less about the scandals than about the coverage. "I am appalled by the coverage," said Carole Kohlmar of East Hampton, a retired librarian, as she made her way with her husband, Matthew, through a throng of shoppers at the mall here the other day.
"It titilates people, nothing more than that," said Mr. Kohlmar, a retired history teacher. He attributed the vast coverage to Long Island's proximity to the networks, magazines and major newspapers of New York City, and for what he called the worst of the media blitz he blamed checkbook journalism, and the ability of movie and television producers to turn real tragedy into Hollywood fiction.
 
Background in Foreground
 But while few here welcome the attention, some say it was all but inevitable, given the backgrounds of those involved.
"If Amy Fisher were black and living in Harlem, that story would have gotten no more than first-day reporting," said Father Hartman. "But the fact that Amy, and now Katie Beers, are white, suburban kids makes them more comfortable" and easier for others in the nation's suburbs to relate to.
Is it mere coincidence that Long Island is awash in scandal now? Perhaps not, he said.
"Long Island is generally an affluent place, but we've got a lot of people out of work and a collapsing real-estate market," Father Hartman said. "We are dealing with the fact that we are no longer on the same economic plane as in the past, and maybe that has contributed to a sense of personal desperation that can push people over the edge."
To whatever extent the recession has played a role, many fear that the publicity has created a new hurdle, if only a small one, to recovery.
"These are individual horrors that should not be associated in people's minds with Long Island, but they will be," said Patricia Poppiti of Seldon, one of the Smith Haven mall shoppers. "Will businesses be discouraged from moving to the Island? I don't know," she said. "Will some people have more trouble selling their homes? It could be."
Mrs. Poppiti said she had already been forced to defend Long Island against exaggerated fears of crime in her own job as an administrator of programs that bring European young people to the New York City area as exchange students and au pairs.
Most people here are confident that the Island will soon fade from the public's consciousness as a center of scandal and bizarre crimes.
"My analysis is that Long Island, like other places, has its share of the abhorrent behavior, but for some strange reason it all came to the surface here this year," said James L. Larocca, president of the Long Island Association, a business group. "Who knows why? But communities do survive these things."
 
A Teen-Ager's View
 Perhaps least upset by the media blitz are the Island's teen-agers. Who better to judge a made-for-TV plot, fictional or real?
"Sure, this stuff is out of the ordinary, but big deal," said Brian James, 17, of Sayville, as he emerged from the Gap here with Rob Sholly, and Simeon Serrao, both of Bohemia.
"These things could happen anywhere," said Mr. Sholly, 18. "There is a lot of publicity, but it won't last. None of this really matters to me."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Sure, this stuff is out of the ordinary, but big deal," said Brian James, left, regarding recent crimes on Long Island. With friends Rob Sholly, center, and Simeon Serrao, Mr. James continued, "These things could happen anywhere. There is a lot of publicity, but it won't last. None of this really matters to me." HEADLINE: Queens Man Kills Wife And 2 Girls, Police Say

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
An unemployed garment worker from Queens fatally stabbed and bludgeoned his wife and two young daughters on Thursday, telling the police that voices had warned him they would be tortured if he did not kill them before the Chinese New Year, the authorities said yesterday.
The man, Da Pei Wu, then tried to electrocute himself with exposed wires from a radio, but succeeded only in blowing a fuse in the apartment on 56th Avenue in Elmhurst, the police said. 
 The police said they discovered the bodies of Mr. Wu's wife, Hui Ming, 31 years old, and their daughters, Lauren, 5, and Renee, 2, early yesterday morning, after a neighbor told them that she had called Mr. Wu when she did not see the children's shoes outside the family's door as usual and that he had explained how he had had to kill them. When officers arrived, they found Mr. Wu pacing in the living room and the bodies, neatly lined up and covered with a blanket, in a bedroom.
Capt. Bernard Gillespie, the commanding officer of the 17th Division detective squad in Queens, said that Mr. Wu had never been in trouble with the police before, but appeared to have recently suffered "periods of mental instability." Six months ago, Mr. Wu, who is 37, lost his job sewing buttons for a factory in the Garment District in Manhattan.
 
Emigrated From China
 "He said he had to kill them before Saturday, the Year of the Rooster," Captain Gillespie said yesterday afternoon at a news conference at the 110th Precinct station house. "In his own mind he was saving them."
Mr. Wu and his wife, who emigrated from the Guangdong Province in China about seven years ago, lived in one of four apartments in a three-story duplex in the diverse middle-class Elmhurst neighborhood beside the Long Island Rail Road.
Neighbors described the Wus as a quiet family. They said that Mr. Wu and his wife had worked at home, sewing garments delivered occassionally by a truck, but that the truck stopped coming six months ago.
Edwin Espinosa, a student who lives in an apartment in the other half of the duplex, said his brother, Kenny, had played with the girls and attended kindergarten with Lauren at Public School 102.
"The girls were happy kids," said Mr. Espinosa, who is 20. "They played outside on tricycles. The mother planted flowers."
Mr. Wu, who speaks little English, is said to be cooperating with detectives, speaking Cantonese through a translator. The police said he had told them that he bought a knife on Monday after voices told him he had to kill his family before the Chinese New Year, which begins today.
On Thursday at 11 A.M., the police said, he beat his wife, apparently with a hammer, and stabbed her repeatedly with the knife before slashing the throat of his youngest daughter.
He then changed clothes and walked to his daughter's school to pick her up, the police said. When they returned home, he slashed her throat, officers said.
Mr. Wu was charged with three counts of intentional murder, three counts of murder by depraved indifference and one count of possession of a weapon. He was to be arraigned last night in the Criminal Court Building in Kew Gardens. District Attorney Richard A. Brown of Queens said that if Mr. Wu is convicted, he faces a prison sentence of 25 years to life.
"This is a terribly tragic case," Mr. Brown said at the news conference, "not only because of the vicious and mindless killing of a young woman and her two defenseless children, but because it has occurred on the eve of the Chinese New Year -- on the eve of that which would otherwise be an occasion of great joy."

HEADLINE: Top Futures Regulator Quits; Clinton Can Name 3 to Panel

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Wendy Gramm resigned as chairman of the Commodities Futures Trading Commission yesterday, clearing the way for President Clinton to appoint a majority of the five-member body that regulates the nation's futures markets.
William Albrecht, a member of the commission since 1988 and a former economics professor at the University of Iowa, was named acting chairman by the other members of the commission. He will serve in that post until the President appoints a chairman. Mrs. Gramm had headed the commission since 1988. 
 Mrs. Gramm's departure, coupled with the resignation earlier in the week of Fowler West, leaves the commission with only three members. Mr. Albrecht's term expires in April, giving President Clinton the opportunity to appoint a majority of the five members within the first few months of his term.
 
3 Democratic Openings
 The two other remaining members, Sheila Bair and Joseph Dial, are Republicans, while Mr. Albrecht is a Democrat. The rules require that no more than three commissioners be from one political party, clearing the way for the President to make three Democratic nominations.
The commission under Mrs. Gramm's leadership successfully fought off an attempt by the Securities and Exchange Commission to gain regulatory control of stock index futures. That Congressional decision was strongly supported by the futures exchanges, but they were disappointed earlier this month when the commission voted to exempt over-the-counter trading of currency and interest rate swaps from regulation without providing a similar exemption for similar products traded on futures exchanges.
It is likely that the futures exchanges will press for appointment of commissioners who might be willing to change that decision, while the large banks and brokerage firms that dominate the swaps markets will be looking for regulators who would not upset the previous decision.
 
Gramm Defends Record
 Mrs. Gramm, who holds a doctorate in economics from Northwestern University, was an official in the Office of Management and Budget before being appointed to the commission by President Reagan. She did not disclose any employment plans.
"I have worked to assure that our regulations measure up to sound economic analysis," she said in announcing her departure, which had been expected. "We've followed the philosophy that consumers are best served by free market innovation and competition, not paternalistic government."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
SOUTHWESTERN BELL CORP. (N)

 BODY:
The Southwestern Bell Corporation, the regional Bell company for Texas, Arkansas and some Midwestern states, attributed its fourth-quarter earnings growth of nearly 11 percent to the "outstanding" performance of its local-phone business, which provides the majority of its revenue.
It posted a record increase in the number of telephone lines, adding 405,000 lines in 1992, compared with 293,000 in recession-weakened 1991. The total is 12.8 million lines. 
 The company also benefited from a strong performance by Telefonos de Mexico, the Mexican national carrier in which Southwestern Bell owns a 10 percent stake. Mexico, which adjoins Southwestern Bell's main territory of Texas, has been growing rapidly.
Southwestern said its wireless telephone business was growing rapidly. Cellular telephone customers totaled 1.4 million, an increase of 453,000. The year before, Southwestern got only 293,000 new wireless-phone customers.
