HEADLINE: New-Home Starts Rose Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Builders broke ground for new homes in December at a pace 5.5 percent faster than in November, the Government said today, ending a year in which housing starts posted their first advance since 1986.
The 1992 total of 1.2 million represented an 18.5 percent increase from 1991 that helped lift the economy out of recession. 
 Yet housing starts, the effects of which ripple broadly through the economy, remain far below the 1.8 million of 1986, the year in which an overhaul of the tax code made real estate investment less attractive.
While genuine, the 1992 increase is "certainly nothing like we had in the past," said Patrick J. Moriarty, chief investment officer for Bank Julius Baer in New York. Analysts also cautioned that further gains were being jeopardized by continued sluggish growth in jobs, a factor that limits confidence and incomes.
 
Optimism, and Wariness
 Indeed, the Labor Department today reported a second straight rise in first-time claims for unemployment insurance, which suggested that the lengthy downtrend in new claims was flattening.
On five occasions during the 1970's, when demographic factors were more favorable than today and the Federal Government was providing huge subsidies for low-income apartments, the United States built two million or more dwellings in a year.
Last month's gain, to an annual rate of 1.302 million, was the biggest since December 1991. It was spread across all regions but the West and was aided by rebuilding of homes, mainly in Florida, damaged by hurricanes. It was a better performance than analysts had expected since much of the country suffered severe December weather.
Still, analysts noted, after the 1981-82 recession, housing starts soared some 60 percent in 1983.
In the week ended Jan. 9, 361,000 new jobless claims were filed, 17,000 more than in the preceding week. On a four-week average, which many economists view as a more accurate gauge than weekly numbers subject to big gyrations, claims edged up to 331,750, from 331,500 in the Jan. 2 week.
The latest week's claims were also the highest since just before Thanksgiving.
"The data confirm that the improvement in the job market will be gradual," said Marilyn Schaja and Christine Schneider, economists at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
The biggest rises in claims were 25,618 in California, 18,791 in Tennessee and 16,708 in Michigan. The biggest declines, on the other hand, were smaller than 1,500 -- in Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Indiana.
The gain in housing starts included some rebound in the long-depressed multifamily sector, but specialists were skeptical that this signaled a turnaround.
"There's no indication that things are fundamentally better in multi," commented David Seiders, economist for the National Association of Home Builders. He also expressed concern about a failure so far to renew the tax credit for low-income housing, an important support for the market that has expired.
In December, the rate of housing increase was 68,000 -- 40,000 in single-family homes, 8,000 in buildings with two to four units, and 20,000 in buildings with five or more units, the Commerce Department said.
The single-family pace was 1.1 million, up 3.7 percent, bringing the gain for the full year to 22.6 percent.
Today's report also showed a 7 percent December gain in permits for future construction, to an annual pace of 1.2 million. But specialists have come increasingly to believe that permit issuance is a poor predictor of activity.
By region, starts in December jumped 32.7 percent in the depressed Northeast, and rose 7.9 percent in the Midwest and 4.3 percent in the South. The West recorded a 4.9 percent drop.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Lower on Fears Over Level of German Rates

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the German mark and settled weaker against most other major currencies yesterday amid fears that German interest rates would not be lowered soon.
The dollar slumped to 1.5915 German marks, from 1.6144 on Thursday, in late afternoon trading in New York. Earlier in London, the dollar traded at 1.5970 marks, down from 1.6158 late on Thursday. 
 Gold prices fell 60 cents on the Commodity Exchange in New York, where gold for current delivery settled at $328.60 an ounce. The Republic National Bank of New York reported a late price of $328.85 an ounce, off 70 cents.
 
 
Too Early to Ease
 The dollar opened modestly lower in the United States but managed to stay above 1.60 marks overseas. It barely took notice of mixed economic data but plunged around midday on heightened fears that the German central bank would not lower rates.
A regional Bundesbank president was quoted as saying that it was too early to ease German rates. His comments, coming after other similar remarks by German monetary officials, brought more support to those who see the dollar continuing to slide.
Uncertainty as to what measures President Clinton will take to trim the United States deficit and stimulate the economy were also weighing on the market, traders said.
"In the short term, the dollar looks a bit bearish in response to uncertainty about Clinton, Iraq and German rates," said Peter Connolly of Wells Fargo.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 125.15 yen, up from 124.68 on Thursday. It dipped in London, settling at 125.10 yen. In New York, it settled at 125.14 yen, up from 124.88 yen late on Thursday.
In London, the British pound settled at $1.5280, above $1.5185 late on Thursday. In New York, the pound rose to $1.5305 from $1.5224.
Other late dollar rates, compared with Thursday quotes, included: 1.4600 Swiss francs, down from 1.4787; 5.3830 French francs, down from 5.4565; 1,465 Italian lire, down from 1,479, and 1.2823 Canadian dollars, down from $1.2850.

HEADLINE: Q & A

 BODY:

Valuing Nonpublic Stock

Q For purposes of an employee stock option plan, how is stock in a corporation valued if it is not publicly traded?
 
 FRED STURUP, WOODSIDE, QUEENS 
 A There are four principal ways to value stock that is not priced by market forces, said Eric Scoones, a principal of William M. Mercer Inc., benefits consultants. "The first is to have an outside appraisal done about once a year," he said. "It has the advantage of taking into account all the facts and circumstances in the value of a company, but some people consider it to be subjective."
Another way consists of book value. According to Mr. Scoones, "book value, the company's assets minus its liabilities, is easy to measure, but may not be an accurate reflection of the company's true market value."
Then there is a formula intended to mirror the market value of a company. For example, this value may be a multiple of the company's total earnings, often based on the multiple used to value publicly traded companies. "Sometimes companies don't use a formal method at all," Mr. Scoones said. "The board of directors simply states what it believes to be the market value of the stock."
 
Buying Foreign Stocks
Q What are the benefits of investing in foreign stocks?
 
 AZARIAH ESHKENAZI, FOREST HILLS, QUEENS
A "Significant values exist for investors in foreign stocks," said Michael A. Dritz, president of Smith New Court Securities. At some points in the cycle, stock markets in other countries may be a better investment than in the United States. For example, if the United States market has been strong and the Swiss market has been weak, it may be advantageous to switch out of United States equities and into Swiss equities.
"Dealing with other currencies can be both a positive and a negative," Mr. Dritz said. "Whenever you buy a foreign stock in any form, there is a currency risk involved. But because of economic considerations, you might want to diversify some of your holdings into nondollar-denominated equities."
 
Differences in Insurance
Q What are the advantages and disadvantages of whole life insurance, as opposed to term insurance?
 
 JAN ANDERSON, WASHINGTON
A Whole life insurance, which is permanent insurance designed to provide coverage for a person's lifetime, typically has a fixed premium and death benefits that do not change. "A whole life policy has a cash value -- a savings element -- that you may borrow against or will be paid to you if you surrender the policy," said Diane Coffey, a spokeswoman for the American Council of Life Insurance. "However, whole life insurance premiums are generally more costly than term insurance premiums."
Term insurance, considered to be temporary insurance protection, does not have a cash value. "The premium rises every time the policy is renewed, which most often is annually," she said. "Term insurance is particularly attractive for people who need life insurance for a limited period or who cannot afford to pay whole life premiums."

HEADLINE: Munis: Popular, Tax Free and Tricky

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
With as much as $15 billion worth of municipal bonds being redeemed this month by the states, cities and public authorities that sold them, and almost $7 billion worth of new municipal bond issues coming to market, many investors are focusing their attention on these tax-exempt securities.
It is their freedom from Federal income taxation, and in some cases their exemption from state and local taxes as well, that accounts for the popularity of these investments. Millions of Americans, and particularly people who invest for income rather than growth, include municipals in their portfolios. 
 Among them is Jerome Rabkin, an executive at a Long Island pharmaceutical wholesaler. Several weeks ago, he bought $25,000 worth of New York City bonds that expire in the year 2000, continuing his efforts to stagger the maturities of his holdings.
"Because I'm in the 31 percent bracket, the taxable yield equivalent is much higher than the actual tax-exempt yield," he said.
 
What Exemption Means
 Mr. Rabkin bought the New York bonds at a yield of 6.05 percent, but because he will pay no tax on the income, they are worth as much to him, a resident of New York State, as a fully taxable bond issued by a corporation and paying about 9.50 percent.
At the end of 1992, the yield to maturity of the Bond Buyer municipal bond index was 6.39 percent, compared with interest rates of 7.20 percent for the Salomon Brothers index of medium-term corporate issues and 7.40 percent for 30-year Treasury bonds. However, some one-year municipal bonds yield as little as about 3.25 percent.
Despite their advantages, many investors find that the pricing system for municipals is too complex for them to understand.
"Don't be put off by the fact that superficially municipal bonds seem to be a much more complicated business than rolling over a C.D. at your local bank," said Heather L. Ruth, president of the Public Securities Association."
However, munis are not for everyone. For one thing, the return of the money invested is not guaranteed by the Federal Government the way up to $100,000 in a bank account is. If you sell a bond before maturity, the market price could be lower than your purchase price. The reason is that when interest rates rise, the prices of municipal bonds and other fixed-income securities decline to bring the yield up to current levels.
Conversely, when interest rates fall, the value of the bonds rises and they can be sold at a profit. Unlike the tax-free nature of interest earned by municipal bonds, the profits on a such a sale are subject to capital gains tax.
What is more, there is always the possibility -- although a slim one -- that a municipal bond issuer will default and fail to pay principal or interest when it is due. The Washington Public Power Supply System defaulted on $2.25 billion in bonds in 1983, the largest default in history. Even New York City defaulted on some of its short-term obligations in 1977 until the courts compelled city officials to pay up. To cover such eventualities, many municipal bonds are backed by insurance.
"Credit quality is something that investors should continue to be concerned about," said Howard D. Sitzer, director of municipal bond research at Greenwich Money Management. "The appropriate advice is that people should diversify."
But a more common risk for muni bond buyers is a redemption, or call, by the issuer before the bonds reach maturity. The terms of most bonds authorize such calls, and issuers make them when their bonds are paying a high interest rate at a time when rates have moved significantly lower.
That is what is happening now, and it explains the high level of redemptions this month. The holders of called bonds get the full face value of their investment -- and sometimes more -- but when they reinvest the money, they will have to accept a lower rate of return.
Investors can acquire municipal bonds in several ways. They can invest in individual issues, usually in $5,000 denominations, by purchasing bonds from dealers who make their profit on the spread between the wholesale and retail prices. Many dealers, however, require minimum investments from their customers of $10,000 to $25,000.
Or they can invest in municipal bond funds, which are like other mutual funds, with relatively low minimum investment requirements and professional management of a group of diversified securities. Funds have no specific maturity, so that there is not a set expiration date when shares must be redeemed. Instead shareholders receive the net asset value on the day they sell.
Unit investment trusts and closed-end funds are other types of municipal bond products, both also widely available with a relatively small minimum investment.
Unit trusts contain a fixed portfolio of tax-exempt bonds and mature at a specified time, when the units are redeemed. And closed-end funds are managed investment companies holding a variety of municipals and traded on a stock exchange, with prices determined by supply and demand.
 
Classifying the Bonds
 Municipal securities can also be classified in one of two basic categories. General obligation bonds, which must be voter-approved, are backed by the issuer's full taxing and revenue-raising power. Revenue bonds finance specific projects like hospitals, airports and bridges -- and their principal and interest are secured only by the income earned by these particular facilities.
"Historically it was felt that general obligation bonds were safer, but we've seen during the 80's that some municipalities passed legislation prohibiting the raising of property taxes," said Samuel R. Fales, vice president of Legg Mason. "A lot of professional portfolio managers now prefer looking at the flow from a particular revenue source because they can look at the financials."

HEADLINE: Too Many Specialists

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Only 12 percent or so of American physicians are generalists, the rest specialists. In part this explains the high cost of medicine in America. 
 In Europe's socialized countries, 30 percent of doctors are generalists, and the cost of medicine is about 8 percent of gross national product.
About 80 percent of what's medically wrong with Americans is rather ordinary stuff. That is to say, in the United States we've developed a medical system of specialists, who do ordinary things at very special prices.
 
PHILIP C. HOLZBERGER, M.D.
Milbrook, N.Y., Jan. 7, 1993

HEADLINE: Tax Breaks for Companies in Puerto Rico Don't Help Islanders

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Trade Pact Threatens Puerto Rico's Economic Rise" (front page, Jan. 3) implies that Puerto Rico's economy continues to benefit from Section 936 of the Internal Revenue Code, which exempts United States corporations from paying taxes on profits earned in Puerto Rico. 
 However, these companies employ few Puerto Ricans, and 936 has done little lately to improve the island's economy or quality of life. Only 12 percent of the work force is employed by companies benefiting from 936. These companies receive a $3 billion annual tax break from the Federal Government under 936, meaning Washington provides a $100,000 subsidy for each 936 job.
These tax credits are based on profitability, not the number of jobs created. Because industries such as pharmaceuticals are not labor intensive, they do little to create the vast number of jobs and training opportunities envisioned. Instead, industries have used 936 to exempt some of their United States income from taxation. Meanwhile, the island's per capita income, at $6,000, is lower than that of any state and falling.
The North American Free Trade Agreement will not have a significant impact on the more than 600 corporations that benefit from 936. Many of these -- especially the pharmaceuticals -- are regulated by the Food and Drug Administration and cannot manufacture their products elsewhere in the Caribbean. They will not leave, with or without the trade agreement or elimination of 936.
Puerto Rico will benefit from elimination of section 936. It is time to replace outmoded economic blueprints with a strategy for today, providing United States companies with compelling reasons to operate in Puerto Rico, while offering real training and employment opportunities to an able work force. Such strategies should include a tax credit to wages and real investment as in the enterprise zone proposals before Congress.
Once Puerto Rico is a state, special tax treatments will no longer be needed.
 
MIRIAM RAMIREZ DE FERRER
President, Puerto Ricans in Civic Action
Mayaguez, P.R., Jan. 7, 1993

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Tax Breaks for Companies in Puerto Rico Don't Help Islanders;
Repeal Is Dangerous

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Trade Pact Threatens Puerto Rico's Economic Rise" (front page, Jan. 3) states that the North American Free Trade Agreement, if approved by Congress, will encourage United States companies in Puerto Rico to take advantage of even lower wages in Mexico. 
 As a result, you state, Puerto Rico will become more reliant on the benefits of Internal Revenue Code Section 936, which exempts United States corporations in Puerto Rico from paying taxes on the profits they earn on the island. Even this tax advantage, you state, is threatened because the Clinton Administration has promised to reduce the huge Federal budget deficit. Congress and the Treasury Department, you report, have shown interest in proposals to abolish or reduce Section 936 exemptions, which could raise as much as $26 billion a year in tax revenues.
Puerto Rico is not just another part of the United States, to be affected by measures aimed at balancing the Federal budget. Puerto Rico is the most vital United States Army and Navy stronghold in the Caribbean, with one of the largest United States naval bases.
The United States must keep Puerto Rico's economy healthy and stable, free from the ruinous economic and political instability that repeal of or amendments to Section 936 could bring to Puerto Rico.
It won't be easy for an island like Puerto Rico, small, overpopulated and lacking natural resources, to establish by itself a solid and stable economic base. It will need help. It must attract outside investments by providing maximum incentives.
We are not getting something for nothing. Nor do we intend to continue being beggars of the Federal Government.
 
GUILLERMO MOSCOSO
San Juan, P.R., Jan. 6, 1993

HEADLINE: World Bank Keeps Improving Its Approach

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Before We Let World Bank Squander More" (letter, Jan. 6), Deborah Moore, Bruce Rich and Lori Udall of the Environmental Defense Fund are misguided in their argument that the United States should not support the World Bank's International Development Association's $18 billion replenishment. 
 Worse, their attempt to make the development association a whipping boy for what they perceive as poor project policy at the World Bank threatens to transfer the burden to the world's poorest people, who are desperate for programs and projects to improve their lives.
The authors cite "Effective Implementation: Key to Development Impact," a World Bank report whose task force I headed. The authors have misread this report. It says that about one-third of the projects do not live up to the bank's standards in implementation; but it also says that projects need to meet a minimum 10 percent economic rate of return to be deemed satisfactory.
Many projects have not reached this target, but have been of considerable value to developing countries in building institutions and other benefits. Many others may still yield a positive rate of return, especially as efforts to improve performance continue after construction is complete.
The report notes that the percentage of projects not meeting the bank's rigorous criteria doubled in the last decade. But it also notes that much of this can be attributed to difficult world economic conditions in the 1980's -- the debt crisis, the global slowdown in growth, persistently low commodity prices. Many of the assumptions once thought reasonable turned out to be too optimistic, a fate that has befallen many investments -- not only those in developing countries or those supported by the bank.
The bank's criteria for and record of financing successful projects compare favorably with those of any other development agency. Our report is part of the bank's self-assessment. It should be seen as telling evidence that the institution is not complacent, but continuously seeks to improve.
Lewis Preston, president of the bank, has said the report underscores the bank's commitment. The report and its reception by the World Bank, far from an argument against supporting the International Development Association, should assure supporters that the development association remains concerned that the resources entrusted to it are used prudently.
 
WILLI A. WAPENHANS
Washington, Jan. 8, 1993
 
The writer retired as a vice president of the World Bank.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Paying for Health, The German Way -- A special report.;
Medical Care in Germany: With Choices, and for All

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Jan. 22

 BODY:
If the most critical problem in providing national health care is getting control over rapidly rising costs, as President Clinton has often said, he may find some intriguing ideas in the German health care system, which offers coverage to all at a much lower price than Americans pay.
Germany's much-admired system of health care, provided through nonprofit but private "sickness funds" that are legally mandatory for nearly 90 percent of the population, leaves patients with freedom to choose their own doctors and their own hospitals, and freedom from almost all medical bills. 
 Germans spend only about half as much per person on health care as Americans do, $1,486 in 1990 for Germany, compared with $2,566 for the United States. As a percentage of gross national product, however, it was 14 percent for the United States in 1992 and a little more than 8 percent for Germany. In 1990, the G.N.P. comparisons were 12.1 percent for the United States and 8.1 percent for Germany.
American health experts and politicians have flocked here in recent years to try to learn how they could apply at home what they see here. But they have found little that could simply be copied from a country with different cultural traditions.
Visiting a German doctor's office or hospital is much like visiting a good one in the United States. Many German hospitals are regarded as among the best in the world, and few have the crowded emergency rooms and waiting areas that are common in urban American hospitals because people have no other source of medical care. Neither do they have to increase bills for insured patients to cover those who cannot pay, because in Germany insurance covers virtually everybody, including foreign workers and asylum-seekers.
For years, the German Government has tried to keep medical expenditures from growing faster than the economy as a whole, not so much by limiting benefits as by pressing drug makers, doctors and hospitals to contain fees, an approach that has worked fairly well.
The biggest savings have come from Government-mandated programs that brought down the prices of German pharmaceutical products, once the highest in Europe, by ordering insurance funds to pay only what generic drugs cost.
Doctors administer their own payments from the health insurance system, and since 1985 they have agreed to annual caps on total payments, which they share depending on the number of treatments performed.
In another effort to curb costs, and to counter what is generally seen as a surplus of physicians, doctors have been told that from now on they would have to retire, as far as the sickness funds were concerned, at age 68. New practices can only be set up in localities where the Government agrees there is a need for them.
The restrictions have stirred some unhappiness among doctors. German general practitioners earn an average of $95,565 before taxes, which puts them among the country's highest earners, but their incomes have not risen as fast as average wages over the last two decades.
"Many people go into the medical profession with expectations that are too high," said Dr. Karsten Vilmar, head of the national physicians' association in Cologne. "But these kinds of limitations seem to us to violate the constitutional guarantees on professional freedom."
Another factor in keeping costs down is that malpractice suits are less common in Germany than in the United States, and so are extraordinary life-prolonging measures for patients judged to be terminally ill. "If an elderly patient is clearly dying of natural causes, I treat her at home," said Dr. Ursula Friedrichs, who like most of her colleagues still makes house calls. "I know a hospital stay wouldn't do any good."
According to a recent study by John K. Iglehart in The New England Journal of Medicine, "On the average, German hospitals have fewer pieces of high-technology equipment than most big urban hospitals in the United States." But Germany concentrates its most expensive medical technology in teaching hospitals like the University Hospital in Bonn, where the basic daily room rate can be as high as $400 -- but remains far below American rates.
 
A Mounting Demand
 Still, with a mounting demand for medical services, costs have been soaring here too, putting the insurance funds billions of dollars in the red last year. To try to bring costs under control the Government, with a determination worthy of Otto von Bismarck, the Chancellor who expanded the sickness fund system in Prussia 110 years ago to keep the Socialists at bay, has recently run roughshod over the lobbies of doctors, dentists, hospital administrators and drug manufacturers, all of which are seemingly far less powerful here than they are in Washington. A law that went into effect Jan. 1 imposed more across-the-board reductions in the price of most medicines, tightened the caps on doctors' fees, and changed the way hospitals are paid in ways devised to encourage efficiency and lower costs.
 
How Things Work
Some Choices, Some Limits
 Germany's system bears little resemblance to the state-run system of cradle-to-grave national health care the British adopted after World War II. It is also very different from the American health-insurance system, which leaves some 35 million people uncovered.
The main difference between the German system and the American one is that most Germans have no choice about whether to join a health insurance plan, and no problem finding coverage, either. Unless they are either very poor or pretty well off, the law requires them to become members of one of 1,147 "sickness funds" in the country. Some of the funds are connected to private employers, while others are quasi-public institutions.
The funds are supposed to break even, and each one sets a monthly premium rate as a percentage of a wage-earner's monthly salary. The rates among the funds now vary between 8 percent and 16.8 percent of salary, and have reached a historically high national average of 13.1 percent. The premiums are shared equally by employer and employee and paid by payroll deduction. The rate is the same for single and married wage-earners, with or without dependents, in any given sickness fund.
"Everybody knows exactly how much health insurance costs, and when the figure climbed above 13 percent, everybody in the system knew they had to get costs under control or the public would be after them," said Uwe E. Reinhardt of Princeton University, an economist who is an expert on the German system.
Nearly all employers are required to participate, including small businesses and low-wage industries, which in the United States often say they cannot afford to offer health benefits.
The funds cover not only workers and employees but retirees and people on welfare. Government agencies pay the premiums for the elderly and the indigent, as well as for the three million Germans now out of work. Changing jobs, or losing them, does not mean losing insurance coverage, even for a minute.
 
Never See a Bill
 Germans who have the basic, mandatory insurance never see their doctor or hospital bills. Starting this year, most of them have to pay more for medicine, but only up to a maximum of 7 marks -- less than $4.50 -- every time a prescription is filled.
Hospital patients must pay only $6.80 a day in western Germany, and $6.25 in the formerly Communist eastern part, and only for the first 14 days -- after that, even this charge is dropped.
"All I had to do was fill out a health care coupon from my sickness fund and present it to the doctor," said Mrs. Marianne Wettlauffer, 68, who had a slight heart attack several years ago and also spent six weeks in a rehabilitation cure in the Black Forest. All but a nominal amount was paid for by her sickness fund.
Her husband, Hellmut, 68, also had a heart attack 10 years ago, while he was a Government employee. His current care, too, costs him nothing out of pocket, though he supplements his Government pension plan with an inexpensive private policy that provides additional benefits like private hospital rooms.
Their physician, Dr. Friedrichs, has a small second-floor practice in a modern building in Bad Godesberg. From the small waiting room to the two consulting rooms, every room is white and antiseptically modern. Dr. Friedrichs takes privately insured patients as well as those in the sickness funds.
The private patients bring in bigger fees, but the funds provide the bread and butter, with a minimum of administrative headache, she said. "I get the payment automatically when I turn in the coupon, with the services performed marked on it," she said.
Germans who earn more than $40,000 a year ($29,450 this year in the formerly Communist eastern part of Germany, where wages and salaries are still lower) are not required to buy health insurance, but almost all of them -- about 6.3 million people -- purchase it anyway.
Because 88 percent of the population is covered by the sickness funds, risk is more evenly distributed among them than in the United States, and private insurance is also relatively cheap by American standards.
 
Containing Costs
Price Rollbacks And Limits on Fees
 How to reduce waste and inefficiency has been a preoccupation of German Governments since the mid-1970's. Three years ago, changes were put into effect that were supposed to put the health system on a secure financial basis for the next century. Sickness funds were ordered to pay for generic drugs only wherever possible, dental benefits were curtailed and hospitals were directed to increase efficiency.
But costs kept rising anyway, much faster than the rate of inflation or the funds' income from premiums. Either the rates had to be raised or costs had to be cut. And for German politicians, raising health premiums was about as desirable as raising taxes.
Since the system is set up to be self-financing, the German Government did not bail out the funds with taxpayers' money. Instead, it enacted a draconian new law that went into effect on Jan. 1, with the backing of all the major political parties.
Among other new controls on the pharmaceutical industry, the law mandates an across-the-board reduction of 5 percent in the price of most nongeneric medicines sold in the western part of the country this year, and a price freeze through 1994. In the poorer east, the law requires all medicine to be sold at a 20 percent discount.
The law also reduces orthodontists' fees by 10 percent, mandates that hospital fees rise during the next two years no faster than incomes, and bars clinics or private practices from buying expensive new "major equipment" without Government approval.
 
Charges for Weekends
 The law eliminates the traditional practice of reimbursing hospitals' costs and letting them bill the funds at a daily rate -- a practice that, many doctors concede, often led to admissions on Fridays, so hospitals could collect fees over the weekends even though no treatment was given, and discharge 10 days later on Mondays for operations that need only have taken a few days.
By 1996, German hospitals and physicians are to work out new fees based on the procedure, not the length of stay.
To hold down doctors' fees, the new law provides that reimbursements from the sickness funds rise only as fast as income from premiums. The funds pay doctors by the number of services they perform at a rate negotiated with the sickness funds, so by limiting the total "pot," the payments can be limited too.
 
What the Future Holds
Changing Needs In Aging Population
 In all, the Government says that the new law will save $6.5 billion this year and that premiums will not have to rise faster than inflation.
Government and health officials all insist that they do not want to be forced to delay care, the way the British National Health Service does for "elective" operations like hip replacements and heart transplants, with waiting lists that can delay them for years. Nor can they understand why Americans accept a system with what they see as Darwinian traits.
"We are not entitled, particularly with our German past, to decide who is entitled to survival and who is not," said Dr. Vilmar, who heads the national physicians' association. "All we have to ask ourselves is whether we really need a system that provides 100 percent coverage to everybody. There should be a system of perceptible cost-sharing."
He is among the critics of the new law who question if providers of medical care will ever have a strong reason to keep costs under control as long as most consumers never have to even think about how much their care costs.
Regardless of the new law, serious challenges will remain. As in the United States, for example, there is debate about how to cover the costs of long-term care like nursing homes for the growing population of disabled elderly.
Nursing care for the elderly at home is partly covered under the German system, but only up to four weeks and only if it is connected with an illness or accident.
Nursing homes cost about as much here as they do in the United States, and those who cannot pay usually have to sign over their assets or rely on help from welfare. Children with incomes can also be required to pay for nursing home care for their invalid parents.
The Labor Minister, Norbert Blum, has proposed a new state-run old age insurance plan to cover nursing home care, to be paid for by payroll deductions and by eliminating one national paid holiday. But opposition from churches as well as labor unions makes it doubtful whether the plan will become law by 1996, as Mr. Blum wanted.
Only one thing seems sure: with a rapidly aging population -- the proportion of those over 60 will grow by 19 percent by the end of the century, while the segment between 20 and 40 is shrinking by more than 12 percent -- the pressure from medical costs will continue to mount.

HEADLINE: The Rehabbing of America

BYLINE: By Michael Massing; Michael Massing, a fellow at the New York Institute for the Humanities, is working on a book about drugs in the United States.

 BODY:

THE MAKING OF A DRUG-FREE AMERICA
Programs That Work.
By Mathea Falco.
254 pp. New York:
Random House/Times Books. $22.
 
RECKONING
Drugs, the Cities, and the American Future.
By Elliott Currie.
405 pp. New York:
Hill & Wang. $25. 
 OVER the last 12 years, America's drug problem has erupted from a low-grade fever into a raging contagion. In 1981, when Ronald Reagan took office, the nation had about three million hard-core drug users; today, the figure is around six million. The number of deaths by drug overdose has soared, and drug-related homicides have pushed murder rates to record levels in cities across the country. All of this has occurred despite an eightfold increase in Federal antidrug spending. Clearly something has gone wrong.
Now the Democrats get their chance. During their years out of power, alternative drug strategies have piled up like Chinese menus under the door. Mathea Falco and Elliott Currie provide two new ones. Both authors criticize the Republicans for relying too heavily on law enforcement. Both reject drug legalization as too extreme an alternative. Both propose a new middle way for dealing with drugs. Otherwise, their approaches have little in common -- an indication of how sharply today's liberals can differ.
"The Making of a Drug-Free America: Programs That Work" comes with a seal of approval from the new Administration. Vice President Al Gore has publicly endorsed the book, and Ms. Falco was an adviser to Bill Clinton during the Presidential campaign. A visiting fellow at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, Ms. Falco says she decided to write the book as an antidote to the widespread pessimism she has encountered about drugs. At a meeting of Midwestern business and civic leaders, she says, a newspaper publisher asked, "How can we do anything if we don't know what works? We'll just have to write off this generation until someone comes up with some answers." Determined to find them, Ms. Falco spent five years visiting schools, clinics, treatment centers and community groups all over the country. She found many programs that did seem to work, and her book provides a sort of consumer's guide for policy makers.
In Westchester County in New York, for instance, Ms. Falco came upon the county's Student Assistance Program, "one of the most promising approaches to preventing teen-age substance abuse." In the program, health professionals working full time offer students at some schools regular confidential counseling. Ms. Falco attended a session at one high school in a plush suburb. Here, beside a lake, flower beds and a parking lot filled with expensive cars, a group of ninth-grade girls discussed the "Monday morning oh-no's" -- the foolish things they did while high or drunk at weekend parties.
Jill B., as Ms. Falco calls her, a social worker trained in adolescent development, offered advice about how to resist peer pressure to drink or smoke dope at parties. "We would die without Mrs. B.," one of the girls tells Ms. Falco. "She's the only person we can talk to honestly." A 1989 study of Westchester high schools found that the rates of drinking and drug use were one-third lower among students at schools offering the program.
In an inner-city Detroit neighborhood, Ms. Falco toured streets with members of a church-led citizens' group called Reach (Reach Everyone Administer Care and Help). Going beyond the usual street patrols, Reach engaged residents in a number of volunteer programs, such as feeding the elderly, operating a day-care center and, especially, renovating houses. Using local sweat equity, Reach bought and repaired two dozen houses, some of them previously used by drug dealers. By thus galvanizing the community, Ms. Falco suggests, Reach has managed to banish open drug dealing from the area and reduce property crimes by 25 percent.
Ms. Falco is especially bullish on treatment. She writes glowingly of visits to a therapeutic community in Tucson, Ariz., an acupuncture clinic in Miami, an Alcoholics Anonymous meeting in Boston, and Matrix, a program for wealthy cocaine users in Beverly Hills, Calif. "Drug treatment remains our best hope for breaking the costly cycle of crime and addiction," she writes, "but we have not yet begun to meet the nationwide need for new programs." Noting that treatment is available for fewer than 15 percent of the nation's addicts, Ms. Falco would channel funds from prison construction and border patrols into rehabilitation centers and methadone maintenance clinics.
On this point, Ms. Falco is quite eloquent. The United States, she declares, needs a "new vision" of drug policy, one focused on "reducing demand, changing attitudes and engaging citizen participation." The question is, does her vision go far enough?
Ms. Falco, who directed the State Department's antinarcotics bureau under Jimmy Carter, foresees a very limited role for the Government. "The most promising strategies," she writes, "are coming not from Washington, but from communities working to find new solutions to their drug problems." Federal spending to combat drugs, now $12 billion a year, is quite enough, she believes.
Without more public support, though, it is unclear whether local initiatives can succeed. Despite the achievements of Reach in Detroit, for instance, citizens' groups have generally had limited success in sweeping drugs from their neighborhoods. Most rely on the dedication of a few energetic individuals -- a quality not easily replicated. As one organizer from Pasadena, Calif., tells Ms. Falco, "Apathy is our greatest enemy. . . . To get the whole neighborhood involved is very tough. I've got a hard-working small group and I have to pull the rest in by their hair." Even when successfully mobilized, neighborhood residents seldom prove a match for Uzi-toting crack gangs.
TREATMENT and prevention programs, meanwhile, have had uneven success, especially among low-income drug users. The Westchester Student Assistance Program is a good example. In 1988, Ms. Falco notes, some of the program's counselors began working at six homes for abused and delinquent children in Westchester County. Most of the children were poor blacks and Latinos. The results were decidedly mixed: half the homes recorded "substantial declines" in alcohol and drug use; the rest had "much smaller declines." For the most part, school-based prevention programs have been less successful in depressed urban neighborhoods than in prosperous suburban ones. Not only do inner-city youths face far more serious problems, but many are not even in school to begin with.
"We know that a drug-free America is within our grasp," Ms. Falco states at the conclusion of her book. Yet as she herself notes, drug abuse, while declining among the educated and well-to-do, is rising among poor minority groups. In 1991 more than one-third of all Americans who reported using drugs at least once a month were black or Hispanic. For policy makers, the problem of addiction in the inner city remains the primary challenge.
The inner city is the focus of "Reckoning: Drugs, the Cities, and the American Future." Its author, Elliott Currie, a research associate at the Institute for the Study of Social Change at the University of California, Berkeley, maintains that the United States really has two drug problems. One is drug use among the affluent. While not insignificant, he writes, this is a "manageable problem" that has been steadily decreasing for several years. The other problem is drug use among the "have-nots." And this, he says, "has grown malignantly in the face of the drug war -- and it is much farther from solution than it was when that war began."
In a previous book, "Confronting Crime," Mr. Currie argued that violent crime in the United States reflects the grinding poverty and inequality in our nation's cities. In "Reckoning," he makes a similar argument about drugs. The United States has the world's worst drug problem, he believes, not because of its affluence or permissiveness but because of "deeper structural problems in our economy and society." To support this view, Mr. Currie draws on a storehouse of statistical surveys, sociological monographs and ethnographic studies dating back to the 1950's. Then (as now), drug addiction was widely viewed as a psychological phenomenon; addicts, Mr. Currie tells us, were considered "maladjusted" individuals drawn from all sectors of society.
In the early 1950's, however, a team of New York University researchers began recording all the cases of adolescent heroin addiction that came to the attention of the courts and hospitals in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx. It then charted those cases by census tract. The overwhelming majority, the researchers found, were concentrated in Harlem, Bedford-Stuyvesant and other poor neighborhoods. For the first time, Mr. Currie says, scholars had "pointed clearly to the central role of social and economic forces in addiction." Since then, he adds, numerous studies have borne out the point: "The link between drug abuse and deprivation is one of the strongest in 40 years of careful research."
Class, not race, is the key factor. Thus a survey of more than 1,000 disadvantaged youths in Baltimore, Detroit, Cincinnati and Providence, R.I., found that 19 percent of the Irish young adults admitted using heroin regularly -- virtually the same proportion as blacks in the survey. Since deprivation is most widespread among minority groups in the inner cities, Mr. Currie says, drug abuse is most acute in those areas. In his view, crack struck with such force not just because it was cheap and plentiful, but because social conditions were ripe. The loss of traditional blue-collar jobs in the 1970's and early 1980's helped to create a pool of unskilled, uneducated Americans. Just when they needed help the most, the Reagan Administration sharply cut social programs. "Had we set out consciously to prepare the ground for a fast-moving drug epidemic, we could hardly have done a better job," Mr. Currie writes. Crack "was like a match thrown on dry tinder."
Oddly, Mr. Currie does not discuss alcohol, the nation's most widely consumed intoxicant. Middle-class Americans who abuse substances are far more likely to use alcohol than heroin or cocaine. By limiting himself to illicit drugs, Mr. Currie may have understated the extent of addiction among better-off Americans. Nonetheless, he makes a convincing case for the role of root causes in generating the nation's drug problem -- a perspective long out of favor in Washington.
Mr. Currie is less convincing when it comes to solutions. Dismissing conventional treatment and prevention programs as palliatives, he holds that "in the long run, dealing with America's drug crisis means attacking the conditions that breed it." To that end, Mr. Currie advocates a national employment policy, an increase in the minimum wage, an expansion of the Job Corps, increased health care for the poor, paid family leave, affordable housing and, not least, a reduction in social inequality. "Over time," he proclaims, waxing lyrical, "we can shift the social and cultural balance -- turning blasted wastelands where the dominant youth occupations are idleness, drug dealing and sporadic work in poor jobs into vital neighborhoods where most of the young are either in school or working at respected jobs with a visible impact on their community."
Such a utopian agenda is, at bottom, a prescription for doing nothing. In these belt-tightening times politicians will no doubt find Ms. Falco's approach more appealing. Still, one hopes they will consider Mr. Currie's views as well. "Reckoning" is a provocative book -- precisely what we need in this time of political transition.

HEADLINE: Hard Landing in Tokyo

BYLINE: By David E. Sanger; David E. Sanger is chief of the Tokyo bureau of The New York Times.

 BODY:

THE BUBBLE ECONOMY
Japan's Extraordinary Speculative Boom of the 80's and the Dramatic Bust of the 90's.
By Christopher Wood.
210 pp. New York:
The Atlantic Monthly Press. $21. 
 ONLY in the Japan of the late 1980's would office workers and casual investors reach for their newspapers in the morning to check what golf club memberships are worth. More than any other published item (except perhaps for the news report that the land under the Imperial Palace had so swelled in value that it was worth more than all the property in Florida), the Nikkei Golf Club Membership Index took the measure of the financial insanity that until recently gripped Tokyo.
The reason the index attracted so much attention is that the club memberships were not about golf at all. They were about speculative crazes and, of course, behind-the-scenes national politics. For if you dug into the underbrush of a Japanese golf course, you were bound to find, along with lost golf balls, shady characters scheming with each other to enrich themselves, Japan's banks and the coffers of the country's ruling Liberal Democratic Party.
Now with the bursting of the multitrillion-dollar speculative bubble that brought the stock and property markets to remarkable heights, the covers have been ripped away from some of the most sordid aspects of the close relationships that keep the Japanese economy ticking -- most recently, the ties that bind Japanese business, organized crime groups and the country's politicians.
Christopher Wood, a correspondent for The Economist, has turned the details of the schemes that underlay Japan's financial boom, and now its bust, into a gripping account of how the greedy and the corrupt were able to lead the blind. Throughout the 1980's, he recounts in "The Bubble Economy," the accepted wisdom in Tokyo was that the property and stock markets could not plummet, no matter how overvalued they became, because "Japan Inc. would never let it happen." In fact, "Japan Inc." is not nearly as monolithic as many, in the West as well as in Tokyo, would like to believe. And when the supports that were holding up the speculative boom got kicked out one by one, with a tightening of credit and a sudden ending to Japan's free-spending ways, the markets began to tumble.
The results, Mr. Wood shows, were startling. Mighty brokerage houses like Nomura Securities, which seemed invincible in the late 80's, began compensating their biggest clients for their sudden stock losses in order to preserve their most valued business relationships. The securities houses should be thankful they got caught at this; in time, their effort to manipulate the market on the way down (a lot harder than manipulating it on the way up) would have bankrupted them.
Similarly, the giant banks were caught with enormous bad loans on properties that were now worth a fraction of what they once were. The banks are still denying these losses, for fear of the consequences if the depths of their misjudgments became known. The Government has abetted them, making sure that they are not required to tell their shareholders or depositors the ugly truth. It has come out anyway, as some of Japan's mightiest institutions have been forced to merge or dump their worst holdings. "The Japanese banks' preferred approach has been to sit on their hands and literally do nothing," Mr. Wood notes. "This has the merit of preventing them from having to admit to a loss, which would mean wiping out capital."
Indeed, the careful plans and endless strategies that propelled Japan on the way up have been notably missing as it has fallen back to earth. In part, Mr. Wood says, this was because hope was allowed so often to overwhelm logic, as it did for life insurance executives and Government bureaucrats who confidently came up with implausible justifications for the stratospheric land and stock prices. In part, it was because the few oversight mechanisms Japan had, especially in the Ministry of Finance, were one with the banking and securities industries. In part, too, it was because the biggest beneficiaries were the politicians, who found ways to funnel huge amounts of the finance and property industries' profits toward their own causes.
The question is: Is Japan still deluding itself? Mr. Wood observes that "the Japanese establishment still clings to the comforting though naive notion that the excesses of the bubble economy -- the supposedly fringe world of the stock market, property market and assorted speculative nonsense, such as frenzied trading in golf course memberships and the like -- were somehow distinct and separate from the core industrial economy and therefore could not harm it. Unfortunately, this is not the case."
True enough. But for those outside of Japan there is a different "comforting though naive notion" at work, one that Mr. Wood does not discuss. It is the idea that somehow the United States can relax because the Japanese have run into trouble. At best, though, the United States has been given a brief respite, a few years perhaps, for the Clinton administration to revive American competitiveness. We should remember that in recent years Japan has survived every economic crisis that was supposed to level it, adjusting more quickly than anyone thought possible. The energy crises of the 1970's and the Plaza Accord of 1985, which revalued the yen in an effort to slow the export machine, come immediately to mind.
The fact is that while research and development funds are now scarcer in Japan because of the market losses, and while new factories are not being constructed at so frenzied a pace as before, Japan is still rebuilding its manufacturing sector faster than the United States is rebuilding its own. Desperate as Americans might be for a signal that they can stop worrying about Japan, the collapse of the bubble economy is not it. Japanese-style capitalism, despite its ugly side, still has more than a few things to teach us.
Mr. Wood emerges with some reassuring conclusions that Japan's financial system is converging with the rest of the industrialized world's -- that the endless stream of scandals is forcing a change. One can only hope that he is right, but so far the evidence is scant. In the past few months alone, court trials picking through the wreckage of some of the "bubble" companies have uncovered a far deeper nexus of cooperation among business, government and organized crime than anyone imagined.
Indeed, there are still many in Japan who, as Mr. Wood puts it, are "yearning for the golden days when stock prices could be supported by administrative decree or rank manipulation." They are also yearning to keep the forces of reform at bay as long as possible. But it will be years before we know if they have won out.
