SECTION: Section 6; Page 18; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 5070 words

HEADLINE: The Reformation of a Street Preacher

BYLINE: By Catherine S. Manegold; Catherine S. Manegold is a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The New York Times.

 BODY:
Al Sharpton was up on the stage, that familiar voice booming and his words streaming in a hot cascade over an audience of teen-agers, most of them black, who strained forward in their chairs. The Democratic senatorial primary was long since over. But Sharpton looked as though none of that had really registered. Two months after his defeat, he was still running. His speaking, handshaking, protest marching, celebrity bow-taking, back-room strategizing schedule was so busy that his youngest daughter, Ashley, who is just 5 and perhaps does not yet understand what makes her father run, had to ask, finally, "Does Daddy know yet that he didn't win?"
Nothing that small could ever stop Al Sharpton. 
 "Hey," he shouted to the packed auditorium at the John Marshall High School in Rochester on a cloudy afternoon. "There is nothing hip or slick about being ignorant. And there is nothing hip or slick about going around killing each other for no good reason."
The kids shouted back. Connected. He was right. They knew it. They were jumping in their seats, locked onto every word, driving the school monitors a little wild as they cruised the aisles. It was a losing battle. Kids who later would sit listlessly in classrooms were spinning and twisting, clapping each other on the back, interrupting "the Rev" with little spurts of glee and agreement.
Sharpton rocked back and forth, leaning toward the thousand or so faces, drawing them to him like a magnet. He pulled them all in talking about Malcolm X, today's repolished hero, and about how "an X on your cap" means nothing "if you've got zero in your brain." He admonished, cajoled and shared his life. "Everything I always tried to do -- they laughed at," he boomed in a baritone swept by the cadences of Pentecostal preaching. "That laughter made me harder. You have to believe in yourself and stand by yourself and trust yourself. Ignorance is easy. It's easy to talk bad. The hard thing is to try to lift yourself up."
Called to Rochester to talk some sense into these kids after a shooting last September, Sharpton arrived to play his new role of father, teacher, politician and wacky, inspirational disciplinarian. The students were jittery at first, waiting to check out "Reverend 911," the guy who always comes when he is called. School officials worried that just his presence might make matters worse. But the speech won them over.
Afterwards, Mary Gallina, a secretary in the school's guidance office, rushed toward him. "You were great," she told him. "If you get to just six kids, it will be worth it." Later, she turned to a stranger. "You hear so much about him," she said. "And his old reputation. He deserved that. So, you hear he's changing, but you just can't imagine it until you see him personally."
THERE IS A STORY that Al Sharpton tells, invariably to laughter, of how loud and long he hollered as an infant. "I yelled when I was hungry," he says. "I yelled when I was wet. I yelled when all those little black bourgeois babies stayed dignified and quiet. I learned before I got out of the maternity ward that you've got to holler like hell sometimes to get what you want."
Standing in a typical pose, his thick legs spread wide like braces beneath that famously capacious frame, his dark hands laced across his paunch and his soft chin tucked back in a way that can, at times, seem almost childish, the Rev. Alfred Charles Sharpton Jr. cuts a singular picture of pugnacity. Thirty-eight now, and working to reform an image that has made him internationally famous as a rabble-rousing pain in New York City's side, he is yelling, still. Modulation holds no interest, compromise no real allure. He has always wanted to be the thumb in the eye, the tack on the park bench, the lone voice calling: "No justice. No peace." His bumper stickers said as much during his grass-roots, $63,000 run for the United States Senate last year. Bold orange and green, they were unmistakably Sharpton, a glaring challenge to complacency.
Yet something was distinctly different about the Sharpton that New York and the nation saw during the primary season. He was still talking passionately about injustice. But he seemed softer, more focused and more intellectually polished. In his own words, that change was the essence of simplicity: "It was time," he says, "to bring down the volume and bring up the program."
Others saw a new sophistication in his performance and said it was time, finally, to bring him into the fold. "No question about it, he's matured" says Representative Edolphus Towns, a Brooklyn Democrat who is the former chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus. "He's been out there for so long that sometimes people think that he is older than he is. But when he started, he was literally akid." The primary, Towns says, showed the city an older, more seasoned politician and a man who had finally "learned to knock on the right doors." Just as important, it showed New York power brokers that Sharpton had something that many more traditional politicians lack: an uncanny ability to reach the poor and chronically dispirited, voters who otherwise would turn away from politics. "There is a real commitment there," Towns says. "I have a lot of respect for him. He paid a lot of dues. He was the one who shook the trees. Some of us were the ones to come by and pick up the fruit. He can relate. But instead of saying 'Burn, baby, burn,' he's telling them, 'Build, baby, build.' "
Since the election, Sharpton has pressed this new public perception of his goals. He went with Towns to meet with Edward J. Perkins, the United States's representative to the United Nations, to talk about Somalia. He daily devotes himself to meetings and telephone conversations with prominent blacks and appearances at some of the most high-profile political events. On the day Mayor David N. Dinkins made a televised appeal for an end to the running conflict between New York City's blacks and Jews, the mayor spotted Al Sharpton in a crowd of prominent city leaders and greeted him with a bear hug.
Some of that change is earned, arising from basic political arithmetic. When he held his own in televised debates and held his temper on the campaign trail, some voters scoffed. But 166,665 others pulled the lever with his name beside it, giving him about 15 percent of the vote in the Democratic primary and landing him third in a field of four, ahead of Elizabeth Holtzman, perhaps forever changing the idea that this man with flowing hair and an endless avalanche of angry prose would never do more than pose for the cameras: part street preacher, part buffoon, persistent claimant to the heritage of black rage.
The primary battle silenced many detractors, whites and Republicans among them, who found "the Rev" more dignified -- that was the word they used -- than the seasoned politicians he faced. As Robert Abrams, the Attorney General, Geraldine A. Ferraro, the one-time Vice Presidential candidate and Elizabeth Holtzman, the City Comptroller, traded barbs, Sharpton followed the Rev. Jesse Jackson's advice to "fly above the storm."
Everyone took note. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, after one particularly vicious debate, singled out Sharpton by favorable contrast, "Because he was positive, because he was mature." The other three candidates, the Governor concluded, "all got hurt" in their debate. Reflecting on that change, Representative Maxine Waters of California, who herself successfully balances activism and mainstream politics, says she, too, was surprised by his transformation. "He obviously made a decision to show how smart he really is."
Sharpton's longtime supporters do not see much change. They maintain that American politics shifted with the Rodney King verdict and the race-related police beatings exposed since. They say the political mainstream is moving in Sharpton's direction, not the other way around. "The 'political experts' gave him no chance at first," says C. Vernon Mason, a lawyer who has worked with Sharpton for years. "I think that what has changed is that other people have changed. Once Mario Cuomo praised him, that had a major impact on the other elected officials. Now Mayor Dinkins knows that he needs Al Sharpton to win his own election."
New Yorkers were certainly startled by his new, buffed image. They had lived so long with Sharpton's angry sound bites that most started the primary season with an image of him as an irresponsible, inflammatory, race-baiting agitator hungry for publicity. They saw him as devoid of grace, a bashing plug of a guy dashing about in a jogging suit and Martin Luther King medallion, more interested in winning air time than in healing racial wounds. They recalled his former link with the New Alliance Party, likening the group to a cult. To most New Yorkers, Sharpton was the guy it was always safe to hate, the real-life equivalent of the wild-eyed street preacher who wreaked havoc in Tom Wolfe's "Bonfire of the Vanities."
To the nation he was a nightmare image, the ultimate expression of New York's fall from the epitome of sophistication to a troubled urban madhouse. Overseas, the image was sour, too. During a trip to London in 1991 the Brooklyn-born Sharpton was introduced to the reading public as "The Bronx Beast" by a slightly confused tabloid press. Conservatives in the House of Commons glumly discussed blocking his entry altogether -- only to be forestalled by the Home Office.
Cornel West, who heads the Afro-American Studies Program at Princeton, describes Sharpton as "in process." That is true. Since the primary, Sharpton has been offered many maps to his own future, including running for City Council President, a post likely to be vacated if Andrew J. Stein runs for Mayor, or for a House seat. But he has loftier ambitions, pointing instead to the Senate primary in 1994. "I plan to continue my drive for statewide office," he says, "and to run against Daniel Patrick Moynihan for the United States Senate seat."
Even as he plots his future, though, he runs. A typical day includes a dozen stops or so at schools, union headquarters, Harlem restaurants and the offices of politicians. He meets with Mayor Dinkins, Towns, Representative Charles B. Rangel and other New York politicians, editors, radio personalities. As he works to extend his political reach, he visits with Italian-American, Jewish and Hispanic voters, too, and bones up on environmental, gay rights and other issues in which he admits he needs education. Almost everywhere, but particularly in Harlem, he is stopped for a handshake and a word or two, an autograph or a bit of advice. Some people simply stop to gape, like the woman in midtown Manhattan who screeched to a halt on her high heels and stuttered: "Well! Al Sharpton! You look . . . just-like-you-look!"
Sharpton takes it all in stride. When the votes were finally tallied, he walked away with 67 percent of the black vote statewide, 20 percent of the union households and 16 percent among Hispanic voters. He sees that as just the beginning.
"You know, they never will admit that I have a core of people, a basic group that is behind me," he says of the political establishment. "They said I had about 200 followers. But 200 people cannot cast almost 170,000 votes -- I don't care where you went to school."
ALTHOUGH HE DID NOT recognize it then, Al Sharpton's process of political rebirth began two years ago, at 1:30 P.M. on Jan. 12, with a sudden blow to the chest and a dull stab of pain as a steak knife with a five-inch blade was plunged two inches from his heart. For a moment, he was startled. He thought he had been punched.
"I felt something brush past," he remembers. "But when I looked down, there was a knife sticking out of my chest. Instinctively, I grabbed the knife out and that's when the air hit and I went down." He crumpled to his knees, then slumped forward on the sidewalk as his assailant, a drunken 27-year-old named Michael Riccardi was tripped up and pummeled before police could bring the situation under control. Sharpton was rushed off to Coney Island Hospital where he was listed in serious but stable condition. The assailant was later sentenced to 5 to 15 years in prison, despite Sharpton's plea for leniency.
The attack came in Bensonhurst, a part of Brooklyn famous for the racial tensions that swirled around the death of Yusuf K. Hawkins, a black youth killed by a white mob in the summer of 1989. Sharpton had gone there, as he went most places, to stage an angry protest march accompanied by busloads of supporters, many of whom, the rumors went, provided their support only in exchange for money. (A former Sharpton aide testified in court that many young blacks were paid $5 each to show up at rallies.) More than 100 police had cordoned off a "frozen zone" intended to keep passions muted and Sharpton and his flock from harm. But Riccardi easily dove past the defenses.
Recuperating in the hospital, Al Sharpton suddenly found himself surrounded by some of New York's political elite. Mayor Dinkins, with whom he had always had strained relations, appeared at his bedside along with other prominent black leaders. To this eternal outsider, the laying on of hands of the establishment was strange and unsettling. "I'm always teasing Mayor Dinkins that I looked up and I thought I had died and gone to hell," he says with his deep, rolling laugh. "But I told the Mayor that I did not want violence because I didn't want to be remembered that way."
The person he did want to see was someone who for years has been both a mentor and a friend. He told his wife, Kathy Lee Jordan, a former backup singer for James Brown whom he met in 1979, that he wanted to speak to Jesse Jackson. The next morning, when Sharpton was wheeled out of the emergency room, the head of the National Rainbow Coalition was there to meet him. They talked at length about strategy, street protest and longterm goals.
Jackson's advice to calm down and spread a wider net went against Sharpton's grain. But he could not ignore it. "When somebody hits you two inches from your heart, you have to start thinking: 'Well, I could really die. How do I want to be remembered? Do I just want to be the guy who could vent?' You re-evaluate yourself."
Then, too, there is the inescapable fact of approaching middle age. "You get older," he says with a shrug. "I am 38 now. I am not 28. You begin to say: 'Our generation is in charge now, where is our base? Where is our power? If I stay one dimensional then where does the next generation go? They can either eliminate me or I can make room.' All of that ran through my mind."
It was time for a change, anyway. His street constituency had been dwindling for some time and his credibility was at a low ebb. The Washington Post, months earlier, dismissed Al Sharpton as a "professional provocateur," one of "an assortment of kooks, crazies and crackpots" given undue attention by the press and television. Other newspapers had turned against him, too. And by then, exhausted by Sharpton's steady stream of outrage, many blacks agreed.
AL SHARPTON doubtless will always have to answer for the old days. He was, even he admits, sometimes out of control, reveling in incendiary tactics that included picketing a meeting of city officials and prominent black activists with a sign accusing them of being "coons"; promising New York the most widespread civil disobedience the city had ever seen, and so stirring racial passions throughout the 1980's that, by 1990, a poll published by The Daily News found that 90 percent of whites and 73 percent of blacks in New York City believed that he was worsening race relations, not improving them.
It is the Tawana Brawley case, however, that has created the most lasting doubts about him. He aggressively sided with a 15-year-old black girl who claimed to have been raped, smeared with dog feces and abandoned by a group of white men. He took on the State Attorney General's office and indulged in a series of stunts and confrontations that, to many, reeked of self-promotion. He came across as both paranoid and opportunistic, willing to inflame race relations just to further his own fame. When a special grand jury dismissed the case as a hoax, he did not budge. To this day, he maintains that Tawana Brawley was raped, then abused by a judicial system that would not believe her.
Yet in talks with reporters after the case was dismissed, Al Sharpton showed the lengths to which he would go to manipulate the public and the press. In one instance, he acknowledged that his claim that he was taking Brawley into hiding for her own protection was nothing but a ruse. Instead, he merely took her out for an ice-cream cone.
There were other conflicts with the press. Once he lit out after a photographer in a rage. "That left the public image that I was out of control," he says. In that instance, he admits, he was.
Many New Yorkers saw a hint of that same recklessness just recently when Sharpton stood by Ralph Nimmons, a 25-year-old black man who was beaten in Crown Heights by Hasidim who accused him of burglary. Though the case was different, and Nimmons's injuries were indisputable, old fears of Sharpton's cynical manipulations resurfaced when Nimmons vanished the day he was due to appear before a grand jury. Yet Sharpton's basic point was one that few would dispute: No matter what Nimmons may have been doing in that alley behind Lubavitch World Headquarters, there was no justification for the beating he received.
For many, though, doubts about the "new" Sharpton linger, and old hints of impropriety still resonate. In 1989, he faced a 67-count indictment on charges that he stole $250,000 from charitable donors and cheated on his income taxes. He was ultimately acquitted of all 67 counts. Of three other taxcharges that lingered, two were dropped this month, after he pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge of failing to file a tax return in 1986, for which he was fined $5,000.
Even after all that, however, his accounting still seems lax. His $2,200-a-week operation runs on funds from public speaking and cash donations at his weekly Saturday rally for the nonprofit National Action Network, a loose-knit political group of which he is president. Though he retains an accountant and insists that his books are in order, it is hard to see how the funds can be tallied and how he can keep track of his daily expenses. The phrase "cash flow" for him has a literal meaning. As he spins through town, many of his expenses seem to be met with a wad of bills that he pulls from his pocket.
Sharpton answers questions about his taxes, his activism and his rhetoric with barely a shrug. He is calm in the face of a possible jail sentence that still awaits him, after conviction on charges stemming from a 1987 protest. When confronted with questions about his legal troubles, he leans back in his chair and recounts case after case of civil rights leaders being held to a higher standard than white politicians. He volunteers that his stint as an informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation -- he insists he did it only in response to the bureau's attempt to frame him -- would be a badge of honor for other politicians, who might cite it as a mark of their respect for law and order.
He waves off his youthful indiscretions, too. Now, he says, he has a higher calling, to reshape black leadership. "The battle of the 60's and 70's was to get blacks into office," he says. "The battle now is to get the right blacks in office. Clarence Thomas got into the Supreme Court. But he is the most reactionary black jurist that I have ever seen."
Cornel West ranks Sharpton with a half dozen or so young men and women who will define black activist politics in coming years. But theirs, he believes, is a delicate challenge: to pressure their elders without either alienating the black establishment or being co-opted by it. "Al Sharpton has been much more critical of the black establishment than the power club has ever been," West says. "He is now one of our most progressive voices. But the best way for him to proceed is to keep some kind of pressure on. Because if he just becomes another insider, his impact will erode and people won't keep listening."
The risk for Sharpton is clear: how to yell and yet seem reasonable. Some critics doubt that he can do it. "People in Scarsdale and those places see him and say, 'Oh, he is just going to support that one group,' " says one political veteran who spoke on condition that his name be withheld. "That's the problem you have. When you look at the profile of him in whiteAmerica, they say he is just out for black people." Even many blacks, he says, would turn away if Al Sharpton got too close to victory. "He came and spoke and we gave him a standing ovation," he says of ameeting of the city's black leaship. "But don't confuse that with going out and voting for him. I think he ought to stay out there -- outside. That is the place for his kind of pot stirring."
Mostly, though, New York's black leaders back Sharpton up, and stiffly reject suggestions that his temper could flare and knock him back. "He was the only one who brought not only humor but substantive issues to the campaign," Rangel says. "When you consider the percentage of the vote that he got, the past has already been answered."
Some of his harshest critics do not care to speak of him at all. Neither Robert Abrams, the Attorney General who faced him down over the Tawana Brawley case, nor Charles J. Hynes, Brooklyn's District Attorney, would comment on his change, or lack of it.
Sharpton, meanwhile, revels in his new prestige. "Now, when I go to talk to Governor Cuomo or anyone at the state level," he said after the election, "I talk to them with an established state constituency. Before, I was talking to them based on the yelling of the crowd or whatever media was covering the issue. That doesn't mean that I'm going to get everything I want, but they can't just dismiss my point of view."
TO UNDERSTAND THAT point of view and its roots, one must look backward at Sharpton's youth, his teachers and his upbringing. Preaching, he says, is where his education started. "I think it was a natural, inborn thing. Like we say in church, your 'call to life.' "
Born in Crown Heights, he found his voice in the church before he could either read or write. He preached his first sermon, "Let not your heart be troubled," at the Washington Temple Church of God in Christ in Brooklyn at the age of 4. Those who remember him from his pre-teens invariably say that he was precocious, demanding and wired, a "groupie" in a dark suit who had a way of charming himselfright into the center of things. "I met Al Sharpton when he was about 12," Jesse Jackson says. "He was a child prodigy. It was obvious that he had special gifts. And he had a will to lead early on."
It was before that meeting, though, that Al Sharpton's life had changed in a way that would inform it always. He grew up in a classic nuclear family rising gradually up the economic ladder. His father, a contractor, moved the family from East New York in Brooklyn to a 10-room house in Hollis, Queens, and did so well that the kids were squired about in twin Cadillacs.
Suddenly, when Sharpton was 10, his father moved away and his world changed. "When he walked out, the money walked out," he says in his spartan Brooklyn office, talking on a cloudy winter afternoon over the constant ringing of a telephone. His mother took work as a domestic helper and moved her son and 13-year-old daughter, Cheryl, into a project. One year later, in 1965, the family moved to what Sharpton remembers as a "five-room ghetto apartment" in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn. It was an experience that gave him a lasting sense of life's inequities.
"I knew that the world was better than this," he says. "In the project, I thought: 'No, I don't have to accept this. I know there's a better life. I know there's good schools. I know that the garbage man picks up garbage in some neighborhoods, because I lived in them.' So that really gave me indignation."
At the same time that his personal sense of outrage grew, his understanding of politics was developing at the knees of some of the nation's most prominent black leaders. Today, he unabashedly ticks off a list of men he adopted as surrogate fathers.
The first was Bishop Frederick Douglas Washington, who helped him find his way in the church and encouraged him to read theology. Then, still in his teens, he attatched himself to Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., minister of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem. In 1973, a year after Powell's death, he found another friend, the soul singer James Brown, whom he met after Brown's son died in an automobile accident. He worked with Brown through the 1970's, helping promote concerts and even styling his hair similarly.
"I did a lot of on-the-job training with people who are masters," he says. "To grow up under people like James Brown, Jesse Jackson and a promoter like Don King, I would have to be either retarded or totally incompetent not to learn something."
As an adult, he has tried to create the family core he lacked in his youth. Though his schedule gives him a seemingly endless string of long days, he talks proudly of his marriage of eight years, of his 5- and 6-year-old daughters and of the fact that his wife worked for years as an Army reservist to help pay the bills for his grass-roots politics. For several years, he and his family have split their time between a Crown Heights apartment and a house in Englewood, N.J., where they spend most weekends. This spring, however, he plans to move the family into a two-bedroom cooperative apartment in Crown Heights. He counsels his children not to follow in his footsteps. "The only advice I ever give my kids," he says, "is just don't come home with an activist. I've done enough of this for all of us."
THIS FALL AFTER THE primary, when Sharpton had to look ahead, he determined that he would, in the 60's tradition, keep on keeping on and worry later about his destination. His advisers form a bridge between his old life and his new identity. He still works with Mason and Alton H. Maddox Jr., the lawyers who worked with him (and became equally controversial) throughout the Bensonhurst, Crown Heights and Tawana Brawley periods. But he has added new names and faces, too, and stays in touch with them as he spins through town in his leased black Mercury Grand Marquis. On the road, he is in constant touch, a phone junkie forever linked to people like Spike Lee, local politicians, union leaders, the Mayor and a new legal and political adviser, Michael Hardy, an activist lawyer.
Between guttural, grunting phone conversations on diverse subjects, Sharpton's head sometimes drops back. He tends to fall asleep in an instant, snoring at high volume, making up for a schedule that seldom allows more than four or five hours of sleep a night. Then the car phone rings and he swings to attention, usually with a snort and a monosyllabic drawl: "Yeah. Hunh. Yeah. When?"
Day by day, he is moving fast through a new milieu. Cornel West says he was always impressed by Sharpton's perseverance and courage, but had not appreciated his intelligence. The two men met last April at Sylvia's, the famous Harlem soul food restaurant, to "chat" but ended up holding a five-hour marathon that Sharpton would later call the cornerstone of his re-education. The two men talked of politics, strategy and history, and West provided a reading list to help Sharpton fine-tune his political thinking. Among the books he recommended were "Who Will Tell the People? The Breakdown of American Democracy," by William Greider; "America: What Went Wrong?," by Donald L. Barlett and James B. Steele, and "Breaking Bread: Insurgent Black Intellectual Life," written by Cornel West and Bell Hooks, a feminist scholar and social critic.
Another new adviser is Patricia L. Irvin, a partner at the Manhattan law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, whom Sharpton credits with coaching him to relate to the "issues and fears" of the upper class. That coaching came only after Sharpton allayed Irvin's own fears. After meeting him during a luncheon hosted by the firm, Irvin later admitted to him that, as a black, she was nervous that he would come across as strident, foolish or ill-informed. Her first reaction, he recalls, was: "Oh, my God. He's the only black candidate running, and he's going to embarrass us because he's going to come on in here and say, 'No Justice. No Peace.' " Instead, he talked about the issues and the two quickly became friends.
Others have not been so easily won over. One prominent former elected official dismisses Sharpton's prospects, saying that the next generation of black leaders will come through more traditional political backgrounds. Some simply will never trust him, expecting him to go wild at any moment. "The guy symbolizes all the hatred and all the problems and all the anti-Semitism of New York City," says Noach Dear, a City Councilman who has savagely criticized Sharpton for his behavior in Crown Heights. "We will listen to him. But the degree of repentence must be equal to the degree of the sin. And Al Sharpton has been one of the city's worst sinners."
Sin. Outrage. The words pound a rhythm through Al Sharpton's days. "I am given to being flippant and just shooting from the hip," he admits. "I think I have been not looking at the broader picture sometimes and haven't been analytical enough. I've called the Mayor names and I've called other people names. But now I've learned."
Now he can picture a new future. Al Sharpton at 70. He stops a moment to think. "I'm writing my memoirs. I've been in the United States Senate for 20 years. And I am explaining to young people the days when we had to march to even get a prosecutor on a race case, something that is now automatic. I'm explaining to them that there was a day when I was very controversial and people had real emotional opinions of me. And I am wondering how I ever made it to 70."
His hair, he says, will still be long, but totally shock white. He pictures himself in the style of a British barrister, with that hair, that lasting trademark, a sign of distinction in the year 2024.

HEADLINE: ENDPAPER/LIFE AND TIMES;
Gunmen, $150 a Day

BYLINE: By Jane Perlez

 BODY:
On a misty July afternoon when I first arrived in the Somali bush town of Baidoa, two young workers of the International Committee of the Red Cross greeted me nervously on the veranda of their compound. A journalist, accompanied by a photographer with a bulging bag of equipment, was more than they wanted to cope with. We could stay the night but after that we were on our own. It had taken them weeks to gain the confidence of the suspicious Somalis who, with guns and no sympathy, lorded over this town they would later call the city of death.
In fact, our overnight hosts provided Fiona McDougall, the photographer, and me with a vehicle, four armed guards and a Somali translator, our essential tools for the next six months. We didn't have to go far to see what the Red Cross had been telling the world but few had chosen to believe. 
 Six months later, after tens of thousands had perished, humanitarian workers suffered from a more exasperating problem: too many journalists, with too much equipment and too much air time to fill. Suddenly, Somalia, a story that had come and gone in spurts -- an August wave of ghastly photographs, an airlift announced just before the Republican Convention, the United Nations flailing, Washington Congressmen hand-wringing -- was full blast.
WE KNEW THE SOMALIA STORY HAD arrived when the networks rolled into Mogadishu. The Marines and other American forces were coming, 28,000 of them -- nobody quite knew when -- and television had to be there to record the American-doing-good-for-the-starving-Somalis Christmas images. So about a week before the military waded ashore on the beach of Mogadishu, the airstrips suddenly got very busy. The bush planes that arrived every morning from Kenya with khat, the plant with amphetamine properties that Somalis use for their afternoon high, had some competition.
CBS was the first in, with a 707 bearing five tons of equipment, and an armada of light aircraft ferrying Dan Rather, and more than 40 reporters, producers and technicians. CNN, NBC and ABC were not far behind.
Where to house all the people and their planes full of satellite dishes, generators, phones, editing banks, sleeping bags and crates of bottled water? For a $17,000 deposit and the pledge that Mr. Rather could use his comfortable bedroom, the owner of the Shamu Guest House, rented his high-walled, triple-storied whitewashed building with views of the Mogadishu shoreline as CBS headquarters.
The place turned out to be perfect for television. When Mr. Rather was ready for a face-the-camera piece, a specially rented, theatrically painted "technical" would be wheeled through the front gate, its anti-artillery gun cocked at a provocative angle providing trouble-free but menacing atmospherics for the viewers back home.
A WORD ABOUT "TECHNICALS." AID workers in Somalia discovered early in 1991 that as clan warfare raged around them, they needed protection. So humanitarian agencies would rent souped-up jeeps, with outrider teen-aged gunmen from the bush -- "camel boys" -- as bodyguards. Wherever an aid worker went, his personal car, carrying several gunmen in the back seat, would be followed by a heavily armed, makeshift war machine, making a conspicuous two-car convoy.
There is some dispute among aid workers how the word "technical" came about. The pious say it was coined from the word used by some European armies for a self-contained military unit.
But probably more accurate is its derivation via expense accounts. Aid agencies found it difficult to describe to headquarters that they were renting, for up to $150 a day, gunmen to protect themselves and food deliveries. How would "gunmen, $150, daily rate," look on the monthly statements? So in suitable, vague bureaucratese, the gunmen and their vehicles were listed as "technical assistance," a euphemism that entered the Somali lexicon.
By Christmas week, when American buff-colored military trucks had replaced the gaily decorated Somali jeeps as the most ubiquitous vehicle on the Mogadishu streets, they were being called "American technicals."
THE MARINES AND THE journalists got to Mogadishu when the worst of the famine was over. Convenient words on American television aside, Somalis did not get miraculously better thanks to the Marines. Despite a lot of looting, the aid agencies and an American airlift from Kenya had pushed enough food into badly off areas in the months before so that by December the starvation had eased.
And by the year's end, the financial thrill of looting food had lost much of its attraction anyway. The price of rice in Mogadishu was probably lower than anywhere else in the world: 10,000 Somali shillings, or about $3 for a 50-kilogram sack, equivalent to about three packs of African-made Sportsman cigarettes hawked by street kids in the capital.
So with the looting of food no longer lucrative, the always opportunistic Somalis found other avenues for profiteering, namely manipulating the currency. Perhaps the most worthless money in the world, the Somali shilling doubled in value after the journalists and military arrived. With no banks, no law and no scruples a handful of Mogadishu money-changers made a killing.
"Sorry, Mr. McDonagh, the Somali shilling will be down to 3,000 by the end of the week," said Ibrahim, a money changer, to Mike McDonagh, the head of the aid agency Irish Concern, just before President Bush arrived. The shilling had been a steady 7,000 to the dollar; by mid-December it was 4,000.
The hike in the value of the shilling caused havoc to humanitarian agencies and also to journalists, who could better afford it.
One news organization -- The Times, as it happens -- paid $12,000 for one month's rent for a house -- without running water or electricity. If the basics had been working, the house might rent for $4,000 in New York City. On top of the rent came $100 a day for a tanker of water, $200 every other day for diesel fuel to run the tempermental generator and $150 a day for each car, with its driver, translator and pair of gunmen. The networks launched fleets of up to a dozen cars.
As the main thrust of the Marine action was about to end, and the cameras had moved on, what had been accomplished? The entrepreneurs had gotten richer. The camel boys were now unemployed. But Somalia's armory of weapons was largely intact, and the economy remained in tatters. That left the humanitarian workers, obscure once again, to grapple with a country still on the edge of chaos.

LENGTH: 894 words

HEADLINE: WINE;
The Price Is Ripe

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

 BODY:
A NEWSPAPER COLLEAGUE, propelled by talent and a touch of luck into the editorship of a major Midwestern daily, said to me:
"We don't run any wine stuff. No one in this town's going to shell out $30 for a bottle of wine." Allowing for the fact that that's the way editors talk, he nevertheless put his finger on one of wine's persistent problems: Most people think it has to be expensive to be good. 
 For many people, of course, the point is moot. In these uncertain times, $30 is food money or gas money, not wine money. Better times are ahead, we are told, but the signals are mixed. So, until the forecast clears, here are a few suggestions for good red wine -- this being the season for roasts and stews and other hearty red-wine food -- that costs no more than $10 a bottle. Not all these wines will be found in all locations but most are reasonably well distributed. And most, it is hoped, will change some minds about what's good.
Beaujolais, for example, was once a blue-collar wine, and even though it has moved up the economic scale a bit, it continues to be what it's always been: one of the best of all wine bargains.
There are plenty of different Beaujolais in this country, most of them good. And one of the easiest labels to find is Georges Duboeuf. Though Duboeuf bottles the offerings of many towns, it's impossible to beat his simple Beaujolais-Villages. It sells for around $6 in New York and, at the moment, it's still possible to buy the fine 1991 vintage.
With its thousands of chateaus, most of them small and obscure, Bordeaux produces more bargains in good wine than almost any other wine region in the world. But distribution is haphazard; the little chateaus to be found in one shop will rarely be found in another.
Luckily, a few fine Bordeaux properties are making enough wine to satisfy customers all over the map. Look for Chateau Greysac and Chateau Larose Trintaudon. Both make excellent Bordeaux for under $10 and both are not too difficult to find.
Wines from vintages maligned by the critics often turn out to be bargains. The 1987 Bordeaux is a good example. It was dismissed because it did not match up to some of the finer vintages flanking it. Even so, good wine makers make good wine, i.e., Jean-Louis Triaud at Chateau Gloria. His '87 Bordeaux is just right for drinking now, and it can found for as little as $9.99.
Cotes-du-Rhone is another perennial bargain but many of the wines are mediocre. Not so the 1989 of Marcel Guigal, which can be found for around $8. This big wine is made for hearty winter meals.
You could do a book on good Italian wines under $10. I recently tasted a delightful 1990 Frescobaldi Chianti that sold for $5. The sturdy Chiantis from the Castello Gabbiano cost a fraction more, but the Gabbiano Chianti Classico at about $8, is a buy. Try, too, the 1990 Rosso di Montalcino from the Fattoria dei Barbi, also about $8. Further north, in the Piedmont, Luigi Dessilani & Sons produce a variety of excellent wines made from the nebbiolo grape. The 1989 Spanna, which is what the nebbiolo grape is called in the Novara Hills, sells for about $7.
The Olympics introduced many people to Catalan wines. Torres is the best-known wine name in this part of Spain (Barcelona is the capital), and one of the best-known Torres wines is Sangre de Toro -- bull's blood. A soft but full-bodied red, it sells for about $6. Rioja, to the west of Barcelona, is Spain's best-known wine region. The excellent 1987 from the Marques de Riscal, is available in New York for about $7.
From Australia, Penfold's 1990 Koonunga Hill cabernet and shiraz blend is a remarkably full, rich wine at a great price: about $7. Rosemount's 1990 Shiraz at about $8 is also worth seeking out.
Hard times have taken their toll in California, and though there are still a few $75 cabernets around, hubris has taken a back seat to pragmatism. Look out for the old standbys: Beaulieu Vineyard's Rutherford cabernet sauvignon for just under $10 and the same winery's Beautour cabernet at around $7. Rodney Strong Vineyard's 1989 Sonoma cabernet sells for between $7 and $9 and the 1989 Hawk Crest, a second label for Stag's Leap Wine Cellars, is around $9. Both these wines are as good as others at double the price.
If you prefer an easygoing cabernet with no sharp corners and even a touch of sweetness, try Glen Ellen's Proprietor's Reserve. It usually sells for around $5 but I've seen it as low as $3.50 when sold by the case.
Estancia Estates, a label of Franciscan Estate Selections, adorns some excellent wines at affordable prices. The 1989 Estancia cabernet, at about $7 in some New York shops, is a true bargain. Marietta Cellars, in Sonoma, offers an intriguing blend of cabernet, zinfandel and other reds called Marietta Old Vine Red, which sells for about $6, and is worth every penny.
The Fetzer family recently sold the booming Mendocino winery bearing their name but their wines are still in the stores, and, as always, rank among the best California bargains. Fetzer's Barrel Select cabernet sauvignon, at about $9, is a wine that could grace any table, any time.
If better times truly are ahead, you may soon be in a position to pay $30 for a bottle of wine. Which is fine, but you'll inevitably discover that $30 is no guarantee that you'll do better than the wines suggested here.

HEADLINE: ART VIEW;
Money, Prestige, T-Shirts -- and Even Art

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

 BODY:
One of the more curious spectacles this autumn was the sight of out-of-towners frantically checking their watches. Like amateur air-traffic controllers, they were calibrating traveling time from the Modern to the Metropolitan, from the Whitney to the SoHo Guggenheim, factoring in tricky variables like closing days and, of course, arranging everything around the Matisse tickets they had bought months in advance. The lines that stretched all the way from the Modern down 53d Street and up Fifth Avenue for the poor souls who had not bought advance tickets were eclipsed only by the mob at the Met on the Sunday the Magritte show closed. You would have thought the museum was giving the art away.
Every week, it seemed, another important show opened in New York City. Not only Matisse at the Modern and Magritte at the Metropolitan, but also an exhibition of the 17th-century master Jusepe Ribera at the Met, a survey of the Russian avant-garde at the Guggenheim uptown, Rauschenberg's early work and Chagall murals at the downtown Guggenheim, retrospectives for Agnes Martin and Jean-Michel Basquiat at the Whitney, and an overview of the 19th-century French painter Frederic Bazille in Brooklyn. When the Matisse show closed this past Tuesday, it effectively brought to an end an exhibition period so frenzied, even by the standards of this city, that it had everyone wondering what had happened. 
 "The great international art exhibition is passe," Thomas Hoving, as director of the Metropolitan, wrote in 1974. He wasn't alone in thinking so. The blockbuster, which originated decades before Mr. Hoving brought King Tut to town, was declared dead more often than Bill Clinton's prospects for the Presidency. Yet just as President Clinton is unpacking his sax and shades in the White House, the blockbuster reigns.
So what exactly is a blockbuster?
There is still little agreement about the meaning of the word. Try Webster's, and the first definition you will find is a "bomb that can demolish a large area," which may apply to the Guggenheim's Russian behemoth of 800-plus works but which is not otherwise relevant here. The second definition is apropos, although still not precise enough: "a particularly powerful, forceful or effective person or thing; specif., an expensive or pretentious movie, novel, etc., intended to have wide popular appeal." (Isn't it interesting that this applies almost as well to Mr. Hoving as to his Tut show?)
Blockbusters needn't be big in terms of the number of objects they include. The Tut show had only about 50 works. And most big exhibitions do not turn out to be blockbusters. Impressive international loans are usually at the heart of those that do; yet content isn't the issue, really. A blockbuster can be as scholarly and focused as the late-Cezanne show that was such a hit at the Modern several years ago or as unfocused as the Vatican treasures exhibition earlier at the Met. You may think of blockbusters as hyped events, with lots of advance publicity. But the late-Cezanne show was an unanticipated blockbuster.
To qualify as a blockbuster, an exhibition must be a crowd-pleaser of extraordinary proportions. The Matisse and Magritte shows qualify. About 900,000 people saw the Matisse show during its four-month run, and had the Modern not limited tickets to 6,900 a day, who knows how many more would have stuffed themselves into galleries often so crowded that they resembled the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during trading hours. After the Picasso retrospective of 1980, which was seen by 1.1 million people, the Matisse show was the best-attended exhibition in the Modern's history.
During its two-and-a-half-month run, the Magritte retrospective was seen by about 453,600 visitors, an average of 7,000 a day -- more people, in other words, than saw the Matisse show. (Tut still rules at the Met, with an average of 10,600 visitors a day.) Even more impressive, a survey of out-of-town visitors to the Magritte show suggested that about half of them had come to the city specifically to see it and/or the Ribera exhibition (which attracted a respectable but modest total of about 142,000 people).
Are big shows big moneymakers?
You might assume that with all those people paying to see these shows, the museums housing them rake in big bucks. Wrong.
Some shows are breadwinners, of course; but contrary to popular belief, modest shows that don't attract the biggest crowds can be the most profitable, while blockbusters often end up costing a museum money. "They're usually expensive to put on, and in most cases they don't raise the full cost it takes to organize them," said Emily Rafferty, the Met's vice president for development and membership. "I think you'll find that blockbusters on the whole don't make money."
Museums figure costs and earnings in different ways, and their public estimates may not always be reliable: nonprofit institutions don't necessarily want to be seen as making large profits or taking heavy losses. Whatever the case, the Guggenheim says its Russian show was seen by almost 250,000 people and ended up setting the institution back tens of thousands of dollars.
The museum's math is complicated: the show cost $1.15 million to put on, at least $375,000 of which the Guggenheim calculates was covered by "in kind" support like the transportation of art by Lufthansa. Lufthansa also gave about $60,000 in cash, and the Frankfurt museum where the show was presented before it came to New York accounted for another $350,000.
Because the museum could not find additional corporate sponsorship, it hiked admission fees for the show from $7.50 to $10. The museum estimates that admissions accounted for $470,000. Because the net loss on the catalogue, to date, is $130,000, the bottom line is a debit of at least $25,000. "We're struggling to break even through catalogue sales," said Michael Govan, the deputy director.
The Ribera show cost $530,000 to mount, which includes packing, shipping, insurance, installation and so on. At the Metropolitan, which does not sell tickets to specific exhibitions, it is difficult to determine precisely how a show does financially. Still, even though the Ribera exhibition was supported by a $350,000 grant from Argentaria, a Spanish banking consortium, and other grants, the museum estimates that it probably cost the institution about $100,000.
Nothing demonstrates more clearly the current recession's effect on museums than the fact that no corporate sponsor could be found for the Met's Magritte show, which cost $450,000. Last spring the museum even contemplated canceling it.
Taking into account the number of people who paid admission to the museum because of the Magritte show, who bought spinoffs like Magritte posters, who ate in the museum restaurant and parked in its garage, officials at the Met have concluded that the fifth most popular show in its history did little more than break even.
The Matisse show was something of an anomaly. The cost was at least $5 million, slightly less than half of which was covered by a donation from Philip Morris. The contribution was generous. But when a sure-fire hit cannot cover even half its costs through corporate gifts, that is further proof that corporate sponsorship has become scarce.
The practice of selling tickets for a specific show within a museum, as the Modern did with Matisse, costs money. Another Matisse cost involved the drop in admissions revenues during the weeks before and after the show, when the galleries where it was presented have had to close. Although Richard Oldenburg, director of the Modern, emphasized that the museum does not yet have final figures on the exhibition, he said "there is no question we will have made money, certainly several hundred thousand dollars, although probably less than people think."
If these shows don't guarantee big returns, then why do museums do them?
The short answer is that nonprofit institutions are not in the business of making money. The full answer is more complicated.
Museum directors insist that shows are organized for their contribution to learning, and that if such shows become blockbusters, so much the better. In fact, popular exhibitions mean increased membership -- a whopping 14,000 new members joined the Modern during the Matisse show. They mean lots of people passing through the front doors who might not otherwise have come to the museum -- and who may return. They also mean happy trustees and sponsors, whose satisfaction can translate into future support. Moreover, many museums depend in part on public money, and the clearest way to demonstrate their value to the public is through impressive admissions figures.
Yet these very incentives to organize blockbusters can also be disincentives. Sponsors may be attracted to a museum by its blockbusters, but they may expect blockbuster returns for each investment. They are not necessarily interested in the vast majority of shows, which attract smaller crowds. Trustees at museums where blockbusters have made money can come to feel that museums should solve their money problems by focusing on mega-shows. More than one museum has failed to take into account that much of the rise in attendance and membership during a show is temporary. "These shows distort your figures because they set levels which you're not going to match normally," Mr. Oldenburg said. "You hold on to some of the new members, but not all."
Some institutions have expanded their operations based on blockbuster numbers only to discover that they can't support themselves. This causes them to conceive of shows with blockbuster results in mind. That proposition is not only risky financially; it also degrades the museum. "Blockbusters can be profitable and that's one of the big dangers with them," said Philippe de Montebello, director of the Metropolitan. "They can suddenly make the exhibition program look like a cash cow, which invites depreciation of the currency of art. Such an attitude invites abuses, and it attacks the intellectual integrity of the institution."
Mr. Oldenburg agreed: "Too many shows are cynically and badly calculated to be popular -- 'Treasures of X' shows, for example, that have no substantial purpose otherwise. Blockbusters are seductive. And if the content is right, there's nothing wrong with having a big popular success. But even if you wanted to, you couldn't produce these too often, especially nowadays."
Will there be continue to be mega-shows?
 This autumn's spree partly reflects a last gasp of 80's optimism, a delayed reaction, since most of the shows were conceived years ago. It also reflects serendipity. Since it takes so long to put an exhibition together, some inevitably fall by the wayside or must be postponed for one reason or another. This year, many shows on the books were realized, and a few, like the early-Rauschenberg exhibition, which turned out to be available at the end of a tour, were added at the eleventh hour.
For as long as there have been blockbusters, museum directors have been saying that major exhibitions are becoming harder to produce. Still, recent economic changes have clearly made it more difficult to assemble the sort of ambitious loan show that is the most likely blockbuster. Insurance costs have risen while corporate support has dwindled. Companies like United Technologies, Mobil, I.B.M. and Chrysler, significant sponsors of exhibitions during the booming 80's, have drastically curtailed their arts financing or dropped out entirely, and the number of new players is small. For a while, museums like the Metropolitan could rely on European companies to pick up the slack, but now Europe is in a recession. "Corporations are still spending money on marketing," Mr. Rafferty said, "and sponsorship of an exhibition provides good visibility for them. But everybody recognizes that it's tougher than it's ever been before. It's not the priority when people are laying off employees."
Museums try to set aside money to cover costs of shows. The average annual cost at the Met is between $6 million and $8 million, not including catalogues. But the museum allots only $1 million of its $85 million yearly operating budget for the exhibition program, which underscores its dependence on corporate help. At the Modern, where the average annual cost of shows is between $3 million and $5 million, officials are trying to build up an endowment that at present generates only about $350,000 toward exhibition expenses.
The forthcoming schedules look leaner than usual at institutions like the National Gallery in Washington and the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, where, among other things, new directors have yet to make their mark. But despite the financial strains, there will, of course, continue to be mega-shows with blockbuster aspirations: the National Gallery is planning a major de Kooning show; the Modern will stage a big Miro show; the Met has a huge Impressionist exhibition in the works; the Art Institute of Chicago is planning a Monet retrospective, and there's plenty elsewhere, including a survey in Paris of 16th-century Venetian art that looks to be one of this year's most glittering events.
At the same time, in straitened circumstances, museums are having to think about more modest shows and shows that depend on their permanent collections -- typically less glamorous undertakings, if no less beautiful and instructive, than the big international loan exhibitions. As a measure of things, consider the precarious state of a medieval Spanish art show, a potential blockbuster, which at the moment is on the docket at the Metropolitan. Mr. de Montebello flew to Spain 10 days ago to seek corporate support. He learns this week whether the corporation comes through. If not, the Met says, the show will be indefinitely postponed.

HEADLINE: LAUGHING OFF THE RECESSION

 BODY:
It was I who, with my colleague Bob Freedman, hired Diane English as a secretary at WNET ("Laughing Off the Recession," by Hilary de Vries, Jan. 3). We had a wonderful time, and indeed, Diane and her husband, Joel Shukovsky, have remained my friends.
What Diane may not remember, or may never have known at the time, is that at a certain point it became clear that we needed to give her a real raise if we wanted to keep her. Public televison wasn't exactly Fort Knox, and all any of us were getting as raises that year were cost-of-living increases. I tried to get my boss to take the percentage I was supposed to get and add it to Diane's increase. He couldn't do it. 
 Although that circumstance certainly wasn't the start of a chain of events leading to her success, it is another piece of the story that might let people aspiring to their dreams believe they can come true, even from modest beginnings.
 
HOLLY M. REDELL
New York, N.Y.

HEADLINE: Once-Sleazy Timeshares Gain New Vacation Respectability

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD

 BODY:
THE concept of a timeshare vacation had never appealed to Sandy Bowman of Cincinnati. "Buying a studio for a specific two weeks at the same resort didn't seem that attractive," she said.
Like many vacationers, she had been pestered by hard-sells and even toured a few resorts. "But nothing persuaded us to buy," she said.
Last spring, when Ms. Bowman, her husband, Chuck, and son, Adam, now 11 years old, visited Disney World, in Orlando, Fla., they took a look at the Disney Vacation Club, the company's first time-share venture, started in December 1991. 
 "We heard it was a pleasant experience and no one would pressure us to buy," Ms. Bowman explained. When the Bowmans returned to Disney World the following August, they had decided to buy a time share there.
"We trusted the Disney name and liked the fexibility they offered," she said. Instead of selling specific weeks in perpetuity, Disney offers purchase points that the buyer can spend to create different kinds of vacations.
Each point costs $56.50 and the Bowmans bought 230, the minimum number allowed, which they can use for three weeks in a studio or one week in a one-bedroom house in the spring or summer. Or they can switch to a two-bedroom house in the fall. They can even bank their points over to the next year and splurge on one week in a three-bedroom, four-bath villa.
This new flexibility, tied to the entrance of many high-profile companies, like Disney, Marriott, Westin and others, is giving the time-share industry a new respectabilty. In fact, some are predicting it will be the next wave in the vacation business.
"People who wouldn't have winked at time sharing before now have a comfort level with the big companies involved," said George Leposky, communications director for Interval International, a vacation exchange service for time-share buyers. "And the luster is rubbing off on some of the lesser-known resorts as well."
Demographics also seem to be working in the industry's favor. There are indications that ownership of second homes will rise dramatically in the next 20 years as baby boomers reach the ages of 45 to 64, the group accounting for 48 percent of recreational property owners, according to American Demographics magazine.
"This increased demand for second homes should benefit time sharing, since many people don't have the money for a full-time second home," said Brad Edmonson, editor of American Demographics.
Typically, a week at a time-share resort costs an average of $9,500, according to the American Resorts Development Association, the trade group representing time shares. The term is usually 25 to 50 years, and there is an annual maintenance fee, which can range from $200 to over $1,000, depending on the resort.
"I can't afford my own condominium, especially the maintenance of one," said Chuck Giglio of Miami, who owns four time shares in Florida. "I like the fact that I can share my expenses with 51 other people."
Time sharing is really an infant industry in this country. Started in the French Alps, it was exported here in the 70's.
"After initial growing pains, it's starting to be a mature industry now," said Bill McCreary, senior vice president of Westin Hotels and Resorts, which operates a time-share resort in Lake Buena Vista, Fla., bordering Orlando.
The industry has grown dramatically in the last decade. The American Resorts Development Association reports that more than 440,000 time-share weeks were sold in 1991, a 340 percent increase over 1980. The gross sales volume in 1991 was $3.7 billion (the latest figure available), a more than 650 percent increase over 1980.
The United States has 43.6 percent of the world total of time-share resorts and Americans account for 60 percent of all time-share owners.
In the industry's early years, abuses were rampant, from overselling of units, bait-and-switch tactics and outright embezzlement. By the mid-80's most states had begun regulating the selling of time shares, requiring the licensing of salespeople, the registration of developers, bonding for completion of improvements and an escape period for those who bought contracts.
"In almost all states, especially those with a lot of time shares, there are extensive protections for the consumer," said Stephany Madsen, vice president of state legislative affairs for the resort association. "The sleazy operators have long ago been put out of business."
"THERE'S no question that the industry is better regulated now than it was in the early 80's," said Tom Bell, chief attorney with the Florida Department of Business Regulation. "But there are still problems of enforcement. So the consumer must still use his head."
Mr. Giglio has seen both sides of the situation. One of his time shares, in Key Largo, Fla., went bankrupt and another, in Marathon, Fla., fell into disrepair. "The most important thing to watch out for is that the resort has good management and that it's well maintained," he said.
Mr. Giglio's most recent time-share purchase was at Disney. "With that kind of company, I figured that accountability is going to be to the dime," he said. "And I'm pretty sure they're not going to go bankrupt."
Disney has already completed 197 timeshare units at Orlando and is building 150 more. The company hopes to build a total of 500 units eventually.
"We're also considering building more clubs in established resort areas in other parts of the country," said Mark Pacala, general manager and senior vice president of Disney Vacation Club. "We expect to make an announcement early this year."
MARRIOTT was the first of the major players to enter the timeshare business, in 1984. The company now operates 16 resorts and has sold units to 40,000 owners. It is currently building a 280-unit resort in Hilton Head Island, S.C. The first phase, 60 units, is scheduled to be completed in June.
"Marriott was a trendsetter in that regard," said Mr. Leposky of Interval International. "When they first got into the business, other big companies waited for them to make fools out of themselves. Instead they were a howling success and soon it was like critical mass -- everyone followed."
A major part of the reason for that is that hoteliers all over the world were hit hard by the recession. Saddled by a huge supply of empty rooms and falling profit curves, they were eager to latch onto any new opportunity.
In contrast to Marriott, his company has been "tiptoeing into time shares," said Mr. McCreary of Westin. At the start of last year, it began converting the Blue Tree Resort, a rental and condominum complex in Lake Buena Vista, , into a time-share resort. "We feel its's a solid opportunity," said Mr. McCreary. "Consumer trends indicate a preference for a guaranteed vacation experience. And we can provide it."
Other big names now in the time-share industry include Ramada International Hotels and Resorts, which acquired a 214-unit complex in the Bahamas that it is converting into a time-share resort, and Hilton Hotels Corporation, which formed a partnership with Grand Vacations Ltd., calling the new enterprise Hilton Grand Vacations.
To overcome the industry's negative image, the new time-share operators are being very careful about how they sell units. Disney, for instance, has a 30-day cooling off period after a contract is signed, allowing the buyer to change his mind; Florida requires only 10 days. Most time-share resorts are affiliated with one of the major vacation exchange services, Interval International and Resort Condominiums International. This allows people to swap their time-share weeks with other owners around the world.
A recent survey by resorts association showed that 80 percent of time-share owners cited the exchange opportunity as a primary motivation for buying a time share.
Unlike other real estate transactions, however, time shares should not be considered an investment. Reselling them can be next to impossible, unless one has bought at one of the top resorts in the country.
"Time shares should be bought for vacation fun and savings over the long term," said Ms. Madsen of the American Resorts Development Association. "It may be they're like cars that depreciate the moment they leave the showroom. But as a vacation investment, they're ideal."

HEADLINE: Delegation Gains Posts To Guard Home Front

BYLINE: States News Service

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
NO one knows exactly what it takes to win a coveted seat on a major Congressional committee because voting on assignments takes place behind closed doors. The ingredients seem to be a predictable political mixture of seniority, networking, regional affiliation and power of personality.
Whatever the magical formula, the Connecticut delegation managed to work wonders in the waning days of 1992, coming out of December's assignment frenzy with appointments to four of the most prized committees. The assignments will add to the delegation's clout in the 103d Congress, influence already enhanced by its building seniority and enviable connections to the new White House. 
 "The delegation will have infinitely more power," said Peter Sloan, a Washington lobbyist and Connecticut native. "Its Democratic members are now so well-placed that the delegation is really in a position to get things done for the state."
The possibilities include insuring Connecticut's military-dependent economy suffers as little as possible from Federal budget cuts, as well as guaranteeing that the state receives its share of money for transportation projects, military projects and for programs to help companies convert to civilian enterprises.
New committee assignments include the appointment of Representative Rosa L. DeLauro, Democrat of New Haven, to the House Appropriations Committee, which holds the pursestrings in Congress, and Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, Democrat of Hartford, as one of three liaisons from the tax-writing committee, the House Committee on Ways and Means, to the Budget Committee.
House Republicans voted Representative Gary Franks of Waterbury onto the House Energy and Commerce Committee, which has jurisdiction over more than half the bills that move through the House. And in the Senate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of New Haven, won a seat on the Senate Armed Services Committee, which draws up the Pentagon budget and has a hand in deciding such issues as whether another Seawolf submarine is needed. Mr. Lieberman also will probably be appointed the chairman of a subcommittee on the Senate Environment and Pubic Works Committee.
 
'Helps to Be at the Table'
 "It really helps to have members of the delegation in more powerful positions because decisions aren't always made in the public eye during committee meetings," said Terry Meulenberg, spokeswoman for Gov. Lowell P. Weiker Jr.'s Washington state office. "It's crucial to have those people to make contacts and build those relationships that will help the state get what it needs. It helps to be at the table."
Ms. Meulenberg heralds Ms. DeLauro's appointment as most important for the state because the Appropriations Committee makes the decisions which states spend what money."She will be looking out for the state's interest on that committee and making sure Connecticut is as well protected as it can be," Ms. Meulenberg said.
Ms. DeLauro will be on the Labor, Health and Human Services Subcommittee, which covers health-care issues. Health-care reforms are expected to be considered in this session. Ms. Meulenberg said Connecticut, like most states, has been hard hit by spending cuts on medical care. Money is desperately needed for drug- and alcohol-abuse treatment programs, community health centers and AIDS care, she said.
Ms. DeLauro said she would also use her position on the Appropriations Committee to insure that Connecticut received aid for education and job-training and diversification programs and for cleanup efforts in Long Island Sound. "It will be a way in which to address national problems and, at the same time, to address our problems in the state of Connecticut," Ms. DeLauro said.
 
A Backup in the Senate
 Mr. Lieberman, who also has forged a strong relationship with the Senate Appropriations Committee chairman, Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, will insure Ms. DeLauro's work is not undone in the Senate. But Mr. Lieberman will do most of his bidding for the state in his new assignment to the Armed Services Committee, where he will look out for Connecticut's extensive military-dependent industry.
Mr. Lieberman's committee seat comes at a time when major Pentagon cutbacks are expected. The end of the cold war presages a re-evalution of the country's military needs and the will be in a position to influence the tenuous transition period, according to Peter Kelly, a political consultant and longtime Democratic Party leader.
"Joe has done a brilliant job of developing the right relationships and he is widely regarded as the most effective member of that class," Mr. Kelly said. "The delegation will need to preserve critical contracts that major employers in the state fought hard to win."
Mr. Kelly said the Senator, who is a friend of President Clinton since their law school days at Yale, would have a series of battles ahead of him, not least of which would be holding President Clinton's "feet to the fire on Seawolf."
Mr. Clinton voiced his support for the nuclear submarine during his election campaign, but it is not yet clear whether he supports the construction of a third Seawolf. Senator Lieberman said he was beginning to lay the groundwork in Congress for the battle to finance another Seawolf and has scheduled a meeting this week with Adm. Frank B. Kelso 2d, Chief of Naval Operations and the highest-ranking Navy official.
Mr. Lieberman is expected to make the case for maintaining a strong military base. "Once you have dismantled our defense, it will be very difficult to resurrect," Mr. Lieberman said. "I will be concerned with both national security interests as well as those of Connecticut."
Mr. Lieberman's appointment is especially important for the state because Connecticut lost its only representation on the committee in the House when Mr. Franks secured his appointment to the House Energy and Commerce Committee, which has some of the most far-reaching powers in Congress.
In his new slot, Mr. Franks will contend with issues like Medicaid financing and nuclear energy. Mr. Franks said he would use his position to enact welfare revisions and to enforce state laws for collecting child support.
Mr. Franks said he also hoped to push a series of bills introduced last year to revitalize deteriorating urban centers, including providing incentives to corporations to invest in urban areas.
 
A Boon for Machine Industries
 Connecticut's machine tool and ball-bearing industries may also get a boost from Representative Nancy L. Johnson, Republican of New Britain, and Mrs. Kennelly, both appointed to the Trade Subcommittee of the Ways and Means Committee. Mrs. Johnson and Mrs. Kennelly plan to work together to protect these industries from unfair competition and to insure they receive government support.
"We will use our position to make sure Connecticut industries are not unfairly taken advantage of," said Mrs. Johnson, who was largely responsible for forcing the Department of Defense to buy ball bearings from domestic producers.
Mrs. Kennelly's appointment to the Budget Committee is also seen as a boon for the state. She already has her finger on the pulse of Congressional power as the Chief Deputy Whip. Her appointment as Ways and Means Committee liaison to the Budget Committee will give her more power to shape budget priorities, influence tax policy and set the agenda for the House.
Mrs. Kennelly, a seven-term lawmaker, last week reflected soberly on her growing influence and the decisions that will be made. "This week of celebration will end," she said. "It will be followed by many difficult choices and tough years."
