HEADLINE: Have Snow, Forget the Travel

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH

 BODY:
EVEN though machine-made snow is the staple of their existence, Connecticut ski areas have always been affected by weather factors miles away.
"Unless they see snow, a lot of people, particularly beginners, won't go skiing," said Ed Beckley, general manager at Mount Southington. "They have to see snow before they think skiing." 
 Within the ski industry, that is known as the "snow in the backyard" snydrome. And for more than a week now that syndrome has proved a boon to the state's five ski areas, since many people living in Connecticut, New York and Massachusetts can look outside and see snow.
The sight of snow, after three light snowfalls within four days in mid-January, has given Connecticut ski operators their best year's start in recent memory. Thousands of skiers turned out a week ago at the five ski areas, all of which offered excellent conditions during what for many people was a three-day weekend because of the observance of Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday on Monday.
"It was the best weekend we've had in years," said Carol Lugar, owner of Mohawk Mountain in Cornwall, the state's largest and oldest ski area, with the highest vertical drop of 660 feet. "Not only did we have plenty of snow, but we had sunshine, too."
Connecticut ski areas, while they were able to make snow, had little sunshine and natural snow the last two winters, which were among the mildest on record. Coupled with the recession, the unseasonably mild weather kept many skiers away from the slopes, both in Connecticut and farther north. But so far this year, cold weather has enabled the state's ski operators at Mohawk, Mount Southington, Powder Ridge, Ski Sundown and Woodbury Ski Area to blanket their trails with machine-made snow. "The natural snow is just so much frosting on the cake," said Rick Carter, president and owner of Ski Sundown in New Hartford, the state's northernmost ski area 22 miles northwest of Hartford.
 
Snow, Deep Snow
 Ski Sundown, the state's second-largest ski center in terms of trails and skiable acreage, got a huge helping of "frosting" on Dec. 12 when two feet of snow fell. That snowstorm, combined with several snowfalls since then, has given Sundown its deepest base in years, as of last week up to 40 inches.
"The last three years were tough," said Mr. Carter, a former math teacher who has owned Ski Sundown since 1978. "It was a combination of the weather and the recession," he said. "But so far this year, we're off to a great start."
Largely because of the recession and in an effort to lure skiers back after two virtually snowless winters, the state's ski operators have essentially held the line on lift-ticket prices. Mohawk has actually reduced the price, to $29 from $30 for adults, seven days a week. Mount Southington and Woodbury, the state's smallest ski area, are charging the same as last winter. Mount Southington, which has 12 trails, charges $26 on weekends and $22 on weekdays, while the price at Woodbury, with 15 trails, is $20 every day. Ski Sundown and Powder Ridge, which is in Middlefield, between Meriden and Middletown, charge $28 on weekends, up a dollar from last year, and $24 and $22, respectively, on weekdays.
Prices for rental equipment have remained about the same as last year, the operators say. Lift-ticket prices for juniors and skiers 65 years and older are usually less. Half-day tickets and those for night skiing, which is now offered at each of the state's five ski areas, tend to be about $5 cheaper.
 
Staying Closer to Home Slopes
 Though the recession may have kept some skiers home the last few years, Mrs. Lugar, at Mohawk Mountain, said she believed the poor economy might have helped business. "I think it actually has been positive for us," she said. "People have been more cautious about their spending and not as willing to drive great distances to ski."
Connecticut ski areas, besides being heavily dependent on machine-made snow (ski operators abhor the term "artificial" snow), rely almost entirely on day-trippers for their business. Though the vast majority of skiers drawn to the state's ski trails are from Connecticut, some come from nearby areas of New York, New Jersey and Massachusetts. But in almost every instance they return home after skiing, since the Connecticut ski areas are not "destination resorts," like those with lodging and other amenities farther north.
However, the state's ski areas do serve food and beverages and sell skis and other accessories. And at one, Woodbury, which is about 15 miles west of Waterbury, there are weekend ski parties in the lodge.
Though it is the state's smallest ski area, with a vertical drop of 300 feet, Woodbury is also the most unusual. Downhill skiiers (downhill is the most popular form of skiing) are usually outnumbered there by cross-country skiers and, at times, by snowboarders. "We may be small, but we do a lot of different things," said Rod Taylor, owner and manager. "About half of our business is cross-country, and we have 15 miles of cross-country trails, which is more than any of the other places."
 
Make Way for Snowboarders
 Until this month, though, most of those cross-country trails had not been skiable for five years because of a prolonged snow drought. During much of that time, Mr. Taylor said, cross-country skiers were able to ski on machine-made snow on a two-mile trail, part of which is lighted at night.
Mr. Taylor said that snowboarders account for anywhere from 20 to 50 percent of the business at Woodbury. "We were the first place in Connecticut to allow snowboarding," Mr. Taylor said in referring to the sport that primarily appeals to teen-agers and young men. Originally known as "snurfing," snowboarding employs a single board similar to those used in surfing and skateboarding.
Most skiers and ski areas were slow to accept snowboarders, who initially were restricted to a specific trail. Now they are welcome at all Connecticut ski areas, which even rent out boards and offer lessons while permitting the snurfers on most trails.
"We were the last of the holdouts in the state, but we haven't had any problems or complaints since we started permitting snowboarding three years ago," Mr. Beckley, at Mount Southington, said. "We had to face up to the fact that it's the fastest-growing winter sport in the country."
 
A Revival Sport
 At Powder Ridge, crowds last weekend numbered in the thousands, with as many as 3,000 skiers on hand on Sunday, according to David Harlow, general manager. "It was the third-best day since I came here in 1984," Mr. Harlow said.
"Last year was a little better than the year before, which was about as bad as it can get," he said.
For those not inclined to try downhill or cross-country skiing or snowboarding, Mr. Taylor at Woodbury has turned back the clock and in effect gone full circle when it comes to snow sports. His newest snow activity? Sledding, which he says has proved as popular among adults as with children.
"All you've got to do is bring a sled along and for $10 you can go sleigh-riding down the mountain," Mr. Taylor said. "And if you don't have a sled, we'll rent you one for $5."

HEADLINE: New Effort To Teach Homeless Children

BYLINE: By PRISCILLA VAN TASSEL

 BODY:
A STUDENT at the Burnet Street School in Newark recently learned how to read.
For most elementary school students, that might not seem a notable accomplishment, but for this homeless sixth grader, who has attended 10 different schools in the last year and a half, it represented a major triumph. Through intensive remedial instruction during school and a tutorial program after school and on weekends, he has been able to make up much of the learning time he lost while moving from temporary shelter to temporary shelter, surrounded by the chaotic welfare-hotel environment of drug dealing, gunfire and neglect. 
 At a time when the number of homeless children in New Jersey's schools continues to rise, these children are beginning to benefit from new federally supported programs in effect since Octoberaround the state.
"When you think of homelessness, you don't think of children," said Dalia Georgedes, coordinator of the New Jersey Department of Education's Office of Education for Homeless Children and Youth. But, she said, 60 percent of the homeless are families with children.
Despite a decline in New Jersey's unemployment rate, school districts say that, more and more homeless children are showing up in the schools. In East Orange, for example, the total jumped from 614 in the 1990-91 school year to 684 last year. In Newark, school officials say homelessness is on the rise and is probably double or triple the official state count of 892 students for that city.
The increase, Mrs. Georgedes said, is being felt beyond Newark and Camden, "in areas that have never had to deal with it." Communities like Englewood, Prospect Park, West Orange and Montclair have begun calling the New Jersey Department of Education for assistance.
In addition to the expense and logistical problems associated with busing students from welfare hotels and shelters, districts are finding that homeless children often have psychological problems that require remedial education and counseling to compensate for the confusion of their home lives.
Charles Lagos, who runs an after-school arts program in Hackensack for the homeless through the Bergen County Special Services School District, said that his students, though not learning disabled, show many behavioral patterns often associated with the learning disabled.
"They're not acting up or being disruptive," he said, "but these youngsters are desperately clingy and in terrible shape emotionally."
Until this year, districts received little financial assistance in coping with the homeless. But the reauthorization of the Stewart B. McKinney Homeless Assistance Act has made more Federal financing available to support supplemental programs for the homeless.
One such program offers science instruction on Saturdays for students, accompanied by their parents. Ruth Schumacher, supervisor of financed programs for the Bridgeton schools, said it was easier to capture elementary school children's attention with science because many viewed it as magic. Older students are serving as lab assistants.
During the school day, parents living in shelters are visited and given information on services and housing.
"It's basically anything to make it simpler for the family so the child can get all the services he can," Mrs. Schumacher said. "Our philosophy is to take it to them. Don't insist that they have to come to you all the time."

 
Never Played Softball
 In East Orange and Newark, families gather for dinner once a week as part of the school district's after-school tutorial programs for the homeless. In Newark, the time is split between academics and recreational activities, since many of the children have never learned to play group games like kickball or softball.
Another program financed through the McKinney Act is an after-school tutorial project in Pemberton, which is offered by a consortium of districts in Burlington County. Trenton has an after-school program for homeless high school students.
The rewards of such supplemental programs can be high. In East Orange, 85 percent of the students enrolled in a pilot after-school tutoring program for the homeless saw improvement in their grades. Most students attending Newark's after-school tutorial program for the homeless are now performing at or above grade level.
Teachers involved in both programs say the improvement in performance can be credited not simply to the extra tutoring but to the nutritional benefits of the supplemental meals the students receive.
Last year, a City University of New York research project on stress and homeless children indicated that they share two fears -- that they will be physically harmed and that someone close to them might die.
 
'Survival Is a Priority'
 "Education isn't a priority; survival is a priority for these children," said Sheila Guions, a guidance counselor at the Burnet Street School and coordinator of its after-school tutorial program for the homeless, where the C.U.N.Y. study was conducted.
The reasons behind homelessness are varied. Many of the children have drug-abusing parents. Some children are living in shelters for victims of domestic violence. In Belleville, a new program of supplemental instruction and support services at a domestic violence shelter is expected to reach more than 250 children this year.
"These kids are not only homeless; they have to deal with the emotional problem of domestic violence," said Mark Solimo, director of special programs for the Essex County Educational Services Commission. "Counseling is a really important and vital part of the program."
But the vast majority of homeless children are victims of harsh economic times. "The primary reason is the economy," said Michael Del Pozzo, director of pupil personnel services in Asbury Park, where the homeless count is, he said, "way ahead" of last year's.
Just how many New Jersey children are homeless is difficult to gauge, in part because of the constant movement of families, but also because of the large number of the "hidden" homeless -- parents and children who are too ashamed to admit they are without shelter. Teachers say they sometimes find out inadvertently, through something a child has written or said, and even then they are often confronted with denial.
 
State Numbers Nearly Double
 In 1988, the state estimated that there were 14,439 homeless school-aged children. Two years later, after a broader survey, the official estimate climbed to 29,527.
New Jersey was one of the first states to pass legislation protecting the rights of homeless children. Under the law, which was enacted in 1990, the school district in which the parent or guardian lived before becoming homeless has responsibility, in consultation with parents, for determining the education of the child.
The law was intended to encourage some continuity in a student's education, and in most cases, officials say, it appears to be working. Before 1990, children would usually enroll in whatever schools were closest to their temporary residences, even if it meant switching schools dozens of times. Now most remain at their original schools until they are permanently settled.
"Our district maintains the position that until the family is securely nestled in its new home, that it would be to the child's advantage educationally to have them be maintained in the same school district," said Geraldine Staadecker, family consultant in East Orange, echoing the policy most school districts have adopted.
There are a few exceptions, however. In some cases, the distance children would have to travel to attend their original schools is so great that commuting becomes impossible. Also, in cases of domestic violence, they enroll in the schools closest to their shelters to maintain a distance from the violent parent.
 
Praise for an Agency
 Educators and advocacy groups for the homeless praise the Office of Education for Homeless Children and Youth as an effective source of information and lobbying.
"We're usually pretty critical of these agencies, but they've done a good job," said David Schiarra, a senior lawyer with the New Brunswick-based Legal Services of New Jersey. "They're responsive, they get right on things and really resolve them, and they have a good sense of what's going on."
Mr. Schiarra said that a number of years ago there was "a lot of agitation" about school districts' handling of homeless cases, but with the creation of the office in 1988 and a state advisory council of homeless parents and representatives from shelters, advocacy groups and school districts in 1990, "the level of complaints has dropped off to nothing."
Ceil Zalkind, associate director of the Association for Children of New Jersey, also has high praise for the tiny Office of Education for Homeless Children and Youth, which consists of Mrs. Georgedes, who works part time, and one full-time aide.
"They've done an outstanding job," said Ms. Zalkind, a former state advisory council member. "Every time I say that, I say it with a bit of surprise because our track record with the D.O.E. on other issues hasn't been great."

HEADLINE: A SENSE OF PLACE

BYLINE: By Michael Norman

 BODY:
A new column, "A Sense of Place," begins today in the New Jersey Weekly; it will appear on the fourth Sunday of each month. The author, Michael Norman, a former New York Times reporter, is an associate professor of journalism at New York University.
In the column, Mr. Norman says, he will explore "how the dislocations of modern life -- economic, political and psychological -- have shaken our sense of place and order and made us re-examine our notions about the cities, towns and villages we call home."
MONTCLAIR 
 THIS was not my town. I was not born here of an old family from one of the stone mansions or gabled summer homes on the hill. I arrived a college student on a weekend break, come to see the large house my mother and stepfather had just bought for their circle of seven.
I was the oldest, already out of the nest, and although I rarely touched down here in the years that followed, years on campus or in the barracks, I came to think of this place as native soil -- green and familiar. The family was happy then, together and content as it has never been since.
And no doubt because of that, the town became a place of myth for us. Long after we left, it lingered in memory. Even now, more than 20 years and thousands of miles away, none of them can talk of this place without longing for home.
I alone came back. It was the beginning of a new decade, the 1980's. The swan in Edgemont Park was gone, but skaters still took to the ice in the winter, and the greensward of the long oval park beside it was still inviting. The old ice-cream parlor on Valley Road was gone, but up the street, the red brick firehouse still stood, and so did the big white-faced clock in front of the bank. A new town hall had gone up; the Police Department got the old building, gray stone and stout.
The Wedgewood Cafeteria was still around -- 50 years of roast chicken and potatoes. There were more antiques shops than I remembered, and more pizza parlors. A video store had opened, but the Bellevue Theater with its balcony and brass rail still had Saturday matinee specials. Walensky's, a dreary haberdashery for "working men," was as durable as ever. Blue jeans bought there always seemed to have a tougher gauge.
And finally, there was the big green house on Erwin Park Road that my stepfather had bought and remodeled, 13 rooms on a corner lot with a gentle slope, someone else's home now.
I was married and a father when I returned. Beth had landed a professor's job at a nearby university, and I was sending off manuscripts to New York. The budget was threadbare, and we should have settled someplace else, someplace cheaper, but the surrounding precincts seemed pale.
They did not have the long streets with colonnades of pin oaks and Norwegian maples. They did not have the Iris Gardens, the train depots, the Art Museum, the parade on the Fourth of July. And even if those other places had been as green, as genial, they would not have had the feel of this place. I had history here, a sense that I belonged.
So we ate hot dogs and frozen vegetables and put a deposit on a railroad flat of an apartment in a two-family house a stone's throw from the busy main drag, Bloomfield Avenue. The house sat on the edge of an asphalt parking lot, and our quarters were hot and dusty. At night, the lot seemed to draw muscled young men in sleeveless T-shirts -- from other towns, I imagined -- who drank from bottles in brown paper sheaths and took long drags from the same twisted cigarette.
Beth was promoted, I went to work for The New York Times, and soon we'd saved enough for a down payment on a house, a small two-story
Colonial on a long, narrow lot with four massive pin oaks that formed a canopy over the large backyard.
The house was in desperate shape, but we grabbed the deal. I wanted a piece of the place I'd once called home.
And yet, back in town over a year at that point, I could not fully recapture the sense of place that was so palpable when my family first lighted in town years before. Something was wrong; something was wanting. I could feel it, but not give it form.
Then I spotted an ad for a garage sale at my parents' old house on Erwin Park Road. The family that had bought it was moving, lightening its load. I thought a visit might help make my return complete.
I got there at midafternoon and lingered until the detritus was sold and the last of the customers turned away. Then I introduced myself. "Oh," the mother said, "so you're one of the Hellers." (My stepfather's name.) And then they took me through the place, slowly, room by room.
Here again was the huge kitchen with the center island and breakfast nook where the family gathered after first light. Here were the butler's pantry, the dining room, the huge center hall where, every Christmas, we stood a 12-foot spruce. Here was the front porch where I embraced my mother as I went off to war. Up the stairs were the master bedroom and sitting room, down the hall the children's rooms, and on the third floor at the end, the chamber that once was mine.
I walked the empty halls and listened for the echo of old footfalls. But it did not help. The house seemed smaller and worn -- a stranger's house -- and I came away as unfulfilled as before.
What did I want? In the dry age of alienation, I wanted a place to refresh myself, that's all, a place that matched memory.
And then, slowly, I began to see: the town had moved on, but I hadn't. My idea of home -- safe, peaceful ground ruled by the laws of rectitude -- was a product of desire. In short, I was chasing a myth.
When I finally turned forward instead of back, I realized that every month something was happening to unmask the illusion I was trying so hard to embrace.
The Wedgewood Cafeteria closed. A sprawling restaurant with a King Cole mural on the wall and busboys in yellow waist jackets, the Wedgewood was our town's common table -- everyone ate there, from the shoeshine man to the mayor. Hahne's department store closed; I'd bought presents there for three generations of family. The balcony in the Bellevue Theater came down to make way for a "triplex"; the toy store shut its doors; the five-and-dime went out of business too. And it wasn't long before every block of stores seemed to have the same four anchors: a monotony of banks, real-estate offices, Chinese takeout shops and video stores.
The psychic dissolution was worse. My neighbor in the house on the left announced he'd lost his job -- a victim of the recession that had yet to touch me. His wife and daughter seemed to keep more to themselves after that.
A short time later, the couple in the house on the right started a domestic war that ended in divorce. We had shared a lot across our common divide of peonies and hedges. On warm summer evenings, we exchanged news and invitations to drinks and dinner. When things turned sour, their sorrow drifted across the divide.
In the end, we watched him load up his car and leave. Then she sold the house and took the children away. We have a picture from next door on our mantelpiece -- their little boy and ours, hugging each other.
Across the street, a woman we knew came home one day to discover her husband hanging in their bedroom. The block was dark and quiet after that. I would sit on a window seat and stare at the front of their house, at the door she entered the day she found him.
Not long afterward, Charlie the contractor -- a short, genial man who loved mussels in red sauce -- unexpectedly died of a heart attack. I went to Charlie's wake with two neighbors. It was crowded when we arrived; not an empty seat in the room. I took a Mass card and stepped to the coffin to pay my respects.
Charlie seemed a quiet man, the sort who would deliver a kindness, then slip silently away. When it snowed, he'd crank up his front loader, scoop out his own driveway, then cross the street to mine. By the time I had a shovel in my hand, the job was done, and there was no sign of the driver or sound of his yellow machine.
I know from all of this, and so much else since, that home is not a matter of two-by-fours or topography. Home is complicated, and like all complex truths it is slow to reveal itself. One must examine the small things; one must search the unexpected places. So I've become a perambulator, trying to get a new sense of place, a feel for a thing that is constantly changing.
Perhaps it's in the office of the eye doctor or the alcove of the Congregational Church. Maybe it's under the oaks at the cemetery on Valley Road or in the dark, malodorous lobby at the Y.M.C.A. The cleaning ladies might know it, the black and Portuguese women with worn faces who make the long bus ride from Newark up Bloomfield Avenue to the big homes on the hill. I can look in the schoolyards among the knots of angry boys who sometimes bloody one another's noses, or possibly in the stooped ranks of the weathered floriculturists who weed the town's iris beds.
Maybe I should go back to Edgemont Park and walk the oval that surrounds the great lawn. Little Ben, my Ben, the younger of two, will soon play ball there, just as his brother and uncles did, hitting home runs that roll along the greensward toward the pond where the white swan no longer swims.

HEADLINE: Building the Electronic Superhighway

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
AMID all the sweetness and light at Bill Clinton's seminar on the economy last month came a not-so-harmonious exchange between Robert E. Allen, chief executive of A.T.&T., and Al Gore, then Vice President-elect.
The topic was the development of Mr. Clinton's No. 1 priority for improving the country's infrastructure: a national "superhighway" for data. This high-capacity, high-speed computer network could do for the flow of information -- words, music, movies, medical images, manufacturing blueprints and much more -- what the transcontinental railroad did for the flow of goods a century ago and the interstate highway system did in this century. 
 Mr. Gore said the enormous network of fiber-optic cable and sophisticated switches should be built by the Government. Mr. Allen disagreed.
"I was hoping we'd have one disagreement before lunch," Mr. Clinton quipped.
Polite and brief though it was, the discourse got to the heart of a widening dispute among some of the nation's most powerful industries, the new Administration and public-interest advocates. That dispute is over how best to build, and control, a project widely viewed as a national resource that would improve education, health care, scientific research and the ability of corporations to compete in the world economy, among many other things.
On A.T.&T.'s side are the nation's other long-distance phone companies, which own and operate the nation's voice communications network quite profitably and stand to lose big if they suddenly face competition from a more advanced network they don't control. They argue that the data superhighway should be built, owned and operated by private companies, including themselves. Agreeing with the long-distance carriers is a diverse group including opponents of industrial policy and those who say that Government can't afford to pay for a data superhighway, that a viable network could be fashioned much less expensively from the current telephone network.
 
Gore's Argument
 Mr. Gore argues that the private sector won't gamble on such a risky investment. Even if it did, he says, it would build not a superhighway available to all but rather a kind of private toll road open only to a business and scientific elite. He says a new national data highway should be a public network constructed and regulated by the Government for all Americans. Indeed, the whole project would be a key test for the industrial policy that Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore view as a way to revive the economy.
The regional Bell operating companies, which could profit by delivering the data from the superhighway to homes and businesses, might well support Mr. Gore because they think the Government can get the superhighway up and running most effectively. Public-interest advocates for groups like the nation's librarians and educators also support a large Government role to prevent them from being excluded from the network.
Also on Mr. Gore's side are computer makers like I.B.M., Apple and Digital Equipment, which hope to gain as the network creates a greater demand for new computers. Like the Bell companies, they think the Government can make the superhighway happen most quickly. Businesses offering information services, like Prodigy, Compuserve and America Online, take a similar view.
The data superhighway will carry data on hair-thin glass fibers at thousands of times the speed of today's digital systems and will link a computer user at home or work to a multitude of services that are either not available today or are time consuming, difficult to use and expensive.
As now envisioned, when the data superhighway is finished early in the next decade, a student whose local library proved inadequate for research could tap into an enormous electronic library once available only to elite scholars. Someone with a personal computer could ask a supercomputer far away to help solve a complex problem. Health care could become more efficient because computerized patient records, containing not just words but X-rays and other medical images, would be instantly available to any hospital or clinic; a faraway specialist, for example, could therefore make recommendations in a local case. Scientists, engineers or product developers far from each other could collaborate because their computer screens would become a sort of electronic blackboard for everyone to work on.
A couch potato could summon any movie ever made by pushing a button. Working at home could become a snap because one's personal computer could retrieve and manipulate information just as fast as the office work station; communicating with fellow workers would be far more natural because the network could handle videophone conversations.
The data superhighway will also alter the way manufacturers work with customers and suppliers by allowing the huge volume of orders and records that now go back and forth on paper to be exchanged electronically. Mr. Gore also thinks dozens of information industries will be spawned, promoting economic growth.
"What we are talking about is nothing less than a revolution in the way we communicate," said Lawrence H. Landweber, a University of Wisconsin computer scientist who has been a leader in developing an early version of the data superhighway. "The complexity of the task is so great that it is absolutely essential that government and industry work together."
 
An Existing Version
 A primitive form of the data superhighway already exists. Construction began in 1969 when the Department of Defense financed the design of a computer network to link a handful of universities, research laboratories and military bases. Since then, that has mushroomed into a matrix of more than 9,000 interlocking networks communicating over existing telephone lines and touching down in 102 countries. Today, most of these networks are still used by the Government, universities and research laboratories to communicate and share information. But there is also a rapidly growing number of businesses offering information services and electronic mail to companies and individuals.
Although there are no accurate estimates, it is widely thought that more than 10 million people are connected over the global network, which has come to be called the Internet. Some estimates indicate that the number of people connected is now doubling annually.
 
What Is Needed
 But the Internet conveys data much too slowly and does not reach enough people to have the kind of impact that Mr. Gore envisions.
Creating a much faster data highway that reaches as many homes and businesses as today's telephone network would solve that, but it will cost hundreds of billions of dollars. The nation's long-distance and local telephone switches cannot handle the flood of data that would be carried over the superhighway, and must be upgraded. And the nation's copper phone wires must be replaced by higher-capacity fiber-optic cables; that has already happened for long-distance lines, but not for local telephone lines that connect homes and businesses to the closest switching center. Finally, software must be developed that would allow such huge amounts of data to move effortlessly over such a complex network, and allow tasks like transmitting X-rays or video from a teleconference.
 
The Gore Proposal
 Mr. Gore, whose father championed the nation's interstate highway system in Congress, argues that a data superhighway should be built by the Government and then operated by private industry. The result could be a powerful competitor for the long-distance carriers.
His scenario resembles what has happened with the Internet: Government financing paid for the construction of the network, but virtually all of the services are being provided by the private sector, under the supervision of the Government.
So far, however, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore have not articulated a detailed plan. Henry H. Perritt Jr., a member of the Clinton Administration transition team on telecommunications issues and a law professor at Villanova University Law School, thinks that a plan will emerge quickly, perhaps within 100 to 200 days.
But he suggested that the Government would play an active role in building a data superhighway. "I think the telecommunications industry is not moving very rapidly," Mr. Perritt said. "If the Federal Government sets out to build a high-speed digital infrastructure, that will be a kind of competitive spur. You will have competition between private and public sectors and that would be a wonderful thing for the infrastructure."
The kind of Government-industry cooperation that Mr. Gore envisions can perhaps best be seen in legislation he pushed through Congress two years ago as a Senator. Called the High Performance Computing Act of 1991, it authorized $2.9 billion in financing over five years for the development of a National Research and Education Network (N.R.E.N.).
If completed, that network would raise the capacity of the Internet to more than 3 billion bits -- the equivalent of 300 copies of "Moby Dick" -- per second, up from 45 million bits, the capacity of the current backbone of Internet. Today the N.R.E.N. projects consist of five Federally financed "testbed" centers where industry and university researchers are developing techologies for a data superhighway.
In short, the Government is financing the development of advanced technology that may be the basis for the data superhighway. What isn't clear, however, is who will finance the construction of the network, who will own it and how it will be regulated.
Mr. Allen of A.T.&T. is comfortable with the Government's role in developing new technology but is uncomfortable with the Government's building a network that would compete with that of the phone companies. That should be left to private communications and computer companies, which are already rapidly deploying new kinds of data networks, he feels.
"I think the Government should not build and/or operate such networks," Mr. Allen said at Mr. Clinton's economic seminar. "I believe that the private sector can be and will be incented to build these networks."
Mr. Allen has company. Although the rapid growth of computer networks has been subsidized to a significant degree by the Government, many computer executives think future Federal investment in building networks is wrongheaded.
"The Government should declare victory and get out," said Mitchell D. Kapor, a computer industry pioneer who co-founded the Electronic Frontier Foundation. The Washington-based foundation is conducting a campaign to persuade state and Federal officials that the quickest way to a data superhighway is to permit the deployment by the phone companies of a digital technology called Integrated Services Digital Network (I.S.D.N.).
Deploying this technology would offer a shortcut by using existing copper telephone cables to enable every home in America to have computer communications as easily as using a telephone and for just about the same price. But while the technology is largely developed, many people think it isn't fast enough, and the phone companies have run into problems in winning approval from state public utility commissions on the proper rates to charge.
Mr. Kapor said the I.S.D.N. could be easily upgraded to a higher capacity once new markets open. Those who back him say I.S.D.N. is the best solution in light of the difficult economy facing the Clinton Administration.
"Everybody sees a big feeding trough, but I'm not sure where the money is coming from," said David Farber, a University of Pennsylvania computer scientist who was a creator of the original proposal to build the experimental N.R.E.N. with Government financing.
Some economists wonder whether huge Government investment in a data superhighway will be wasted because there is no strong evidence that markets exist for the services it would offer. They point to costly commercial failures like the Bell Laboratories Picture Phone fiasco of the late 1960's as well as the failure of the SBS broadband corporate satellite network of the late 1970's.
But Mr. Clinton, Mr. Gore and Robert B. Reich, the new Secretary of Labor, all favor long-term investment in infrastructure and are likely to take a more activist approach than their Republican predecessors toward Government involvement in areas like building telecommunications networks.
Their view is cautiously supported by the regional Bell operating companies, which have been urging the Government to build a "backbone" for a data superhighway that they could then extend to homes and businesses using additional fiber-optic cable and switches that would be the equivalent of feeder roads.
Other industry and public-interest groups think there is room for a large Government role in building the network. This month members of a computer manufacturers' group called the Computer Systems Policy Project, which includes I.B.M., Apple and Digital, called for the creation of a Government entity to be chaired by Mr. Gore and called the National Information Infrastructure Council.
The council would direct Government spending, possibly more than $3 billion annually, for computer-network development as well as for existing Federally developed networks that are part of the Internet.
Electronic information services and other businesses that would use the data superhighway argue that private industry has been slow in developing it and that Government involvement is necessary to create the market for advanced networks.
"Your perspective on this depends on whether you already own a network or not," said Stephen Case, president of American Online, a commercial information service that has recently connected to the Internet. "There needs to be a core infrastructure and I don't care how we get there. If the Government kick-starts the market it will happen more quickly, and that makes sense."
This kind of spending, according to some economists and industry executives, would help create markets that are not now being pursued by private industry because of the prohibitive costs of developing new technologies.
 
The Public Interest
 Perhaps the organizations most concerned about losing out if the Government does not play a big role in the data superhighway are libraries, schools, hospitals and other public institutions.
If the highway is built and run by private interests without significant Government investment, these institutions might not be able to afford hooking up to the network.
"There is the danger of the public interest being lost here," said Carol C. Henderson, deputy director of the Washington office of the American Library Association. "We see libraries as the public institution available everywhere that could be the safety net for those who can't afford such access."
Indeed, said Marc Rotenberg, Washington director of the Computer Professionals for Social Responsibility, "in the final analysis the success of Gore's information superhighway won't be measured by frames per second but by who has access and on what terms. Those are the real policy questions."
 
 
REVOLUTIONIZING THE WAY WE DO THINGS
 THE primitive version of the data superhighway known as the Internet has already become a way of life for some students, teachers, researchers, government officials, office workers and executives.
It foretells the coming of a world in which virtually all aspects of modern life, from shopping to making medical diagnoses, will take place electronically.
In the future, say advocates of Vice President Al Gore's data superhighway, with the advent of extremely fast computer networks connected to homes and businesses, we will be able to order any movie with the press of a button rather than going to the video store. Medical specialists in the best hospitals will be able to help doctors in remote areas after examining X-rays and MRI scans over the network.
Inexpensive videoconferencing will make it possible for employees to work from home or avoid traveling, saving them time and cutting traffic in urban areas.
Even today's lower-speed Internet has had a remarkable impact on the way people learn and share information. Following are some examples.
* Michael Hawley, a graduate student at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, now routinely browses through a digital version of the Library of Congress catalogue from his computer work station in his office in the school's media laboratory. When he finds a book he wants, he simply orders it from a bookstore connected to the Internet; it arrives the next day by overnight mail.
* High school students who have access in increasing numbers to the Internet from computers at their schools are finding that it changes the way they do research.
Asked to do a term paper on the bombing of Hiroshima recently, one student in Washington connected to a database in a university's computer. There he found a reference to a second computer database, in Hiroshima itself. Without leaving his classroom terminal, he obtained transcripts of eyewitness accounts of the bombing from interviews with survivors.
* Perhaps the most important facet of the Internet is that it has created what computer researchers call virtual communities. These are computerized conferences that bring together people with shared interests in business, research and hobbies.
For example, David Kahaner, a Navy researcher who has lived in Japan for several years, has regularly passed detailed reports over the Internet to American researchers on the latest technical advances in Japan.

An early form of the data superhighway already exists. Called the Internet, it is the world's largest data network, accessible in more than 100 countries. Below is some of what's available on the network:
DIGITAL LIBRARIES A vast library accessible to virtually anyone at minimal cost is being assembled. Ambitious projects are under way to make much of the world's literature available electronically.
DATABASE PUBLISHING The major commercial databases, like Dialog and Mead Data Central, are now available over the Internet.
ELECTRONIC MAIL Electronic messages can be exchanged with millions of users worldwide. MCI, A.T.&T, Compuserve, America Online and Prodigy all offer electronic-mail connections to the Internet.
ELECTRONIC COMMUNITIES The Internet allows what computer researchers call virtual communities -- conferences through the computer that attract people of common interests around the world.
 SOFTWARE ACCESS Software programs, even large ones, can be copied from one machine to another in seconds.
WEATHER INFORMATION Up-to-the-minute weather forecasts can be found for any city in the United States. Hourly updated weather-satellite digital photographs can be copied from a computer at the University of Illinois.
 ENTERTAINMENT "Interactive" computer games include chess and role-playing fantasy games called Multi User Dungeons. In the future, the Internet may carry video services such as television and movies as well as new forms of interactive entertainment.
 DATA EXCHANGE The Microelectronic Computers and Computer Technology Corporation now offers a service that allows corporations to exchange business information with suppliers and customers.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Sharing the Load, and Other Topics

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
READERS have written recently asking about sales commissions, fund performance data, tax-exempt funds and more. Following are some of their questions.
Question: How much of the sales commission do stockbrokers keep when they sell shares in load funds? 
 Answer: Broker compensation varies from firm to firm, but most brokers receive 30 to 45 percent of the sales load, said Dan Jamieson, who edits Registered Representative, a trade publication in Irvine, Calif. The fund sponsor normally takes 20 percent and the brokerage gets the remaining 35 to 50 percent.
At big brokerage houses, the percentage paid to a broker often is based on the broker's gross commissions: the more sold, the bigger the cut. The median in gross commissions for the industry is $225,000, and at that level a broker from Merrill Lynch, for example, would receive 32 percent, Mr. Jamieson said. Thus, a broker who sold $10,000 worth of shares in a fund with a 4.5 percent load would earn $144 on the sale.
Merrill discontinued the practice of paying brokers more for selling shares of its own funds several years ago, but many other big brokerages have not. A Paine Webber broker at the middle level in gross commissions would be paid 37 percent on outside funds and 47 percent for Paine Webber funds. Kidder Peabody would pay 40 percent on outside funds, 45 percent on in-house shares.
Funds are also sold by financial planners, insurance agents and others who are supervised by brokerages but basically run their own businesses as independent contractors. These people would receive 70 to 80 percent of a fund's sales load, Mr. Jamieson said. The balance would be split between the mutual fund and the brokerage.
Instead of upfront loads, some funds levy "12b-1 fees," which are intended to cover marketing expenses and normally range from a tenth of 1 percent to 1 percent of the value of an account every year. Because this could exceed the 8.5 percent legal cap for a front-end load over time, the Securities and Exchange Commission, beginning in July, will limit total 12b-1 fees paid to 7.25 percent, or 6.25 percent if funds also collect a 0.25 percent "servicing" fee. A broker's share of these fees usually follows the same payout schedules.
Q: The weekly table accompanying this column shows whether a fund is a no-load (NL), low-load (LL) or load (L) fund and then gives its performance over various periods. To interpret the figures correctly, I would like to know whether the returns are computed using the fund's net asset value or its total cost, including the sales charge. The second method would yield a lower but, in my viewpoint, more honest figure.
A: The New York Times table, like most published mutual fund performance data, does not factor front-end sales charges into total returns. Nor do the figures include any "back-end" loads or redemption fees, assessed when investors sell shares in a fund before a specified time, usually five or six years. Any 12b-1 fees, however, are figured in because they are treated as ordinary fund expenses. As you noted, accounting for front-end loads creates a smaller return on the investment because less of your money is used to buy fund shares; the table with this column demonstrates the results.
Q: When I used the Morningstar Mutual Fund Sourcebook to research tax-free bond funds, I noticed that Morningstar analysts credited the Dreyfus Municipal Bond Fund's strong performance to the fact that it owned many New York state and city issues. Given the fiscal problems in New York, how can this be?
A: Morningstar says its ratings are based on a fund's past performance, not on the current creditworthiness of its holdings.
Municipalities are clearly feeling the pressure of the recession, with budget problems and potential defaults, said Ralph Norton, editor of the Bond Fund Advisor in Woburn, Mass. But given the diversification built into funds, he adds, "I have no concerns about New York tax-free bond portfolios now; it's a big state with many different types of issues." In fact, he said, yields on all New York tax-free funds are extremely favorable right now, even for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket.
He suggests New York residents consider national municipal bond funds if they are leery of those that invest solely in their state, which do carry slightly more risk. Income from the national funds would be free of Federal taxes, and state and city taxes for New York residents on the portion in New York issues. (Funds provide this information to investors.) Right now, the Dreyfus Municipal Bond Fund, which has 15 percent in New York issues, yields 5.71 percent, or 7.93 for people in the 28 percent tax bracket (and 8.28 percent for those in the 31 percent bracket), compared with 5.25 percent for its New York Tax-Exempt Bond Fund, or roughly 8.68 percent for state residents.
Note: Many readers have asked how to contact funds mentioned in the column. Most have toll-free telephone numbers, which can be obtained by calling (800) 555-1212. Comprehensive fund information, including telephone numbers and addresses, can be found in the Morningstar Mutual Fund Sourcebook, available in some libraries.

HEADLINE: At Work;
It's 1993. Is Your Office Outmoded?

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble

 BODY:
BY commission or omission, how offices look is no coincidence. Most Fortune 500 companies are organized and furnished by design. Decisions about who goes where and gets what perk are deliberated. Smaller businesses have tended to cobble their corporate look as they grow and develop, but how the use of office space evolves still reflects, de facto, relationships between co-workers and their differential access to power.
A nifty new book called "Office Access" is designed to guide businesses through the tricky waters of planning an office, from the sublimina of distributing offices to the nuts and bolts of choosing curtain fabrics or lighting fixtures. 
 True to its name, it makes accessible what might be called the semiotics of office design -- what the position of a desk means, say, or the proximity of one person to another. It is intended for smaller businesses -- the biggest growth segment of the economy -- wanting to be more deliberate about spatial relationships. But because the book throws down a challenge to conventional thinking about space, it could certainly find a home at larger companies too.
"Office Access" was commissioned by Steelcase Inc., a maker of office products based in Grand Rapids, Mich., and is being brought out by a San Francisco information and electronic publishing firm that goes by the name TheUnderstandingBusiness (or TUB). The book will look familiar to anyone who has used TUB's distinctive, graphics-happy "Access" city guides. As in those books, text shares equal billing with photographs, columns of epigrams and data-rich charts and diagrams.
The book's writers -- a committee, according to Mark Johnson, TUB's president and creative director -- don't quibble with the truism that space and proximity are indexes of power. But they observe that the evidence of outmoded management thinking is obvious in many corporate environments. Some of the misguided assumptions about the best way to organize the office:
* Title and organizational status should determine the location, size and furnishings of an office. Until recently, it may not have mattered that vice presidents -- of whatever -- were removed, perhaps by several floors, from the people who work for them or, by walls and secretaries, from their peers. Under today's management styles, executives should see continuities between departments. Woe betide the marketing exec who doesn't understand finance. And the book raises the question implicit in the current enthusiasm for managing by walking around: "How effective can you be if you're away from the action?"
* People who do the same functions should be grouped together. A holdover from the days when managers thought "little people" like accountants or salespeople ought to be segregated for efficiency. It makes more sense to assume that people in different jobs, like executives in different divisions, will learn from each other and apply what they learn to their own jobs. Companies can encourage encounters outside the immediate work group by, for example, weaving a path to the elevator through work stations.
* Coffee rooms, drinking fountains and lunchrooms are wasted space and possibly an invitation to poor work habits. Threats of layoffs and downsizing may give managers the upper hand, but whip-cracking is a mistake. "Office Access" asserts: "Good conversation breeds good ideas, and serendipitous conversation breeds the best ideas of all." In other words, work often continues during breaks and meals, when the employee theoretically is on his or her own time.

IF the book offers a guide to managerial philosophy on the macro level of allocating space, it also helps with the more prosaic decisions that everyone will have to live with day to day.
It offers suggestions for prevention and relief of carpal tunnel syndrome, by now well documented as a scourge of the millions of workers who use keyboards.
It also provides a guide to other potential irritations and threats to health. Deciding on the type of lighting, for example, may seem to be a "mere" technical problem, but as one of the book's charts indicates, the decision begins with the fact that there are several types of artificial light. And as other diagrams show, ambient light, wall surfaces, computer screens and glass create an almost infinite number of aggravating light-reflection-glare combinations. Which makes light -- as in simple old fiat lux  -- one of the most complicated elements of office design.
Mr. Johnson cautions that the book is not intended to be a substitute for an architect or a design consultant. But what it clearly can do is prepare a company to work with the pros when they arrive.
"Office Access" ($12) will be in bookstores in early February.
 
 
SOME OF THE FIRST QUESTIONS
 "OFFICE ACCESS" ends with an inventory of questions businesses should consider before redoing office space. A sample follows.
How does your office renew and reward people's performance? How are people motivated to work effectively? Is everyone on a career path? What type of management style reigns? Is work team-oriented and does the office physically make it easy for people to work together?
How are people organized in terms of proximity? Are they placed near others whose work they support? Does everyone have access to equipment like copiers and fax machines? Is there a place for quiet work? Is it easy to get from office to office?
What kind of structure does your company have? Do people's job titles match their job descriptions and their responsibilities? Do employees have any say over their environment? Does everyone have enough room?
Are your office seats comfortable? Is there a lot of sneezing and illness in the office (possible indicators of poor air quality)? Are glare and reflections a problem? Is work compromised by lack of privacy? Are there any views? Can they be shared by everyone?

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
When Inflation Hits the Gallop -- Duck

BYLINE: By SUSAN ANTILLA

 BODY:
INVESTING during high-inflation times is apparently fun only for the short sellers. When the consumer price index soared 1.8 percent in August 1973, tobacco stocks dropped 8 percent, and drug issues lost 8.5 percent in a single month, said Laszlo Birinyi of Birinyi Associates, a research firm in New York. In August 1974, the price index jumped 1.2 percent and electrical equipment stocks lost 20 percent while retailers dropped 16 percent, he added.
"The upshot of it is that there aren't a whole lot of things you can buy that make sense" when inflation is high, said Mr. Birinyi. Investors get more maneuvering room when price increases are minimal -- or when inflation has actually been negative. 
 In the five months between January 1970 and September 1992 when prices actually declined, auto, retail and tobacco stocks rose. Just now, inflation is holding at historically low levels and autos especially are doing well. The bears, no doubt, are hoping for some reckless Democratic spending to get inflation rolling again.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
A Fairy-Tale Scenario for the Nikkei

BYLINE: By James Sterngold

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
CALL it the Theory of the Royal Rally.
Over the past year, the best that could be said of the Japanese stock market was that it was floundering. When it was not floundering it was generally plummeting, as it has been for three years, and most analysts predict more of the same for 1993. The economy is in recession, banks are mired in bad loans and a Government stimulus package of public works spending has had no apparent impact. 
 But now some think that with all earthly remedies exhausted, help may have arrived from a higher power -- Japan's imperial family. After an embarrassingly protracted seven-year search, Crown Prince Naruhito has found a bride. His engagement to the Harvard-educated diplomat Masako Owada was formally announced last Tuesday.
Some economists and analysts wasted no time in proclaiming this just the thing to revive the stock market. Researchers at Nippon Life Insurance reckoned that a revival in consumer confidence and increased buying spurred by the wedding, expected in June, could add as much as one percentage point to the anemic economic growth rate this year.
Travel agents are reportedly already planning royal tours to Oxford, where both Miss Owada and the prince studied. Department stores are watching carefully what she wears to introduce new lines of clothes copying her styles. Commemorative stamps, gold coins and even a special cigarette are anticipated.
Some are betting that the stock price of companies like Tasaki Shinju, a major pearl producer and distributor, will soar as young women begin wearing strings of thumbnail-sized pearls, as the princess-to-be has.
"The news will loosen up the wallets of housewives," said Rokuro Ishikawa, head of the Japan Chamber of Commerce.
It is a nice idea, but in fact investors do not seem to have bought it, at least not yet. The Nikkei stock index closed Friday at 16,336.81, down 201.87, little changed from the beginning of this year. "This whole idea has gotten some credence because there's very little else out there," said Jeff Bahrenburg, the stock market strategist at Merrill Lynch Japan Inc. "It's a straw to grasp."
"It's iffy, but conceivable," said Mike Allen, the retailing analyst at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities here. "But if you see retail sales pick up it won't be because of the wedding. It'll just be a coincidence. We have yet to hit bottom in my view."
The more pessimistic assessments begin with the fact that the market remains, by some measures, extremely expensive. The ratio of stock prices to that of the expected earnings per share of companies is slightly more than 50, down from more than 60 three years ago but some four times the level in the United States.
The dividend yield of Japanese stocks, relative to stock prices, is slightly less than 1 percent, about a third that on Wall Street. That does not strike many analysts as a market that has hit bottom.
After three years of declines, however, one of the worst problems is that the market is dead: volume is about a tenth of its peak level four years ago. There is not enough investor energy to move the market significantly either way, some say. If anything, the only thing keeping it above 16,000, many agree, is concerted buying by Government-controlled pension and trust funds.
Banks, through which the Government does most of its stock buying, purchased a total of more than 600 billion yen, or nearly $5 billion, worth of stock in November and December last year. That compares with net sales of 527 billion yen by all other sources in that time -- a sign that the only real buying at the moment may be by the Government.
There is, in fact, an open debate within the Finance Ministry over the wisdom of continued intervention, officials say. "There's a sort of paralysis," said Alan Bell, deputy head of research at Baring Securities here. "Over all, there's just no impetus to go anywhere."
In Mr. Bahrenburg's view, this has resulted in part from the Government's continuous intervention. In addition to the buying by Government-controlled trusts, officials have pressured institutions not to sell their shares and trigger another big decline. The institutions have shown restraint, but that has contributed to the dearth of trading.
Mr. Bahrenburg rates as high the chance that the market will drop to 14,000 in the next few months -- near its low last year. There is even a chance, he added, that a panic could push the market down further than that. But he added that the Nikkei average is likely to climb to 20,000, although well after the imperial wedding.
Mr. Bell's range for the year is similar; he puts the top at 21,000 on the Nikkei index. But he is much more sanguine about the prospects for picking individual stocks that will perform better than the overall market.
"The general paralysis does not extend to every individual stock," he said. "There is tremendous potential for individual stocks if you pick carefully."
In particular, he said, he likes stocks of companies that have done very poorly over the past couple of years but have now taken measures to improve their businesses. These include Nissan and Isuzu, which announced recently that it is getting out of general auto production.
"I'm looking for companies that were doing badly," Mr. Bell commented. "The evidence is beginning to come through that some of them are turning themselves around. But any connection to this wedding is purely coincidental."

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
It's Comedy at Night After McKinsey by Day

BYLINE: By Sylvia Nasar

 BODY:
IT'S January. The Bills are on their way to the Super Bowl. There's bombing in Baghdad. And another Stuart Flack play is poised to open in Buffalo.
Swelling the small audience at the Alleyway Theater next Thursday night will be a number of business consultants from McKinsey & Company, the New York-based management firm whose offices ring the globe and whose client roster boasts some of the biggest of big businesses. 
 The consultants will be on hand not to advise the tiny Alleyway Theater on strategic alliances or on how to market its plays on a weekend when everybody is glued to the tube, but to cheer the aspiring playwright who happens to be a colleague.
This is the second comedy by Mr. Flack to be staged since he joined McKinsey as a public relations executive in May 1990. Loosely based on the real life kidnapping of several students working with the primatologist Jane Goodall in the mid-1980's, "Peaceful Creatures" is set in a steamy African rain forest teeming with America-loving terrorists, endearingly inept pols, morally myopic scientists and deviant chimps.
Mr. Flack, at 32, is anything but the stereotypical struggling artist with a day job. Married to another McKinsey employee, Claudia Eisen, he relishes the business of business. A former Forbes writer, Mr. Flack helps McKinsey's 400 partners cope with press requests for interviews and information. Most of his time is spent promoting McKinsey's research findings, including negotiating contracts for books by McKinsey consultants, drafting Congressional testimony and pitching McKinsey research to the editors of the Harvard Business Review.
The son of a teacher and a businessman in the floor-covering trade in Evanston, Ill., Mr. Flack says "the economic dimension of people's lives" is just as important as their inner, emotional lives. "People who write plays all try to understand human psychology," Mr. Flack said. "How can you depict life and teach people, which is what the theater is about, without a full understanding?" He sees having a full-fledged business career as a way "to immerse yourself."
In addition to business, Mr. Flack immerses himself in basketball, bridge and the banjo, as well as reading about science and economics. His hero? Brecht.
Combining the pursuit of the muse with that of money was actually the theme Mr. Flack tapped for his first play, which was also staged off-off-off Broadway at the Alleyway for no other reason than that that was the theater that booked it. The subject of "American Life & Casualty" is an imaginary meeting between two highly successful insurance executives returning on a train from a Harvard-Yale football game. One is the poet Wallace Stevens, the other the pioneering American composer Charles Ives.
What made Stevens and Ives so intriguing, said Mr. Flack, was that they were truly dedicated to their business careers, from which they made a lot of money, while at the same time being devoted to their art. Ives, in particular, who was almost evangelical in his enthusiasm for selling life insurance, built a highly successful agency and wrote an influential book called "The Amount to Carry." Stevens, a surety claims lawyer who achieved much more fame as a poet during his lifetime than Ives did as a composer, turned down numerous offers to teach poetry that would have involved quitting the insurance business.
"What occurred to me if they actually met," said Mr. Flack, "is that neither would tell the other he was an artist because they would have been embarrassed."
When Stevens, who has taken Ives home with him after the latter apparently suffers a heart attack on the train, learns from his clerk that Ives is a composer, he shouts: "An artist and an insurance man . . . good God!"
The point of the play, as Mr. Flack puts it, is that "you can't confuse the token of the thing with the thing itself, the artist with a certain life style that you associate with being an artist."
Mr. Flack is already at work on a new play, squeezing in as much time as he can writing on nights and weekends, largely between bouts of play with his 2-year-old son, Nathaniel. The new play is based on Denton Cooley, the larger-than-life millionaire Texas heart transplant surgeon who filed for personal bankruptcy a couple of years ago.
"Good dramatic characters contradict themselves," said Mr. Flack. "There's an omnipotence to being the world's greatest heart surgeon. Yet there's a certain incompetence in mishandling your finances so badly that you go bankrupt on $8 million a year."
Mr. Flack's commitment to his job is also a realist's decision. From Arthur Kopit, the author of the Broadway hit "Oh Dad, Poor Dad" for whom Mr. Flack once worked as an intern, he learned that making a living, even as a very successful playwright, was dauntingly difficult. At Joe Allen, the theater district restaurant where he recently discussed his playwright ventures, Mr. Flack pointed out that the posters adorning the restaurant's walls were all for Broadway shows that had closed after a single night.
"In the theater, a thousand things go wrong," said Mr. Flack. "My first play opened during the Gulf War when the Bills were in the Super Bowl."
Mr. Flack did try going the normal route of more casual day jobs. Once, while trying to complete "American Life & Casualty" in the mid-80's, he teamed with a former bridge partner and stockbroker in Vermont who wanted to run a $10 million investment fund while he was attending Dartmouth. Mr. Flack's job, in return for rent, was to execute trades based on a so-called hedged portfolio strategy twice a day, once after breakfast, once after lunch.
"We were the only people in the world that were short Macy's when it was taken over," said Mr. Flack. "The guy in New York whose money it was would call us and scream: 'Where are you guys? In Vermont, in the middle of the woods?' "
