HEADLINE: Men at Work

BYLINE: By DAN SHAW

 BODY:
FASHION shows, it turns out, are really just business meetings with music.
Most of the 250 people who crowded into Donna Karan's gold-colored showroom on Tuesday morning to preview her fall men's wear collection were conservatively dressed in safe, serious dark suits. "This is what's wrong with men's wear in this country," said Garth Condit, a fashion stylist, surveying the room filled with the most influential men's wear buyers, editors and retailers in the United States. "I feel like a freak in my sweater. Everyone here looks like he has to rush back to the bank after the show." 
 Except for Liza Minnelli, the token celebrity (who sat in the place of honor next to Ms. Karan's husband and muse, Stephan Weiss), the crowd consisted of people who earn their living buying and selling, praising and damning, photographing and accessorizing clothes.
It was a busy week for them, with nine men's wear shows, which ranged from intimate showroom presentations to a lavish production at the New York Public Library.
Many in the audience at Donna Karan had just returned from four days of shows in Milan, Italy -- where they had seen Edwardian silhouettes, romantic ruffled shirts and velvet jackets -- and they were eager to see a down-to-earth, hometown collection.
Ms. Karan did not disappoint them. It was her first full runway show for the two-year-old Donna Karan Menswear company, and she went all out. She hired 35 models -- tall, tanned and toned guys with names like Lance, Haskell, Zane and Luciano -- to model the company's three lines: DKNY sportswear, her brand-new gold-label collection (suits in the $795 to $950 range) and her black-label couture (suits $1,250 and up).
"We're going head-to-head with Armani and Valentino now," said Linda Beauchamp, the president of Donna Karan Menswear.
The first model sent down the 64-foot-long runway wore a morning-after gaze and a blanket-plaid robe over a rayon nightshirt. He was followed by a procession of models in separates that might be called gentrified grunge -- gray wool jodhpurs tucked into brown leather combat boots, hand-knit Scandinavian-style sweaters, Henley shirts, union suits, shearling vests and paraffin-coated cotton overalls. The clothes looked like they could even be worn out on the street.
" A bsolutely gorgeous," said Jon Weiser, the president of Charivari, who watched part of the show through black Ray-Bans. "This is as good as anything in Europe. I'm proud for America."
Mr. Weiser was not sure whether his enthusiasm would translate into a big order, but he was encouraged because he thought the clothes looked expensive, which, he explained, is necessary when selling high-ticket items to men. "I always try to visualize writing a check for $2,000 plus tax for a suit when I'm putting in my orders," he said. "That's a hard check for anyone to write."
It was the first men's show Ellin Saltzman, the fashion director for Bergdorf Goodman, had attended in her 30 years in the business, and she was most impressed by something she rarely sees at women's shows: male models. "I was having a ball," she said. "I kept circling Stefano and Claudio's names on my program."
 
THE RIGHT-AND-LEFT GRIP
The men's-fashion establishment is a fraternity that even has its own handshake. As you shake with your right hand, you grab the other guy's right bicep with your left hand, rubbing it gently. It's a way of saying "Nice to see you, old chap," to check out the fabric of his jacket and to see if he's been lifting weights as often as he says he has.
 
THIS OLD THING?
"I don't know if people are looking at me because I'm a freak or because I look like Kiefer Sutherland," Jeffrey Uhl, a fashion associate at Details magazine, said on Wednesday, the second day of men's market week.
Actually, people were staring at Mr. Uhl last week because each day, his clothing seemed to be an oddly prescient, thrift-shop variation on the main runway show.
At Donna Karan's on Tuesday, he arrived in old mismatched tweeds, distressed brown leather boots and a sweater tied around his waist -- an outfit that Ms. Karan might have sent down her runway. "It's thoughtfully disheveled, which is why I liked the DKNY clothes so much," said Mr. Uhl, who is 26 and has a goatee and pomaded blond hair with a few strategically untamed tendrils.
On Wednesday, at John Bartlett's show, the week's poster boy was wearing another thrift-shop outfit of a totally different sort -- a navy Nehru vest over a gray suit jacket, with black ski pants ("I got them for $5 at Canal Jeans and they look like leggings") that were tucked into black motorcycle boots. It was an appropriately unorthodox combination, echoing Mr. Bartlett's iconoclastic designs.
On Thursday, Mr. Uhl put together a look that he called "corporate grunge" -- cutoff striped suit pants over long underwear, a blue pin-stripe suit vest and a gray pin-stripe Romeo Gigli jacket, which foreshadowed what Calvin Klein would show that afternoon.
Mr. Uhl, an Oklahoma native who studied feminist and Marxist sociology at the University of Chicago, mused about 20-something men and their relationship to fashion. "I think most guys want to have an interesting look," he said. "Eclecticism is big with us. We're doing a bizillion different things. There's a greater tolerance, which crosses sexual and religious lines."
 
WALKING THAT WALK
One of the problems with men's fashion shows has always been how to get the models to have a sexy strut without seeming feminine. This season, the fashions themselves provided the solution. The slow, deliberate, undulating walk that signals confidence and masculinity is an invariable result of strolling in a pair of thick-soled boots, and all the designers this season outfitted their models in them.
 
THE BOYS HAVE SOME FUN
Some of the models finally smiled Wednesday afternoon, during the small show of clothes by John Bartlett.
There were the accessories, like knit hats speared with a single plume, that could not be worn with a straight face. There was the music, including "The Hustle," which accompanied the showing of flared corduroy pants, and "The Lonely Goatherd," which accompanied Tyrolean jackets and von Trapp shirts. And then there were the props, like a giant sickle that a model in a soot-brown vest and drawstring mountain jeans carried as though he were a Lilliputian.
And why exactly did Mr. Bartlett design a handsome hooded winter coat based on the robes worn by Trappist monks?
"Monks," he said cheerfully, "are unbelievably sexy."
 
JUST BODY COVERING, AFTER ALL?
Ingrid Sischy, the former editor of Artforum and current editor in chief of Interview, was front and center at Joseph Abboud's megashow -- 109 outfits, 45 models -- at the New York Public Library on Tuesday evening. It was fashion in the round (actually, the stage was square) so that a lot of people could claim front-row seats.
The show attracted both the new guard, which is led by James Truman, the editor in chief of Details, and the old guard, which was represented by Nonnie Moore, GQ's fashion matriarch, and GQ's editor in chief, Art Cooper. Mr. Truman wore tapered trousers with zippers at the ankles, and Mr. Cooper had on a blue shirt with a white collar and an 80's yellow power tie.
Since Joseph Abboud is not known for cutting-edge design, it seemed odd that Ms. Sischy, a champion of the avant-garde, was in the audience.
"What's always interested me about Abboud is his lack of pretension," she said. "He faces up to the fact that clothes are how we get warm and keep us from getting arrested because we're walking around on the street naked."
Ms. Sischy was also impressed by Donna Karan's show. "There was a lot of rugged individualism there," she said. "It wasn't the man in the gray flannel suit. It's interesting to see how the definition of men is changing."
She's also wary of overanalyzing fashion phenomena. "Remember when pants dropped down on kids last year?" she said. "I thought you could think of it as recession wear. At the Gaultier show last fall, the pants were pulled up to the breasts, just about the time Bill Clinton's fortunes were rising. I've noticed some of the pants way high at the shows here, too. It might mean something about hope, or nothing."
 
MAN AS PROP
"The view from here is so weird," said Dave Howard, a model who was standing on a 20-inch-high platform on the second floor of the Guggenheim Museum SoHo, where GQ magazine had a party on Wednesday night. Dressed in layers of Andrew Fezza, Mr. Howard, who spent two hours staring at an untitled matte black triptych by Robert Rauschenberg, was glad that he hadn't ended up dressed in a wool sweater and scarf like some of the other fellows.
GQ had hired 24 models to stand on platforms throughout the galleries, and they looked like they didn't know why they were there or what they were supposed to be doing. Weren't they given any instructions as to how to act or what attitude to project? "The only thing they told us," Mr. Howard said, "was 'Don't get off.' "
 
SHOWER, SHAVE, LAYER AND TUCK
On Thursday, Tommy Hilfiger seemed to be predicting another energy crisis. At his showroom, which resembles one of his department-store boutiques, which resemble libraries in neo-Georgian mansions, he sent his models out in several layers of wool, plaid and tweed.
Mr. Hilfiger also seemed to be predicting a flood. Most of the models came down the runway wearing their pants tucked into their boots, which ranged from heavy black biker styles to knee-high Wellingtons. It was a show of classic preppy-inspired design mixed up in color-coordinated ways. In other words, dry-cleaned grunge.
 
BOX SEATS FOR THE FAMILY
It looked like lunchtime at the Royalton.
Calvin Klein's extended family -- Ross Bleckner, Tina Brown, Barry Diller, David Geffen, Fran Lebowitz, Ian Schrager -- crowded into his showroom Thursday afternoon. They all sat together, all in the front row, their Boswell, Billy Norwich, behind them. They were there to watch models with an "I'm stoned out of my mind" air amble down the runway wearing the new Calvin Klein Collection, the designer's most sophisticated and expensive men's line.
The clothes that were paraded past the crowd, which also included Tommy Tune, Miranda Richardson, Griffin Dunne and Phil Hartman (from "Saturday Night Live"), were not what you'd expect Marky Mark to wear. They weren't really clothes you'd expect to see on Mr. Geffen, either, whose trademark is a white T-shirt with a V-neck cashmere sweater, or on Mr. Diller, who favors banker's suits.
"They're clothes for men who like Matsuda and Comme des Garcons," said a magazine editor.
For aficionados who wanted to know which way the fashion winds will blow next fall, there was a very clear forecast: button only the top button of your three- or four-button suit jacket; wear your pants casually tucked into your leather chukka boots; throw a shawl over your suit; wear leather suspenders over your sweater or a thick wool vest over your suit jacket.
Outside on West 39th Street, models on their way to Paris for another round of men's shows looked for their radio cabs, while the taste makers held post-mortems.
"There's a little grunge, a little androgyny," said Michael Goff, the editor in chief of Out magazine, who had just returned from attending inaugural events in Washington. "It's really right for the Clinton years."

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
Again -- and at Last -- a New Camaro

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
"In the 1960's, muscle cars were like the muscle men of the era: formidable, hulking presences dominated by brute strength. But the science of muscle has come a long way since then. Like today's bodybuilders, the 1993 Camaro is lean, finely proportioned and powerful. It's a muscle car for the Nineties."
 -- Chevrolet overview of the 1993 Camaro.
I HAVE been prowling through my computer, looking for notes on a conversation that is now more than a decade old. Electrons are amazing, and I actually found what I was looking for.
It turns out that it has been 11 years since that sunny morning when the late Pete Estes and I stood talking in the outdoor dining area of Tavern on the Green in Central Park. Estes was then about to retire as president of General Motors, and he had come to New York to show off his final creation, Chevy's 1982 Camaro.
I remember discussing the crucial need for better fuel economy. The new Camaro was lighter than its predecessor but still heavy enough to have displeased the critics. Estes agreed, noting that the engineers had only scratched the surface.
"So far, we've done the easy part," he said. "We got rid of the fat. The rest is going to be tougher."
Aha! And now there is a new Camaro, the fourth generation, exactly 100 pounds heavier than the '82 model, but of the modern ilk, which is to say that it looks nothing like Camaros of the past. In the intervening years technology has taken the place of dieting and, heavier or not, the new car does go farther on a gallon of gas.
I remember expressing surprise, too, during that conversation with Estes, that G.M. had managed to get 10 years out of the same basic model. And his response was this: "It shows what you can do when you do it right in the first place."
In fact, the Camaro and its twin, the Pontiac Firebird, have always been exactly right for their markets, sporty cars that could be dressed inexpensively or in go-fast fashion, appealing both to low-end buyers and to hot-rodders. And the Camaro is still right, still with an available V8 engine to burble pleasantly and to drive the rear wheels, still fast even in its conservative standard mode.
The new car competes against the Toyota Celica, Nissan 240SX, Ford Mustang, Eagle Talon, Plymouth Laser and the Mitsubishi Eclipse, among others. According to Chevrolet, 50 percent of the buyers in the sporty-car segment are women, and nearly half of Camaro's principal drivers are female, a figure that drops to 30 percent for the high-end Z28.
Both the Z28 and the standard car are hatchbacks, and the base coupe carries a 160-horsepower V6. The Z28, with a 5.7-liter V8 under its hood, is as always a flat-out performance car, and it will give a Corvette a run for its money.
That is not surprising, of course, since the 5.7-liter power plant is the same basic engine that lives under the Corvette's hood. In the Camaro, it produces 275 horsepower, and its bulk fills the engine compartment.
The new 3.4-liter V6 delivers 20 horsepower more than was available in 1992's standard car, and it sends it to the road through a five-speed manual transmission. The V8 produces 30 more horsepower than last year, and it is coupled to a new six-speed manual. Four-speed automatics are optional with either engine.
For '93, rack-and-pinion steering has replaced the recirculating-ball system of the past in order to improve responsiveness and an "on-center" feel. Antilock brakes also are standard.
The fourth generation car was redesigned head to tail, and Chevrolet's literature says that "all classic Camaro design ingredients are evident." That is arguable, however, and the new model looks more like a Mitsubishi Eclipse than like anything else.
Part of that, at least in the case of the Z28, has to do with the paint scheme and the upper body. All Z28's have black roofs, and the darkly tinted glass makes the entire "greenhouse" look black. What has been retained from the past is the Camaro's tenacious stance, aggressive front end and brawny tires on 16-inch wheels.
The car is smooth but wedge-shaped. It rides on the same 101-inch wheelbase as the '92, but the body is longer, wider and taller. Sideview mirrors are fared into the front fenders, and a spoiler is integrated into the rear hatch. Trim is of the blackout variety, and the headlights nestle in black pockets.
The new Camaro makes extensive use of dent-resistant, rustproof body panels. The roof, doors, hatch and spoiler assembly are made of sheet-molded compound, and the front fenders, and nose and tail pieces also are made of composite material. Rust-resistant two-side galvanized steel is used for the rear quarter panels and hood.
The hatch itself has a very high liftover, leading to a deep well just inside and then to a shallow cargo floor. Luggage capacity is not this car's long suit.
Space also is at a premium in the rear of the redesigned interior, and even small children are likely to complain. On the other hand, the cockpit is comodious, and the new front buckets -- available only in cloth -- are both commodious and supportive.
The black and white Z28 test car had a two-tone gray interior, nicely finished although abundantly plastic. The instrument panel sort of wraps around the driver, and the analog gauges, dominated by a 150-mile per hour speedometer, are easy to read.
A huge door covers a medium-size glove compartment, in which resides the remote button for the rear hatch. The console contains a small ashtray, a single cupholder and a bin whose cover serves as an armrest. The shifter, as always, is topped by a large round knob, now covered with leather.
As tested and loaded with options, the car carried a sticker of $19,098, although the base price for a Z28 is a more reasonable $16,779. The least expensive Camaro goes for $13,399, and the cars will begin arriving in dealerships early in February.
Oddly enough, they are "imports," coming from an assembly plant near Montreal. And they do now feel less like Detroit iron. The bone-jarring ride of the past is gone, as are many of the creaks and rattles that resulted from the huge metal doors. The new Z28 is tighter and a great deal more civilized than its ancestors.
On the road, though, there is still that slingshot acceleration. There is the taut suspension and good handling. And, of course, there is that wonderful rumble of a potent V8.
Like the '82 model that lasted almost unchanged for a decade, the newest Z28 has been named to pace the Indianapolis 500. And with the 77th running of the race on May 30, Chevrolet will set a record. In all, nine Chevies will have led the pack. Four of them, including the 1967 original, have been Camaros.

HEADLINE: Clinton Steps In, and the World Locks On

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
JUST three hours after President Clinton returned to the White House from his inaugural balls, Saddam Hussein's radar was back in action, locking on to American warplanes over Iraq. American pilots retaliated, but a similar confrontation occurred the next day. Suddenly, the Iraqi leader had maneuvered himself to the top of Mr. Clinton's dance card.
Two months ago, when reporters asked Mr. Clinton to define his foreign policy priorities, he ticked off an ambitious list: a multi-year plan for a defense budget, reducing nuclear weapons, ending the proliferation of biological and chemical weapons, continuing the Middle East peace process, strengthening global economic growth. 
 He later spoke of a "disciplined, aggressive approach" to foreign policy, using preventive diplomacy to head off global problems before they boil over and steal time from his cherished domestic goals.
In these grand visions, nothing was said about how to deal with international thugs.
But now, in the White House, his first need is to face down two of the most unsavory, Mr. Hussein in Iraq and Slobodan Milosevic in Serbia. And, it became evident last week, his team is not ready with a specific approach for dealing with either.
On domestic policy, Mr. Clinton showed an ability last week to quickly seize the initiative -- by cutting his losses in the failed nomination of Zoe Baird to be Attorney General, by signaling dramatic changes in policy on abortion and the presence of homosexuals in the military. But the crisis in Iraq clearly showed him at a disadvantage in his efforts to master the moment in foreign affairs.
The first difficulty in dealing with Mr. Hussein is that no one in the new Administration can figure out just what the Iraqi dictator is up to. When he started flouting allied restrictions on Iraqi flights and resisting other United Nations demands in recent weeks, it seemed a strictly personal challenge to George Bush in his final days in office -- a perverse way, perhaps, of saying goodbye.
But the irritation persists, and now it seems Mr. Hussein may have had something more in mind: a signal to the new Administration that even if he no longer has the force of a bully, he remains a relentless tease. Mr. Hussein's promise to abide by a cease-fire at first seemed a sort of diplomatic housewarming present for Mr. Clinton. But it was followed by the training of Iraqi radar on the allied patrols, and by the weekend it was impossible to determine whether the incidents were accidental or purposeful.
This teasing put pressure on Mr. Clinton and his foreign policy team to first do something Mr. Clinton has vowed to avoid: spend time trying to figure out what is in Mr. Hussein's mind. "Saddam sometimes likes to try everything at the same time," said Phebe Marr, a leading scholar on Iraq. "He could now come in with a charm offensive that would present a package of cosmetic concessions designed to elicit a response from the new Administration and to drive a wedge in the alliance. If the soft approach doesn't work, then there is little doubt he will revert to his pattern of probing, testing and challenging the will of Washington. He might do both at once -- as a reminder of how much trouble he can cause."
Indeed, the tactic of mixing reward and punishment -- ruthlessly suppressing his population while meeting the basic needs of the people who count -- is one that has helped Mr. Hussein survive so long. In his country, it is known as mixing "tarhib" (terror) with "targhib" (enticement).
In response, the Clinton Administration is struggling to come up with a mix of terror and enticement of its own, one that will put Mr. Hussein back in his box and keep him there. But there are deep divisions in the Administration about the best way to do this -- perhaps the inevitable byproduct of an election campaign in which foreign policy was deliberately played down and not worked out in detail.
One approach, espoused by Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, is detachment: Avoid overreaction to Mr. Hussein and try to accept the status quo as a necessary product of a war that left the Iraqi leader in power. "You treat Saddam like a toothache," said a Pentagon official familiar with the general's thinking. "There are periods when it doesn't hurt as much as other times, but it just doesn't go away and you can never quite forget about it."
 
Keeping Hussein Cornered
 This is not essentially different from the Bush policy that Mr. Clinton has inherited: Keep Mr. Hussein cornered in the hope of eroding his power, rather than doing something more drastic and risking the dismemberment of Iraq.
A variant on this approach that is under discussion is to start with Mr. Bush's stated premise that Mr. Hussein must be ousted but then go further than Mr. Bush did by taking real steps to oust him. Vice President Al Gore was -- and may still be -- an advocate of this point of view, having written in 1991 that not only Mr. Hussein, but also his entire Baath Party apparatus, must disappear. Some of the tougher tactics that have been suggested include extending the ban on Iraqi military flights to the entire country and arming the Iraqi opposition with help from Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait. But both steps were rejected last year by the Bush Administration and neither enjoys much support among the countries that would have to help.
A fundamental problem with this approach is that ousting Mr. Hussein has never been popular in the coalition that supported the gulf war. A number of allies might quietly agree today with the stunningly frank statement made on the eve of the war by Boutros Boutros-Ghali, then Egypt's Minister of State for Foreign Affairs and now the United Nations Secretary General. Despite the passions of the moment, he said, Egypt could coexist, even cooperate, with Mr. Hussein.
A third approach might be called, as one official did, "the cake-and-eat-it approach." The goal would be to launch an essentially diplomatic initiative designed to take the focus off Iraq and allow more attention for Bosnia, which the Clinton Administration considers a more intractable problem. In a series of meetings last week, policy makers debated how to do this with a combination of diplomatic sticks (and perhaps carrots) that might persuade Mr. Hussein at last to abide by the United Nations resolutions intended to curb his power. Suggestions include creating a war-crimes tribunal and forcibly deploying human rights monitors throughout Iraq, Administration officials said. But keeping the alliance together is very time-consuming and containment doesn't offer a long-term solution for the Kurds in northern Iraq.
Still, in the long run, the Clinton team may be correct that the more difficult adversary to deal with will not be Mr. Hussein, who has already been isolated for two years, but Mr. Milosevic, the Serb leader in whose name ethnic cleansing is carried out in the Balkans.
 
An Inconsistency
 The new Administration has acknowledged that there is an inconsistency in turning the screws on Mr. Hussein but not on Mr. Milosevic. It finds itself caught between wanting the United Nations negotiations led by former Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance to succeed in bringing peace to the Balkans, and fearing that the proposed settlement would only ratify Serbian aggression and atrocities. The contradiction was exposed last week when the Administration publicly expressed support for the Geneva-based negotiations while Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher expressed doubts through his spokesman that the peace plan will work.
In helping to shape new policies for both Iraq and Bosnia, Mr. Christopher, a lawyer, charged in his confirmation hearings that Democratic and Republican Administrations had "tolerated and supported dictators too long in many countries," and called for war crimes trials for atrocities in both Iraq and the Balkans.
He has also sought to distance himself from an image that lingers from his days as Deputy Secretary of State to Mr. Vance -- of being too much the litigator and too little accustomed to using force.
But there is reluctance among top Clinton Administration officials to state categorically that Mr. Milosevic cannot be negotiated with, just as there is an unwillingness to say that Mr. Hussein must go. And in neither Iraq nor the Balkans has the the new Administration gone beyond strategies for containment to consider how it might promote truly democratic, peaceful rule.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
EVEN before taking the oath of office, President Clinton was bombarded with advice on how to deal with Russia and the other former Soviet republics. Most of it portrayed Boris N. Yeltsin as a critical and threatened bulwark against the revival of an evil empire. If the United States fails to shore him up, goes the argument, Russia could fall to Communists, fascists, revanchist generals or worse.
Yes, Russia is in a perilous state, and the risks this carries are indisputable. But not so long ago, many pundits were similarly arguing that only Mikhail S. Gorbachev's finger in the dike was keeping a new cold war at bay. In those days, Americans and other Western leaders kept the meddlesome Mr. Yeltsin at arm's length. Only a month before the August 1991 putsch, George Bush was still instructing the Ukrainians that their place was in a Soviet Union. 
 Of course, there are plenty of compelling reasons to support Mr. Yeltsin. He is likely to play the central role in Russian politics for some time to come, and he has demonstrated openness, courage and a dedication to change. Still, the struggle being waged in Russia is among ideas and interests far larger than any one man. And Mr. Yeltsin is no more the last word than Mr. Gorbachev was; there is no reason to assume that every alternative to him is terrible.
Within Russia's leadership, after all, the power struggle being played out so far is less a mortal contest between democrats and reactionaries than a tactical tug-of-war between shock therapists and gradualists.
The case of Yegor T. Gaidar is instructive. Many in the West had feared that his ouster as President Yeltsin's Prime Minister would deal a death blow to reform. But first, the West proved helpless to preserve him, and then it turned out that the new Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, may not be the reactionary many had feared. In fact, Westerners who have met him have been impressed by his openness and common sense.
This alone offers strong reason to think that the doomsday notion of a fascist dictatorship slouching toward Moscow is overblown. Some members of Mr. Yeltsin's entourage have tried to rouse such fears with dire warnings, most recently when Foreign Minister Andrei Kozyrev stunned an international conference in Stockholm with a prankish speech concocted from hard-line positions that he didn't really espouse. But among Russians, at least, such cries of "wolf" are increasingly dismissed as irresponsible.
None of this suggests that Russia is safely headed toward democracy and a free market, the goals Mr. Yeltsin has championed, or that the danger of dictatorship has been lifted. The unruly session of the Congress of Peoples' Deputies last month was enough to dispel any such illusions. But even the belligerency there was less an insurrection than a reflection of the boisterousness of Russia's political discourse. Extremists of left and right were isolated, and a large majority applauded when the chief Justice of the Constitutional Court proposed to mediate a pact between the legislature and the president.
Even without an immediate threat of dictatorship, of course, the political contests under way in Moscow are enormously important. The pace of change could well spell the difference between stability and instability. But it is not necessarily a contest in which the United States has to take sides. First, it is not clear whether Mr. Gaidar the shock therapist or Mr. Chernomyrdin the gradualist has the better chance of success. Second, Mr. Yeltsin himself has never made a clear choice. Third, there is little evidence that Washington could have much effect even if it did have a clear favorite. For all the fervent debates on American op-ed pages, foreign advisers are not all that influential in the Kremlin.
It is also worth noting that for all Russia's travails and spiritual dislocation, the people have proved surprisingly resistant to extremism. The National Salvation Front uniting the "reds" and "browns," (die-hard Communists and rabid nationalists) has attracted little support. Russia's most vocal fascist, Vladimir Zhirinovsky, is considered more a clown than a threat. Pamyat, the Russian nationalist organization that roused so much anxiety several years ago, is fragmented and all but defunct.
The more consequential struggle is among groups and interests not so easily classified as good or bad: These are the managers of state-owned industry, the military-industrial complex, the new entrepreneurs, the armies of bureaucrats, the disenfranchised soldiers, elected deputies, regional authorities, the agro-industrial complex, the ethnic minorities, Communist apparatchiks and many more. These are people who might speed or slow the pace of change, but none would easily cede power to a Zhirinovsky, or welcome back central control.
These forces are not inherently anti-West or anti-reform; rather, like the whole of the former Soviet society, they are little versed in the methods and rules of the world they seek to join. So it is with them that America and the West might have the most profound influence, simply by sharing their experience. Many a thoughtful Communist or industrial manager could benefit from exposure to a world that he has perceived until now only through hostile propaganda.
Americans in particular often do not appreciate how great a reservoir of good will the Russians and most other citizens of the former Soviet lands still hold for the United States. This is not the trite sort of "friendship among peoples" that the Communists used to preach, but a deep sense of kinship and admiration. America is still the most important foreign land to most Russians, the one against which they measure success and failure.
These sentiments carry power as great as any financial or humanitarian aid; the risk is that Americans could squander them through inadvertent condescension or dismissiveness, or by promoting a perception that the West is pillaging Russia's resources. Conversely, any gesture of solidarity or concern has a potentially far-reaching effect.
Financial aid is one obvious way to show concern, but magnanimity can also be free. Many Russian leaders were insulted, for example, that they were not consulted on the military actions taken against Iraq, even though these might have serious reverberations in Russian politics. And some diplomats in Kiev thought a touch of personal diplomacy by Mr. Bush would have gone a long way to get Ukrainian support for nuclear disarmament.
The argument here is less for any specific action than for a need to be sensitive to people who have suffered an extraordinary setback, a fractured nation facing the devastating realization that 70 years of its life have been misguided. It is not simply a question of honor or sympathy. Recent history offers compelling evidence that victory in war can be claimed only when the vanquished has not lost everything, including hope. The cold war is no different.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Lesson for a High-Tech President

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
IT is no mystery why Silicon Valley became Clinton country in last year's election. The Clinton Administration's style and policy pronouncements appeal to the people who labor in high-technology industries like software and semiconductors. The Clintonites talk technospeak, often at length. They aren't squeamish about declaring that some industries are more equal than others, or that these favored high-tech fields should get government help and taxpayers' money.
President Clinton arrives in Washington with an ambitious technology policy that calls for using government-backed research projects, tax incentives and trade policy to help high-tech industries become engines of economic growth and job creation. 
 But the future has an elusive quality in fast-changing technology fields, which raises questions about government's ability to help industry get there. Even Japan, often viewed as a model of high-tech industrial policy, hasn't had much luck lately. Its so-called fifth-generation computer project, so feared in the early 1980's, closed up shop recently, left in the dust by the private sector's pace of innovation. Similarly, Japan's high-definition television effort seems to have bet on yesterday's technology.
Perhaps the most vivid example of how quickly shifts in technology can change markets and assumptions is illustrated by the plight of the International Business Machines Corporation, the humbled giant of the American computer industry. Last week, I.B.M. reported a $4.97 billion loss for 1992, the largest in corporate history. Its work force has been slashed, the company's shares trade for less than half the price they did last summer, and some fear that I.B.M. may not be able to pull out of its slide.
Yet not so long ago, in the mid-1980's, the setting was very different. Back then, I.B.M. was the dominant force in the world computer industry. But the great worry in the American computer and semiconductor industries, and in policy circles, was the threat posed by Japan. The Intel Corporation, which makes microprocessor chips that serve as the brains of personal computers, was reeling from heavy losses.
A few years earlier, when Intel was first under pressure, I.B.M. made a big investment in it. This was an act of benevolent self-interest by I.B.M., supporting a key supplier and American semiconductor development.
For its part, the Japanese computer industry viewed I.B.M. as its White Whale. Catching up to I.B.M. was an obsession for Japan and every possible effort, legal or otherwise, was made to match it.
Today, not only is I.B.M. embattled, but the big Japanese computer makers have similar problems. Intel, meanwhile, is enjoying explosive growth as the demand surges for personal computers that use its chips. New, powerful Intel chips let small, cheaper computers replace larger ones.
So I.B.M. is being hurt not by its perceived enemy of a few years ago, Japan Inc., but by its old friend -- or, more precisely, by its inability to adjust to the technological pace set by other American companies.
There is a lively debate about why this happened to I.B.M. Still, whatever the cause, if I.B.M., with all its resources, could not keep up with the trajectory of change, what chance does government have of guiding technology development?
"A crisis like the one I.B.M. is going through raises questions about the kind of technology policy a nation should pursue," said Peter Cowhey, a professor of political science and international relations at the University of California at San Diego.
 
Synfuels to Data Highways
 In Mr. Cowhey's view, there has been an evolution in the thinking about technology policy. The first generation, he says, was the effort to back huge projects like the synthetic fuels plan of the late 1970's to do things like extract oil from shale. The next generation's idea, much discussed in America and actively pushed in Europe in the 1980's, held that Western nations needed to compete with Japanese industrial groups by backing similar groups and so-called national champions -- big corporations with the financial strength and research prowess to be technological standard bearers. I.B.M. long epitomized the national champion corporation.
The focus now is less on the structure of industries or on fostering technologies within single companies than on insuring that the United States has key technologies within its borders or access to them abroad.
The Clinton technology policy is a blend of infrastructure projects like a national optical-fiber telecommunications highway, spending on education to create a more skilled work force, tax incentives for investment in startup companies and aggressive use of trade policy to open foreign markets.
To nurture technologies deemed critical to the economy, government-industry collaborations would be encouraged, patterned after Sematech, which was founded in 1987 to develop American-made tools to make computer chips. The idea is that with private industry putting up at least half the money, there is far less chance of creating costly high-tech pork barrels.
To help pay for new programs, President Clinton plans a post-cold war shift in the Federal research-and-development budget away from defense, freeing up an additional $7 billion over three years.
The Administration's early positions on technology and trade policy owe much to the Berkeley Roundtable on the International Economy at the University of California at Berkeley, where the new chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, was research director.
Government, said Michael Borrus, a co-director of the Berkeley Roundtable, should distinguish between a pervasive and essential technology, like semiconductors, which Washington should back, and a product, like high-definition television, which it should not.
Yet many economists warn that having government select target areas, even broadly, is risky. Washington, they say, should create an environment for innovation with policies that reduce the cost of capital, provide an ample pool of scientists and skilled workers and offer tax incentives for research. Bolster the nation's technological infrastructure, they advise, but then let companies and markets pick the projects.
"It doesn't mean there's nothing government can do," said Robert Z. Lawrence, an economist at Harvard University, "but that you get precise at your peril."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Clinton's Blunt Reminder of the Mood That Elected Him

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THERE were many "if only" post mortems offered last week after President Clinton was forced to withdraw the nomination of Zoe Baird as Attorney General in the first, dramatic failure of his Administration.
If only she had not been an exceedingly well-paid corporate lawyer, her nomination might have survived despite her admission that she hired two illegal aliens for child care and household help. If only she had a more expansive track record on traditionally liberal issues that would inspire support from feminists or other core Democratic constituencies. If only her name had not been introduced at the last minute as Mr. Clinton cast desperately about for an appointment that would demonstrate his commitment to diversity. 
 One White House official even mused that if only Ms. Baird had been considered by the Senate earlier, she might have been approved on the first wave of goodwill that allowed Senators to ignore the questions raised about other nominees.
"If her hearings had been on Jan. 6 and Ron Brown's had been on Jan. 19, there would have been opposite outcomes," the official said.
"Any one of these nominations could have blown up in a similar way," said another Clinton adviser. "There were plenty of other time bombs."
Mr. Brown's violations, of course, were ethical rather than legal. The new Secretary of Commerce seemed to be too cozy with the industries he was overseeing and with his tony Washington law firm.
Ms. Baird had admitted breaking the law to Mr. Clinton's transition officials and yet was still in line to become the nation's top law enforcement officer. Many of the people who elected Mr. Clinton felt that by nominating her, he broke a compact with them. But their complaints, in interviews and in phone calls to radio and television call-in shows, centered more on the fact that she cut corners than that she broke the law.
And Mr. Clinton, who spent the last year warning against taking for granted average people who "work hard and play by the rules," appeared in his first days in office to be doing just that. He has been found guilty of the gravest error for a man who campaigned on a platform of change: conducting business as usual.
Conducting business as usual sank John Tower's nomination four years ago. Although he was accused of excessive drinking and womanizing, his star really fell because he came to represent all that is smarmy about the nation's capital.
In stanching the flow of criticism before it reached the Oval Office on Friday, Mr. Clinton may have taken his cue from James A. Baker 3d, the former Secretary of State, Treasury Secretary and White House chief of staff who headed off a scandal of his own in 1989 by announcing that he would sell his stock in Chemical New York Corporation, a bank holding company that had made billions of dollars in loans to third world countries.
The point of Mr. Baker's announcement was to demonstrate his commitment to high ethical standards by erasing any perception of conflict of interest before the notion took hold in Washington. John Sununu, the White House chief of staff who stubbornly ignored signs that his penchant for using Government-paid transportation for private purposes would be debilitating, could have taken a lesson from Mr. Baker.
He did not, and when he was forced out of his job, the odor of scandal accompanied his exit.
When Senator Tower's nomination ran aground barely two weeks after President Bush took office, historians and politicians murmured that the rules of conduct had all shifted. They said there was a new morality in American politics that was holding Cabinet nominees to a new, stricter standard.
If that was true in 1989, it is also true in a different way in 1993. The standard, however, is more personal and more specific to the chief problem Mr. Clinton has pledged to help cure -- the economy.
For Mr. Clinton, the lesson to be learned from the Zoe Baird debacle is that he should not allow the Presidential bubble to block his famous political instincts. Some of the advisers who helped run his effective and media-savvy campaign fretted among themselves last week that those around their old boss seemed to have gone politically tone deaf.
Caught up in the rush of the Inaugural, working with a White House staff he appointed barely a week ago, and assuming overconfidently that a Senate controlled by Democrats would not reject one of his most important nominees, he failed to note that no one among the reliable constituencies was standing up for Ms. Baird.
Absent this support, Mr. Clinton, Ms. Baird and her backers needed to organize a groundswell on their own. When they did not, Clinton advisers said, the Senators were listening only to ringing phones with angry home-state voters on the other end.
Perhaps Mr. Clinton was following the wrong score. He was listening for the sounds of organized opposition, not the absence of organized support. In the end, that absence was just as damaging.
The televised images of Ms. Baird in a designer suit, talking about how motherhood had forced her to break the law, clashed with the chord Mr. Clinton struck in his campaign book, "Putting People First."
"For the last 12 years, government has served the rich and special interests," reads the preface signed by Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore. "Millions of middle-class Americans have paid more to government but gotten less in return."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Britain Senses a Lapse in That Special Relationship

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
FOR weeks, editors and politicians here have been waging an unusual trans-Atlantic campaign, nudging the incoming Clinton team to consider preserving at least one holdover from the Bush Administration: Raymond G. H. Seitz, the United States Ambassador to Britain. "If he is wise," The Times of London advised, "Mr. Clinton will recognize that there are some virtues in continuity."
The new Administration has not yet signaled what it will do with Mr. Seitz, a Foreign Service officer whose appointment by President Bush in 1991 broke a more-than-200-year tradition of naming well-heeled political appointees to the London post. 
But on this side of the Atlantic, the public testimonials on behalf of the United States Ambassador appear to represent more than admiration for his skills as a professional diplomat. These days there are many in Britain who have a bad case of jitters over the transition from the Bush to the Clinton Administration, and they perhaps yearn to hang on to Mr. Seitz as a calming influence during what could be a bumpy ride.
At stake is the future course of what Winston Churchill called "the special relationship," that complex bundle of shared history, values and language -- coupled with common economic and strategic goals -- that over time have made Britain America's closest and most loyal ally, even if there are those in London who would prefer still to regard America as the junior partner.
In some ways, the special relationship matters more now than ever. While the United States dwarfs Britain in military prowess and global influence, Washington has increasingly relied on the British as a loyal sidekick as they try to police an increasingly fractious world after the cold war.
In the Persian Gulf war, in Bosnia and, most recently, in the renewed conflict with Iraq, the United States and Britain have become the axis around which at least part of the new world order spins. Last weekend, Prime Minister John Major and Mr. Bush conferred by telephone six times about the military reply to Saddam Hussein's defiance of United Nations resolutions.
But in a world in which instant telephone diplomacy is increasingly important, the change in administrations represents a challenge to the British after 12 years of ideological compatibility between Reagan-Bush Republicans and the Conservative Governments of Margaret Thatcher and Mr. Major.
For one thing, there is a strong sense in London that Mr. Major is setting out with a big disadvantage. Last fall, some Clinton aides concluded that Mr. Major's Government was pulling for Mr. Bush in the American elections. Not only did the Conservative Party dispatch advisers to Washington to work with the Bush campaign, they say, but British bureaucrats searched Government records to check out spurious rumors that young Mr. Clinton had sought to renounce his American citizenship while a student at Oxford University in the 1960's.
At the same time, candidate Clinton irked Britons during the campaign, criticizing British policy in Northern Ireland and suggesting a harder line with China at a time when the British already have their hands full with China's leaders over the future of Hong Kong.
Officially, the Government plays down any friction with Mr. Clinton, or foreboding over the relationship. An aide to the Prime Minister even suggested that Mr. Major would get on splendidly with Mr. Clinton, not only because the new President studied at Oxford and knows Britain, but because both he and the Prime Minister are "self-made men" with humble backgrounds.
Over the last 40 years there have been real jolts to the special relationship. The biggest came in 1956, when President Eisenhower angrily blocked a British-led campaign to wrest back control of the Suez Canal from the Egyptians. President Nixon and Edward Heath never got on well, partly because the Prime Minister pushed British policy toward Europe. And Harold Wilson's refusal to commit even a token British contingent to Vietnam rankled President Johnson.
 
Strain Over Bosnia
 Despite the tandem between Mr. Major and Mr. Bush, strains were becoming evident in their relationship, too. The biggest stumbling block, now and probably in the future, is Bosnia, where the British have resisted stepping up military pressure on the Serbs, as the United States has urged. The British, with 2,400 troops on United Nations peacekeeping duty in Bosnia, are reluctant to put their soldiers at risk.
In the end, Ambassador Seitz says, the strains in the American-British relationship have little to do with changes in American administrations. The larger issue is the shifting structure of European politics itself, since the end of the cold war has erased the central fact of the trans-Atlantic alliance: the specter of a large, hostile, military, anti-democratic power in the center of Europe, embodied first in the Nazis and later the Communists.
In both countries, perspectives are shifting. Mr. Clinton intends to focus inward, to secure America's economic security, and Britain is increasingly distracted by a debate over its role within the European Community. The more troubling question for the future is whether Britain and the United States will be able, jointly, to continue to look at the new world in the same way.
David Reynolds, a historian at Cambridge University, says that for now Britain and America share the same strategic goals as "status quo powers," particularly since the British, unlike the Germans, are willing to project their power. "Like most alliances, the cement has always been an external threat," he said, referring to the special relationship. "The cement now is a general and alarming threat of global instability."

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Business Is Losing Patience With The Cold War's Export Police

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
IN the twisted skein that is the post-cold-war world, a big tangle is Cocom, the 17-nation Western trade organization that polices high-technology exports to Russia.
Western companies complain that Cocom -- short for the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls -- continues to fight the cold war. It is also being cautious to a fault, they say, in guarding against sensitive technology being resold to unintended recipients like Iran or Syria. 
 As a result, company officials say, Russia and other former Soviet republics aren't getting technology that could be immediately useful in jump-starting their collapsing economies.
Cocom officials argue that caution is justified precisely because the former Soviet republics are so unstable, leaving great uncertainty about how the technology will be used. Also very much in mind is the lesson of Iraq, which thanks to lax Western export controls was able to import technology for its nuclear arms program.
Cocom, founded in 1949 at the outset of the cold war to stem sensitive exports to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, is made up of all the NATO countries except Iceland, plus Japan and Australia. Over the years, Cocom's Paris headquarters has seen many diplomatic battles, with the United States usually succeeding in blocking exports to the Soviet bloc by its European allies.
Last November, acknowledging that the world had changed after the collapse of Communism, Cocom's member countries announced what they called a sweeping relaxation of export controls.
But two months later, companies like A.T.&T., Sun Microsystems, Cable and Wireless of Britain and Siemens of Germany say little has changed: a group organized to say no cannot bring itself to say yes.
Barred for export are computers like many of those found on American desktops that could help Russian managers convert military factories to civilian use. Also, Western companies have been blocked from modernizing a telephone system that dates to the Russian Revolution. Such an overhaul could lead to more efficient distribution of all kinds -- for example, dispatching trains and trucks when and where they are needed and thereby preventing huge grain losses.
 
Hold the Phones
 Sun Microsystems, the computer maker, says that since the November Cocom announcement it hasn't applied for any potentially controversial export licenses. Innocuous computer-test programs have still not been approved for export nearly a year after application. "Why even try something controversial?" asked David R. Ditzel, director of advanced systems for the research arm of Sun Microsystems.
Christopher A. Padilla, government-affairs manager for A.T.&T, said, "Practically speaking, we've yet to see any results." Cocom pronouncements about liberalization "are almost always a snow job," he said.
Cocom's regulations are administered by each member country, rather than its Paris-based staff. In the United States, the rules are overseen by the State Department, but others reviewing applications are the Commerce Department; the Defense Department and its intelligence arm, the National Security Agency; the Energy Department; the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency and occasionally the President's national security adviser.
The cold war still shadows Cocom decisions. Because Russia and the other former republics are in turmoil, intelligence agencies want to monitor potential threats to Western interests there. One way is listening in on phone conversations, and the more primitive the telephone system, the easier it is to eavesdrop with spy satellites and other devices.
For example, Cocom allows A.T.&T. to sell the Russians the world's best-selling advanced computer for routing telephone calls -- a device called the 5ESS switch -- but not the hard-to-wiretap software capabilities that make it useful.
A few years ago, U S West, the American regional phone company, and Cable and Wireless of Britain each proposed installing fiber-optic lines across northern Russia. Such high-capacity lines are essential for installing large numbers of neighborhood telephone lines that work. .
But both projects were scuttled by Cocom because of objections by the National Security Agency, experts both inside and outside the Government say. The American agency feared that Russian military commanders could evade eavesdropping by connecting into the fiber-optic lines that would pass near Russian missile fields. The N.S.A., the nation's largest intelligence agency, declined to comment.
The fiber-optic lines would have entailed one of history's most ambitious construction projects, with crews laboriously chipping through more than 5,000 miles of land that is either ice or swamp. In most countries, such work would take many years and several billion dollars. But in Russia, either project would have taken two years and cost $500 million, primarily because of cheap and plentiful Russian labor.
Cocom rules have also prevented Sun Microsystems from selling work stations, or high-powered desktop computers, to two large auto and truck factories in the Moscow area. Its $20,000 work station, about the size of a pizza box, is defined by Cocom as having the power of a multimillion-dollar supercomputer, the kind used to design nuclear missiles.
Even if Sun could sell the computers, it may have to comply with more than 30 State Department restrictions, including a 24-hour guard around the computer and bans on computer networking and on moving the machine anywhere, even across the street, once it is installed.
Some experts think Cocom should be abolished and replaced with a more unified organization to help stop the spread of nuclear and other weapons.
"I'm a hard-liner on export controls," said Stephen D. Bryen, the former Pentagon official who helped write Cocom export restrictions during the Reagan Administration. "But the world has changed and Cocom doesn't make sense anymore."
Others say that Cocom will still be needed. "A lot of people think Cocom is a cold war dinosaur," said a State Department official who, like other Government officials, asked for anonymity as a condition for being interviewed. "Maybe it is and maybe it isn't. But there are some nitty-gritty decisions ahead for the Clinton Administration. Security concerns have to be high on his list."

HEADLINE: Increasingly, 2-Career Family Means Illegal Immigrant Help

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG

 BODY:
The hiring of illegal household workers appears to be so commonplace that licensed employment agencies in an immigrant haven like New York routinely violate the law by recommending undocumented immigrants for hire, usually at lower wages than legal workers would be paid.
Even the controversy over Zoe Baird's employment of illegal immigrants, which led to her withdrawal Friday as President Clinton's nominee for Attorney General, did not push employment agents to hide their practices last week. Thirteen of 18 agents who were called acknowledged without hesitation that they represented both legal and illegal immigrants, with illegal workers earning as little as $175 a week and legal ones as much as $600. 
 "It's just a reality of life that without the illegal girls, there wouldn't be any nannies, and the mommies would have to stay home and mind their own kids," said the owner of a Manhattan nanny agency, who, like many others, spoke on the condition of anonymity since he regularly places illegal immigrants.
 
Furtive Encounters Not Needed
 The employment agents' matter-of-fact admissions about illegal activity clearly indicate that this part of the country's growing underground economy does not depend on furtive encounters or discreet advertisements. Rather, the public spotlight on Ms. Baird's household situation has brought to light a pervasive phenomenon: the pragmatic, above-ground relationship that links illegal immigrants and middle-class homes in gateway cities across the country for decades. Caribbean women gravitated to the New York area, and Latin American women to Miami and the West Coast. In the 1980's, as more American women with young children moved into the workplace, the demand for housekeepers increased exponentially, satisfied by greater numbers of West Indians and Latin Americans and by new illegal migration from the Philippines, China, Ireland and Poland.
As this informal economic network grew more entrenched, Congress passed a law in 1986, aimed at large companies, that created penalties for employers who knowingly hired illegal immigrants. But the web of relationships was so established and the law so sporadically enforced that the illegal housekeeper and child-care business, which employs hundreds of thousands of immigrant women, continued to thrive.
Since immigration officials did not check employment agency records or raid the apartments of professional couples, parents continued to hire illegal immigrants, who they said were easier to find, less expensive, and, in some cases, more loyal. And they continued to pay their household workers cash, regardless of their immigration status.
"It all comes down to money," said Nedra Kleinman, who runs the All Home Services Agency on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. "No matter how you slice it, the reason that people hire immigrants without papers is that they're looking to save. If they want legal, they can get it, but it costs."
Families with incomes like that of Ms. Baird and her husband -- $600,000 a year -- tend to pay the extra money for legal workers since they like having the option of taking their nannies on trips abroad, many agents said.
 
Slave Job to Most Americans
 And rarely does an American-born worker apply for a nanny job, they added.
"These days, most Americans see it as some kind of slavery," said Dorothea Grant, a Jamaican nanny who received a green card last summer after seven years without working papers.
Mrs. Grant's career has followed a typical path, a hierarchy of household jobs. When she arrived from the town of Ocho Rios, she started by working as a baby sitter for her cousin, a legal nanny. The cousin later recommended Mrs. Grant for her first live-in job, where she earned $125 a week. With two references, Mrs. Grant next found a Brooklyn Heights couple who paid her $200 a week and sponsored her for legal residency. In early January, green card in hand, she gave notice to the Brooklyn couple, who could not match the $500-a-week salary she was offered for a live-out job on Park Avenue.
"Now I will be my own master," Mrs. Grant said Friday morning, bragging to the other baby sitters, almost all illegal, in a Brooklyn Heights playground.
 
Most Rely on Network
 Most families in the New York area do not find their baby sitters through agencies, which charge about $600 to $1,250. Instead, they rely on the nanny network, collecting names from friends' employees, or on the nanny shopper, the nickname given The Irish Echo, a New York weekly.
Susan Serota, a tax lawyer who has two teen-age sons, placed one of the rare ads in The Irish Echo that specify "U.S.A. citizen or green card only."
"My husband and I are both lawyers, and we never wanted to do something that might come back and haunt us," she said.
Professor Moss predicted, only half-jokingly, that hiring an illegal baby sitter would become the young professionals' new sin, and that sinners by the score would come forth with public confessions. "Now that sex and drugs have become acceptable, yuppies will be judged by the immigration status of their baby sitters," he said.
In fact, two candidates for the Republican nomination for New Jersey governor, Christine Todd Whitman and Cary Edwards, disclosed on Friday that they, too, had employed illegal aliens in their homes and failed to pay their Social Security taxes.
 
Baird Couple Faces Hearing
 After her nomination for Attorney General, Ms. Baird paid a $2,900 fine to the immigration agency and $8,000 in back taxes and interest. The agency then declared its intention to deport Victor and Lillian Cordero, the Peruvian couple who used to work for her.
Mr. Cordero has gone into hiding, but Helene A. Pepe, his lawyer, said yesterday that he would try to stay in the United States. "He doesn't understand why he's being singled out," said Ms. Pepe, an immigration lawyer in Stamford, Conn. The Corderos have separated, and it could not be determined where Mrs. Cordera was.
Critics of the new sanctions against employers, like Michael Fix of the Urban Institute, argue that the law is largely symbolic of a tough stance against illegal immigration, but has done little to control it. Many say, at the least, that household employers should be exempt, or that household workers should get a special visa.
"A law that forces thousands of illegal immigrants and middle-class families to engage in criminal activity desperately needs to be reformed," said Philip Kasinitz, a sociologist at Williams College and an authority on Caribbean culture in New York.
Most household employers rarely thought about breaking the law or getting caught until Ms. Baird was forced to withdraw. Some said they would start paying Social Security taxes this year, although they feared creating a paper trail leading to their illegal housekeepers. Other said they would not change the way they lived.
 
Housekeeper Before Politics
 "After Zoe Baird, my husband and I discussed whether it was now an issue for us, and decided that neither of us will ever run for office," said an Upper West Side mother of three, who said she would continue to employ an illegal Peruvian housekeeper.
Despite the controversy, a woman in Floral Park, Queens, said she was specifically looking to hire a newly arrived, illegal immigrant to care for her newborn triplets. "I want someone who cannot leave the country, who doesn't know anyone in New York, who basically does not have a life," the woman said. "I want someone who is completely dependent on me and loyal to my family."
Many agencies describe their illegal immigrants euphemistically, as "girls looking for sponsorship situations." Like Ms. Baird, some employers agree to sponsor immigrants for legal residency, but the process now takes up to a decade and the employees remain in an illegal status during that time. Some illegal immigrants say they feel like indentured servants during that period.
One such housekeeper, a Guyanese woman who live and works in Woodmere, L.I., said she paid a lawyer $2,500 to file her application for residency six years ago. Meanwhile, she earns $200 a week and is expected to be available around the clock to the family sponsoring her.
"You're trapped in this situtation, very trapped," the woman said.
But Naomi Victor, a Haitian immigrant, said she had thrived in the years she worked for a family that was sponsoring her. "Yes, there are vicious people out there," she said. "But there are also women like my Blossom Unger, who taught me to speak proper English, and sent me to school for word processing and found me a $275-a-month apartment on Amsterdam and 94th."
Jon Lukomnik, who hires only legal baby sitters "for peace of mind" and because he is the Assistant Commisioner of New York City's Department of Finance, called the required government paperwork a disincentive to those who want to abide by the law. After securing a fFederal tax identification number and completing an I-9 immigration application proving the worker's legal status, household employers must file 28 other forms a year, four of them yearly and six quarterly.
Ms. Kleinman of All Home Services noted that the Government never once checked the immigration records she had meticulously kept for six years. She said it was lonely being a "goody-two-shoes."
"You have no idea, the frustration, sitting here, knocking your head against the wall, trying to do what's right," she said. "And then you have a Zoe Baird who exposes the fact that everybody else is breaking the law."

(Lee Romero/The New York Times) (pg. 32)

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: Rare in Ivy League: Women Who Work As Full Professors

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
Phoebe S. Leboy did not set out to change the academic world when she joined the faculty of the University of Pennsylvania School of Dental Medicine in 1967. She was a young scientist eager to become a full professor of biochemistry because it was one measure of achievement in her field, even if it was a position no woman had ever held at the school.
Today, Dr. Leboy is chairwoman of the dental school's department of biochemistry, a faculty member for a quarter of a century and the only female professor the dental school has ever had. 
 Eight other women are on the 51-member faculty of the school, but none are full professors. "I would like some company," Dr. Leboy said.
After more than two decades in which the nation's most prestigious universities have pledged to overcome the shortage of women on their faculties, Dr. Leboy's experience is far from unusual. In the Ivy League -- an elite group of eight universities that presumably can have their pick of the most talented candidates -- women make up 7 percent to 13 percent of professors, excluding those in the medical schools. Many departments do not have a single female full professor.
Whole schools in the Ivy League, like Penn's dental school, have few or no female professors. Harvard University's dental school has nine male professors but no female ones (six women are on track for tenure); its John F. Kennedy School of Government has 20 male professors and one female, with four other women working toward tenure, a system intended to insure academic freedom by making it very difficult to dismiss professors.
Inequity continues after women are hired. In general, women at every step of the tenure ladder still earn less than men, sometimes substantially less. At Harvard, for instance, male professors earn $93,600 on average while women of equal rank earn $79,900 on average.
 
'Much Worse in Universities'
 "What it comes down to basically is a reluctance to believe that women are as good as men," said Mary W. Gray, professor of mathematics and statistics at American University in Washington who is also a lawyer. "Generally, it's much worse in universities than in the corporate world because academics are so arrogant we don't think anyone can tell us what to do."
Members of minorities are also not represented in anything like their numbers in the classroom -- about 11 percent of the faculty members nationwide are minorities, as against 19 percent of all college students, according to the National Center for Education Statistics.
The outlook for hiring more women has been dimmed by university budget problems and competing demands to hire faculty members from under-represented racial and ethnic groups. And the situation could get worse next June when professors will no longer have to retire at age 70, leaving fewer openings in senior faculty positions. After Congress passed legislation in 1986 outlawing mandatory retirement based on age for most workers, the protection was later extended to professors.
The Ivy League is not alone in its lack of female professors. While women make up more than half of all college students, they make up just 27.6 percent of faculty members.
 
Inroads Where Pay Is Lowest
 And even that figure is misleading. The more prestigious the institution, the fewer women there are. And the higher the rank, the lower the likelihood that a woman will hold it. Thus, women make up only 11.6 percent of full professors nationwide and have made their greatest inroads at community colleges, where the pay is lowest. Women hold 38 percent of all faculty positions in those colleges.
A sampling of the nation's most selective universities shows that the percentage of female faculty members hovers around 20 percent over all. Looking at just the Ivy league, which has the prestige and scholarly opportunities to be able to attract the most talented candidates, shows how slow progress has been.
This is a sensitive area for the universities; some react defensively to queries about hiring, complaining that statistics are misinterpreted and that they have made progress in hiring women and minority faculty members.
"You can't expect academe to look like America instantaneously, if ever," said Daniel S. Hamermesh, an economist at Michigan State University who compiled an extensive survey of the nation's professors for the American Association of University Professors. "It takes a lot of time to feed through the academic process."
Professor Hamermesh's latest report shows that, on average, women make up 10 percent of the professors in the Ivy League. In the next two ranks -- associate professor, which also usually carries tenure, and assistant professor, which can lead to tenure -- women are much better represented, with an average of 30 percent of each of those positions. These figures lead universities to hold out hope that, in time, women will move into the most senior positions.
Besides the obvious issues of equity, this lack of representation causes concern because if minority students and women have trouble identifying with professors they may hesitate to consider becoming professors themselves, thereby prolonging the shortage. And especially in fields like mathematics and the sciences where minorities and women have historically not been present in large numbers, their absence is seen as doubly damaging.
"Having a field like mathematics viewed as the province or property of one segment of society is no better than having all gold and silver owned by one segment of society," said Deborah Hughes Hallett, a member of the mathematics department at Harvard for 20 years. "This is an intellectual kind of gold and silver."
Change has come slowly to the most tradition-bound of universities, the Ivies. Most of the eight institutions -- Brown, Columbia, Cornell, Dartmouth, Harvard, Pennsylvania, Princeton and Yale -- did not accept female students, or worry about hiring female professors, until the late 1960's and early 70's.
Over the years since then, each Ivy League institution has started efforts to increase the hiring of women and members of minorities, commissioning studies and printing reports. Since 1968, Yale University has conducted 18 studies dealing with either female or minority faculty members. It has more than doubled the number of tenured women, to 33, on its arts and sciences faculty over the last decade, but that still represents just 10 percent of the positions.
The latest hiring report, in 1991, found that "Yale's position and its national image in this area remains precariously close to the backwaters of academic progress."
Judith Rodin, who, as provost of Yale, is the highest-ranking woman in the Ivy League, said universities needed to rethink their hiring policies to increase the number of female and minority faculty members.
 
'We're Trying Very Hard'
 "We're trying very hard," she said. "That's not a defense, it's an explanation. And if we're serious about having our faculty reflect the graduate pool, and more closely reflect what we see at the undergraduate level, we need to rethink our tenuring policies."
Yale and Harvard differ from most other universities in the way they hire faculty members. Senior positions, or slots, are filled with the best scholars that can be found, even if it means passing over younger faculty members already in the department and recruiting from the outside.
Life in the Ivies can be uncertain for those young scholars because if their term -- generally seven years -- ends and no position is available, they are let go.
Ms. Rodin said the traditional system had served Yale and Harvard well but may now be outdated. "The cost to individuals and the institution may now be too great," she said.
Considering what things were like 20 years ago, many Ivy administrators take pride in how things have improved.
For example, a Brown professor sued the university in 1977, asserting that she was denied tenure because she was a woman. This led to a class-action suit that was settled out of court with a decree that set affirmative-action goals and timetables that the university agreed to abide by. Last May, after 14 years during which Brown increased the number of tenured women to 67 from 12, and female faculty members over all to 128 from 52, a Federal District Court judge lifted the decree.
Pennsylvania has shown similar movement. In 1981, 5 percent of the university's professors were women. Today, 11 percent of the professors are women and four of the university's 12 deans are women.
But by their own accounts, the universities have taken too long and done too little. In part, they say, when the Ivies went co-educational and the push was on to hire more women, the baby-boom generation had already enrolled in college and the greatest faculty expansion was over. Still, many professors say hiring in their departments continued apace, but women got few of the jobs.
Another reason is that even when women are hired many leave before they are promoted to senior positions because they are often worn down by subtle discrimination and suspicion about their abilities. Many women in senior positions say this is worse in the Ivy League, where the stakes are so high and the pressures to perform, publish and win research grants so great that women, like some men, are driven to leave for more congenial campuses.
Universities are also highly decentralized. While deans and provosts can set policy guidelines on hiring, decisions are made by senior professors in academic departments, who are sometimes averse to change.
Then there is the pipeline argument, which says that universities would like to hire more women but that candidates are simply not available. Out-of-work Ph.D.'s and a whole generation of female scholars find that argument hard to swallow, since women receive 36 percent of the 38,000 doctorates conferred each year.
The bottom line, many Ivy League women say, is that the all-male tradition of the Ivy institutions still haunts them. Until women are in senior positions, and able to influence choices about hiring, they say, many areas of academe will remain hostile to women.
