HEADLINE: SETTLING IN: Clinton's Departure;
The Reagan-Bush Era Is Left Behind In a Flurry of Executive Policy Moves

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Although his moves were partly obscured by the uproar over his Attorney General nominee, President Clinton in his first days in office actually did begin to carry out what he had promised: a fundamental shift in the role that the American Government will play at home and abroad and the values it will seek to encourage.
While trying to quell the political damage from the retreat on Zoe Baird's nomination, Mr. Clinton was also signing a series of executive orders and ordering up a series of foreign policy reviews, which are expected not only to alter 12 years of Republican policies but also to inaugurate a new era of Government action. 
 "What got lost in the controversy over Zoe Baird was that Clinton was initiating a radical change in the way that the President and the executive branch will approach public policy," said Michael Beschloss, a historian of the Presidency. "This is as sharp and genuine a change as Franklin Roosevelt's takeover from Herbert Hoover in 1933, or Ronald Reagan's takeover from Jimmy Carter in 1981 -- from a passive Presidency to an activist one, and from one ideology to another."
It is too early to predict how effectively Mr. Clinton will sustain what he has started, Mr. Beschloss said. And his biggest promises on providing more jobs and affordable health care will be far harder to deliver.
 
All at One Stroke
 But nevertheless, with the stroke of a Presidential pen this past week Mr. Clinton took these actions:
*Lifted restrictions imposed by Presidents George Bush and Ronald Reagan on abortion counseling at federally financed clinics, on the right to perform abortions at American military hospitals overseas and on the use of fetal tissue in federally sponsored research.
*Lifted the restrictions on extending American financial aid to United Nations programs sponsoring family planning and population control -- a move that will have a far-reaching effect in countries from China to India to Egypt, which have been short of money for such programs.
*Imposed new ethics guidelines that will bar senior Government officials from lobbying the Federal agency in which they work for five years after leaving the Government -- a move that should inhibit people from seeking Government jobs in the hopes of being able to cash in once out office. The old limit was one year.
*Moved ahead with plans to repeal the ban on homosexuals in the armed forces, despite intense opposition by the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
*Abolished the Bush Administration's Council on Competitiveness, which gave business a way to obtain exemptions from Government regulations.
*Ordered his aides to review the Bush Administration policy toward Bosnia -- with an eye to taking a much bolder approach in opposing the Serbian attacks if the current peace talks in Geneva fall apart. Such steps could include lifting the American arms embargo on Bosnia, selective American air strikes against Serb gunners and war crimes tribunals against Serbian leaders.
In a sharp departure from the Bush Administration, Mr. Clinton has told aides that he will not tolerate an American policy on Serbia based purely on how it affects the global balance of power.
On other issues, Mr. Clinton is planning to prepare a new family-leave bill, like the one Mr. Bush vetoed, before Congress recesses in early February. The proposal would require employers to grant workers up to 12 weeks of unpaid family and medical leave, with continued health-insurance coverage. He also plans to introduce a bill that would require states to allow eligible citizens to register to vote when they obtain or renew their driver's, fishing or hunting licenses.
 
Comparison With 1981
 When Ronald Reagan came to office in 1980 he, too, ushered in an ideological changing of the guard, but it was different, and in some ways much simpler, than Mr. Clinton's. Mr. Reagan brought conservative values on issues from the family to abortion to taxes, but his general view of government was that it should be scaled back, that it was part of the problem, not an instrument for solutions.
Mr. Clinton brings not only liberal values on issues from family to abortion to taxes, but a general view of government that is active, not passive. What Mr. Clinton is seeking is not only a change in ideology, but also the rejuvenation of an active government for the first time since it was discredited under Lyndon B. Johnson.
"What we are trying to show is that Government can be an initiator, not a sink hole, that it can be a place where problems are solved, not where they are exacerbated," said Mr. Clinton's Communications Director, George Stephanopoulos. "These executive orders made a tangible difference in people's lives immediately. It is not like some lower deficit number or new tax. Women who go into abortion clinics Monday are going to be treated differently and that is something that is going to ripple through society."
But what is striking about the executive orders that Mr. Clinton signed in the afterglow of his inauguration, is precisely that they were the easy part: the ideological changes that can be done with a stroke of pen. They are not the test of whether this type of government can deliver.
 
Harder Jobs Ahead
 Michael J. Sandel, a political theorist at Harvard University, said: "That test will be the ability of Clinton to get through Congress his programs for economic renewal, affordable health care, job training, and national service in return for college tuition. The reasons that this is the real test is because there is more to gridlock than just the fact of divided government. Americans now wonder whether interests have become so entrenched, the economy so complex, the effects of policy so difficult to predict that government cannot be an effective agent of change.
"Changing abortion regulations is important, and has real consequences that touch peoples daily lives. But changing the health-care delivery system or educational system requires transforming massive institutions, not just issuing regulations. Doing that in a way that really touches people's lives for the better will be the true measure of whether activist government can succeed."
 
State of the Union Message
 Mr. Clinton is planning a State of the Union Message for mid-February that will include some proposals for action on these larger issues.
In the meantime, though, there is still last week's mess over the Baird nomination to be cleaned up. Sitting for his first photo session at work in the Oval Office, Mr. Clinton said he had already begun the process of selecting a new Attorney General and has told his aides to look at three or four people. Neither he nor aides would provide any names.
Despite his rather tumultuous first few days in office, Mr. Clinton said he rather liked his new job, and to underscore his links with another activist President of the past, he has retrieved the desk that John F. Kennedy used.
"So far I've liked it very much," Mr. Clinton said of the Presidency. "We just got started, you know, and I've got a lot to do."

HEADLINE: Fifth Horseman of Somalia: Stealing

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Jan. 23

 BODY:
On the hills of the city, the roofless, windowless buildings stand as a testament to war -- stucco shells that look like the remnants of bombing raids. But the truth is, most of the buildings were not bombed at all, but systematically stripped of their roofs, windows, wiring and contents during two years of civil war.
Marauding gangs, many organized by warlords and merchants, cut down telephone cables and dug up electric wires for the copper inside. They tore up the streets to steal the sewer pipes, leaving sewage to pour into the streets. 
 In a village near the port city of Merca, Somalis tell how an entire electric station disappeared overnight. In Berbera, a concrete factory disappeared and reappeared in Yemen, a United Nations official said. Statuary was spirited away, some later turning up for sale in the United Arab Emirates.
Economists, bloodlessly, call what happened disinvestment. But for the Somalis left to live in the ruins, it is both sheer physical devastation and a metaphor for how ruthless, destructive and short-sighted Somalis became, decimating their nation and continuing their war even as it brought hundreds of thousands to death by famine.
 
'Somalis Destroy Themselves'
 "I never thought Somalis could go down to this level," said Ahmed Jama, a former national police chief. "I thought I knew Somalis, but I was totally ignorant as to what could happen. I never thought Somalis would destroy themselves and all their services."
Plans are being made to undo that self-destruction and rebuild the country. Now that the Clinton Administration has taken office, the United States and United Nations will begin negotiating on when the American-led military force protecting food supply routes here will pass on its duties to a United Nations peacekeeeping force.
But the military intervention is only the first step. After the hungry are fed, Somalia needs to be rebuilt completely, both physically and psychically, because government, schools, homes and sanitation were destroyed along with personal hope and self-esteem.
Hundreds of thousands of Somalis have sought refuge in neighboring countries, and as many as 1.5 million are estimated to be living in squalid squatter camps like Camp 100 in Mogadishu.
The camp is a dusty lot where 1,600 people, many of them ill, live in beehive-shaped huts built from pieces of burlap ripped from relief food bags, scraps of linoleum, old rugs and donated green plastic sheeting. Packs of barefoot children race about, with open sores on their legs and flies covering their arms. When they become too unruly, pushing too close to peer at a visitor to the camp, the men simply cuff them to the ground.
 
Feeling Bad About Themselves
 Philip Johnston, the United Nations coordinator of humanitarian assistance in Somalia, said: "Not many people feel very good about themselves because of what Somalis have done to Somalis. Many Somalis want to demonstrate they are not ruthless uncaring human beings, that in fact they have been victims of a minority with guns."
The warring clans with the guns agreed to a cease-fire in the civil war after days of meetings on the neutral territory of Addis Ababa, and are to meet in a full-scale conference on political reconciliation in March. But a United Nations spokesman said talks to prepare for the conference broke off after the Somali National Army charged that the cease-fire had been violated by heavy fighting near Belet Uen.
Somalis say fighting has continued in Mudug and Galguduud in the north, where there are no international troops, between the forces of Gen. Mohammed Farrar Aidid and the Daroud clan of Mohammed Siad Barre, the deposed dictator.
 
Interested in Spoils of War
 Diplomats and development officials who have met with the factions still find them mostly interested in the spoils of war and in patronage, worrying about who gets to control revenue from the port, or demanding international assistance to rebuild government bureaucracies for them and provide money for government salaries.
"If you think about who went to Addis, you had the assembly of mass murderers and looters of this country," a United Nations official said. "They should have been arrested on arrival."
The peace talks the United Nations is sponsoring are tenuous, and many Somalis believe any settlement could collapse the moment international troops are pulled out.
As part of the effort to fill the power vacuum, the United States and United Nations have been reaching out to develop leaders among tribal elders, women's groups, intellectuals and religious figures, prodding them to become more active in the face of anarchy.
An American official predicted that Somalia could evolve into a decentralized country with regional decision-making. "How long it will take, and who comes out on top and how many interim steps there will be, I don't know," he said.
 
Donors to Be Sought
 Despite the uncertainty over who will run the country, the United Nations is drawing up a multi-million-dollar rehabilitation plan for the next year. Donors will be sought when the plan is presented at a conference in February.
"To do certain things you need a government, but if we don't stabilize this society, all of the money that has been spent and all of the X-number of lives given by the international community will have been wasted," said Mr. Johnston, who is on loan to the United Nations from the relief agency Care. He wants to create regional administrations and regional police forces, job programs, a food security system, garbage collection and a system for providing drinking water.
One of the most crucial tasks is to create employment, so as to end the banditry and looting by which many people survive, particularly the young men from the bush who once herded camels but were brought into the cities and armed to provide militias for the clan leaders.
"People who never worked in their lives, who were shepherds, have found a way of living with their gun," Mr. Jama said. "They will lose their business. They will be desperate."
Even with American marines checking vehicles for guns and patrolling Mogadishu, the city remains lawless. The few Somalis who have found work try to hide their employment from their neighbors, dissembling about their absences from home and hoping they will not become targets of people who think they have money.
 
Aid Vehicles Attacked
 On Friday, in separate incidents, cars belonging to several relief agencies were attacked by looters firing machine guns, and several people were wounded. Earlier in the week, a Chinese journalist was wounded and his driver shot dead when bandits tried to steal their pickup truck.
Despite the promise of education, health care, jobs and millions in aid, violence and banditry remain the daily realities for a country that is fighting for survival.
A typical survivor is the 12-year-old boy whom marines caught stealing a radio at the port. They brought him to the commanding officer, who told him he would be released if he promised not to steal.
The boy replied through an interpreter that his mother and father had died in the civil war and that he had to steal to stay alive.

HEADLINE: Bush Sets Out to Prove He Can Go Home Again

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Riding up in the elevator to work Friday morning, the new ninth-floor tenant at the pink-granite office building on Memorial Drive turned to the lone photographer riding up with him and said politely but firmly that he could come to his office door but no further.
"I've been in public for more than 20 years," said George Bush, who was wearing a windbreaker, checked shirt and running shoes and was lugging a briefcase and three duffel bags. "Now I just want a little time to myself." 
 With the stark finality of the American transition, Mr. Bush this week began his cold-turkey readjustment from the world of state dinners at the White House to tacos al carbon at Molina's Mexican Restaurant, and Houston began readjusting to having both Mr. Bush and his longtime cohort, James A. Baker 3d, back as residents.
Neither man has announced many precise plans, no doubt because neither has yet formulated them. Mr. Baker probably spoke for Mr. Bush as well as for himself on Friday when he was asked about his plans at a press conference at Rice University.
 
Future Is Fuzzy
 "I'm still trying to decide what I'm going to do when I grow up, and that's going to take a little while," Mr. Baker said. He plans for now to split his time between Houston, where he will join the governing board of Rice University and work with the university's proposed James A. Baker 3d Institute for Public Policy, and Washington, where he will return to law practice.
Back in the city where he started his political career, the 68-year-old Mr. Bush began his first days in 12 years as a private citizen with a flurry of routine activity.
Mr. Bush, who flew here Wednesday after President Clinton's inauguration, arrived early at his new office on both Thursday and Friday mornings. He is occupying the top floor of a pyramid-topped office building with a bubbling fountain in the lobby. The 154,000-square-foot building was built in 1986 as the headquarters for a savings and loan that failed. It later housed offices of the Resolution Trust Corporation, charged with cleaning up the S.& L. debacle.
On Thursday Mr. Bush was driven home for lunch to the two-story white colonial house he and Barbara Bush are renting from their longtime friend, Jack Fitch, while they build their own in Houston's affluent Tanglewood area. On Friday Mr. Bush ate lunch at Otto's Bar-B-Q, which was decked out in yellow ribbons in honor of his return.
 
Visiting the Hardware Store
 He also went jogging and stopped in at Patterson's Hardware to pick up coffee filters and a stepladder.
Andrew Maner, an aide, said Mr. Bush had spent much of his first two days in his new office unpacking, fielding calls and getting organized.
"He's had calls from friends, Cabinet members, the Vice President," Mr. Maner said, then added quickly: "The former Vice President, I mean."
With Secret Service protection, an eight-person, full-time staff, travel in a three-or-four car convoy and an eight-room office complex with a 16-foot-high rotunda surrounded by eight Tuscan columns, Mr. Bush has not exactly been thrown out in the cold. He receives a pension of approximately $187,000 a year and has substantial income from other investments.
He will be involved with establishing his Presidential Library a hundred miles away at Texas A&M in College Station. There's the inevitable talk of writing a book, and Mr. Bush has often spoken of spending more time with his 12 grandchildren. But even those closest to him say he returns to private life with very few firm ideas of what he will do there.
 
Validating Houston Roots
 "I've asked him the question myself, and he said, 'I don't know,' " said George W. Bush, the former President's oldest son, who lives in Dallas. "I just don't think he's worked it out."
Mr. Bush returns to a neighborhood where he's lived on and off for more than three decades. The Bushes get their food from the Rice Epicurean Market and do their cleaning at Miller's Laundry and Cleaning. They eat at Otto's, Molina's and Hunan, worship at St. Martin's Episcopal Church and will probably be seen at the Bayou Club and the Houston Country Club.
Their return is something of a vindication for Houston friends who chafed for years at insinuations that Mr. Bush was a Yankee at heart whose ties to Texas had more to do with political convenience than reality.
"As a little girl I had a crush on him," said Betsy Parish, gossip columnist for The Houston Post. "I thought that's the cutest man I ever laid eyes on. I live in the same neighborhood as the Bushes, and people feel like it's old friends moving back."
Ms. Parish thinks Mr. Bush's adjustment to private life will be easier than some think. "I think he's from the old school, that you take victories modestly and defeat with a smile and get on with life," she said. "I think that which he was accused of being as President, being patrician, he will be admired for when he comes back."
 
And Then There's Maine
 But some of the attention clearly goes beyond mere affection. Hal Foster, whose public relations firm, Callas & Foster, works regularly with the city's elite, says there is wide speculation about everything from the possible economic benefits spawned by visiting dignitaries to which charities the Bushes will lend their names to.
"Most of the people I talk to are very excited," he said. "Everyone has the idea they'll be the chairmen at their ball. But I hear through the grapevine they'll head for Kennebunkport at the beginning of April, which takes care of all the spring balls, so they're all fretting."
Still, the return was not all warm and fuzzy. Neighbors on the cul de sac where the Bushes live glared balefully at reporters and fretted about the steady stream of gawkers driving by.
Some visitors had their own agenda. Richard Stonely, an autograph collector, said he had 18 Clinton autographs and only one Bush signature; Mr. Bush later made his day by autographing two baseballs for him.
 
Another Local Attraction
 Most were there either out of curiosity or to show their support for the Bushes. But even they were a reminder of how big a difference there is between being President and being one of the five living men who used to be.
"We skipped school to come see him," said Marshall O'Neill, a 17-year-old who showed up with his friend Mark Wright to try to catch a glimpse of Mr. Bush. "His living here gives the city an attraction."
Then, referring to a nearby town and its ageless pitcher, he added: "Alvin's got their Nolan Ryan, and now Houston's got George Bush."

GRAPHIC: Photo: George Bush leaving the two-story colonial house he and his wife, Barbara, are renting in Houston on his way to his office Friday. (F. Carter Smith for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: JACKSON, IN HAITI, CAUTIONS MILITARY

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 23

 BODY:
The Rev. Jesse Jackson, in Haiti for a two-day visit, said today that he had come to warn the country's military rulers that they would face harsh action, perhaps even force, if they failed to cooperate with a plan to move toward restoring democracy here.
Mr. Jackson, who met on Thursday in Washington with Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher said he had not been officially authorized to carry a message to Haiti's military leaders. But he said the Clinton Administration had assured him that it intended to restore Haiti's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, to power. 
 "The only question is whether they are going to cooperate in the transition toward democracy or resist," Mr. Jackson said of Haiti's military leaders in an interview here. "That transition is coming, and the only question is whether it will require force."
 
Pressure to End Crisis
 Mr. Jackson's visit comes as the Clinton Administration, working closely with the United Nations, is sharply increasing pressure on all parties to end Haiti's 16-month political crisis. Father Aristide was ousted in a military coup in September 1991, less than eight months after he took office as Haiti's first freely elected President.
A trade embargo was imposed against Haiti in late 1991 to step up pressure for Father Aristide's return. The country's economic misery deepened and military repression increased, prompting thousands of Haitians to flee in boats.
A special United Nations envoy to Haiti, Dante Caputo, announced this week that he expected negotiations to begin shortly that ultimately would be aimed at reinstating President Aristide. Mr. Caputo said that the United Nations would not allow Haiti's rulers to retreat from an agreement reached last weekend to allow the deployment of human rights observers to Haiti beginning in early February.
 
Haitian Generals Hedge
 After consenting to the deployment of the observers last Sunday, Haiti's military commander, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, seemed to hedge on the issue in a radio interview on Monday, less than 24 hours after Mr. Caputo's departure from Haiti. In the interview, General Cedras said the military was not legally authorized to sign international agreements of any kind.
The Haitian army's willingness or ability to pursue negotiations was cast further into doubt this week by a small-scale mutiny by soldiers on Wednesday. Diplomats said that retired officers had told the soldiers that General Cedras had reached a secret accord with Father Aristide and warned them that they would be sold out in any negotiated settlement.
Haiti's military-backed civilian Government, however, has said that plans to deploy the human rights observers here were proceeding.
"The first thing to be done is to establish a cease-fire, politically speaking," Haiti's de facto Foreign Minister, Francois Benoit, said in an interview. "We recognize the need to stabilize the patient and remove the fear. That is why we have accepted the sending of an observer mission."
 
Clinton-Aristide Agreement
 During his visit, Mr. Jackson also said White House officials had told him that President Clinton had an agreement with Father Aristide committing the United States to the exiled Haitian leader's return.
Mr. Jackson said the agreement would require the priest to help prevent his followers from taking revenge on his opponents after his return.
In a recent letter to the United Nations calling for the deployment of the observers, Father Aristide said he wished to "reassure all parties that the current political crisis will be solved only by eliminating violence and the systematic violation of human rights from whatever source."
Mr. Jackson scoffed at criticism of Father Aristide's human rights record in a recent State Department report, including a suggestion that the Haitian leader had ordered political killings.
"It is not unusual for those on their way out to fire a last salvo," Mr. Jackson said, in a reference to outgoing Bush Administration officials.

HEADLINE: Pentagon Agrees to Delay a Reactor Test in Space

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

 BODY:
Pentagon officials, responding to complaints by astronomers, have agreed to defer for at least six months any commitments to carry out a nuclear reactor test in orbit. The delay would give scientists time to assess the chances that the test might produce radiation that could interfere with astronomical observations.
The decision was reached last week after a meeting with astronomers, mission planners and scientists familiar with the Russian-made Topaz 2 nuclear reactor planned for use in the $150 million experiment. The reactor test is part of the military's plan to investigate new technologies for generating electricity for missile defense monitors in space and for long-distance propulsion systems. 
 The action raised hopes on all sides for an amicable settlement of the issue between astronomers and officials of the Strategic Defense Initiative Organization, the antimissile defense-research arm of the Defense Department commonly called "Star Wars."
"We are committed to making sure the test does not interfere with any astronomy mission," said Maj. Frederick A. Tarantino, an Army scientist who manages the space power program for the missile defense agency. Major Tarantino made the comment in a telephone interview Thursday after the meeting, at the University of Maryland in College Park.
 
Rocket Purchase Delayed
 Until a more thorough study of potential problems can be completed, probably by the middle of the year, the project will not settle on any specific mission plans or sign any contracts to buy the rocket, Major Tarantino said. The rocket was to be purchased next month from an American concern. Once such commitments are made, it would be more expensive to alter the spacecraft and the mission to reduce or eliminate the risk of radiation interference on satellites studying the universe.
Steven Aftergood, a senior research analyst at the Federation of American Scientists, a Washington-based group that has opposed the space-based missile defense program, said the tone of the meeting suggested that the Pentagon "is going to accommodate the astronomers to one degree or another."
Dr. Don Q. Lamb, an astrophysicist at the University of Chicago, said he and other scientists who had raised objections to the reactor test had come away from the meeting feeling that military officials "do want to do the right thing."
As chairman of the American Astronomical Society's high-energy astrophysics division, Dr. Lamb raised the first public objections to the proposed reactor test six weeks ago. He cited scientific studies and the experience with earlier Russian space reactors in warning that radiation would cause serious disturbances to the sensitive instruments of such satellites as the American Compton gamma ray observatory, the German Rosat X-ray observatory, the Russian X-ray and gamma-ray craft Granat and many others.
 
Higher Orbit Is Suggested
 In raising these objections, the astronomers emphasized that they did not necessarily oppose the mission but rather were concerned about the failure to take into account its possibly adverse effects on astronomy. They suggested that with a more powerful rocket, the initial altitude of the reactor's orbit could be raised to 3,700 miles from the 1,000 miles now planned. At the lower orbit, radiation interference would be especially strong, the astronomers said.
At a conference on space nuclear power in Albuquerque, N.M., two weeks ago, military officials and nuclear engineers indicated they were willing to discuss the issue and perhaps even modify the mission. The conference adopted a resolution that "nuclear technology should be used in a manner so that interference with space science objectives is minimized." The resolution also said that an acceptable solution to the problem was "clearly achievable."
Russian nuclear engineers sought to reassure the scientists that the reactor could be a good orbital neighbor. They have sold two test reactors to the American military and expect to sell at least four more, thus reaping sorely needed hard currency for the Russian economy.
But Major Tarantino and Dr. Lamb said that at the meeting last week it became clear that more research is required to determine if there is reason for concern about radiation and, if there is, how the radiation could be prevented from causing harm.
If preparations for the mission resume by mid-summer, it might still be possible to launch the first test mission in late 1995 or early 1996. But some scientists and space policy experts noted that the delay could give the Clinton Administration time to reconsider the priority of such a project and of the broader policy toward the "Star Wars" research, a legacy of the Reagan and Bush Administrations.

HEADLINE: Exposing Oceanfront Property and Human Folly

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WESTHAMPTON, L.I.

 BODY:
The December storm that carved two new inlets in the narrow barrier beach here and ripped acres of sand away from summer homes has also exposed a reality long buried in promotional fiction along the region's shore:
A rising ocean, part of a long geologic process, is relentlessly claiming parts of the coast faster than man can reclaim it. 
 And property owners long accustomed to building beach homes wherever they want -- in some cases demolishing protective sand dunes to expand their ocean view -- may be closer to a day of reckoning when the public will no longer pay the high cost of protecting them from future storms.
Scientists and coastal engineers have worried aloud for years about how much longer the ocean, which has risen nearly a foot in this century along the Atlantic coast, could be kept from destroying beachfront development. But four major storms in 16 months have reinvigorated a debate over where human structures can safely coexist with a surly ocean.
The outcome of the debate has enormous consequences on Long Island and in New Jersey, where for years home rule has allowed municipalities to ignore many of nature's laws and permit the construction of thousands of expensive homes on fragile sections of barrier beaches in places like Long Beach Island in New Jersey and Fire Island and the Hamptons on the southern shore of Long Island. Now there is growing pressure to let nature take its course and swallow beaches that are considered too costly to defend against storms and hurricanes.
The beautiful but fragile white sandy beaches of eastern Long Island and southern New Jersey -- some of the most expensive real estate in the world -- have long been minefields of explosive politics. When scientists and environmentalists call for a retreat from some vulnerable beaches, private and commercial interests object, citing the economic benefits of tourism and tax revenues produced by summer visitors.
"There's no question that summer homes and visitors are extremely important to the economy of our villages," said Arma Andon, Mayor of Westhampton Beach, a community that shares the barrier beach here with Westhampton and other south shore villages.
"Our merchants are already hurting because people can't reach their second homes next to us in Westhampton because of the storms," Mr. Andon said. "If that section is permanently closed it would really hurt the tax base.
"But local people keep asking me how many more millions of dollars have to be pumped to keep some stretches healthy."
The advocates of beach reclamation say the barrier islands are too critical to the protection of the inland bays and populated mainland shores to consider abandoning any of them.
In the four storms, including the Dec. 11 northeaster, homes were destroyed on Fire Island and protective dunes were washed away from Montauk Point to Cape May, N.J. Several seashore communities lost boardwalks and fishing piers in the widespread flooding.
But the storm damage is the most striking along what had been Dune Road in Westhampton. By the latest count, 87 structures have been destroyed since 1991 -- more than 40 in the December storm -- and scores more, held up by wooden pilings once sunk deep in sand, are stranded in the surf zone with ocean waves breaking beneath them, rolling into the newly opened inlets. Other houses are sunk deep in sand amid 200-pound slabs of asphalt and concrete washed away from Dune Road, broken telephone poles with snaking black power lines, smashed Jacuzzis and hot tubs.
 
Continuing Litigation
 The owners of the stranded houses have been involved in litigation against Suffolk County and the United States Army Corps of Engineers for nearly two decades. The owners claim that environmental pressures forced the abrupt halt of a beach protection project before a series of rock jetties -- being constructed to reduce beach erosion -- reached them. The cancellation, they said, caused drifting sand that moves from east to west along the Long Island coast to pile up along the completed jetties, unable to reach their beaches, hastening the erosion process in front of their cottages.
In Westhampton Beach, where the jetties were finished in the 1960's, houses sit high and dry in luxuriant sand dunes.
But the western end of Dune Road and some sections of the Fire Island barrier beach are among those that a new task force that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo formed this month will investigate as probable targets of the new thinking on retreat.
With local and state governments facing deficits, it is hard to argue that public money should be spent on what is increasingly seen as a losing effort to protect vacation cottages and second homes, said Kevin McDonald, vice president of the Group for the South Fork, residents at the eastern end of Long Island involved in environmental issues.
"This is a tax issue, not environmentalists aligned against private landowners," he said. "What is of concern are the absurd public costs of keeping the beaches safe for private ownership."
But the Dune Road property owners insist that it is an environmental issue. The state has to plug up the new inlets and build the beach back up, they argue, to keep ruinous amounts of salt water from pouring into Moriches Bay.
"Everyone has always assumed the property owners only talked out of self-interest," said Merle Debuskey, a New York theatrical press agent who owns a threatened beach house here. "But now that two new inlets have cut through there, the repairs have to be made to protect the bay and the mainland shore."
 
Pressure on a Project
 The property owners are also pressing the Army Corps of Engineers to proceed with a project agreed to two years ago to rebuild the beach and taper the jetties immediately to the east to allow drifting sand to reach their property. But the project's original cost estimate of $45 million is expected to grow by 50 percent or more because of the December damage, state officials said.
Fred W. Thiele Jr., Supervisor of the Town of Southampton, said $60,000 in local money was spent two years ago to repave parts of Dune Road and the work was almost immediately wiped out by flooding from a major autumn storm. An additional $25,000 was spent last year to provide a trail passable only by four-wheel-drive vehicles, he said.
"This situation," he said recently, standing at the edge of the 500-foot wide gash carrying the ocean into Moriches Bay where the island is only 200 feet wide, "speaks to the issues of development on coastal barriers and should be a question for the public to decide.
"One thing is for certain: Only the Federal Government has the money to do the repairs and I'm not sure Washington is going to want to pour money into the ocean as things get worse."
What is almost certain is that the Dune Road property owners will seek and get some form of public compensation if they are prevented from rebuilding or from occupying homes that are still standing, state officials said, because governmental action contributed to their problems. But Fire Island property owners are unlikely to get a similar break.
 
'A Natural Progression'
 "There's no reasonable view that we owe the Fire Island owners compensation," said William W. Daley, chief of coastal erosion management for the State Department of Environmental Conservation. "It has been a natural progression of the shoreline and there comes a time when the land is submerged and can no longer stand the onslaught of the ocean."
But the 4,000 Fire Island property owners, like those on Dune Road, are prepared for a fight. They, too, contend that rebuilding the beaches is necessary to protect the ecology of Great South Bay.
Any move to exert more state control over the shorelines will pit legislators against the wishes of local interests that derive income and prestige from coastal development.
"There is strong resistance to state intrusion on traditional prerogatives of local government when it comes to beaches," said Gail S. Shaffer, the New York Secretary of State. "The result is we have a tremendously fragmented patchwork of authority."
Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board, said: "Local officials, not the county or the state, decided if beach houses were built on the dunes, behind the dunes or if the dunes were bulldozed to get them out of the way of the ocean view." He said that since 1965 the board has initiated many environmental programs like preserving open spaces and farmlands but that its recommendations on coastal preservation have seldom been heeded.
Suffolk County's only regulatory control of beach development is limited to health matters like sewers and septic tanks, he said.
 
A Profitable Arrangement
 From the point of view of local government, the trend that brought wealthy New Yorkers to the Hamptons as summer residents was a profitable one. Construction on the beach created jobs for local workers and increased property tax revenue relieved year-round residents of much of the burden.
"The summer people also were affluent, sophisticated and politically well connected and not afraid to use those connections at all levels when necessary," Dr. Koppelman said. He contended that state and Federal officials have consistently "caved in" behind the scenes to special interests rather than give firm support to beach preservation policies they have publicly endorsed.
Representative George J. Hochbrueckner, a Democrat who represents the First Congressional District, which includes Westhampton, said the time had arrived for new thinking about beach development and protection. "The barrier islands are clearly rolling toward the mainland and I see a tendency to allow some of the undeveloped beaches to erode without help," he said. "But in areas like Dune Road where government and man have intervened in the past we are going to have to protect the beach and plug those inlets."
Mr. Hochbrueckner said he was not satisfied with the Army Corps's estimate that it could not begin work on closing the new inlets until May and said he was working with other members of Congress to accelerate it.
Gilbert Nersesian, senior coastal engineer in the New York District office of the Army Corps of Engineers, acknowledged that political pressure could revise the Corps's timetable.
"Politics tend to govern decisions about the coast," the engineer murmured. "Always have, always will."

HEADLINE: POLITICAL NOTES;
Inside Cuomo's Budget: A Discreet Fee or Two

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

 BODY:
With budgets, as with life, the devil is often in the details.
And with the 1993-94 budget proposed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo last week, the details were sometimes buried far beneath the surface. 
 It took some digging through the hundreds of pages of budget documents and bills, for instance, to discover that Mr. Cuomo proposed giving 4 percent raises to his agency heads at a cost of $400,000. The raises would be equivalent to those negotiated last year with a variety of state workers' unions.
The raises, which were referred to briefly on page 55 of an appendix to the budget, were not mentioned in the 15-page news release issued by Mr. Cuomo.
Neither was the $17 fee that Mr. Cuomo wants to impose to pay for the state's mandatory program of genetic testing for newborns. The state has paid for the program in the past. The fee would be imposed on hospitals, which presumably would pass the cost along to patients.
The Governor also did not highlight his proposal to eliminate a state program that compensates crime victims for up to $100 in stolen cash and property.
 
Negotiating in the TV Age
 The union representing New York City's public school teachers, having already taken their search for a new contract with the Dinkins administration to Albany for arbitration, opened a second front last week -- this time on the television airwaves.
The United Federation of Teachers, which represents about 65,000 teachers and 20,000 other school employees, began a six-week advertising blitz intended to pressure the administration into reaching a new contract. Union officials said they plan to spend about $1 million on the campaign, which highlights the difficulties of teaching in schools they describe as overcrowded and undersupplied.
Two versions of the 30-second ad started running last Tuesday on virtually every station in the city. Each opens with a quick succession of scenes showing teachers dealing with jammed classrooms, packed hallways, and ill-equipped science labs. They also show teachers breaking up fights, working with students on a play and talking at a faculty meeting about a shortage of textbooks.
In one ad, a teacher says: "It's a tough job teaching in New York City schools and it keeps getting tougher. What I don't understand is given the conditions and how important education is to New York's economic future, why won't this city offer its teachers a decent contract? It's just not right."
Whether the commercials alter the prolonged negotiations over the teachers' contract remains to be seen. After intermittent talks with the city failed to produce a settlement, the union sought state mediation late last summer. Mediation also did not produce an accord, and so, two weeks ago, both sides began nonbinding arbitration with the state.
 
Same Old Names, New Faces
 Although President Clinton has made "change" the political watchword of the year, there will not even be nominal change resulting from the Feb. 16 special election for the 112th Assembly District in St. Lawrence County.
The seat became vacant Dec. 10 when Assemblyman John G. A. O'Neil, a Republican who was first elected in 1980, died in an automobile accident.
His widow, an elementary school teacher, Chloe Ann R. O'Neil, is running as the Republican candidate to complete his term. Her Democratic opponent is June F. O'Neill, who is on unpaid leave from her job as director-designate of the state's Office of Rural Affairs.
May the best O'Neil(l) win.
 
Solarz Waits and Hopes
 With choice jobs in the Clinton Administration dwindling by the day, former Representative Stephen J. Solarz of New York still held out hope late last week that there might be a spot for him in the State Department.
"I honestly don't know what is going on," Mr. Solarz said. "I hear a lot of things and I read a lot of things. But I'm not sitting at home waiting for calls from Little Rock, or, I suppose now, from 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue."
Mr. Solarz had been considered a strong contender for Deputy Secretary of State, the No. 2 spot. But his name has not been among the stream of appointments announced since Mr. Clinton took office on Wednesday.
Mr. Solarz, whose bid for a 10th term in office ended abruptly last September when he was defeated in the Democratic Primary, was arguably one of the most knowledgable members of Congress on foreign affairs.
But what may be standing between him and the State Department job he covets is the House banking scandal that involved 269 of the 435 House members and contributed to a wave of retirements and election defeats. Mr. Solarz was among 17 members identified in a House ethics committee report as among the worst abusers of the bank, with 743 overdrafts in three years.
But Mr. Solarz said that was no cause for the Clinton Administration to pass him over. "They nominated someone for Attorney General who admitted violating the law," he said. "My position is that I haven't done anything improper or illegal."

HEADLINE: BOXING;
Justice Delayed Is Bitter Justice for Carter

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 23

 BODY:
With his one good eye, his left, still piercing out from behind steel-rim glasses, the black man, the onetime middleweight contender, half-blind because of a botched operation in prison, stood Friday night at the lectern and looked out over an audience of some 400 people in the Austin Hall auditorium here at Harvard University.
For nearly 19 years he had looked out from behind steel bars, until, in 1985, a Federal judge in New Jersey determined that he had been unjustly and wrongly convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment for a triple murder he did not commit. 
 "It's a long way from Trenton State Penitentiary to the Harvard Law School," Rubin (Hurricane) Carter said Friday with a smile that combined irony, humor, pain, anger and even warmth. "A very, very long way."
 
The Keynote Speaker
 Carter, now 55, a free man for the last seven years, living in King City, Ontario, near Toronto, had been invited to give the keynote address in a two-day conference on "The Future of Habeas Corpus" at the Criminal Justice Institute at Harvard. Carter is an expert on the subject, and a subject of prominence to the experts, because it was the Great Writ, as the Federal review is known, that became Carter's passport to freedom from a New Jersey state verdict.
Habeas corpus -- the requirement that a detained person be brought before a court to determine the legality of the detention -- has been under attack in recent times, primarily by conservatives who contend that the process clogs up the courts, Carter said. But Carter, who fervently studied the doctrine in his cell, was at Harvard to defend it, to talk about it as an American "birthright," and did so with understandable conviction, in a strong, almost clipped speaking style.
Carter, at 5 feet 7 inches and close to his fighting weight of 160 pounds, wore a dark suit and a blue tie. His hair is full on his head and he has grown a mustache. This is not the way many remember Hurricane Carter. Sports fans recall him in the ring with a shaved head, sometimes a goatee, and a look that was baleful at best. In a middleweight championship fight in Philadelphia on Dec. 14, 1964, Carter lost a controversial 15-round split decision to the reigning champion, Joey Giardello. "I lost because I didn't knock him out," Carter said.
 
No Chance to Avenge Loss
 He was convicted of murder in 1967, when, reaching his prime as a prizefighter, he had signed and was in training to fight again for the middleweight title, against Dick Tiger, who had dethroned Giardello. Carter had lost a 10-round decision to Tiger -- "he beat me up pretty bad" -- and had hoped to avenge that loss. He never got the chance.
In 1966, Carter and a friend, John Artis, were arrested for the murder of three white people at the Lafayette Bar and Grill in Paterson, N.J., in June of that year. They were convicted on the testimony, later recanted, of two criminals. They were convicted even though identifications by eyewitnesses varied, and despite the fact that both of them had strong alibis -- and even though two separate grand juries had refused to bring indictments.
Carter and Artis were finally released because, said Judge H. Lee Sarokin 19 years later in his statement to the writ of habeas corpus brought by Carter and Artis, "the extensive record clearly demonstrates that (the) petitioners' convictions were predicated upon an appeal to racism rather than reason, and concealment rather than disclosure."
"To permit convictions to stand which have as their foundation appeals to racial prejudice and the withholding of evidence critical to the defense," Sarokin continued, "is to commit a violation of the Constitution as heinous as the crimes for which these petitioners were tried and convicted."
 
Much to Address
 Carter's talk here, with Judge Sarokin in the audience, ranged wider than just the importance of not allowing habeas corpus to erode. He spoke movingly of the root causes of crime -- "it is not genetics, but economics," he said -- and added that serious commitment by government to educate and to provide jobs is what is needed, "and not the building of more prisons."
As for prisons, he said they are in need of monumental reform, from medical care (his eye operation for a detached retina was performed in the prison and not in a hospital) to general treatment.
"They take away your dignity, your humanity, your goodness, your meat and bones," Carter said. "And then when they release inmates into society, people wonder why the recidivism rate is so great."
At a reception later, Carter was asked about Mike Tyson, the former heavyweight champion, who is in prison in Indiana on a rape conviction.
 
'One They Had to Break'
 "I feel sorry for Mike Tyson," said Carter. "I'm sure his problems in prison will be magnified because he was somebody when he was outside. He probably won't have difficulty with fellow prisoners -- I never did -- but with the administration. The warden and the guards, they want him and the other inmates to know, 'Hey, he's not the champ in here. He's not a strong black man. He's just a number, like everybody else.' I was the one they had to break, to put in line, as an example for the other prisoners.
"I was the prizefighter, the man making $100,000 a year, which in those days was like the millions some fighters are earning today.
"And my difficulty was compounded because I refused to go along with anything the administration wanted from me in prison. I was innocent and I didn't recognize their authority. When I first walked into prison, I refused to wear prison clothes. They threw me into solitary confinement for four months, with nothing to eat but bread and water."
On the other hand, Carter said, being a boxer helped him get through those 19 years in prison.
"It's very individualized -- a boxer has to be dedicated, disciplined and learns to live with loneliness," he explained. "You're basically alone as a fighter, and you learn to talk to yourself, laugh with yourself, and in training camp you bear up under being alone."
Carter clearly bears resentment for what he went through. "The state wants inmates to show remorse and rehabilitation," he said. "They want us to repent. But they do none of that. They never gave me anything back when I was released and when it was proved I was wrongly confined. They never even said, 'Look, man, it was a mistake.'
"And I still had some good years in boxing left."
 
No Time for Boxing
 He said that he stopped following boxing because his fight for freedom took up all of his time.
"I have no interest in boxing these days," Carter said. "I'd like to have the money they're making. If I can have that without getting my brains rattled, I'd be glad to accommodate."
These days, he earns a living primarily by lecturing. His book, "The 16th Round," has just been reissued in Canada. He has also sold his life story to a Hollywood movie company.
At the Harvard reception, a woman serving hors d'oeuvres extended her tray to Carter. He picked up something and bit into it. "Quiche," he said. He smiled, but looked slightly uncomfortable.
"Well," he said, "it's better than prison food."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rubin (Hurricane) Carter holding a copy of his petition for writ of habeas corpus, during a lecture at Harvard University on Friday night. (Cindy M. Loo for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
'Chris' And Aspin And Lake

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Almost 30 years ago in the U.S. Embassy in Saigon, the lives of a young Army lieutenant -- Les Aspin -- and three very junior Foreign Service officers in their mid-20's -- Anthony Lake, Peter Tarnoff and Frank Wisner -- touched one another. Today, the four sit at the pinnacle of power and, together with Secretary of State Warren Christopher, form two interlocking triangles that will command America's national security machinery.
In the top triangle, two rumply policy intellectuals -- Defense Secretary Aspin and Mr. Lake, the national security adviser, will vie with each other to shape strategy, while Mr. Christopher essentially counsels and reacts. 
 In the second triangle, the three old pals -- Mr. Lake, Under Secretary of State-designate Tarnoff and Under Secretary of Defense-designate Wisner -- bureaucratic black belts all, will control interdepartmental deliberations and tamp down internal conflicts.
Policy fights will not split these triangles into the usual hawks and doves, conservatives and liberals. Instead, the five will maneuver in ever-changing coalitions of activists and cautioners. One mix might want to get tough in Iraq; another, in Bosnia. The question mark in the picture will be President Clinton.
As a history buff, Mr. Clinton will discover that his senior triangle will resemble the Robert McNamara, Dean Rusk and McGeorge Bundy team of the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations.
Defense Secretary McNamara was the activist and conceptualizer, trying to run foreign policy out of the Pentagon -- and often succeeding. He generally called the tune not only on Vietnam, but also on arms control and European and Asian policy.
Mr. Bundy, the national security adviser, mainly played the honest broker and remained almost out of public sight. From time to time, he would strike with his own policy memo and carry the day -- but few knew about it.
Secretary of State Rusk was not out to change the world. He did have some strong views and sometimes objected to the goings-on around him. Mostly, however, he said "O.K.," or "O.K. but . . ." He saw himself primarily as the President's adviser. He rarely took the bureaucratic lead on policy-making and generally let the State Department bureaus fend for themselves.
In Mr. Clinton's senior triangle, Mr. Aspin -- an idea machine of staggering proportions, judging from his paper deluge over his last 20 years as a Congressman -- will want to be the driving force. Just like his old idol and Pentagon boss, Robert McNamara. In the McNamara mold, he is building a high-I.Q. team of activists who soon will be launching lightning bolts on everything from defense policy to democratization in Russia to economic policy.
Mr. Lake will want to be the main idea-man himself and, from inside the White House, is better positioned to press his case than Mr. Aspin. In any event, he will be the one who personally shapes the consensus on most issues. He will be more activist than Mr. Bundy was, but like him, he will play an inside game -- often presenting an opaque exterior.
Mr. Christopher, like Mr. Rusk, has no burning policy agenda. If Mr. Aspin and Mr. Lake agree, he will likely go along, adding stylistic cautions and warnings. If troubled, he can appeal to Mr. Clinton, with whom he forged a close and avuncular relationship over the last year. His power will rise or fall on that relationship.
Behind the scenes, the Lake-Tarnoff-Wisner network will often be as important as the top triangle. These three are quite capable of working out policy lines themselves, then selling them to their respective bosses. All three are also first-class operators, able and eager to do deals with Congress and manipulate the press.
Their power rests on their mutual trust, which goes beyond their shared Vietnam experiences. They also worked together intimately in Cyrus Vance's State Department. All are pragmatists. Mr. Wisner is the most conservative, Mr. Tarnoff a curious amalgam of liberal and skeptic, and Mr. Lake ranges in between.
Whether the two power triangles produce cautious or activist policy lines will depend on Mr. Clinton. President Kennedy handled his advisers with self-confidence and assertiveness. Lyndon Johnson was tentative about foreign policy. Mr. Clinton could turn out to be either -- or both.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Presidents Ask a Place in Posterity; Posterity Keeps Rearranging Them

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

 BODY:
AS Bill Clinton begins to seek a place in history, and George Bush wonders what his will be, they need to remember that those places are fixed not just by their accomplishments and their failings, but also by the values of the time when they are judged.
For most of the 19th century, for example, Andrew Jackson was dismissed as a backwoodsman whose populism wrecked the economy and as the forefather of the spoils system whose excesses civil service was meant to cure. But in this century, new times called forth different values. Old Hickory was seen by the first Roosevelt as the exemplar of a strong Presidency, and by the second as a great upper and lower case Democrat, and the histories have reflected those shifts. 
 In the business-oriented 1920's, and in histories published in that decade and the next, progressives like Theodore Roosevelt and Woodrow Wilson were devalued. Their stock soared when the country, in the New Deal, revalued their approach.
But changing Presidential reputations are more than just a function of historians following the election returns. Stephen E. Ambrose, biographer of Presidents Eisenhower and Nixon, offers two more thoughtful reasons.
One is "how things turn out." He said Mr. Wilson was considered a disaster in foreign affairs when he left office. By the late 1930's, he said, "the common wisdom became World War II started because we didn't enter the League of Nations" and his standing improved. Now, he said, history may turn again, watching the bloodshed in Bosnia and wondering if Wilson's commitment to self-determination in the old Austro-Hungarian Empire was at fault.
The second reason is that historians can actually learn more about the President they study than people knew at the time, especially with the development of serious Presidential libraries for every President, except Mr. Nixon, since Herbert Hoover.
"The image of Eisenhower as the mumbling, grinning empty-headed President who played golf and let Foster Dulles run the world had to give way once the Eisenhower Library opened up," Mr. Ambrose said. For example, when Mr. Dulles wanted to reject North Korea's proposal to resume armistice talks in 1953, the President squelched him.
 
The Public Counts Hope
 But the judgment of history is not the exclusive property of historians. The American public claims a say. For example, it regards John F. Kennedy as an ideal President even if recent histories have argued that he accomplished little and have stressed his sex life, emphasizing his successes in domestic liaisons more than his triumphs in foreign relations.
David McCullough, Harry Truman's biographer, says that by now Kennedy is "too far down -- it's almost as though he had no ability at all." But the public's view is not based on a contrary reading of the same evidence. The public focuses on the inspiration he provided, starting with the stirring words of his inaugural address. The hopes he raised then in young Americans, recalled last week when one of them, Mr. Clinton, visited his grave, are too imprecise for many historians to weigh, but the public counts them in the balance.
There was a similar disconnect on Mr. Truman when he left office. His last Gallup Poll approval rating was 31 percent, lower than that of any who followed him except Mr. Nixon. And he was widely scorned and disliked. But at the same time there was a strong element of respect from the internationalist community for his firmness against the Soviet Union.
Mr. McCullough says the rise in Truman's popularity since then has come about partly for the wrong reasons. Merle Miller's "Plain Speaking" made him come across as "kind of a cosmic hick," Mr. McCullough said. "The real man was much more complicated, far more intellectual, sentimental, sensitive and certainly much harder-working than he was generally perceived." Politically, Truman is dragged out every four years by whatever candidate hopes to replicate his comeback victory in 1948, with hardly a reference to the liberal domestic program he ran on.
His reputation seems settled, and perhaps most of all by the first test Mr. Ambrose offered, "how things turn out." For in his farewell address, on Jan. 15, 1953, Truman told the nation: "As the free world grows stronger, more united, more attractive to men on both sides of the Iron Curtain -- and as the Soviet hopes for easy expansion are blocked -- then there will have to come a time of change in the Soviet world. Nobody can say for sure when that is going to be, or exactly how it will come about, whether by revolution, or trouble in the satellite states, or by a change inside the Kremlin. I have not a doubt in the world that a change will occur." And he was right.
Lacking that sort of historic anchor, most of his successors' images seem less firmly fixed. For example, Mr. Nixon's floats up, bit by bit, though his disgrace is indelible.
 
The Vietnam Albatross
 So is the Vietnam War's legacy to Lyndon B. Johnson. But the temper of this time may affect his status. If Mr. Clinton seems a successful, activist President, Johnson's reputation may rise. The public may come to remember him more for the domestic successes of his first years in the White House -- a record it has largely dismissed as it focuses on the war.
Historians have hardly started in on Ronald Reagan, thus far the subject of more partisan scribbling than of serious history. Mr. Reagan, as a two-term President of often staggering popularity, has a chance for major Presidential stature in the future. Ultimately, his standing may come to depend fundamentally on whether he gets credit for the end of the cold war or blame for the awesome budget deficits he left behind. And that in turn may depend on which seems more salient when histories are written.
As George Bush begins to write his own memoirs, a genre usually so trivial and self-serving that it hardly ever has significant impact on a President's lasting reputation, he goes with decent poll ratings. The last Gallup Poll measured approval of his handling the Presidency at 56 percent. The only post-war President with a distinctly higher rating was Mr. Reagan, at 63 percent.
But Mr. Bush seems almost certain not to be ranked above the middle range of Chief Executives. One-term Presidents seldom are. The public viewed Mr. Bush quite well on foreign policy, but as it made clear in the most important poll of all, last November's election, it didn't care about foreign policy all that much. And it is hard to foresee how the Gulf War could come to be thought of as a central moment in the nation's history.
Mr. Bush is relatively old at 68 to expect to read the measured judgment of history on his Presidency. But if it seems to sour, to him or his followers, they have a consolation to contemplate: it is likely to change. As Arthur Schlesinger Jr., the Jackson, Roosevelt and Kennedy biographer, put it in 1986 in his "The Cycles of American History":
"Revisionism is an indispensable part of the historical enterprise. 'The one duty we owe to history,' said Oscar Wilde, 'is to rewrite it.' But second opinions are not necessarily wiser than the first. Time in due course revises the revisionists."
