HEADLINE: A City That Sunshine Built

BYLINE: MICHAEL DRINKARD's new novel, "Disobedience," to be published in June by W. W. Norton, is set in southern California.
<BYL>By MICHAEL DRINKARD

 BODY:
AFTER the icy monochrome of New York, winter in Pasadena can make the most skeptical Easterner understand why 120,000 people put up with traffic and smog-choked summers to live here. And those of us who are ex-Westerners may pause to wonder why we ever left. People say southern California has no seasons, but on a recent December afternoon in Pasadena, I sampled the delights of several: a fragrant orange tree, roses in bloom, a maple dropping one flame-colored leaf at a time -- all against the background of the snow-powdered San Gabriel Mountains.
Occupying 23 square miles in the San Gabriel Valley under Mount Wilson, Pasadena slopes gently south from an elevation of 1,200 feet to 700 feet. Thousands of trees -- palms, oak, Italian cypress, willow, olive, avocado, walnut, banana and eucalyptus, to name a few -- make the landscape a bewitching blend of the exotic and familiar. You've seen each of these trees before, just not all in the same place. 
 Pasadena owes its birth -- as well as a current popular and economic resurgence -- to the climate. It was founded as an agricultural community called the Indiana Colony in 1874 and, according to the Pasadena Cultural Heritage Commission, took its present name from the Chippewa word meaning "crown of the valley." Another version says the etymology is Spanish for "passage to Eden."
In the late 19th century, the pure, dry winter air was promoted as a cure for respiratory ailments, particularly tuberculosis, which was then reaching epidemic proportions in Eastern urban centers. Farming gave way to development as health seekers and tourists flocked into town. After the completion in 1885 of a rail link to downtown Los Angeles, about 10 miles away, and connection by Santa Fe Railroad to Chicago and the East two years later, Pasadena became not only a vacation mecca, but the winter home for Eastern industrialists.
Many of the mansions and resorts are still standing. On Orange Grove Boulevard (once nicknamed Millionaires' Row) is the Wrigley Mansion, headquarters for the Pasadena Tournament of the Roses. The Castle Green Apartments, at the corner of Green and South Raymond Streets, is a former hotel built in a Moorish adaptation of Mission Revival with prominent domes and a bridge arcade. Slightly rundown, its grandeur now has a haunted, wistful edge. The stunning Ritz-Carlton, Huntington Hotel was opened in 1914. Seismic problems closed the hotel down in 1985, but it has since been reinforced and refurbished.
AWAY from Millionaires' Row (now primarily luxury condominiums), away from other wealthy enclaves -- the palatial estates on San Rafael Avenue hidden behind walls and private security systems, the opulent homes to the south bordering San Marino -- are Pasadena's less conspicuous but equally representative neighborhoods. The flatland south of Colorado Boulevard, between Arroyo Boulevard and Lake Avenue, is quintessential southern California suburbia, with bungalow courts and Spanish-tiled stuccos, bougainvillea, oleander, palm trees and rose bushes. Areas north of the 210 freeway have grim blocks of tract houses. The terraced hillsides, wide curving streets, stone and mortar retaining walls of Linda Vista, of the east bank of Arroyo Seco and of the city's southwestern ridges provide the setting for ranch styles and split-levels, including dramatic residences designed by the likes of Frank Lloyd Wright, Richard Neutra and Irving Gill. The Greene brothers, Pasadena architects, also left an indelible stamp on the community with their many "craftsman bungalows" of the early 1900's.
Early in the 20th century, Pasadena's growing, affluent population needed a commercial center. Railroad promotion and land speculation prompted development along Colorado Boulevard. This strip, now known as Old Town, displays a splendid, chaotic mix of buildings. As with the city's tree species, perhaps you've seen the styles before -- Revival, Deco and Spanish Colonial -- but not cheek by jowl. Rambling two-story edifices (some sharing the same facade) feature Victorian details, projecting bays, brickwork and articulated cornices.
The city is served by three freeways and, with the exception of a few residential neighborhoods, the streets are laid out in a straightforward grid. And though a car is essential in exploring the outlying parks, neighborhoods and attractions, Old Town is one of the rare places in Los Angeles where the sidewalks bustle with pedestrians.
Even as other parts of Los Angeles are mired in economic recession, business here is brisk. In shops and restaurants, boutiques and bookstores, antique marts, cinemas, jazz and billiard bars, we continually heard comparisons being made between Old Town and Westwood, a district 20 miles west known for its restaurants, movie openings and the University of California at Los Angeles.
I LIKE (and once lived in) Westwood, but Pasadena has something it lacks: a history. Route 66 (a stretch of Colorado Boulevard) intersects the Santa Fe railway at the heart of Old Town. Stand at the crossing while a locomotive chugs by and you can almost feel the ghosts of those led west by dreams of the Golden State.
Old Town does have the trappings of trendiness, especially on weekend nights, when street musicians, clowns and performers appear. Crowds come from all over Los Angeles for its restaurants, sampling the wild boar at Parkway Grill on Arroyo Parkway or the ginger catfish at Shiro in South Pasadena. In Old Town, Mi Piace and Roxxi particularly attract the young and fashionably attired.
But things here have not always been so rosy. After the Great Depression stopped the heady westward flow of tourists, the Crown City slid into decay. Later, the rise of automobile traffic and resulting smog was a blow to Pasadena's blue sky reputation. (In summer its air pollution index is still among the county's most hazardous.) As the business and cultural focus shifted to South Lake Avenue -- still a lively commercial center -- Colorado Boulevard hit the skids. Home to bars, single-room-occupancy hotels and pawn and porn shops in the late 70's, the old structures were scheduled for razing to make way for high-rise office buildings. Instead, the city designated Old Town an Urban Conservancy Zone, which made available Federal tax credits, and today it is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. Virtually every structure on Colorado Boulevard -- as well as those on the quaint side alleys -- has been recently renovated, with seismic fortifications against earthquakes. Still, in other areas of Pasadena there is much work to be done. Northern and eastern business districts and neighborhoods continue to suffer from blight, neglect and poverty.
As one would expect given the climate, Pasadena offers plenty of opportunities for outdoor recreation. Brookside Park, bordering in part on North Arroyo Boulevard, is Pasadena's largest. Brookside covers 520 acres, including the Rose Bowl grounds, lighted ballfields, a swimming pool compound, a golf course, a picnic area with barbecues, and free tennis courts. A short walk south, under the concrete-arched Colorado Street Bridge, is the Arroyo Seco Park, a classic Southern California chaparral ravine threaded with hiking and horse trails.
My wife, Jill, and I spent many pleasant hours in the parks with our racquets, running shoes and sunscreen, until a storm hit. Yes, it does rain in southern California. On the average, Pasadena gets 20.03 inches a year, although so far this month the Los Angeles area has received six times its normal allotment. But when three straight days of downpours and squalls put an end to our athletic pursuits, we found plenty of indoor attractions.
Just west of Old Town, near the corner of Colorado and Orange Grove Boulevards, is the Norton Simon Museum. It has an international reputation for a collection featuring works by Old Masters, Impressionists, Post-Impressionists and 20th-century artists. The museum itself is wonderfully casual. Airy and sprawling, the two-story, 1969 building has curvy walls and floor-to-ceiling windows that look out onto sculptures, fountains and eucalyptus trees. It's not large enough to get lost in, but there's always another surprise around the next corner -- Lewis Baltz's black and white photographs of southern California tract houses, for example, or a looming Henry Moore bronze. Complementing the Western art is the dramatically spotlighted Asian sculpture from the Indian subcontinent and Southeast Asia. The Pacific Asia Museum, a few blocks east on 46 North Los Robles Avenue, displays Chinese ceramics, Tibetan rugs and oriental art. Constructed as a private mansion in 1924, the Chinese Treasure Style building and its art were later donated to the city by Grace Nicholson. In San Marino at Pasadena's southern edge, the Huntington Library, Art Collections and Botanical Gardens is a merging of three disciplines on the former ranch of Henry Huntington.
A DRIVE on the 210 freeway to the northwest city limit brought us to the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, a NASA facility operated by the California Institute of Technology that studies the solar system with automated spacecraft. Once we got beyond the tour guide's monotone recitations, and the slide show's heavy-handed public relations-speak, we were captivated by the finely detailed photos of Venus and Jupiter. Even better were life-sized models of the satellites themselves. Galileo, no bigger than a mobile home, was launched in 1989, and is due to arrive at Jupiter on Dec. 7, 1995. The twin Voyagers, launched in 1977, have already explored Jupiter, Uranus and Neptune, and, traveling at 66,000 miles per hour, are expected to leave the solar system in the year 2000. I found myself lingering at the exhibits of moon rocks, plasma-wave antennas, orbit trajectories and images of outer space.
Perhaps Pasadena's most famous landmark is the Rose Bowl. The 70-year-old stadium seats 103,000 and, in addition to being the site of the Rose Bowl football championship and Super Bowl XXVII next Sunday, will play host in 1994 to World Cup soccer.
About 30,000 Angeleno browsers and 1,500 vendors know a secret side to the stadium: On the second Sunday of each month from 9 A.M. to 3 P.M. year round its parking lot is transformed into a massive flea market.
Everyone knows about Pasadena's proudest event: the Rose Parade, which rolls through Old Town on New Year's Day. Since its inception on Jan. 1, 1890, it has shown the nation that even in the middle of winter the Pasadena climate produces roses and oranges.
A southern California original, the Crown City has its own distinct mythology.
 
 
 
PLACES TO STAY, THINGS TO DO
Hotels
 In addition to the Ritz-Carlton, Huntington Hotel, described in an article on page 15, the choices for accommodations in Pasadena include these:
The Doubletree, 191 North Los Robles Avenue, (818) 792-2727 or (800) 528-0444, fax (818) 792-3755. A double room is $140 to $170 plus tax. Self-parking $4 a day, valet-parking $9.
The Pasadena Hilton, 150 South Los Robles Avenue, (818) 577-1000 or (800) 445-8667, fax (818) 584-3148. A double room is $79 to $134 plus tax, including Continental breakfast.
The Pasadena Holiday Inn, 303 East Cordova Street, (818) 449-4000 or (800) 465-4329, fax (818) 584-1390. A double room is $79 plus tax. Parking $3.50 a day.
 
Restaurants
 Arguably, Pasadena offers the best dining in Los Angeles. Try these, or ask around. It's hard to go wrong.
Parkway Grill, 510 South Arroyo Parkway, (818) 795-1001. One of the best and most popular. Pastas, pizzas, fresh fish, wild game.
The wild boar is excellent. Entrees $15 to $25.
Roxxi, 1065 East Green Street, (818) 449-4519. Another best of. Fresh California-style grill, Italian and Thai pastas, inspired salads. Entrees $15 to $25.
Shiro, 1505 Mission Street, South Pasadena, (818) 799-4774. French-Japanese. Diners rave about the chef's special catfish with ginger. Entrees $15 to $25.
Mi Piace, 25 East Colorado Boulevard, (818) 795-3131. Pastas and Italian fare. Prime Old Town location.
With its huge streetside windows and sleek halogen track spotlights, this is the place to see and be seen. Entrees $5 to $15.
For inexpensive, fiery, salty Mexican, if you can't find the Taco Truck (location changes) go to Tacos Buenos at 1308 North Lake Avenue, (818) 797-5941. Entrees $3 to $5.
 
Tours
 The Wrigley Mansion, 391 South Orange Grove Boulevard, (818) 449-4100. From February through August, 2 to 4. Admission is free.
The Gamble House, 4 Westmoreland Place, (818) 793-3334. Thursday to Sunday noon to 3. Admission $4, seniors $3, students $2, under 13's are admitted free of charge.
Jet Propulsion Laboratory, 4800 Oak Grove Drive, (818) 354-9314. Call for tour reservations. Free.
 
Museums
 The Norton Simon Museum, 411 West Colorado Boulevard, (818) 449-6840. Thursday to Sunday noon to 6. Admission $4, seniors and students $2, under 12 free.
Pacific Asia Museum, 46 North Los Robles Avenue, (818) 449-2742. Wednesday to Sunday noon to 5. Admission $3, seniors and students $1.50.
Pasadena Historical Society, 470 West Walnut Street, (818) 577-1660. Thursday to Sunday 1 to 4. Admission $4, students and seniors $3, under 12 free.
Kidspace, 390 South El Molino Avenue, (818) 449-9143. Wednesday 2 to 5, weekends 12:30 to 5. Hands-on exhibits especially for children, including a Grand Prix racer, and radio and television studio. Admission $5 children, $4 adults.
Huntington Library and Art Collection, 1151 Oxford Road, San Marino, (818) 405-2141. Tuesday to Friday 1 to 4:30 P.M., Saturday and Sunday 10:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.
A donation of $5 for adults is suggested.
 
Night Life
 The Pasadena Playhouse, 39 South El Molino Avenue, (818) 792-8672. By all reports, the theatrical productions here are very good to excellent. And the Spanish Revival architecture (circa 1925) is impressive.
The Espresso Bar (a k a "The E Bar"), 34 South Raymond Avenue, (818) 356-9095. A local after-dinner favorite. Poetry readings Wednesday night. Open mike on Tuesday.
Landmark Rialto Cinema, 1023 South Fair Oaks Avenue, (818) 799-9567. Constructed in 1888, this shrine to film has a real balcony, ornate decoration, and an old-time ticket booth.
The Baked Potato, 26 East Colorado Boulevard, (818) 564-1122. Jazz and, you guessed it, every variation on the baked potato theme.
Innarty's, 36 East Holly Street, (818) 793-3723. Jazz and Continental food.
The Ice House, 24 North Mentor Drive, (818) 577-1894. Comedy and dinner.
Q's, 99 East Colorado Boulevard, (818) 405-9777. Trendy billiards. "Three stories of attitude," according to one local.

HEADLINE: Disabled Fight to Insure Their Rights

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
JOE BRAVO'S young life changed in the space of a few seconds. When he was 12, he was struck in the chest by a sniper's bullet while riding his bike near his home in the Bronx. Mr. Bravo remembers being a tough street kid back then, a boy who held his own in a gritty neighborhood. After being shot, he said, he was paralyzed from the waist down, forgoing his bike for a wheelchair.
Mr. Bravo is now 38, and he still thinks of himself as tough -- but he is fighting a different kind of battle. 
 As executive director of the Westchester Independent Living Center in White Plains, one of 35 nonprofit centers for the disabled in the state, Mr. Bravo is an advocate for others like him -- people who use wheelchairs, crutches, guide dogs or the arms of friends in conducting their everyday business.
According to statistics from the County Office for the Disabled, there are 149,000 Westchester residents with disabilities, a category that includes not only those with physical impairments but also those who have a learning disability or are mentally ill or who have AIDS or any ongoing illness that might make it difficult to work or to get hired.
Throughout the county, people like Mr. Bravo and Kenneth B. Hill, an advocate in Yonkers, are fighting to remove barriers preventing full implementation of a new Federal law guaranteeing the rights of the disabled.
"Unfortunately, we have a long way to go on this front," said Mr. Hill, a paraplegic who works for Disabled on the Move, another independent living center. Mr. Hill, 27, who was shot in the back as he fled from a robber eight years ago and now uses a wheelchair, works to find housing for people with disabilities and to resolve complaints about discrimination in the workplace.
Although it has been almost 20 years since the first Federal law was passed making it illegal for publicly financed programs to discriminate against the disabled, most advocates agree with Mr. Hill that not enough changes have taken place.
It has also been almost three years since the Americans With Disabilities Act was signed into law. But two deadlines for complying with the most recent law have passed, and another is quickly approaching.
"It was a big deal on the South Lawn of the White House when the law was signed," Mr. Bravo said. "Wow, I thought, we've finally come of age. It took years of advocacy to get that to happen."
Recently, though, Mr. Bravo has begun to temper his initial enthusiasm. "It was naive to think that everything would change just because there was a new law on the books," he said. "It's like what happened with civil rights."
 
Still a Long Way to Go
 The Americans With Disabilities Act, which was passed in the summer of 1990, says employers cannot discriminate on the basis of a disability; public transportation must be accessible to all; places of public accommodation, like restaurants and retail stores, may not discriminate; services by state and local government must be accessible to all, and companies offering phone service to the public must also offer services for the deaf and hearing impaired.
In other words, Mr. Bravo said, disabled people sought through the law a "user-friendly environment that would not separate us out."
By Jan. 26 last year, places of public accommodation were required to comply with the provisions of the Americans With Disabilities Act. By July, all private employers with 25 or more employees had to comply. All public buses ordered after Aug. 26, 1990, were to be accessible to the disabled. And this July 26 key rail stations are to be accessible to all, although some exceptions allow deadlines to be moved ahead to July 26, 2020.
At the State Office of Advocate for the Disabled, Robert J. Boehlert, a lawyer, said that although many retail establishments, hotels and restaurants are beginning to comply with the law and there is a growing awareness among employers and local governments that changes must be made, full compliance may be a long way off.
For example, accessible public transportation is a key issue for many in the county, where Westchester Paratransit, a curb-to-curb van service, is the only comprehensive source of public travel for people with disabilities.
And although Metro-North has developed a plan for upgrading some train stations to make them accessible for the disabled, the plan falls far short of the mark, said Terence J. Moakley, associate executive director of the Eastern Paralyzed Veterans Association.
Mr. Moakley's organization -- an advocacy group representing 2,000 members in New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Connecticut, which is based in Jackson Heights, Queens -- attended Metro-North public hearings last year on plans for upgrading about 10 stations. But the group, along with other advocacy organizations, recommended that 30 stations in the county be upgraded.
Meanwhile, the Federal Transportation Department is reviewing Metro-North's proposal, and many advocates are worried that full access to train service may elude them for many more years.
 
Personal Barriers
 But not all hurdles for the disabled come in the form of architectural barriers, like inaccessible entrances to buildings and train stations or bathrooms that don't accommodate wheelchairs, Mr. Boehlert said from the Office for the Disabled in Albany.
"People's attitudes," he said, "are the biggest stumbling block."
Richard Manley, director of the Westchester County Office for the Disabled, agreed. "It's sad," he said, "but we still hear some very chilling stories."
"When I was a kid," recalled Mr. Manley, who suffers from a congenital bone deformity, "if you ever saw anyone with a disability on TV, the movie either ended with them jumping out of their wheelchair and running away laughing, all cured, or they died. There was no in between."
"Clearly," he said, "some of those stereotypes are fading."
Mr. Manley, who also lectures in classrooms about disabilities, said that a decade ago, students would ask him questions like, "Do you have to sleep in a wheelchair?" or, because he is four feet tall, "Do you live in a little house?"
"Now," he said, "they ask me things like, 'Do you play basketball in a wheelchair?' or 'Can you drive a van?' I do see signs of progress."
While the progress heartens some advocates, it is not enough for others, who say that many businesses and local governments -- concerned about the economics of implementing mandated changes to buildings, for example -- are delaying action.
"Everyone is crying about the costs," Mr. Bravo said. "They make it a low priority because it represents a financial burden."
Mr. Boehlert said, "We may need one or two court cases in the future to point people in the right direction."
But for now, Mr. Bravo and others are employing the power of the boycott, choosing not to frequent restaurants and stores that are not fully accessible. In December, after years of holding their annual Christmas party at a restaurant that did not have accessible restrooms for the disabled, employees in Mr. Bravo's office agreed to go elsewhere.
"That's what it's going to take," Mr. Bravo said. "With 43 million Americans with disabilities, our power as consumers can hit home. It's our numbers that will finally make the difference."
People who want more information about the Americans With Disabilities Act or who are concerned about possible violations of the law, can call the Justice Department at (202) 514-0301.
Blind and visually impaired people can call Richard M. Keller at the Independent Living Center in White Plains. Mr. Keller runs support groups and counseling sessions and has information about new communications technology, including computers, which are available for the visually handicapped. His telephone number, and Mr. Bravo's, is 682-3926.
In Yonkers the number for Disabled on the Move is 968-4717.
The County Office for the Disabled also provides information about the new law and acts as a referral agency for services. That telephone number is 285-2957.

HEADLINE: After-School Centers Fill a Gap in Students' Lives

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG

DATELINE: ARDSLEY

 BODY:
AT an hour when most elementary school students are still rubbing the sleepy dust from their eyes and scrambling to make the school bus on time, 10-year-old Tracy Green and her 7-year-old brother, David, are already engrossed in a board game at the Ardsley Children's Center at the Concord Road Elementary School.
Several children are reviewing the previous day's homework assignments as they sprawl on a rug in front of a picture window, while others sit quietly and read in a brightly lighted corner. 
 Down the hall in the cafeteria, eight boys from second through fourth grade are playing Frisbee with soft foam disks, while a cluster of kindergarten and first-grade girls compare the toys they have brought in their backpacks.
 
More of the Waking Day at School
 During a time when educators, industrialists and politicians debate the benefits of expanding the school day and increasing the academic year, many children are already spending a significant part of their waking day at school, albeit not always in academic pursuits.
The school day may officially start at 8:30 A.M. and run until 3 P.M. in most districts, but for increasing numbers of Westchester youngsters, it is not uncommon to be at school from 7:30 A.M. to nearly 6 P.M.
"Sometimes we assume that a child is grown-up if he goes to school," said Sally Ziegler, executive director of the Child Care Council of Westchester, based in White Plains. "School-age child care is an essential family support, and it's wonderful to see how it has grown in the last 10 years. As the economy got crunchier, more people had to work. Once women had the freedom to use these centers, even on a drop-off basis, they could move into a working life."
In even the most affluent Westchester bedroom communities, two-career couples are becoming increasingly the norm rather than the exception.
The cost of a full-time housekeeper may be prohibitive for many families, and even those who can afford weekly salaries of, say, $200 to $300 often prefer to have their children spend their time in the more social setting of an after-school center.
For other parents, after-school center fees, which range from about $190 to $250 a month for a five-day program, are reasonable enough to justify their staying on the job.
 
Constantly Increasing Enrollment
 Parents who have to catch the 7:57 A.M. train to Manhattan or return home two hours after the school day ends may be reluctant to rely on baby sitters or neighbors to get children to school in the morning or meet a school bus in the afternoon. In most cases grandparents or other family members are not available to help with child care.
"I have found that the enrollment is constantly increasing," said Julie Fraitag, executive director of the Ardsley Children's Center, which has served as a model for other centers. "There's a great need. We started with 10 children in 1981 and now have 140 children registered."
The Ardsley Children's Center serves students in kindergarten through fourth grade, and last fall it started a program in the district's middle school for fifth and sixth graders.
Whether these centers provide before-school and after-school services, operate on school holidays or during vacation breaks, they are often necessary to fill in the gaps between a parent's work schedule and the school calendar.
The programs serve families with a wide range of incomes and include private school programs like the Hackley School's in Tarrytown. They offer children a structured afternoon of recreational and educational activities as well as providing a safe and quiet place to be until parents return from work. Some centers will escort children to and from after-school clubs or meet them at churches.
In several communities with half-day kindergartens, the centers also offer parents an opportunity to have their children in a full-day setting with stimulating activities. For example, the 10-year-old Chappaqua Children's Workshop has 83 percent of enrolled kindergartners in its program, said Jill Stewart, executive director of the workshop. "We definitely felt the need for an all-day program," she said. "First and foremost, we are here for working parents who need to have their children in an enriching educational program for more than two and a half hours a day. There's a symbiotic relationship between the kindergarten program and our program; we reinforce the skills of the Chappaqua kindergarten program."
Jane Arcaya, director of the Dobbs Ferry After-School Center, said, "Society and the community have to catch up with the fact that parents are working."
 
The Reliability Factor
 And because both are working, parents must be able to count on their children's being taken care of.
"For parents, the biggest factor is reliability," said Shelly Levin, director of the Children's Corner in Larchmont, which serves 150 children in kindergarten through sixth grade. "The biggest anxiety is that the sitter won't show up," she said. "Some parents also don't like it if the kids are at home with a sitter, watching TV and playing Nintendo, and not learning how to use their leisure time in a healthy way."
Other families are concerned about having their children in a social and stimulating environment. "A lot of parents want their children to have other children to socialize with," Ms. Fraitag said. Like many other centers, the Ardsley Children's Center offers special events and a family evening, possibly a karaoke sing-along or a square dance, to foster a community feeling among those using the program.
With their mixture of cooking and crafts, homework help, sports and recreation, board games, puzzles and other activities, the centers offer children an alternative to the "What'll I do?" syndrome. "We like to give freedom of choice for kids," Ms. Fraitag said. "There's encouragement to try different activities, but it's not high pressure. This is a recreational program, where we try to enrich a child's life."
 
Most Are School-Based
 Anne-Marie Terrone, director of Kids Extended Educational Program, known as Keeps, which serves school-age children in the Rye Neck and Mamaroneck school districts at a building not on school premises, added, "We try to make it like home, where kids feel comfortable, with a quiet, supervised area for them to do homework."
Although the programs are usually run by independent, nonprofit organizations that rent space from school districts, the fact that most of them are based at a school is an advantage. "There's a great deal of comfort for parents, because they know where their child is at all times," Ms. Fraitag said.
Georgiene Dempsey, principal of the Springhurst Elementary School in Dobbs Ferry, said: "We don't want this to be just day care. We want it structured to help children. There's a nice connection where children have a comfortable feeling because their regular teachers work in the After-School Center. There are a lot of adults here, which adds to a parent's feeling of security. For parents, the fact that the children are here with us means that if a child had a problem that day in the lunchroom, someone knows about it."
The programs offer supervision for children who might otherwise spend their afternoons in unsupervised settings. The Kids Bridge program, which started at the Oakside Elementary School in Peekskill last fall and is sponsored by the Peekskill Area Health Center, serves 20 school-age youngsters in kindergarten through sixth grade from 3 to 5:30 P.M.
"There's really a paucity of services, with a lack of well-organized child care," said Roberta Marcus-Leiner, director of Women and Youth services at the Peekskill Area Health Center. "Too often, kids are left to their own devices, especially in the fifth and sixth grades. Everyone at all levels feels the impact of diminishing resources. We're providing consistent daily after-school care, including homework help, indoor and outdoor recreation, games, snacks and arts and crafts." Added Anne Nolon, president of the Peekskill Area Health Center, "We have a terrific opportunity to impact these kids in a holistic, comprehensive way."
 
Fun for the Children
 For children in after-school centers, the experience is fun and carries none of the punitive connotation of being made to stay after school. "I like being with the other children, and I like being here with my brother," said Tracy Green, a fourth grader at Ardsley's Concord Road School. "I like to do the cooking." Added David Choyne, another fourth grader who attends only morning sessions, "I have friends here, and I like to go to the cafeteria and play games."
For parents, the programs are more than merely an affordable alternative to baby sitting. "It was a lifesaver and one of the reasons I bought in the district," said Harrel Morris, a special education department head in Yonkers and a member of the Ardsley Board of Education. "I would have had a problem without it because I wanted to be independent. I was very impressed with the quality of supervision, and my children enjoyed it. It's a definite asset to the community."
Allyson Funicello, a teacher in New Rochelle whose 7-year-old son attends the Mamaroneck Keeps program, said: "It was a godsend to me. I get out of my school later than he does and otherwise would have had to pay a baby sitter. It was very important to me that he had it, because Mamaroneck has half-day kindergarten, and I felt that he was ready for a more social situation. The fees are reasonable, and I like the stimulation of it."
No matter how enthusiastically parents endorse the programs, as districts struggle with expanding enrollments, space at schools is becoming more scarce. "No matter how much the community loves it, the reality is that it's the first to be pushed around when there's a space crunch," Ms. Ziegler of the Child Care Council of Westchester said.
Most parents who depend on the centers are reluctant to contemplate the alternatives. "The Irvington Children's Center is the only way I could be a part-time working mom," said Robin Dellabough, a writer and editor. "You don't have to sign up for full time, and they offer very gracious amounts of flexible time. They bend over backward to accommodate working mothers. I feel totally secure because my children are in a quality environment where they are nurtured and well cared for and not plopped in front of the TV. I don't have to worry about a baby sitter calling in sick because the children's center is always there."
 
 
Extending the School Day
 AFTER-SCHOOL centers are generally open only to residents of the immediate community or school district, and they adhere to the school calendar, although some open their doors on half-day conference days and during school vacations. Fees vary by program and attendance. The fees given here are for the month for one child attending five afternoons a week.
The following is a selected list of after-school programs in the county.
*Ardsley Children's Center, Post Office Box 731, Ardsley, N.Y.; 693-6686 (for Concord Road site), 693-6655 (for Middle School site). Open from 7:30 to 8:30 A.M. (Concord site only) and from end of classes to 6 P.M.; $231.20 at Concord Road, which serves students in kindergarten through fourth grade; $268.20 at the Middle School, which serves students in fifth and sixth grade.
*Chappaqua Children's Workshop, Post Office Box 254, Chappaqua; 238-3295. Programs at three elementary schools (Westorchard, Grafflin and Roaring Brook) and in a portable classroom. For half-day kindergarten students, there is an academic and recreational program. Kindergartners participate in activities ranging from fish dissection to cooking, woodworking and drama. Before-school and after-school programs for students in kindergarten through fifth grade include community-service projects as well as special events and trips. *Children's Corner, Hommocks School, Hommocks Road, Larchmont; 834-0022. An extended-day program for students in half-day kindergarten (11:40 A.M. to 3 P.M.). For students in kindergarten through sixth grade, hours are 7:40 to 8:40 A.M. and 3 to 6 P.M.; $236.
*Dobbs Ferry After-School Center, Springhurst Elementary School, Walgrove Avenue, Dobbs Ferry; 693-2406. For students in kindergarten through fourth grade. Open from 7:30 to 8 A.M. and 2:30 to 6 P.M.; $210.

*Irvington Children's Center, St. Barnabas Episcopal Church, 15 North Broadway, Irvington; 591-8182. Open from 7:30 to 9 A.M. and noon to 6:30 P.M. Because the program is at a church and not at Dows Lane Elementary School, the school district provides bus transportation to the church.

Open from end of classes to 6 P.M.; $80.

HEADLINE: FORAGING;
Where Treasures Wait to Be Wanted

BYLINE: By Cara Greenberg

 BODY:
GOODWILL INDUSTRIES' thrift store on Ditmars Boulevard in Astoria, Queens, is different things to different people.
To those who can't pay department-store prices, it's a place where they can get decent, wearable clothing for a few dollars. 
 To antiques dealers, it's a place where they can stop on Monday and Thursday mornings, when deliveries arrive from Goodwill's nearby headquarters.
And to Kim and Mike Bratland, a couple who live in the neighborhood, and their friend Lisa Perez, all in their early 20's, it's a place for whiling away a Sunday afternoon indulging in their passion for 1970's synthetics.
"One hundred percent polyester," said Ms. Perez, a secretary at the Ayer advertising agency in Manhattan, holding up a shiny black button-down shirt ($4) with a large pointy collar. "It'll go with my platform shoes," she said. "Gotta get a pair of bell bottoms. I'm going for the dated look."
Ms. Bratland, an aspiring actress who also works at Ayer, chose a painfully gaudy yellow ruffled blouse ($4). "It's the whole 70's thing going on in fashion," she said. "Ruffles are happening; and clashing colors."
Mr. Bratland, a long red ponytail sticking out from under his turned-around baseball cap, said: "It's like a treat for me to come in here. I come once a month with $20, $30." Holding a pair of maroon velvet bell-bottom jeans ($5), he added: "I buy anything that flares on the bottom. They're my stage clothes." Mr. Bratland, who works in a music store by day, plays in a heavy-metal fusion band called Naked Sun.
A practiced thrift shopper, Mr. Bratland is convinced that the Astoria Goodwill is "the best one in the city -- they don't overprice things." Ms. Bratland agreed, adding, "This stuff in the Village vintage-clothing stores would be five times as much."
The 2,500-square-foot Astoria store is one of the largest of 18 Goodwill thrift stores in the five boroughs. The shops are owned and operated by Goodwill Industries of Greater New York Inc., a nonprofit organization that gets its goods from individual and commercial donors.
Goodwill Industries also operates an array of vocational and rehabilitative programs for people with disabilities, the unemployed and disadvantaged youth.
The store in Astoria sells primarily clothing and toys, in addition to occasional pieces of furniture, some housewares and a few antiques.
Barbara Dorry, a bookkeeper who lives in the neighborhood, said, "I snoop out the good stuff, like Liz Claiborne and Calvin Klein."
"My daughter saw a sweater I bought here for $6 that was $48 at the Gap," Ms. Dorry said. "She asked where I got it, and I told her. She said, 'Oh mother, how could you?' But still, she was impressed."
Two sisters, Spiredoula and Marika Viglis, who grew up in the still largely Greek neighborhood, said they check the store periodically for books and classical-music recordings. "The old thick ones, recorded in the 50's," said Spiredoula Viglis, a sophomore at the High School of Art and Design in Manhattan. Marika Viglis, a student at Columbia Teachers College, added, "We like the pops and scratches."
On this occasion, Spiredoula Viglis bought what she called "an old lady's handbag" for $3. She swung the large leather rectangle by its sturdy strap. "If somebody bothers you, you just slug them with it," she said.
The Goodwill thrift store, at 31-20 Ditmars Boulevard in Astoria, Queens, is open Monday through Saturday from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. and Sunday from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Telephone: (718) 545-8875.

HEADLINE: New York Post Finds a Reprieve In Investor Who May Buy Paper

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
On the brink of announcing a suspension of publication, The New York Post found temporary reprieve last night in a wealthy investor who said he might buy the embattled newspaper. The Post, meanwhile, declared that it would publish today and fight on for survival.
"Contrary to what everybody has thought or said, The New York Post is not dead," Peter S. Kalikow, the owner, said at the end of a day of tabloid-style brinkmanship in which the newspaper's workers agreed to steep temporary pay cuts and a Governor, a Senator, a Cardinal and other prominent New York figures joined the fray to keep the paper afloat. 
 Chomping on a cigar, clad in a sweater and jeans, looking relaxed for the first time in three days of round-the-clock crisis, Mr. Kalikow met reporters in his office and announced that he had struck a deal with Steven Hoffenberg, chairman of the Towers Financial Corporation and a multimillionaire investor and businessman, to rescue The Post in the next four weeks.
"Within that period," Mr. Kalikow said, "we hope to execute a contract of sale to Mr. Hoffenberg and Towers." He said the last-minute reprieve by Mr. Hoffenberg had been unsolicited, and suggested that it had come just as The Post prepared to throw in the towel.
Mr. Kalikow did not spell out the details, but others familiar with the deal said that Mr. Hoffenberg, while not flatly agreeing to buy The Post, had expressed avid interest and had in effect agreed to guarantee the paper's expenses while he investigated the possibility of buying it.
Mr. Hoffenberg, in a statement last night, was less oblique, indicating that he would buy The Post and would sign papers today to set the process in motion. He said he intended to resurrect it as a force on New York's newspaper scene and at a profit. He said he would put his own 1,000-member sales force to work selling ads, offer the unions equity in the paper and strive for a cooperative relationship with the workers, who he said had sacrificed greatly.
"The New York Post does not deserve to die," Mr. Hoffenberg declared. "But more than just a New York tradition, I believe it can be made to be an economically viable newspaper that can successfully compete in the New York marketplace for its share of readership and advertising."
The deal was approved by Bankers Trust, which was unwilling to sink any more cash into the money-losing Post and had precipitated the crisis on Friday by cutting off its credit. The bank had resisted appeals by Mr. Kalikow and others to relent all weekend, until Mr. Hoffenberg entered the picture.
Mr. Hoffenberg will virtually take the bank's place, giving The Post loans against its accounts receivable -- insiders said some $7 million to $8 million was owed the paper by its advertisers and subscribers -- and said he would provide the cash-starved paper an immediate infusion of $300,000 to $500,000 to help get it through this week.
Mr. Kalikow, looking as ebullient as a Dickensian character released from debtor's prison, was lavish in praise of his employees and a host of prominent figures who had helped him through a difficult weekend, including Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, John Cardinal O'Connor, and the state's Economic Development Commissioner, Vincent Tese.
"Mario Cuomo worked literally with me day and night for the last three days," Mr. Kalikow said. "It's been a rough three days, I will admit."
Asked about his employees, who had voted to accept his demand for a 20 percent pay cut for four weeks, he declared: "I would say that without those votes there would be no New York Post."
And what will today's Page 1 headline be in The Post?
"It will cost you 50 cents to find out," Mr. Kalikow beamed.
The front-page banner of a 60-page Post, which hit the streets just after midnight, declared: "Never Say Die." And The Post's editor, Lou Colasuonno, said in an early-morning interview: "We're still here." He said the mood in the newsroom was buoyant after "an incredible roller-coaster of a day."
Another fact of life for The Post's readers was a 10-cent price increase on the city edition, to 50 cents, effective today. The price increase affects 280,000 copies in the five boroughs. The rest of The Post's 440,000 copies go to the suburbs, where the price remains 50 cents.
The transaction that brought Mr. Hoffenberg to The Post was put together through a series of calls involving William Fugazy, the limousine magnate, Governor Cuomo, Mr. Tese, Cardinal O'Connor and Howard J. Rubenstein, the public relations consultant, who has represented Mr. Fugazy, Mr. Hoffenberg and The Post for years.
And while Mr. Hoffenberg had expressed interest in The Post late last week, according to Mr. Rubenstein, the deal almost went awry because Post officials had the wrong telephone number for him -- one digit off. Governor Cuomo at one point called the State Police to locate Mr. Hoffenberg, and a police check found that the number was wrong. Finally, contact was made and Mr. Hoffenberg called Mr. Fugazy, then The Post.
Five hours were lost in the confusion, and the call came only minutes before Mr. Kalikow was to announce that publication would be halted. "We thought we would die because we knew he was interested," Mr. Rubenstein said.
There is no guarantee that Mr. Hoffenberg will ultimately rescue The Post, or that other potential buyers in the wings will step forward in the coming month. But the fast-breaking developments gave an aura of fresh hope to what had been a weekend of gloom and frustration, especially for workers facing the loss of their jobs at The Post.
"It's great," said George E. McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, representing seven of The Post's 11 unions. "We're delighted for the union members and for the people of New York. We hope it means that The Post will continue to be the oldest paper in the country."
But several staff members, all of whom spoke on the condition of anonymity, expressed concern that Mr. Hoffenberg had been reprimanded by the Securities and Exchange Commission for failing to register a $34 million securities offering.
 
Bank Credit Gone
The Post, its cash till empty, its bank credit gone, its owner bankrupt and unable to help pay costs of hundreds of thousands of dollars a week, according to executives at the paper, had decided late yesterday to suspend publication, despite agreement over the weekend by its 716 unionized workers and its management executives to take the 20 percent pay cut.
The savings from that cut were expected to reduce The Post's weekly outlay for wages and benefits by about $170,000, to $680,000 from $850,000. And the increased revenues from the 10-cent increase in the newsstand price, when wholesalers' costs and other expenses were deducted, were expected to provide another $100,000 a week.
But the total of $270,000 in savings and increased revenues -- while probably sufficient to enable The Post to break even, or perhaps turn a small profit -- were not enough to keep the paper afloat because the money would be realized slowly, and the paper's cash needs were immediate.
That meant that Bankers Trust, which had already sunk millions into the paper, would have to supply more cash in the coming month if the search for a new owner was to go on, and the bank's officials were simply unwilling to do that.
As the clock continued to tick, a doomsday announcement was prepared, saying that today's issue of The Post would not come out.
But late in the day, a ray of hope developed. Governor Cuomo and Mr. Tese, in separate interviews, said Mr. Kalikow had found an investor and potential buyer whose interest was sufficient for him to put up a large sum to solve the paper's immediate cash-flow problems.
Mr. Hoffenberg, whose Manhattan-based nationwide financial services company does $1 billion to $2 billion in business a year, has holdings in medical centers and other businesses.
"He's a serious potential buyer in the sense that he's putting up serious money," Mr. Tese said.

HEADLINE: John Corbin Eddison Development Expert, 71

 BODY:
John Corbin Eddison, an expert on economic development who was a former director of Near East Affairs for the United States Agency for International Development, died Friday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 73 years old and lived in Lexington, Mass.
He died of lung disease, said his wife, the former Elizabeth Owsley Bole. 
 Mr. Eddison was with the agency from 1963 to 1970, serving as deputy director of its mission in La Paz, Bolivia, and then in Washington as its deputy director of aid for Central America before becoming its Near East affairs director.
Mr. Eddison was born in Manhattan, grew up in Ardsley, N.Y. Other survivors include a son, Jonathan B. Eddison of Los Angeles; two daughters, Elizabeth O. Eddison of Minneapolis and Martha Sieniewicz of Cambridge, Mass.

HEADLINE: Fighting for Custom House, Boston Appeals to U.S.

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Towering 500 feet above the tourist-packed Quincy Market and only blocks from Boston Harbor, the gray granite Custom House sits dark, dank and empty, waiting for better times.
Plate-size paint chips hang off the walls of the yellow Counting Room, where, beginning in 1847, seafaring merchants once lined up to pay their taxes. Light from the security desk filters weakly into a cavernous room under a grand dome, which formed the original roof before a 30-story tower was added over it in 1915. 
 Elsewhere, rows of clunky fluorescent lights extend from majestically high ceilings, remnants of a hodgepodge of Federal offices housed there until the General Services Administration locked the doors, declaring the building surplus property in 1986.
Built at a time when Boston's port collected one-fifth of the customs tax for the nation, the Custom House has long since seen its glory days pass. But now, after a five-year struggle to develop the property on their own, city officials are taking the fight to Washington in an effort to open the building's doors again.
 
Sale to City in 1987
 Seeking to protect one of its most valuable landmarks and the symbol of Boston's port, city officials bought the Custom House from the Federal Government in 1987 for $11 million -- $1.1 million immediately and the remaining $9.9 million in a 10-year mortgage.
But that was just before the recession sent real-estate values plummeting. Developers working with the Boston Redevelopment Agency complained that there was not enough usable space in the slender tower to justify the renovation costs. A plan to turn it into an office building was abandoned.
Since then, the Beal Companies and Inter-Continental Hotels have received preliminary approvals to build a glass bridge that would connect the Custom House with a historic brick building across the street, using both buildings as a 336-room luxury hotel.
But without a drastic reduction in the mortgage, city officials and the developers say, no lender will put up the money to allow the project to proceed.
Recently, the Custom House was appraised at $2.5 million, less than the $3.5 million the city has already paid on the property since the 1987 purchase, said Paul L. Barrett, director of the Boston Redevelopment Authority, which owns it. "We've already paid more than the property is worth," he said. "No project can carry the kind of mortgage that the G.S.A. is requiring on the property."
 
Plan to Seek U.S. Gift
 Mr. Barrett said he would ask the Clinton Administration to give the building to the city under the Historic Monument Act.
But to change the terms of the sale now would be unfair to taxpayers, argued Earl E. Jones, Commissioner of the Federal Property and Assets Management Service of the General Services Administration. Mr. Jones said the city stopped its quarterly payments in April 1991 and had not resumed them, even though his agency agreed last summer to reduce the interest and extend the mortgage to 30 years from 10.
Mr. Jones said it was unusual for the General Services Administration to finance the sale of a Federal property, and even more unusual to renegotiate the terms.
"We have never stretched it just this far," he said. "This was a great effort on our part to try to help the city."
If the city does not resume payments, Mr. Jones warned, he will have to consider other applicants to buy the property, including organizations that house the homeless.
He said there was no guarantee that the Federal Government would give the city the building under the monument act.
"We're willing to take that risk," Mr. Barrett replied. The city is paying $20,000 a month in security and maintenance costs alone, he said, whereas the hotel would create 450 permanent jobs and tax revenue. "I think a new Administration will take a fresh look at it," he said. "They are talking about growing the economy; that's why they won the election."
 
Need for Economic Stake
 People following the case are not surprised by this latest turn of events.
"To be protected, the Custom House needs to be a part of the ongoing economy of Boston," said Ellen Lipsey, executive director of the Boston Landmarks Commission.
Philip Bergen, the librarian of the Bostonian Society, fondly remembers being taken to the 25th floor observation tower as a child. "For many generations, that was where you went to get a good view of the city," he said. "It's sad to think it's still there, but it's not open to the public."

(Photographs by Evan Richman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BENTSEN SUGGESTS BROAD ENERGY TAX WILL BE PROPOSED

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen suggested today that the Clinton Administration would propose a tax on all forms of energy to help lower the budget deficit and encourage conservation.
In a television interview, Mr. Bentsen, whom President Clinton has made the Administration's chief spokesman on economic matters, also indicated that a tax cut for the middle class was not in the offing. In addition, he did not take issue with a questioner who asserted that an energy tax would fall most heavily on the middle class. 
 On the NBC News program "Meet the Press," on which Mr. Bentsen was interviewed, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who is the chairman of the Finance Committee and thus one of the most important voices in Congress on tax legislation, said he would support an energy tax.
 
'Some Tough Choices'
 Mr. Bentsen's statements amounted to a concession by the new Administration that the only way to bring down the budget deficit is to take the politically difficult steps of raising the taxes of ordinary Americans and cutting Government programs.
"Some tough choices will have to be made that haven't been faced up to in the past," the Treasury Secretary said. He said that spending reductions would provide a large part of what the Administration hoped to cut from the deficit by 1997.
Mr. Bentsen seemed to rule out a tax on gasoline alone and spoke of the benefits of a "broad-based" energy tax. Broad-based normally refers to a tax on all forms of energy, including petroleum, natural gas, coal, hydroelectricity and nuclear power.
 
Impact on Many Products
 For a family spending $100 a month in utility bills and $60 for gasoline, a 5 percent increase in fuel costs would total $8 each month. In addition, the prices of many products and services, like air travel, would rise as the higher cost of fuel was passed along to consumers.
In his campaign, Mr. Clinton had maintained that lowering the deficit could be accomplished rather painlessly by raising the taxes of wealthy individuals and foreign companies and by improving the way Government programs were managed. He promised a tax cut for the middle class.
But since the election, he has begun to talk of the need for some bitter medicine to get the deficit under control. "It will not be easy," he declared in his Inaugural Address last week. "It will require sacrifice."
Mr. Bentsen said the main reason for the change in attitude was that the budget deficit in the middle of this decade had been projected to be much higher than was estimated six months ago. That is because the economy is expected to be weaker, the cost of Government medical programs is rising faster than expected and the timetable for spending for the savings and loan bailout has changed.
 
Falling Behind Schedule
 Other officials who have been working on the economic package said that the deficit-cutting measures offered during the campaign were always insufficient and that the difficulty in reducing the deficit had been underestimated.
Before the election, Mr. Clinton had promised that he would present an economic plan to Congress on Inauguration Day. Officials now say that the plan will not be ready until the middle of next month and that a complete budget will not be submitted until March.
"Four years from now or three weeks from now, people are going to judge President Clinton on the effectiveness of his program and not on whether it was presented a few weeks late," Mr. Bentsen said in a brief telephone conversation on Friday.
On television today, he said that the economics team was working on the matter night and day and that material was sent to him at home as late as 10:30 Saturday night. He noted that Ronald Reagan, the last President to take office determined to turn the Government's economic policies around, did not announce his plans until Feb. 18, 1981, almost a month after his inauguration.
 
Awaiting Political Decisions
 The biggest decisions to be made, officials said, are not so much economic judgments as political ones that can be made only by President Clinton himself. "What it all boils down to is who's going to take the hit," a Presidential adviser said.
In other words, who is going to end up paying higher taxes? Who is going to have their benefits reduced? Which claimants for new Government money will be rejected? Which politicians will be denied projects for their constituents?
During the campaign and the transition and his first few days in office, Mr. Clinton has avoided making those judgments, at least publicly.
Mr. Bentsen argued that Americans were willing to pay the price to cut the deficit and strengthen the economy. "The American people are ready for it," he said, "as long as they think those sacrifices are equally shared and the investment is in our future for the increase in the standard of living of our people."
 
'Our Budget Deficit Now'
 Senator Moynihan said the Democrats in Congress would support unpopular measures. "Look, it is our budget deficit now," he said. "We were partners in creating it. It wasn't our idea, but it's our deficit. And it will paralyze our Administration and our country if we don't get it out of the way."
As for Republicans, they favor consumption taxes like energy taxes over taxes on income or wealth.
Mr. Bentsen emphasized that the plan was still being developed. He avoided most questions about its contents and did not say specifically that the Administration favored an energy tax. But the positive way he responded to a question about such a tax left little doubt about where the Administration stood.
"A broad-based energy tax is certainly one of those that is on the table as an option to be considered, because it does a couple of things," he said. "One, it raises revenue. On the other point, it helps lead to some environmental objectives that we're trying to bring about by conservation of the use of energy. See, at the present time, we're importing almost a billion dollars a week of oil, and that certainly adds to our trade deficit."
 
Emphasis on One Promise
 The imported oil, he went on to say, often comes from "unstable political areas."
Mr. Bentsen also suggested that the Administration might favor higher taxes on alcohol and tobacco and restated the Clinton campaign pledge for higher income taxes on families with incomes of more than $200,000 a year. He said that if additional deficit spending was proposed for this year to stimulate the economy, the stimulus would be smaller than the $50 billion that some economists have recommended.
Vice President Al Gore said last week that he supported an energy tax. Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary said in her confirmation hearing that she opposed new energy taxes, but that is probably evidence that she is not a central figure in overall economic policy-making within the Administration.
Middle-class Americans would bear the brunt of an energy tax because they pay a much larger portion of their incomes for fuel than do the rich. Congress would probably provide some form of rebate for the poor to offset the additional cost of essential fuel.
Mr. Bentsen said a gasoline tax would affect some regions of the country much more severely than others. Senator Moynihan said he agreed with that judgment, even though westerners, who drive longer distances, would be affected much more by a gasoline tax than New Yorkers.
An energy tax could be based on the cost of fuel consumed, on units produced like barrels of oil or tons of coal or on the heat content as measured by British thermal units. Some economists favor a tax based on carbon dioxide emissions, but that does not seem to be what the Administration has in mind.
 
Energy Tax May Have Support
 A broad-based energy tax could be collected by retailers like power companies or filling stations or it could be imposed at an earlier stage of the distribution process.
The Congressional Budget Office has calculated that a 5 percent tax on energy consumption would raise $18 billion a year.
An energy tax might be more politically palatable than other taxes that would raise a similar amount of revenue. All regions of the country would be affected more or less evenly. And one form of energy would not be favored over another, meaning that important lobbies might be held at bay. In addition, it would have the strong support of environmentalists.
The public might be sold by the arguments that fuel prices have not risen as fast as other prices in recent years and that Americans generally pay less for energy than do people in Europe and Japan.
The biggest price difference is in gasoline, which is much more heavily taxed abroad than it is here. In the United States, the Federal gasoline tax is 14.1 cents a gallon, while state and local taxes add 10 cents to 20 cents a gallon. France, by contrast, places a tax of about $2.80 a gallon on gasoline. In Italy the tax is more than $3.50 a gallon, and in Japan it is about $1.70.

HEADLINE: Mayors Press Clinton on Promise to Rebuild Nation

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Pressing President Clinton on his campaign promise to rebuild America, the nation's mayors have given Administration officials a list of more than 7,000 "ready to go" construction projects that would cost $27 billion and create 400,000 jobs.
The projects, in more than 500 cities, have already received all the local approval necessary and need only Federal money to begin. They include the building and renovating of schools, jails, housing, streets and highways, bridges, police and fire stations, as well as sewers and waste-water treatment plants. The mayors estimated that $13 billion would be needed to begin these projects, most of which would take more than a year to complete. 
 At the midwinter meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors, the mayors gave a list of these projects last week to Henry G. Cisneros, the new Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and to Federico F. Pena, the new Transportation Secretary.
"All we need is money," J. Thomas Cochran, executive director of the mayors conference, said in an interview. "The President has talked about an annual increase of $20 billion to rebuild America, and the mayors believe that this promise should be kept."
 
'We Must Do Both'
 But the campaign promise now faces the scrutiny of Mr. Clinton's budget officials, who have set deficit reduction as their priority. The Federal budget for the fiscal year that began on Oct. 1 provides $50.4 billion for major physical-improvement projects, compared with $46.5 billion last year. About half of that money is for transportation projects.
Asked Friday whether there was a conflict between stimulating the economy and reducing the deficit, George Stephanopoulos, the President's spokesman, replied, "The President has said we must do both, and he will."
The mayors look hopefully to Washington after 12 years of Republican government, during which the cities saw direct Federal aid drop to $23.4 billion in the current fiscal year from $44.2 billion in the 1981 fiscal year.
Along with the mayors, some lawmakers have told the Clinton Administration that they believe public-works spending will generate private investment that will create more jobs and thereby help reduce the deficit.
"This is not a case of having to choose between economic investment and deficit reduction," Representative Norman Y. Mineta, the California Democrat who heads the Public Works and Transportation Committee, said at a hearing last week. "If we do not invest in economic growth, we will not achieve deficit reduction."
 
New York's Wish List
 Last week, Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York gave Mr. Pena a list of 519 New York projects costing a total of $1.7 billion. They included $268 million for new and renovated housing; $190 million for schools; $171 million for streets and highways; $164 million for sanitation projects; $142 million for buildings; $123 million to renovate correctional institutions and $110 million for piers and terminals.
But New York's wish list, like that of every other city and every state, will be competing with those of the transportation industry. According to surveys, the industry would have no problem spending most of the $20 billion annual increase suggested by Mr. Clinton, and the American Road and Transportation Builders Association has already begun soliciting financial support from its members for a campaign of advertising, publicity and lobbying.
The American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials, after surveying officials in all the states, said it could spend an extra $8.5 billion in Federal highway money in 1993 beyond the $19.2 billion already provided by Congress. The American Public Transit Association said the easiest way to spend money would be to buy new buses, vans and subway cars.
 
Projects Elsewhere
 Other cities that have submitted lists of "ready to go" projects include these:
*Boston, which is seeking $277.5 million for projects that include $167 million for a water- and sewer-treatment plant, $47 million for public housing and $11.7 million for road and bridge improvements.
*Newark, which wants $175 million in new public-works spending, including $44 million for two garages for city vehicles, $12 million for neighborhood family recreation centers and $7.5 million for sewers.
*Chicago, which is seeking a total of $145 million, including $28 million for a recycling plant, $20 million for street resurfacing, $10 million for a crime laboratory and $9 million for sewers.
*Detroit, which is asking for a total of $577.4 million, including $266 million for public buildings and plants, $94 million for streets and $83 million for environmental improvements.
*Los Angeles, which is seeking a total of $214 million, including $59 million for traffic surveillance and control, $52 million for street improvements, $27 million for new parks and $15 million for housing rehabilitation.
Mayor Raymond L. Flynn of Boston has also made a special pitch to the Administration for $92.7 million in the projects, which he said would create 4,000 construction jobs. "There is work to do in our cities, and unemployed workers to do it," said Mr. Cochran, the mayors conference director. "Investment in public works will lead the cities out of recession, and the cities will lead the nation."

HEADLINE: STRICTLY BUSINESS;
42d Street Project Remains on Track

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
While signs of 42d Street's long-planned redevelopment remain overshadowed by the area's boarded-up stores, bureaucratic delays and a lingering recession, business and government leaders say the project remains in full gear -- albeit on a smaller scale -- and that indications of a new commercial vitality are starting to emerge.
The evidence ranges from an uptick in sales for some of the businesses that remain open to the flowering of new enterprises adjacent to the project and a surge of interest in leasing new retail space. Those involved in the redevelopment project say there is an increasing awareness that there is gold to be mined on 42d Street, and that the prospecting has already begun. 
 "There's a great deal of untapped spending power in the area," said Faith H. Consolo, senior vice president of Garrick-Aug Associates, hired by the developers to lease their retail space.
 
20 Million Tourists
 The reason is pure numbers. Perhaps as many as 20 million tourists a year come to Times Square. Some 190,000 commuters a day pass through the Port Authority and 250,000 through the subway station.
Under the redevelopment plan, two developers -- the Prudential Insurance Company of America and Park Tower Realty -- agreed last August to spend around $20 million to refurbish existing buildings for use as retail establishments. They did this to retain their right to build four giant towers when the market for office space improves.
A design plan for the scaled-back development is expected to be completed by March, with a five-month comment period to follow. Construction could begin by year's end.
But the displaced merchants, ranging from coffee shops to a seller of scuba gear to tiny groceries, will not come back. More upscale merchants are the stated goal.
"We can have one of the best and most exciting shopping streets in America," said Miss Consolo, who added that leasing deals may begin to be signed within 60 days.
 
Eager Shoppers
 A battery of marketing studies indicate that the tourists and commuters who pass through the area are eager to spend money. In one random sample paid for by the project organizers, 45 percent of the people said they would definitely shop in Times Square if there were new shops. A survey of 100 potential retailers revealed that 90 would like to be on 42d Street, Miss Consolo said.
One indication that such optimism might not be misplaced is that not all merchants say business is off, even with the street's dreary appearance. Paul Rosenthal, assistant manager of Modell's Sporting Goods at 243 West 42d Street, says sales have risen recently. "And with spring coming, we're going to do even better," he said.
A more telling indication is the success of the Gap store at 42d and Broadway, which opened last May in space that had been occupied by an O.T.B. parlor. Though the company will not discuss individual stores, public officials and other retailers say it has been startlingly successful. Most days, one can hear a cacophony of languages in the store.
 
Improvements to Terminal
 At the other end of the block, the Port Authority Bus Terminal is brightening up in promising ways. A 7,300 square-foot Duane Reade drugstore is planned for the southwest corner of 42d Street at Eighth Avenue, awaiting only approval of the Port Authority's board.
"Not only is it an anchor for the bus terminal, but also an anchor for retail activity on 42d Street," said Jack Brendlen, the manager of the Port Authority's real estate and property division.
The change in atmosphere at the terminal -- with its classical musical and social services for the homeless -- presage a new 42d Street, optimists say. Their hopes are further buoyed by the success of the Times Square Business Improvement District at cleaning up local sidewalks. The city Sanitation Department rated 88.9 percent of sidewalks clean last summer, compared with just 54.8 percent nine months earlier.
 
Reduced Crime
 This heightened cleanliness combines with a lesser crime rate to make for a better commercial environment. Though William H. Daly, director of the Mayor's Office of Midtown Enforcement, thinks it unlikely that last year matched 1991's 54 percent drop in crime in the area, he said, "We're very optimistic about the street."
But some say the redevelopment effort has actually hurt business because so many buildings have been condemned and there are fewer people on the streets.
"Business is terrible," said Ezra Grazi, owner of J & W Gift Imports at 245 West 42d, which is slated for condemnation. "It's a disaster on the block."
 
Problems May Arise
 Things could still go awry with the redevlopment plans. For example, officials and business owners are watching to see whether the design study shows that the buildings that are to be renovated for the new stores are in worse shape than envisioned.
But even as plans for a new overall commercial environment are completed over the next month or so, retailers from around the world are already pounding on the door of the agent hired to do the renting.
"They're chasing us, we're not chasing them," Miss Consolo said of her efforts to lease retail space. "This is not broker talk. There's really true, serious interest."
Moreover, there is no shortage of ideas for new attractions to bring yet more people. Rebecca Robertson, the president of the 42d Street project, said suggestions include a miniature amusement park with rides zipping between buildings, a country music park and all manner of computerized "artificial reality" games.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The redevelopment of Times Square could eventually resemble the California gold rush as the old bawdy theaters are replaced by new retail space, like the Gap, which opened last May at 42d Street on Broadway. (Photographs by Jack Manning/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
NEW YORK POST GETS A REPRIEVE
On the brink of announcing a suspension of publication, The New York Post has found a temporary reprieve in a wealthy investor who may buy the embattled newspaper. The paper declared that it would fight on for survival. "Contrary to what everybody has thought or said, The New York Post is not dead," Peter S. Kalikow, the owner, said at the end of a day of tabloid-style brinkmanship in which The Post's workers agreed to drastic temporary pay cuts and political leaders joined the fray to keep the paper afloat. Chomping on a cigar, clad in a casual sweater and jeans and looking relaxed for the first time in three days of round-the-clock crisis, Mr. Kalikow announced that he had struck a deal with Steven Hoffenberg, a multimillionaire investor and businessman, to rescue The Post. A1.
 
FROM FINANCE TO NEWSPAPERS
Steven Hoffenberg, the businessman who has emerged as the latest potential savior of The New York Post, is a 48-year-old self-described workaholic who built a small credit business into a $1 billion-a-year enterprise. B3. 

42D STREET REDEVELOPMENT
While signs of 42d Street's long-planned redevelopment remain overshadowed by the area's boarded-up stores, bureaucratic delays and a lingering recession, business and government leaders say the project remains in full gear -- albeit on a smaller scale -- and that indications of a new commercial vitality are starting to emerge. B3.
 
DISCOURAGING WORDS FOR SLUDGE RANCH
Since July, trains have been arriving at a ranch 85 miles east of El Paso, bringing an average of 225 tons a day of treated human waste that New York used to dump at sea until that was prohibited last July 1. From the start the project pitted neighbor against neighbor with small-town ferocity. Coloring all the arguments was a sense that the wastes were arriving from a metropolis so alien and far away that it might as well be from another planet. B2.
 
MEDIA STRATEGIST JOINS GIULIANI TEAM
David Garth, the political impresario, has joined Rudolph W. Giuliani's campaign team as media strategist. Mr. Garth's decision in 1977 to help Edward I. Koch in his bid for mayor lent legitimacy to the congressman's campaign. Metro Matters, B2.
 
REGION
 
CONSEQUENCES OF HIRING IMMIGRANTS
Political professionals vary in their assessments of how badly damaged Christine Todd Whitman and Cary Edwards, two leading Republican candidates for Governor, have been by their admissions that they both hired illegal immigrants. But the judgment of the voters appears more severe: those who violate such laws are not qualified to hold office. "I wouldn't trust them," said Denise D'Amato of Nutley. B5.
 
THE MYSTERY OF TRANSITCHEK
Subway riders puzzled by those advertisements trumpeting "the Biggest TransitChek in History" and showing a man with an inexplicably oversized cardboard check under his arm: don't worry. Nobody else gets it either. If the advertisements are puzzling, the idea behind TransitChek is actually quite simple: to promote the use of mass transportation by workers through tax breaks for their employers. And for subway, bus and train riders, it could add up to $60 in savings on commuting costs each month. The program itself, slightly less simple, works like this: If a company is willing to give its employees a monthly benefit to cover commuting costs, it can write off 40 percent of the total expense as a standard business deduction. For the employee, it amounts to tax-free carfare. B5.
 
MURDER TRIAL'S STRANGE TWIST
On the dance floor in the local V.F.W. hall, prosecutors set out to prove that Dr. Daniel Pack, a neurologist from Armonk, N.Y., was killed in a baseball-card deal gone bad. But by week's end, the unusual scenario and unlikely surroundings -- under a mirrored silver ball -- were eclipsed by the testimony in the increasingly bizarre murder trial. In a courtroom scene reminiscent of Perry Mason, 17-year-old Chad Gordon was accused by the defense lawyer, William M. Kunstler, of committing the killing for which his father, Joseph Gordon Jr., is standing trial. Carmel Journal, B4.
