HEADLINE: On the Menu, Steak Bucks Trend

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The general manager was proud to report that Dan Quayle had once eaten in his restaurant, and so had George Bush as Vice President. Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, he said, was a regular, and these days so is James Carville, the Clinton campaign strategist.
John Norris wasn't necessarily name-dropping. Morton's steak restaurant in Georgetown has been a magnet for years to Washington's leading political figures. 
 But when Richard L. Willey of tiny Hurlock, Md., turned up, negotiating one of those 16-ounce rib eyes, as he did the other night, it appeared to be news of, well, man-bites-steak variety. Mr. Willey is a vice president of the Perdue company.
"It was not something I do on a regular basis," said Mr. Willey, who eats his share of chicken, of course. "But when I'm in Washington or Chicago or New York, and I want to treat myself, I'll go for a steak. It's the flavor. I still enjoy the flavor."
 
He's Not the Only One
 As it turns out, Mr. Willey is hardly the anomaly he seems. He and the three friends who dined with him are part of a growing culture in the United States, people eating expensive steaks despite a sluggish economy and continued warnings by health officials to reduce the intake of foods high in cholesterol, like red meat.
If anything, as hard times have forced more families to eat less meat at home, a steak dinner out has become more of a special occasion.
As a result, restaurants that specialize in steak, like Morton's, have bucked the larger trends of stagnant growth in the restaurant industry and the steady decline of beef consumption in the United States for more than 15 years.
For instance, since it bought Morton's in 1989, the Quantum Restaurant Group Inc., has doubled the number of units, to 20, and the gross revenues, to $42.7 million. Quantum's president, Allen J. Bernstein, whose plan is to position Morton's as "the Tiffany and Four Seasons of steak restaurants," said the company planned to open nine more restaurants this year to generate revenues he projected would reach $65.7 million by year-end.
 
Steak Sales Hold Up
 While gross sales of traditional eating places, defined as all but fast-food outlets, have increased by no more than 1.5 percent in any of the last five years, according to Technomic Inc., a restaurant industry consulting firm, steak sales have remained healthy.
The trend seems especially true for steak restaurants with moderate-to-expensive prices, where steak meals can account for as much as 85 percent of all entrees, as they do at Ruth's Chris restaurants.
Ralph Giardina, president of Ruth's Chris, said that sales last year increased in all but 2 of its 34 units, with an overall growth of 8 percent in gross sales last year. In Beverly Hills, "the health capital of the world," as Mr. Giardina called it, Ruth's Chris increased gross sales by 15 percent in 1992 over 1990. A fire had closed the restaurant for three months in 1991.
In other signs of steak-restaurant strength, Amy Rubenstein, the treasurer of the venerable Peter Luger Steak House, a high-end restaurant in Brooklyn, said she had detected "no downturn" from the industry boom years of the 1980's. "We're almost at capacity all the time," she said.
Also, Outback Restaurants, a chain of moderately priced steak houses with a sort of Crocodile Dundee motif, opened its first restaurant five years ago in Tampa and now operates 86. "We anticipate opening our 100th restaurant this year," said Bob Basham, the company president.
 
Victims of Whims
 Dangers lurk, however. Growth and expansion can saturate any market, and restaurants are especially vulnerable to the whims of fashion and change. Ten years ago, low-end steak outlets like Bonanza and Ponderosa were immensely popular and so was steak on the menus of many family-style restaurants. More recently, seafood restaurants were in favor. Then tastes changed.
"To respond, family restaurants began revamping their menus to reemphasize meat as consumer eating habits shifted," said Ron Paul, an analyst with Technomic. "There was a time Red Lobster was going gangbusters. Now, seafood restaurants are not doing so well. There is a cycle, and consumers will always seek variety."
For now, a juicy steak is hot, and the rationale is hardly a surprise, said Dr. Lionel Tiger, a professor of anthropology at Rutgers University who specializes in the evolution of human behavior and fails to see why the pattern of growth should not continue.
Citing "the importance of meat in human dietary evolution," he said habits developed more than 10,000 years ago were genetic and sociological reasons that humans crave red meat. He sees little difference between a cave man sharing food with his tribe after a successful hunt and a modern wedding party, where steak tartare might be served.
"It provides us an opportunity for celebration," Dr. Tiger said of meat eating. "That's one of the things we really like as a species. In our culture, having meat is a sign we're doing well. Even though it's not supposed to be good for us, we seek more and more public certification for how good our lives are, and one way, is to go to a steak house."
 
Recalling Family Dinners
 Anthropological explanations aside, the success of pricier steak restaurants in the United States has also evolved amid what could easily be interpreted as hostile conditions for growth. They include not only concerns over heart disease and the pinched economy but also fewer 1950's-style families in which Mom stays home and cooks.
Typically, baby-boomers like Mr. Willey of Perdue, who is 42, and Mr. Bernstein of the Quantum Restaurant Group, who is 47, recall childhoods in which they ate meat for dinner most days of the week, as many as six in Mr. Bernstein's case.
As a result, steak dinners reminiscent of those days, served by restaurants with salad, baked potato and gooey dessert, have taken on psychological aspects that make them enticing for nostalgic reasons to some but mystical to others, including those with weight problems or dubious cardiovascular profiles.
In any event, a lavish steak dinner has become elevated far beyond the ordinariness of chicken, pasta or leftovers, to the point where a meal built around prime aged filet or sirloin, available only at better restaurants, now often celebrates a happy occasion or becomes the occasion itself.
That notion has become an intrinsic part of Morton's marketing strategy, the "wow effect," in Mr. Bernstein's words. Morton's is the jewel of Quantum's holdings, which also include 11 Mick's, moderately priced family-style restaurants in the Atlanta area, and 11 other higher-priced restaurants known by various names in Atlanta and Washington.
Besides the expensive cuts of beef and efforts to standardize price, serving style and ambiance at all locations, Morton's tries to create indelible memories by magnifying other aspects of the eating experience.
 
Cuts Are Displayed
 It begins with a "presentation" of the menu, during which the waiter wheels the offerings to the table on a cart and holds aloft each cut of beef, wrapped in cellophane. A live lobster (unwrapped) is also raised for consideration and is not always happy about it. A printed menu is also available but is not as much fun.
Each item is sold a la carte, and some seem expensive. But they appear at the table as much as items of curiosity as of cuisine. Steamed asparagus ($6.50) have stalks as wide as tennis racquet handles. Baked potatoes ($3.95) might fairly be billed as mutant ninja taters, and the menu says the dessert souffle ($9.25) feeds two. Six is more like it.
Morton's growth reflects an attitude that more is better, regardless of price, which Mr. Bernstein said had led to an average dinner check of $53 a person. Although higher than the average at Ruth's Chris (about $40) or The Palm ($45 to $50), which has a dozen restaurants, the formula is working, and the overwhelming attraction is the steak.
"We find that excitement works," Mr. Bernstein said, looking not very far for a reason Morton's is succeeding. He agreed totally with Dr. Tiger's view of things and even questioned the degree to which Americans heed their doctors' nutritional advice.
"The total consumption of certain items, like eggs, pancakes and desserts are down," he said. "The total number of times people eat out is down. But health-food restaurants are not always successful. So in reality, people are not following what they're being told. People still love steak; we're proof of that."

HEADLINE: Lately, More Antiquities Can Go Home Again

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
An ancient bronze-and-silver model of a leopard, which was a shadowy presence in the art market for years before it wound up in the hands of a leading New York City art collector, is going home, to England.
Last fall a group of 48 sacred, centuries-old textiles, which have adorned the walls of a California dealer and a New York collector for the last few years, were returned to the Coroma Indians who live high in the Andes of Bolivia. 
 Many art experts believe that these and similar repatriations -- in settlement of long-drawn-out lawsuits and negotiations -- are a clear indication that pressure is mounting on dealers, collectors and museums to diligently investigate the ownership of ancient treasures before attempting to buy them.
"It's definitely a trend," said Constance Lowenthal, the executive director of the International Foundation for Art Research, which monitors stolen art. "These settlements will encourage a greater level of care before purchasing art."
To be sure not every Greek bust or pre-Columbian stele is contraband. However, a great many such artworks are stolen property. The opposition to the illicit trade in such objects began to gather force in 1978 when the American Association of Museums adopted a code of ethics requiring that members "not support" the illicit trade in antiquities. Five years later ethical restrictions were given the force of law when the United States subscribed to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization treaty on cultural property. The treaty made it possible to ban the import of cultural patrimony that is jeopardized by the pillaging of archeological or ethnological sites.
 
An Influential Policy
 In 1989 the Smithsonian Institution voluntarily began to return human remains, sacred objects and other cultural property to American Indian and other ethnic groups when such property was requested, a policy that has influenced institutions throughout the world.
In the past collectors with an itch for antiquities could acquire them with impunity, whether directly or indirectly, from an international black market supplied by illegal excavators, tomb robbers, corrupt guards and unscrupulous dealers. The rightful owners of these objects -- usually the governments of third-world nations -- were frequently unable to recover them through lawsuits because of the expense and the difficulty of coming up with precise documentation.
In 1989 for example, a Federal court in California denied a suit by the Government of Peru seeking to recover 89 pre-Columbian artifacts seized by the United States Customs Service from an American collector, Benjamin Johnson. The judge, while expressing "considerable sympathy" for the Peruvian claim, explained his decision by citing the testimony of Dr. Francisco Iriarte, Peru's foremost authority on pre-Columbian archeology. Dr. Iriarte had identified the artifacts as being of ancient Peruvian "style and culture," yet he had to admit that they could have been excavated in Ecuador, Colombia, Mexico or even Polynesia.
The black market in antiquities is still active, but several relatively new factors are beginning to favor those from whom the objects were taken illegally.
First, with the price of antiquities soaring, lawyers do not hesitate to summon expert witnesses like Dr. Iriarte from around the world. As a result of such elaborate procedures, the cost of litigation is rising sharply. A legal bill of $250,000 in such cases is not unusual.
 
Pressure of Expenses
 Steven Berger, a major dealer in South American textiles, said in an interview that he had agreed to surrender a large number of Coroma Indian garments chiefly because his legal expenses were getting out of hand.
Bill Verick, an Oakland lawyer who worked for the Coromas, who regard their textiles as having religious significance, said: "If the case had gone to trial, it could have been devastatingly expensive for Mr. Berger, and he knew it. The Indians could have won damages not just for the textiles but for the loss of their god. A jury would be very sympathetic to such suffering, and there's no telling what the damages might have come to."
Furthermore, because lawsuits involving artworks tend to attract public attention, many law firms are willing to donate their services, or work for reduced fees, in representing the plaintiffs. Morrison & Foerster, one of San Francisco's largest law firms, represented the Coroma Indians on a pro bono basis.
Thomas R. Kline, a Washington lawyer who has specialized in art law cases, said that he represented on a contingency basis -- not his usual practice -- John and Rosemary Browning of Icklingham, England, who claim that the second-century bronze-and-silver leopard -- 1 of 16 so-called Icklingham bronzes -- had been surreptitiously removed from Roman ruins in their wheat field in the winter of 1981-1982.
The second factor favoring repatriation is that moral pressure or the threat of public embarrassment has helped persuade some dealers and collectors to relinquish contested cultural property.
Michael Ratner, a lawyer for the New York-based Center for Constitutional Rights, a nonprofit civil rights organization that also represented the Coroma Indians, said he had been involved in a case in which such pressure worked.
"Nobody today wants to be caught with somebody else's sacred objects," Mr. Ratner said.
Third, persistent efforts by plaintiffs have recently demonstrated the possibility of convincingly identifying previously undocumented antiquities.
In the case of the Icklingham bronzes, Leon Levy and his wife, Shelby White, the New York collectors, have bequeathed all 16 objects to the British Museum. Dr. Marion True, curator of antiquities of the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., has called the Icklingham leopard "one of the most important finds of the last 50 years." In addition Mr. Browning said they had been compensated for legal fees, although neither Mr. Levy nor the British Museum would confirm or deny the report.
Torkom Demirjian, the proprietor of Ariadne Galleries Inc., the New York dealer through whom the Levys purchased the artworks between 1988 and 1989, would say only that he had acquired the bronzes "with the utmost care."
 
British Police Investigation
 Mr. Kline impressed lawyers for the Levys and Ariadne Galleries by making use of an investigation by local British police that brought to light several individuals -- including a New Jersey coin dealer -- who testified that they had seen the bronzes and were told they had been dug up from the Brownings' wheat field. Some of this testimony might have been dismissed as hearsay, but some of it promised to hold up in an American court.
"If you're willing to spend the time to look hard enough," Mr. Kline said, "you can often find people who know where the objects came from."
Another out-of-court settlement brought to an end a long-drawn-out legal battle when Mr. Berger, the dealer, and the Rev. Ledlie Laughlin, formerly rector of the Church of St. Luke-in-the-Fields in lower Manhattan and now the rector of St. James Episcopal Church in Florence, surrendered to the United States Customs Service a total of 48 finely woven ceremonial garments resembling tunics, ponchos, capes and kerchiefs believed by the Caromas to have a profound religious and magical significance.
Mr. Berger and Mr. Laughlin insisted that they broke no law, but the Indians claimed that the textiles had been stolen from their village.
Lawyers for the Coroma Indians were able to identify the Indian textiles because they had been in continuous ceremonial use by the tribe for several centuries.
After the Customs Service seized a large quantity of the textiles from Mr. Berger, lawyers for the Indians had them photographed and sent blowups to Coroma, Bolivia, where members of the tribe made tentative identifications. Later, four Coroma Indians and a Bolivian scholar were flown to San Francisco to make more precise identifications of the actual garments, noting such details as repairs with which they were familiar.

HEADLINE: Don't Duck Welfare Reform

 BODY:
The Health and Human Services Department administers hundreds of programs ranging from early childhood education to public health. But nothing the department does will be more important this year than overseeing the nation's welfare and health care systems -- both of which need major overhaul. That is why Secretary Donna Shalala's testimony during Senate confirmation hearings was dismaying. She displayed knowledge of neither subject and, in the case of welfare reform, shocking indifference.
Mr. Clinton has turned health care reform over to a White House-run task force on which Ms. Shalala will play an important but supporting role. That is only proper. The new President has made health care reform a top priority, worthy of White House direction. 
 But welfare reform is fading. In the five-page statement of goals she gave the Senate, Ms. Shalala devoted a grand total of one limp sentence to the subject. The oversight invites suspicion that President Clinton intends to backtrack on his campaign pledge to "end welfare as we know it."
Candidate Clinton proposed giving the needy education, training, and child care for up to two years, then requiring "those who can work to go to work either in the private sector or in community service." The proposal embodied the notion that government has obligations to the needy, but the needy also have obligations to society. The theme figured prominently in Mr. Clinton's speech at the Democratic convention and his Inaugural Address.
Americans have a right to hold him to his lofty promises. The welfare system isn't working very well. Many poor have become long-term welfare recipients -- doing them and their children little good. States, forced by Washington to pick up much of the tab, have permitted the value of welfare payments to shrivel over the last 20 years. Even communities that want to offer generous help shrink from raising taxes, fearing they will drive away well-to-do families.
Under Presidents Reagan and Bush, aid to cities was cut an astonishing 60 percent after adjusting for inflation. New York City now spends a crippling 20 percent of its revenues on Medicaid, foster care and other programs for the poor.
Mr. Clinton could start quickly to reverse this sorry record. There is a fine welfare law -- the 1988 Family Support Act -- already in place. It calls for states to phase in programs that require welfare recipients to participate in education and training. Mr. Clinton was a leading proponent of the '88 law. A noteworthy opponent was the Children's Defense Fund, whose leaders included Donna Shalala.
In practice, the law has been weakly implemented. Congress provided only $1.5 billion a year, matched by state funds, which is about a fourth of what's needed. And states, during recession, have been slow to tap what Congress provided. The reluctance is maddening because where reforms have started, welfare rolls and outlays have fallen.
Ms. Shalala's first obligation is to push Congress to put more money behind the '88 law. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, an architect of the act, has proposed lowering the contribution states are required to make and raising the percentage of welfare recipients states must enroll in education and training.
Ms. Shalala's second obligation is to take an even bigger portion of the welfare burden off city and state governments. If Washington paid for the public-sector jobs Mr. Clinton's welfare reform plan would require, state and local governments would get the budget relief they desperately need. If his plan proves too costly or unworkable, then Ms. Shalala needs to propose a sounder one.
The poor and homeless who roam the streets of New York are not New York's poor. They are America's poor. Presidents Reagan and Bush ignored them for the last 12 years. Mr. Clinton promised to do better.

HEADLINE: Chelsea Clinton Can Transfer to Public Schools

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Choosing a School for Chelsea" (editorial, Jan. 7) is correct in saying that President and Mrs. Clinton have every right to send their daughter to the school they think is best for her, but that they should have given the public schools serious consideration before deciding. 
 The reputation of the Washington public schools as troubled is deserved, but there are exceptions, which were available to the Clintons. They could, for example, have chosen Alice Deal Junior High School and then Woodrow Wilson High School, which our children have attended.
One of the great strengths of these schools is that the student population includes many minority students from poor homes in neighborhoods ridden with violence and drugs, as well as significant numbers of students with well-educated, professional parents representing all races and ethnic backgrounds.
Our son's experience may indicate the challenging academic opportunities. He graduated from Wilson High School two years ago and was far from unusual in his class in qualifying for advance-placement college credit in six subjects. He and many of his classmates were accepted by colleges ranked among the most selective in the country. Clearly, at least some of our public schools are doing something right.
The Clintons said they chose the private Sidwell Friends School in part because of its requirement for public service. The opportunity for community service exists at all schools, whether or not it is required. Our daughter, now a senior at Wilson High School, spends time each week participating in and coordinating service activities at soup kitchens. This work is, we believe, far more meaningful for her and her classmates who join her precisely because it is not required. In any case, beginning with the class of 1995, Washington's public school students will be required to perform 100 hours of community service to graduate.
Each year students transfer from private schools into Deal Junior High School and Wilson High School because they prefer the racial, ethnic and economic diversity and the real life atmosphere they find there. If, after a semester or two, Chelsea Clinton and her parents find the expensive private-school experience limiting, they will be more than welcome in the public schools of Washington.
 
JOAN T. PRIVAL, MICHAEL J. PRIVAL
Washington, Jan. 8, 1993

HEADLINE: Chelsea Clinton Can Transfer to Public Schools;
A National Tragedy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The decision by President and Mrs. Clinton that no Washington public school is good enough for their daughter may mean that ultimately Chelsea loses. I will cite only two of many possible examples from my son's academic experience at Alice Deal Junior High, one of many public schools the Clintons did not bother to visit. 
 My son studies and respects Chinese language and culture through a program unmatched in Washington, and one-third of his seventh-grade class will take the Scholastic Aptitude Test in two weeks because they scored above the 97th percentile on national standardized tests.
Just as important, I believe that my son will not fall prey to mindless stereotypes about people of other ethnic groups, and I do not expect to hear him mouth platitudes about the poor. Deal, like other public schools in the District, treats many kinds of students with respect. The public schools offer a shrinking oasis, where people representing true economic and racial diversity come together in search of a civic good. The resource-starved District schools offer hope that integration can work and that under extreme deprivation people will take responsibility for public education.
The Clintons are just one of many affluent families to abandon the public schools, and many say the same thing: they will not sacrifice their children's education to make a political statement, and this is a private, not a public act. But choosing a private school is an intensely political act with grave consequences. To me it represents the pursuit of class advantage and the desire to avoid those who are different.
The danger is that these students will emerge sheltered, prejudiced, inept at understanding or coping with a complicated world, convinced that they won a fair race. This is a national tragedy.
 
BRETT WILLIAMS
Washington, Jan. 8, 1993
 
The writer is a professor of anthropology at American University.

HEADLINE: Explaining the Check in 'TransitChek'

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON

 BODY:
To New York City subway riders puzzled by those advertisements trumpeting "the Biggest TransitChek in History" and showing a man with an inexplicably oversized cardboard check under his arm: don't worry. Nobody else gets it either.
"Transit Chex? It sounds kind of like a breakfast cereal," said Jeffrey Gartner, a graphic artist who was confused by the poster even after re-reading it a few times on the No. 3 train one recent morning. "Is there some hidden prize? Where can I get one?" 
 If the advertisements are puzzling, the idea behind TransitChek is actually quite simple: to promote the use of mass transportation by workers through tax breaks for their employers. And for subway, bus and train riders, it could add up to $60 in savings on commuting costs each month.
The program itself, slightly less simple, works like this: If a company is willing to give its employees a monthly benefit to cover commuting costs, it can write off 40 percent of the total expense as a standard business deduction. For the employee, it amounts to tax-free carfare.
 
'A Month's Free Ride'
 Begun in 1987, TransitChek is named for the vouchers, or checks, that the companies can buy and that their employees can then exchange for bus or subway tokens or for rail tickets, like those of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, the Long Island Rail Road and the New Jersey Transit. As of Jan. 1, under a law passed by Congress last October, the tax-deductible amount a company can grant each employee almost tripled, to $60 a month from $21.
Advocates of the program point out that the maximum amount is now large enough to pay for a month's worth of subway tokens, or about half the commutation ticket of a typical Metro-North commuter.
"At $60, you're talking about real money," said Larry Filler, executive director of Transit Center, the agency created in 1987 to run TransitChek. "That's a month's free ride on the subway, or the bus, or the PATH train."
He is unsure how many companies, particularly large ones, will sign up for TransitChek. About 2,000 companies were buying vouchers regularly when the tax-deductable benefit was raised to $60, including a few large ones, like Price Waterhouse, Swissbank and Colgate-Palmolive.
But most participants are smaller companies for whom the initial outlay for the voucher is less than for companies that have more employees. Even with the 40 percent tax deduction, buying $60 vouchers for 100 employees, for example, would cost a company about $46,000 each year, or $460 an employee, including a 10 percent processing fee regardless of the number of employees.
Mr. Filler said that a few dozen new companies have joined TransitChek since Jan. 1, and that he expects the number to rise gradually.
 
Lobbying May Come Later
 Executives at some large corporations that are considering the program, including American Express and Chemical Bank, declined to discuss the criteria they are using to weigh the program, apparently concerned about raising expectations among their employees before they decide whether to offer the benefit.
Senior executives at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey describe themselves as major boosters of the program. They have no definite plans for organized lobbying for the kind of large companies that are the hardest to convince of the program's benefits. They say they may do such lobbying eventually.
The executive director of the Port Authority, Stanley Brezenoff, said a major selling point for TransitChek is that during difficult economic times, money for commuting costs is an affordable alternative to a salary increase. Mr. Brezenoff also noted that under the Federal Clean Air Act of 1990, companies with 100 or more employees will be required in the coming years to reduce the number of employees who drive to work.
"A lot of these companies have a stake in reaching clean-air requirements, and this could be a big step in that direction," he said, adding that the Port Authority introduced the program for its nonunion staff this month, partly for that reason.
Promoting mass transportation as an alternative to driving was the rationale behind the Federal law that created the tax-deductible benefit, and that increased it to $60. The amount was $15 when the program started in 1987, and rose to $21 last year.
For years, companies have been able to write off parking expenses for their employees, calling them a legitimate business expense. Congress was persuaded that it would make sense to allow similar tax advantages for commuters using mass transportation, and to limit the amount a company could write off for an employee's monthly parking expenses to $155.
The law, which took effect on Jan. 1, was signed last October. There are similar programs in Boston, San Francisco Los Angeles, Philadelphia and Chicago, and their success varies with the city.
In New York's program, employees exchange vouchers for individual tokens or tickets.
"It would be much easier to take advantage of TransitChek if we had a monthly pass," as in some of the cities that have similar programs, said Gene Russianoff, Senior Attorney for the Straphangers Campaign, a commuter-advocacy group. The Transit Authority has promised to introduce some kind of monthly pass when automated fare cards are introduced in December.
How many new riders the program will attract is also an open question.
At a half-dozen companies already using TransitChek, executives said their employees were overwhelmingly positive about the program, but added that it seemed to be used only by those who already ride mass transportation, rather than by drivers who have been persuaded to switch to a train or a bus.
 
Tax-Free Vouchers
 At Alitalia's New York office, an employee can choose between cash or TransitChek vouchers for an annual or semiannual bonus, and last year only 4 percent chose the vouchers, which are tax-free.
Mr. Russianoff said that the reduction in tax revenue from companies taking the TransitChek deductions was expected to be offset by the increased tax revenue from the limit on parking expense deductions. He said he was interested to see, in the next year, whether companies comply with the new parking-expense limits and how strictly the Internal Revenue Service enforced them.
Mr. Filler said he thought that interest in the program among employees would eventually be followed by participation among companies. He said he was pleased with the response to the 800 number listed on subway advertisements for the program, which now receives 300 to 400 calls a day, several times what it received two months ago. He expects $9 million worth of transit vouchers to be sold this year, up from last year's $5 million worth.
As for the subway advertisements, Mr. Filler conceded that it might take time for the message to sink in, but said he was pleased with the way they looked. So were some riders.
"I like it visually," said Trudy Cheney the other morning on the No. 1 train. "The mix of black and white with subtle coloring is nice, and the big check that guy is carrying looks interesting. But what does it mean?"

HEADLINE: Saudis Call For Cuts By OPEC

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Jan. 24

 BODY:
In a move that could substantially lift sagging oil prices, Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil producer and exporter, has called on the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to reduce its overall output of oil production by more than a million barrels a day.
The move signals at least a temporary end to Saudi Arabia's policy of maximizing production, which has increased its output to more than 8 million barrels a day, from 5.5 million barrels a day in 1990. That is more than a third of OPEC's production, and gives the Saudis enormous clout. 
 But OPEC has had singularly little success at persuading all its members to adhere to their production quotas, and it is far from clear that the other 11 nations will go along with Saudi Arabia. Nigeria and Kuwait in particular are regarded as most determined to produce as much oil as they can.
 
 
Falling Prices
 The Saudi decision is a sign that it and Iran, OPEC's second-largest producer, have decided that OPEC's production has gotten out of hand. An oversupply of oil and weak demand has knocked roughly 20 percent off oil prices since October, sharply reducing revenue for all OPEC nations. On Friday, the price of Arab light crude oil was $14.95 on the spot market, down from nearly $19 in October.
"This is a very significant change in the direction of things -- particularly as it comes from the largest producer of OPEC, Saudi Arabia," Walid Khadouri, executive editor of the Middle East Economic Survey, a weekly oil industry newsletter based in Cyprus, said in a telephone interview. "If it turns into a credible and lasting agreement it is bound to boost oil prices."
Some oil analysts said the move could raise prices by as much as $4 a barrel over the next few months, which would lift prices at the pump for many consumers in industrialized countries.
Gasoline prices have been stable in the United States in recent months and have been determined more by Federal mandates to reduce air pollution than by the supply of crude oil.
 
 
Paris Meeting
 It seems likely that at least 10 members of OPEC will go along with the agreement.
The Saudis' decision was communicated by their oil minister, Hisham M. Nazer, to Allirio Parra, the current president of OPEC and Venezuela's oil minister, at a meeting in Paris on Saturday.
OPEC is currently producing close to 25.4 million barrels a day, well above its official ceiling of 24.9 million barrels.
The Saudi offer to cut from the official ceiling of OPEC rather than actual production, if accepted by other members of OPEC, would in effect reduce the oil cartel's total output by as much as 1.5 million barrels a day.
The policy would reduce Saudi Arabia's own production to about 8 million barrels a day, a drop of 400,000 barrels a day from its current level.
Mr. Parra has begun a tour of OPEC's 12 members, trying to find a way to stabilize oil prices. In a telephone interview from Paris, he said: "We are calling upon OPEC to reduce production from the official ceiling of the organization by one million barrels a day. If it is adhered to in a proportionate way by all members of OPEC, it should have a considerable impact on oil prices -- in my opinion -- in the second quarter."
The Saudis and the Iranians, who have been locked in a production race, appear to have concluded that it is time to coordinate policy and force other members of OPEC, particularly Kuwait and Nigeria, to moderate their runaway output of oil. OPEC is scheduled to meet in Vienna on Feb. 13 to fashion its production and pricing policy for 1993.
 
 
Nigeria and Kuwait
 OPEC's biggest problems will be Nigeria and Kuwait, and it is far from clear that either will adhere to any agreement to reduce production.
Nigeria has repeatedly promised to trim production but has kept it at nearly 2 million barrels a day, 200,000 barrels over its official quota. Kuwait, which has made huge strides in rebuilding oil production -- halted after the Iraqi invasion and damages to its oilfields -- has pushed its oil output to 1.6 million barrels a day this month and says it is heading for 2 million barrels a day by the end of the year.
The Kuwaitis argue they are entitled to pump oil without limits to make up for their huge losses of revenues and the damage caused to their oilfields, set on fire by Iraqis as they withdrew from Kuwait in 1991. Persuading Kuwait to rein in its output at present levels for the rest of the year may prove very difficult -- even for Saudi Arabia.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Re-examining the Fine Print On Clinton's Tax Promises

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
At a time when the public has repeatedly shown its distaste for the maneuvers and machinations of politics, President Clinton's White House is banking on a five-word loophole to save it from voter outrage should Mr. Clinton propose a broad-based energy tax.
During the campaign, Mr. Clinton promised tax cuts for the middle class. Now Mr. Clinton and his chief economic advisers are backing away from the tax cut and strongly hinting that an energy tax will hit the middle class the hardest. 
 "They campaigned on a middle-class tax cut and then four days into a new Administration the chief economic spokesman is talking about a middle-class tax increase," said Robert S. McIntyre, director of Citizens for Tax Justice, a liberal research group. "That's a flip-flop."
Although Vice President Al Gore and Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen have mentioned the possibility of an energy tax in recent interviews, the President and his advisers insisted today that their economic plan was still under discussion and that no decision had been made.
Still some Clinton advisers say they are not worried about public outrage. They say the President built himself an escape hatch a little less than a month before Election Day.
"Every time Clinton said 'I'm not going to raise taxes on the middle class,' he always added the phrase "to pay for my programs," said a chief political adviser to the President, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "He never, never, said just, 'I will not raise taxes on the middle class.' He always said 'I will not raise middle-class taxes to pay for my programs.' "
By this logic, the adviser said, Mr. Clinton's legalistic construct was a "distinction with a difference" that allows him "the opportunity he now has" to raise taxes without incurring voter wrath.
But of late that sort of politics-by-loophole has not been playing well.
In 1990, President George Bush signed an agreement with Congress that obliged him to break his "read my lips" campaign promise of 1988 not to raise taxes. Mr. Bush and his advisers reasoned that voters had never taken his promise seriously in the first place and would forgive its being breached. The voters reacted with far more anger than understanding, and Mr. Bush never regained their trust when the economy turned sour.
In recent weeks, the gulf between Washington's view of what constituted acceptable behavior and that of many voters was again demonstrated in the matter of Zoe Baird. Mr. Clinton pressed forward with his choice of Ms. Baird as Attorney General despite the disclosure that she had once hired illegal aliens. Mr. Clinton and his advisers figured voters would forgive Ms. Baird what they considered a small transgression in an otherwise impressive career.
The voters, recalling Mr. Clinton's emotional promises to run a Government for the "people who pay their taxes and play by the rules," saw him as trying to give a break to a rich woman who had done neither and forced Ms. Baird's withdrawal.
 
Some See a Liability
 Mr. Clinton's aides know full well that Mr. Bush's mistake helped cost him his job. But they still contend that Mr. Clinton is protected by his escape clause. "People won't get away with saying Clinton promised that he was not going to raise taxes and then did," the adviser said. "He had many opportunities to make a 'read my lips' statement, and he did not."
Some outside the Clinton camp disagree strongly with that logic, however.
Kevin Phillips, a Republican political analyst who charted the rise of middle-class anger in the late 1980's and spared no criticism of Mr. Bush's broken promises, said: "At the most recent count, only 800,000 Americans were lawyers, and I don't think the 248 million or so who are not lawyers are going to buy a caveat stuck on in the middle of a passionate plea to the middle-class voters that they should vote for him because he was going to save them. Talk about reading his lips."
Mr. Clinton introduced the escape clause on taxes for the middle class before a national audience in an Oct. 19 Presidential debate in Richmond. "I will not raise taxes on the middle class to pay for these programs," he said.
 
'Very Conscious Decision'
 Listeners without the benefit of law-school training might have taken that as a pledge to not raise taxes on the middle class. But the President's adviser said Mr. Clinton had purposefully used, and reiterated, the phrase "for these programs" to allow himself a way out of what careless voters might have thought they had been promised.
"It was a very conscious decision on his part," the adviser said. "I can tell you this from strategy sessions and debate prep sessions. The idea of a flat-out promise of 'I will not raise taxes on the middle class, period,' was rejected by the President. He refused to allow himself to be boxed in that way."
The matter of the escape clause illustrates a larger point about Mr. Clinton that has become increasingly obvious: It is always wise to read the fine print. The fine print of Mr. Clinton's promise on the tax cut for the middle class was quite different from the broad thrust of his oratory on the subject.
For a year, the Democrat campaigned on a platform of economic renewal in which the Federal deficit could be halved in four years rather painlessly by raising taxes on rich people and foreign corporations and by improving the way Government programs are managed.
In "Putting People First," Mr. Clinton's often-touted plan for American renewal, the candidate promised: "We will lower the tax burden on middle-class Americans by asking the very wealthy to pay their fair share. Middle-class taxpayers will have a choice between a children's tax credit or a significant reduction in their income-tax rate."
On July 13, speaking to reporters in New York, Mr. Clinton said flatly, "I'm not going to raise taxes on the middle class," according to reports by The Chicago Tribune and the Reuters news service. On the same day, in an interview shown by Cable News Network, he said, "I don't think we should raise middle-class individuals' taxes, because their income went down and their tax rates were raised" in the 1980's.
But in the fall campaign, when his words were scrupulously followed by a larger audience, Mr. Clinton took more care. After the Richmond debate, he regularly re-stated the position that his promise to the middle class was only that he would not raise their taxes "to pay for these programs."

HEADLINE: Navy Seeks Data on Lung Disorders

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Fearing that unsafe work conditions might have exposed thousands of deckhands to lethal dust clouds in the 1970's, the Navy has asked a Federal health agency to conduct a major review of naval personnel records.
At issue is whether hundreds of sailors who have a lung disorder for which Navy doctors could find no cause may instead have a job-related illness. Such a determination could cost the Navy millions of dollars in damages. 
 The job in question involved grinding nonskid adhesive off the decks of aircraft carriers in preparation for resurfacing, sending clouds of tiny silica shards into the air. Although regulations in the 1970's required deckhands to wear masks, Navy officials acknowledge that most supervisers did not enforce the rule.
Navy work rules have now been tightened and a new, less hazardous nonskid adhesive is being used. But as a growing number of Navy veterans around the country compare notes on their lung problems, service officials have agreed to investigate their claims. They say that what Navy doctors diagnosed as sarcoidosis, a rare lung disease with no known cause, may in fact be silicosis, a fatal lung disease caused by airborne silica.
 
Navy Asks for Help
 In a letter last month Vice Adm. Donald F. Hagen, the Navy Surgeon General, asked the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, a branch of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, "to determine the relationship, if any, between the risk of silicosis and sarcoidosis, our active-duty members, and the Navy work environment in the early 1970's."
If the Federal health agency finds that the Navy misdiagnosed the documented sarcoidosis cases, legal experts say, the Navy may have to pay millions of dollars in damages to the stricken sailors. Moreover, since the silicosis symptoms can take more than 20 years to develop, health officials say thousands of other Navy veterans may soon be seeking relief.
Dr. Gregory R. Wagner, director of the health agency's Respiratory Disease Studies division, said his technical experts and Navy officials would soon meet to determine what naval personnel records were available. The review will probably take at least three months, a Navy official said.
The Navy's unusual request for help from Federal health experts stems from the efforts of a 39-year-old sailor, Jerry Cochran, who was medically discharged in 1975. Since then, he has been fighting to overcome a Navy bureaucracy that first accused him of malingering and then diagnosed his condition as sarcoidosis. The Veterans Affairs Department recognized Mr. Cochran's illness as silicosis in March 1991, but so far the Navy has stuck to its original diagnosis.
 
Hot and Dirty Work
 Mr. Cochran also urged the Navy to check if any of his former shipmates on the aircraft carrier Independence were suffering from lung disorders. In the ship's hot, poorly ventilated hangar deck, the cavernous storage area for planes, sailors wearing no masks pushed pneumatic-powered machines that cracked worn nonskid adhesive into pieces, kicking up clouds of dust. The work sometimes lasted nine hours a day, three or four days a week.
The Navy refused to investigate Mr. Cochran's concerns until Acting Navy Secretary Sean O'Keefe read an article in The New York Times last September about Mr. Cochran's troubles and ordered Navy medical officials to review the matter.
Sharon Trussell, 35, a legal assistant at a Houston law firm specializing in asbestosis and silicosis cases, also read about Mr. Cochran's plight, and shuddered. Her husband, Dean, 27, did deck-grinding work during his three years on the amphibious assault ship Nassau, and now coughs up black phlegm.
Mrs. Trussell contacted Mr. Cochran, and within several weeks established the Jerry Cochran Veterans Outreach Foundation, a not-for-profit organization to help veterans suffering from silicosis or other related lung problems find proper medical attention, obtain their Navy records and process claims.
 
Medical Records Sought
 The foundation has a toll-free number, (800) 876-3901, and has persuaded two respiratory specialists -- one in Atlanta and one in Houston -- to donate their time to examine Navy veterans who fear they may have the symptoms.
The foundation is now helping about 25 Navy veterans nationwide to obtain their medical records to determine if their conditions were misdiagnosed or not diagnosed at all, Mrs. Trussell said.
According to Navy medical records, there were 947 cases of sarcoidosis diagnosed from 1965 to 1988, the last year for which records are available. The figures are within the national rate of incidence. There also were 88 cases of silicosis in that period, but silica exposure levels aboard ships were not accurately measured until the mid-1980's.
The foundation is also filing Federal tort claims on behalf of the sailors, and is threatening a class-action lawsuit if the Government does not establish a compensation fund to supplement the sailors' veterans benefits.
For many of Mr. Cochran's former shipmates, the pending health inquiry has suggested answers to nagging questions about chronic lung problems.
 
Jogger With Health Problem
 Lucious Felton, 38, a former marine, used to jog through the hangar deck when Mr. Cochran and the grinding crews were working. Mr. Felton was given an honorable discharge in 1975 after a health problem he had was diagnosed as sarcoidosis. Since then he has worked as a janitor, a carpenter and a mail carrier but cannot hold a steady job because of his failing health. He said he had asked for his naval medical records to check his diagnosis.
"I can't imagine the number of people who might have this," said Mr. Felton, now an unemployed artist in Orlando, Fla. "I'm just glad this is all coming out."
Harold Timmons, a 43-year-old cattle farmer from Scotia, Neb., who served on a carrier, said his doctor told him 10 years ago that he had "brown lung" and blamed his livelihood for it. Now Mr. Timmons says he not so sure. "I'm short of breath, but you learn to live with it," he said.
Some of the former grinding crewmates whom Mr. Cochran has tracked down say they are fine and shrug off any worries. Keith Nelson, 40, a packaging inspector in York, Pa., says he jogs seven miles a day.
But for others, the Federal inquiry has raised new fears. Walter Myers, 39, a press operator in Columbus, Ga., has wondered for years why he gets winded so easily. "I'm getting checked out now," he said.

HEADLINE: Christopher Vowing Change In Selection of Ambassadors

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher made his debut before State Department employees today, pledging that the Clinton Administration would not appoint ambassadors solely because of their political connections and assuring them that he would bring career Foreign Service officers back into the State Department's decision-making.
"Recommendations for ambassadorships will be based upon qualifications that extend beyond campaign participation and will require some real expertise with respect to the appointment," he said, to the applause of a standing-room-only audience. 
 The Bush Administration was criticized on Capitol Hill for handing out ambassadorships to close friends and wealthy Republicans who had contributed $100,000 to the Bush campaign. A number of senators, particularly Paul Sarbanes, the Maryland Democrat, have said they intend to hold the new Administration to a higher standard.
During his Senate confirmations hearings two weeks ago, Mr. Christopher said ambassadors from outside the career Foreign Service "have to bring something to the post: some piece of background, some language skill," or "something else that gives assurance that they will make a real contribution as well as having the right temperament and the right attitude."
 
Relationship of 'Trust'
 Mr. Christopher's getting-to-know-you session today, which included questions and answers, was an indirect way of signaling that his tenure will be very different from that of James A. Baker 3d, President Bush's Secretary of State. While Mr. Baker relied on a handful of hand-picked advisers in making policy decisions, Mr. Christopher, who served as Deputy Secretary of State in the Carter Administration, promised that he would establish a relationship of "trust" with the hundreds of officers who will work for him.
He also said he would name both political appointees and career Foreign Service officers to key positions in the State Department, telling the employees they will be "more reassured" when the next round of secondary appointments is named.
Of the 14 appointments announced so far, only two -- Edward P. Djerejian, who will continue as Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, and George E. Moose, the nominee for Assistant Secretary of African Affairs -- are career Foreign Service officers. Peter Tarnoff, named as Under Secretary for Political Affairs, left the Foreign Service more than a decade ago.
Mr. Christopher still has not filled a number of other senior posts, including the director of the Agency for International Development, and the assistant secretaries responsible for Latin America, human rights and United Nations affairs.
 
Doubt on Latin Affairs Post
 Particularly painful is the Inter-American Affairs post. As of last week, Mario Baeza, a Cuban-American lawyer from New York, was the leading contender, but he was roundly criticized by conservative Cuban-Americans in Miami for what they perceived as his insufficient opposition to Fidel Castro.
Today's encounter also revealed much about Mr. Christopher's style, a mix of down-to-earth charm with extreme reserve. He seasoned his remarks with both humor and lavish praise, and called for a new era of "openness" inside the building and in the State Department's relationship with Congress.
The White House has also moved forward to fill a number of the top national security jobs.
Jennone Walker, who served in the Carter and Reagan Administrations, will oversee European affairs; Tobi Gati, vice president of the United Nations Association, will handle the former Soviet Union; Rose Gottemoeller, a strategic analyst at the Rand Corporation, will handle the dismantling of nuclear weapons in the former Soviet Union and related issues; Richard E. Feinberg, president of the Inter-American Dialogue, will deal with Latin American issues; Robert G. Bell, a senior staff member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, will oversee defense and arms control issues, and George Tenet, the former staff director for the Senate Intelligence Committee, will be responsible for intelligence issues.

HEADLINE: SHIFT OF SPENDING SEEN AS A BENEFIT

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
The Federal Government could generate more than 12,000 jobs by shifting $3 billion from military industries to state and local jurisdictions, according to a Government study released today.
Such a move, while eliminating 11,500 jobs in military industries, would create 23,600 new jobs, the study by the Congressional Research Service of the Library of Congress found. 
 The study provides ammunition for many analysts who urge converting military spending into increased spending on domestic programs, rather than using it to help reduce the Federal budget deficit.
"Think of all the positive things we could accomplish by peacetime uses of this funding, and we wouldn't increase the deficit a dime," said Representative John Conyers Jr., the Michigan Democrat who heads the Government Operations Committee and requested the study.
Mr. Conyers today reintroduced a bill to authorize such a $3 billion shift in spending. The committee approved the legislation in the waning days of the last Congress, but the bill was strongly opposed by President George Bush and never reached the House floor.
 
Change in Emphasis
 In his Presidential campaign, Bill Clinton pledged a shift in Federal resources to domestic uses from military ones. "The end of the cold war permits us to reduce defense spending while still maintaining the strongest defense in the world," he said at the Democratic National Convention, "but we must plow back every dollar of defense cuts into building American jobs right here at home."
In spite of those sentiments, the new President's top budget officials have placed deficit reduction at the top of the new Administration's economic agenda, so the extent to which military cuts will be shifted to domestic programs is uncertain.
The study issued today estimated a net increase of 4,054 jobs for each $1 billion shifted. "If the magnitude of the reallocation were increased by tenfold, then the job creation estimate would increase by tenfold," the study said.
If the spending was shifted, guided-missile producers would lose 1,280 jobs, radio and television communication equipment manufacturers would lose 1,819 jobs and 2,264 jobs would be cut in business services.
Industries that would gain more than 1,000 jobs involve construction or repair of highways and streets (4,174 jobs); new sewers (2,761 jobs); engineering, architectural and surveying services (2,334 jobs); maintenance and repair (1,270); and nursing and personal care services (1,140 jobs).

HEADLINE: SERBIA IS DENYING IT HOLDS BOSNIANS

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 25

 BODY:
The Serbian and Yugoslav Governments denied today that prisoners of war from Bosnia and Herzegovina were being held in detention camps on Yugoslav territory.
The assertion that Bosnian prisoners may be detained in Serbia came in a document prepared by United States Government intelligence agencies. The document said that as many as 135 prison camps were being operated by Serbs in Bosnia and Herzegovina and in Serbia itself, and that these camps held the vast majority of the total number of prisoners held by the Serbian, Muslim and Croatian factions in the Bosnian war. 
 The report's estimated total for all sides' prisoners, ranging up to 70,000, is many times higher than the 2,750 prisoners registered and visited by representatives of the International Committee of the Red Cross.
Officials of international relief agencies said they had no knowledge of prisoners from Bosnia being held in Serbia, but they repeated an appeal to all sides in the conflict to open their detention camps to Red Cross representatives. The United States Government report said the Bosnian Muslims and Bosnian Croats might be operating as many as 33 camps.
 
Red Cross Seeks Visits
 "We do not pretend that all sides in the Bosnian conflict are giving us the opportunity to visit all the prisoners they are holding," said a Red Cross official who insisted on remaining anonymous. "We want them to give us the facilities to carry out such visits."
United States officials said they had recently given the report to the United Nations special representative for the Balkans, Cyrus R. Vance, to officials of the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and to the International Committee of the Red Cross. Officials of the Red Cross confirmed today that they had received it.
Yugoslavia has been under stiff international pressure, including United Nations economic sanctions and threats of armed intervention, for supporting the Serbian rebels who have carved away about two-thirds of Bosnia and Herzegovina's territory in the nine-month-old war there.
The Yugoslav Government criticized an article about the intelligence report that appeared in The New York Times on Sunday, describing the article as an erroneous and "racist" attack on Serbia and the Serbian people.
"The State Department notified Yugoslav diplomats on Jan. 16," it said, that in early January the State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, "cited a completely erroneous estimate of 70,000 prisoners on Yugoslavia's territory."
[The State Department said that if Red Cross officials found "the maximum number of possible prisoners in each and every possible site, the number could be as high as 70,000." Administration officials had said earlier that the estimate of 70,000 prisoners was based on an assumption that 45 of the camps might be occupied at one time.]
 
'Never Been Proved'
 The Serbian Government said in its statement that "the American daily The New York Times, relying on unidentified sources in the United States, has repeated earlier assertions on the alleged existence of prison camps on Serbia's territory which have never been proved."
The Serbian Government called the Times article a "contribution to a dishonorable campaign led by some American news organizations in recent days to apply media pressure on the new United States Administration and United Nations to decide to intervene militarily in the territory of the former Yugoslavia."
"Not one of the many international missions to visit Serbia recently confirmed the existence of such camps."
United States diplomats in Belgrade declined to comment on the report or the article in The Times.
In its list of "probable" camps in Serbia, the American report included a Yugoslav Army air base and a police station in the village of Batajnica, a federal prison in the town of Sremska Mitrovica, a military prison in the Belgrade suburb of Zemun and an undescribed site in the central Serbian town of Rudnik.
Accounts that thousands of Muslims from Bosnia and Herzegovina are being held at the Batajnica airfield have been circulating for at least seven months, but no proof of their existence has ever been turned up by international relief agencies or Western journalists in their visits to the base.
Officials of army and federal Government of Yugoslavia -- which now comprises the republics of Serbia and Montenegro -- did not respond to a request to visit the installations today.

HEADLINE: Mexico Fights to Stop U.S. Execution

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 25

 BODY:
In the decade since Ramon Montoya was convicted of murdering a Dallas policeman, most of his relatives have stopped visiting, his name has faded from the newspapers, and opponents of capital punishment have moved on to other cases.
But if the 39-year-old illegal immigrant is executed as scheduled early Wednesday morning in a Huntsville, Tex., prison, it will be in spite of legal aid that the Mexican Government has helped pay for, pleas for clemency that it has made to Texas officials and a modicum of public support that it has helped generate both in Mexico and the United States. 
 Challenging American criminal justice on human rights grounds, the administration of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has engaged the United States in an increasingly public fight for the lives of 18 Mexican citizens now on death row in five states.
In only one of the cases have Mexican officials strongly challenged a convict's guilt. For the most part, they have asserted no circumstances more extenuating than the criminals' poverty at the time of the crimes or their disorientation in a foreign land. Their appeals have centered instead on the argument that capital punishment -- which was eliminated from the Mexican federal penal code in 1929 -- is simply inhumane.
 
Big Impact Predicted
 While the efforts have all been directed at state governments, Mexican officials also offer a broader political consideration: they say Mexicans would be outraged to see one of their countrymen put to death in the United States just as the two countries are moving to link their economic destinies in the North American Free Trade Agreement.
"The day a Mexican is executed, it will impact enormously," the senior Under Secretary of Foreign Affairs, Andres Rozental, said in an interview last year. "Given Nafta, given the closeness of the relationship at this point, it would be very difficult to convince Mexicans why this would be done."
The head of the Foreign Ministry's consular affairs section, Eduardo Ibarrola, described the attempts to block the executions as part of a broader Government effort under Mr. Salinas to defend the rights of Mexicans who live and work in the United States.
That campaign has sought to reassure Mexicans that as they draw closer to a neighbor they have long been taught to mistrust, their Government will stand up for their fair treatment. It has also been intended to overcome the antagonism that many Mexicans in the United States have traditionally felt toward the Government they left behind.
But the death penalty issue is perhaps especially useful to Mexico as it prepares for the American Congressional debate over the trade agreement this year.
 
Abuses in the U.S. Noted
 Some opponents of the accord have asserted that the prevalence of torture and other human rights problems in Mexico are reason enough for American legislators to reject greater economic integration. Mexican officials have responded in part by drawing attention to abuses against Mexican immigrants by agents of the United States Border Patrol and other American officials.
Although nearly all of the consular involvement with Mexicans on death row in the United States dates from Mr. Salinas's administration, some Mexican officials say their efforts have been quickened not so much by a policy change as by the urgency of the cases themselves.
If Mr. Montoya is not spared at the last minute, they said, he will become the first Mexican to be put to death in an American prison in 51 years. The executions of three other Mexican citizens have already been postponed by appeals, and the scheduled death of at least one other is drawing near.
(Ruling on the appeal of a Mexican-American man also convicted of killing a policeman in Texas, Leonel Herrera, the Supreme Court held today that Federal judges may not stop the executions of convicts who bring forward new claims of innocence after exausting their appeals.)
The Mexican efforts have included everything from benefit soccer games to raise legal funds to a personal appeal for one convict's life by President Salinas.
Mexican officials have given money to help support the families of some convicts, and cooperated with the lawyers of others who have wanted to investigate the background of their clients in Mexico. And in at least several instances, the governments of the Mexican states where the convicts were born have also worked on their behalf.
 
Scant Influence in Texas
 But Mexican officials cannot do much more than ask that the death sentences be commuted. Mr. Rozental, the Under Secretary of Foreign Affairs, said the 1977 agreement under which the United States and Mexico exchanged more than 50 sets of prisoners apparently did not apply to those facing capital punishment.
Even in Texas, where Salinas administration officials have enjoyed a warm relationship with Gov. Ann Richards, their influence in such cases is scant. David A. Talbot, the Governor's general counsel, said she could only act on the recommendations of the state's 18-member Board of Pardons and Paroles. On that basis, only a handful of death sentences have been commuted since capital punishment was reinstated in 1982.
In the most prominent case, the Government has repeatedly endorsed the claims of innocence of Ricardo Aldape Guerra, a 30-year-old former factory worker who was convicted of shooting a Houston police officer. Moves on Mr. Aldape's behalf by officials ranging from Mr. Salinas to the former head of the National Human Rights Commission brought an indefinite suspension of his execution last year.
But for Mr. Montoya, who was an unemployed laborer with prior convictions for weapons-possession and burglary when he shot a police officer during an arrest, the Mexican efforts have had no such effect.
"They have done everything you could ask a Government to do," Mr. Montoya's lawyer, K. Duff Lewis, said in a telephone interview today. "Unfortunately, to use the vernacular of Texas, Mr. Montoya is a wetback who killed a white cop."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ramon Montoya, a 39-year-old illegal immigrant, is scheduled to be executed early tomorrow morning in Huntsville, Tex., for the murder of a Dallas policeman. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Olympia & York Liquidation Plan Advances

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Jan. 25

 BODY:
The unsecured creditors of bankrupt Olympia & York Developments Ltd. today overwhelmingly approved an orderly liquidation of the Canadian operations of what was once the world's biggest property development company.
Out of the disintegrating empire will emerge a new property-management concern worth a tiny fraction of the $20 billion that the Reichmann family of Toronto had built over three decades in commercial real estate in Canada, the United States and Britain. 
 Debt-burdened assets in the United States remain intact. Assets in Britain have been placed under British bankruptcy procedures known as court administration.
 
Deep in Debt
 The privately held and secretly-run enterprise, which grew out of a Toronto tile company in the late 1950's, owes $6.7 billion on its Canadian office towers. Last May, an Ontario court granted the company protection from its creditors.
Olympia & York's troubles stemmed from a severe recession in commercial real estate and a heavy drain on resources from an ambitious office development in London's East End known as Canary Wharf, which siphoned off $6 billion.
After creditors in Canada rejected two restructuring plans, the company made an offer that essentially gives creditors the option of taking over the assets that secure their loans.
One of these institutions, the Prudential Insurance Company of America, has already seized its collateral, the 28-story Aetna Canada Center, in a separate arrangement.
Other buildings are expected to be taken over by creditors and held until the market for real estate improves. The Reichmann family's new entity, Olympia & York Properties Ltd., is hoping to be retained as the manager of these properties.
 
Some Dissent
 Over the past two weeks, most classes of creditors with security to back their loans have voted to approve the new plan, which includes provisions to protect the Reichmann family from future lawsuits and to give unsecured creditors a big stake in the new property-management business.
Of 34 classes of secured creditors, 8 have rejected the plan, which means they can take immediate steps to walk away with their collateral. Among the naysayers are the backers of O.& Y.'s flagship Toronto tower, 72-story First Canadian Place.
But the unsecured creditors who voted today could have vetoed the plan, which would have meant immediate dismantlement of Canadian operations.
Unsecured creditors hold the first claim on equity remaining in O.& Y. after the secured claims are satisfied. But O.& Y.'s liabilities far exceed its assets.
Alain Tuchmaier, a financial services analyst with McLean McCarthy Ltd., owned by the Deutsche Bank of Germany, said O.& Y.'s equity value last April, according to a study made by his firm, was more than $5 billion "under water."
Under the plan approved today, which will be submitted to the bankruptcy court for approval on Feb. 1, the largest interest in the property-management company will go to the unsecured creditors. The Reichmann family would own 10 percent and have the right to name at least one director to the board.

 The Big Three auto makers told Federal trade officials that they would seek punitive duties on all imported cars. The auto makers will charge that foreign cars are being sold illegally in the United States for less than in their home markets. [Page A1.]

 Sears will close its catalogue operations, shut 113 stores and carve 50,000 jobs from its payroll in another revamping meant to halt a decade-long decline in its retail business. [A1.]

HEADLINE: U.S. Trade Group Finds Sectors in Japan Closed

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 25

 BODY:
In a report that encourages the Clinton Administration to adopt a more aggressive trade policy toward Japan, the American Chamber of Commerce in Japan today listed dozens of business sectors that it said remained partly closed to foreign companies, despite years of arduous negotiations.
The report also said the Japanese still used numerous practices that hobbled foreign concerns trying to crack this market. 
 In some past reports, the chamber, a trade body, has sounded more conciliatory, suggesting that Japan was not as closed to foreign businesses as some supposed. But today's study, the chamber's "white paper" on trade, was tougher, detailing a network of discrimination.
While describing the problems in each sector, the American Chamber of Commerce recommended that the Clinton Administration quickly pursue new negotiations with the Japanese to strip away trade barriers.
 
Plea to Clinton
 "Despite Japanese Government actions to liberalize and internationalize, years of protection and export-driven strategies have shaped an environment inherently unfavorable to foreign firms," said Richard J. Johannessen Jr., president of the chamber and president of the Asia-Pacific operations of the Rockwell International Corporation.
Chamber officials said they planned to take their report to Washington and explain their difficulties to Clinton Administration officials, who are preparing a trade strategy.
Japan has indicated that it may not tolerate too tough an approach. Sozaburo Okamatsu, a senior official at the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, said today that Japan would consider retaliation if the United States imposed unilateral sanctions against Japanese exports.
The chamber's report, which was based on the experiences of the group's hundreds of member companies, said 34 business sectors remained at least partly closed to foreign concerns, even though some had been the subject of trade negotiations in the past. The sectors included agricultural products, automobiles, computers, computer software, financial services, glass and pharmaceuticals.
The report also criticized Japan's huge and growing trade surpluses with the United States, saying they reflected unfair practices.
"The continued imbalance and near-term trends remain 'politically' unacceptable, economically disruptive and a reflection of continued barriers to entry for U.S. products in Japan," it said.
The report explained how the Government's inclination to regulate every aspect of business life in Japan could impede a newcomer. For example, a dog food company could be prohibited from offering a "buy one, get one free" promotion or from hiring Japanese lawyers.
The report also cited 14 practices, including government procurement practices, tariffs and closed bidding procedures, that it said presented unfair obstacles to foreign companies.

HEADLINE: Weapons Shipment Intercepted On Way to Bosnia

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
In a move that highlights the debate over the embargo on arms shipments to the parties in the Balkan war, Western naval forces have intercepted a large shipment of weapons bound for the Bosnian Government, American officials said today.
They said the ship, called the Dolphin One, was en route to Rijeka, Croatia, when it was intercepted by Italian warships. From Croatia, the cargo would have been carried overland to Bosnia. 
 The ship contained surface-to-surface rockets, Chinese-made pistols and ammunition for Kalashnikov rifles and Toyota jeeps, all believed to have been shipped from Iran. The vessel was taken into custody by Italian destroyers and ordered to steam to an Italian port, American officials said.
The State Department has said the Clinton Administration is rethinking the arms embargo, which has locked in the overwhelming advantage that Serbian forces have enjoyed over the Bosnian Muslims, particularly in heavy weapons. The Bush Administration initially supported the arms embargo on weapons shipments only to question it in the President's last weeks in office.
 
Eluding Economic Sanctions
 Supporters of the arms embargo say that it limits the intensity of the fighting in the Balkans. Critics say the West should provide the Muslims with the means to defend themselves.
At the same time, there have been continuing reports that United Nations economic sanctions on Yugoslavia are being circumvented.
American officials said that a Greek-owned vessel, the Dimitrakis, reached the port of Bar in Montenegro on Jan. 19 after the captain falsely declared that he was making an emergency stop for repairs, a Pentagon official said. The vessel was reported to be carrying 6,000 metric tons of petroleum coke, which officials said can be used in refining oil.
In addition, American officials said that several convoys of tankers traveling up the Danube, bound for Serbia, refused to yield when told to halt.
 
Enforcement on the Danube
 A convoy of six diesel fuel tankers, guided by the tugboat Bihac, refused to heed Bulgarian calls to halt on Jan. 21, officials said. The captain of that convoy reportedly threatened to blow up the fuel when told to halt.
A convoy of 24 barges loaded with fuel also refused to stop when told to do so by Romanian officials, Clinton Administration officials said.
While the Adriatic is patrolled by ships from NATO and the Western European Union, the sanctions are enforced on the Danube only by Romanian and Bulgarian river patrols.
There have also been reports that the supplies have been sent to the Greek port of Salonika and then shipped overland through Macedonia. American officials have been concerned about the possibility of sanctions-busting by Greek companies for some time because Greece has not allowed European Community observers supervise its compliance with the restrictions.
Adding to the pressure on the Clinton Administration to take firmer action is an American assessment that as many as 70,000 detainees are being held in Serbian, Muslim and Croatian detention camps.
The State Department said today that if Red Cross officials found "the maximum number of possible prisoners in each and every possible site, the number could be as high as 70,000."
