HEADLINE: E. W. Kenworthy, 83, a Reporter Who Covered Capital With Flair

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
E. W. Kenworthy, a Washington correspondent for The New York Times who wrote about government and politics with flair and erudition for 20 years, died today at his home here. He was 83.
He died of complications from prostate cancer, his family said. 
 Mr. Kenworthy was 47, an advanced age to begin a new career, when he first arrived at the Washington bureau of The Times in 1957 at the start of Dwight D. Eisenhower's second term. But from the mid-1950's to the mid-1970's he covered Washington with a skill and scholarship that made him a force in daily journalism.
For example, on the White House beat in 1962, he wrote a news analysis article about the way President John F. Kennedy was twisting the arm of labor unions to support his anti-inflation program. The article began this way: "The man from Boston went up to Atlantic City this week and put on a performance for the United Automobile Workers that was one part Honey Fitz (blarney) and nine parts Ralph Waldo Emerson ('When duty whispers low, thou must')."
In addition to the White House, over the years Mr. Kenworthy covered the State Department, Congress and politics, and in the last years of his career he reported on the environment. He retired from The Times in 1977.
 
'Most Literate Reporter'
 Max Frankel, now executive editor of The Times, who was Washington bureau chief in the late 1960's and early 1970's, said Mr. Kenworthy was "simultaneously the most energetic and the most literate reporter in the Washington bureau, and there can be no more potent combination in journalism."
Edwin Wentworth Kenworthy (he used his initials in his byline and went by the nickname Ned) was born on Sept. 23, 1909, in Attleboro, Mass., and received undergraduate and graduate degrees from Oberlin College in Ohio.
He taught English at the high school level for several years and at Indiana University for several more. In World War II he worked for the Office of War Information, providing daily cables to overseas embassies about developments in the United States.
After the war Mr. Kenworthy worked briefly as an editorial writer at The Baltimore Evening Sun and then served as an information officer in the United States Embassy in London and worked for the Reporter magazine.
 
His Proudest Achievement
 In 1949 and 1950 he was executive secretary on President Harry S. Truman's Committee for Equality of Treatment and Opportunity in the Armed Services. The committee's report led to the racial desegregation of the military; Mr. Kenworthy always said he was prouder of the work he did on this issue than of any other professional accomplishment.
In the summer of 1950, after the committee had disbanded, Mr. Kenworthy joined The Times as a writer for The Week in Review. For seven years before moving to Washington, he wrote articles for the Sunday section on subjects ranging from the Korean War to science teaching.
In Washington, in what may have been the tour de force of his career, he covered the 1968 insurgent Presidential candidacy of Eugene J. McCarthy, providing unusual insights into this most complicated of politicians.
Take, for example, this paragraph: "His approach is not political, but moral and religious. The other day, when he offered his platform plank on Vietnam, he said he was not asking for 'repentance' from the Administration and the party. Perhaps not, but he was asking for confession. Confession may be good for the soul, but politicians have never believed it is good for the party."
Mr. Kenworthy's main beat in the 1970's was the environment, and he wrote about it with the same verve he had applied to other fields. Covering the political battle over whether to allow a power-project dam on the New River in North Carolina and Virginia, he began one article by quoting Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes: "A river is more than an amenity; it is a treasure."
Mr. Kenworthy's first wife, Jane Elizabeth, died in 1977. They had three children: John, of Washington; Tom, of Vienna, Va., and Jane Schorsch, of Alexandria, Va. Besides his children, Mr. Kenworthy is survived by his second wife, Martha, whom he married in 1988, and seven grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Republicans Lining Up to Challenge Cuomo

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 25

 BODY:
In May 1990, after being turned down by dozens of potential gubernatorial candidates, desperate Republican Party officials came across the name of Pierre A. Rinfret in a Manhattan district leader's address book.
Within a week, they had nominated the bombastic economist and political neophyte at their state convention. In an election that many Republicans consider a humiliating low point for their once grand old state party, Mr. Rinfret finished 32 percentage points behind Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and less than 1 percentage point ahead of the Conservative Party candidate, Herbert I. London.
 
A Potentially Large Field
 Less than three years later, more than a dozen Republicans from all corners of the state are considering the 1994 race for Governor. They include past and present members of Congress, legislators from both the Senate and Assembly, businessmen, lawyers and professors. 
 Those who are at least thinking about the race, some more seriously than others, include Evan G. Galbraith, a Manhattan investment banker and former Ambassador to France; Richard M. Rosenbaum, a Rochester lawyer and former state Republican chairman; Mr. London, a New York University humanities professor; Clarence D. Rappleyea Jr., the Assembly minority leader from Norwich; James P. Buden, a Tarrytown real estate developer and grandson-in-law of Nelson A. Rockefeller; and Jon S. Fossel, the chairman of Oppenheimer Mutual Funds and a former Assemblyman from Westchester County.
Others include Ronald S. Lauder, an executive in the Estee Lauder cosmetics empire and an unsuccessful 1989 mayoral candidate in New York City; Lewis E. Lehrman, the unsuccessful 1982 gubernatorial candidate; J. Patrick Barrett, a Syracuse businessman and former state Republican chairman; Susan Molinari, the congresswoman from Staten Island; Gerald B. Solomon, a Congressman from Glens Falls; Senator Goodman; Bill Green, the former Congressman from Manhattan who lost his re-election campaign in November; and John R. Dunne, the former state Senator from Long Island and recently departed assistant United States Attorney General.
Without exception, they have been attracted by what they see as a rejuvenation of the Republican Party in New York, the anti-incumbency politics of 1992, the November victory of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the possibility that Mr. Cuomo will be tapped for the United States Supreme Court and, above all, the political vulnerability of the third-term Governor.
"In 1990, no one would touch this race with a 10-foot pole," said Senator Roy M. Goodman, a Manhattan Republican. "Now it's a stampede. It's a very different picture."
Many Republican strategists agree that no one in the current field has enough stature or name recognition to be considered an immediate threat to Mr. Cuomo. But hovering above the crowd is the state's junior United States Senator, Mr. D'Amato.
Within hours of winning re-election to a third term, he backed away from his campaign pledge never to run again for public office, saying he would "never say never" about running either for a fourth term or for Governor. If Mr. D'Amato chooses to run, Republican officials believe the rest of the field will dissipate quickly and unite around the Senator.
Many political analysts, including a number of aides to Mr. Cuomo, believe Mr. D'Amato would never subject himself to what undoubtedly would be a brutal battle against Mr. Cuomo.
But some Republicans are not so sure. They point out that Mr. D'Amato's ability to secure Federal dollars for New York and his control over Federal appointments in the state may diminish this year with a Democrat in the White House. If he becomes frustrated, and if his reputation survives the trial of his brother, Armand, on Federal fraud charges in April, Mr. D'Amato may well take a shot, they said. He would not have to resign his seat in the Senate to run.
 
Providing Few Hints
 Mr. D'Amato provided few hints about his intentions in an interview last week. "I know that there's going to be a race for Governor, but that's not anything that I'm looking at," he said. "I was just elected."
There are other possibilities on the Republican side as well. If former United States Attorney Rudolph W. Giuliani loses this year's mayoral race, but finishes with a respectable showing, as he did in 1989, party leaders believe he could be a formidable statewide candidate.
The other major variable in the race, of course, is Mr. Cuomo. For the time being, the Governor is talking like a candidate, saying in interviews that he is planning to run for a fourth four-year term if President Clinton does not appoint him to the Supreme Court. He would start the race with a campaign treasury that now stands at $3.2 million.
Mr. Cuomo has said he probably will announce a decision by the end of the year. Because there will be no obvious Democratic heir apparent if Mr. Cuomo retires or leaves for Washington, the line of Democratic gubernatorial prospects may make the Republican queue look short.
But now, unlike 1990, Mr. Cuomo is not intimidating the Republicans. They were heartened that Mr. Cuomo, who won with a record 65 percent of the vote in 1986, took only 53 percent in 1990 against a pair of second-tier opponents.
Since then, they have watched his approval ratings in public polls decline steadily to well under 50 percent. An October poll by the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion gave Mr. Cuomo a 44 percent approval rating, his lowest in 10 years. Seventy percent of those questioned said the state was headed in the wrong direction.
For the fifth consecutive year, Mr. Cuomo is preoccupied with eliminating a multibillion-dollar shortfall in the state budget, meaning persistent headlines about spending cuts and tax increases. When he gave a lackluster State of the State speech this month, Republicans charged that he seemed tired and bored, a contention Mr. Cuomo denies.
"He can deny it, but I think he's grown a little tired of it," Mr. Rappleyea said. "He's beginning to show a little flatness. He's run a little too long without a heavy tuneup. A lot of people believe he's going to be bailing out of here if he gets an opportunity. And if he's here, he's got a record that he's going to have trouble defending."
Few of those who say they are considering the race have run statewide campaigns, and none have done so successfully. Among the elected officials, Mr. Rappleyea may be the most prominent, but he comes from Chenango County and is concerned about his small fund-raising base. Many, like Mr. Lauder, who spent $13 million of his own money on his mayoral bid, are individually wealthy and capable of underwriting their own campaigns. Mr. Cuomo calls them "the Republican royalty."
Of those looking at the race, Mr. Rosenbaum may be furthest along. He said he has formed a campaign committee, raised $200,000 and hired professional consultants. Mr. Galbraith has formed an exploratory committee. Mr. Buden and Mr. London said they are virtually certain they will run.
Mr. Barrett, Mr. Fossel, Mr. Green, Mr. Rappleyea and Mr. Solomon said they are giving the race serious thought. Mr. Goodman, Mr. Lauder, Mr. Lehrman, Mr. Dunne and Ms. Molinari decline to rule themselves out.
 
 
 
THE NEW YORK GOVERNOR RACE: THE REPUBLICAN CHALLENGE
 In 1990, the Republican Party had trouble finding a candidate to run against Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, choosing Pierre A. Reinfret, an economist and political neophyte. Mr. Rinfret finished 32 percentage points behind Mr. Cuomo and 1 percentage point ahead of the Conservative Party candidate, Herbert I. London. But with what they see as a resurgence in the Republican Party in New York State, the anti-incumbency politics of 1992, the November victory of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and the possibility that Mr. Cuomo will be tapped for the Supreme Court, at least a dozen Republicans are seriously considering a run against the Governor in 1994. The following six have expressed interest or have set up committee's to explore a possible run.
 
Evan G. Galbraith, a Manhattan investment banker and former ambassador to France
 
Richard M. Rosenbaum, a Rochester lawyer and former state Republican chairman
 
Mr. London, a New York University humanities professor
 
Clarence D. Rappleyea Jr., the Assembly minority leader from Norwich
 
James P. Buden, a Tarrytown real estate developer and grandson-in-law of Nelson A. Rockefeller
 
Jon S. Fossel, the chairman of Oppenheimer Mutual Funds and a former assemblyman from Westchester County.

HEADLINE: Domestic Vehicle Sales Rise 15% in Midmonth

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks rose 15 percent in mid-January compared with the period a year earlier, the nation's auto makers reported today. But the increase remained short of the robust gains the industry had been anticipating.
Accordingly, Ward's Automotive Reports, a trade newspaper, reported today that automotive production in January in the United States and Canada would fall short of planned volume by nearly 6 percent, to 785,000 cars and light trucks. 
 Domestic light-truck sales remained strong in the Jan. 11-20 period at 105,730, a 32.6 percent increase from a year earlier. But car sales rose only 4.2 percent, to 136,462. The seasonally adjusted annual selling rate for the period was 5.9 million, compared with 5.3 million in early January and 5.6 million in the period last year.
 
'Glacial' Improvement
 Tom Webb, an economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association, described the recovery in automotive demand as "glacial." Analysts speculated that sales had slowed from December because auto makers were offering fewer discounts, like those available last month to stimulate sales of the Ford Taurus and Honda Accord, which were battling to be the top-selling car of 1992. The Taurus achieved that distinction.
"As we head into February, if you don't see the rate of sales start to pick up, you'll see discounts again," said Steve Girsky, an analyst for Paine Webber in New York.
The General Motors Corporation, the industry leader, posted a 3.4 percent drop in domestic car sales, to 58,667, and a 33 percent increase in light-truck sales, to 39,218. In cars, G.M.'s Chevrolet and Buick divisions showed large declines, but G.M.'s full-size pickup trucks showed particularly strong gains. Sales of the Chevrolet C/K series pickup were up 58 percent, to 11,400. But analysts theorized that sales a year earlier were unusually weak because of strong competition between Ford and G.M. in late 1991.
The Ford Motor Company's car sales rose 14.9 percent, to 39,753 for the period; light-truck sales rose 18.1 percent, to 33,592. Jack Swygert, new-car sales manager of Hub Ford in Atlanta, said the incentives in late 1992 raised demand then at the expense of current sales. "We don't have any inventory," he said.
The Chrysler Corporation's light-truck sales were estimated to have risen 45.7 percent, to 25,900; car sales were estimated at 15,700, up 18.3 percent. Chrysler announces sales only once a month; interim totals are estimated by Ward's.
The Honda Motor Company's sales of domestically made cars fell 28.2 percent, to 7,223. The Toyota Motor Corporation's sales of American-made cars fell 6.3 percent, to 5,935, and Toyota's light-truck sales were up sixfold, to 1,924. The Nissan Motor Company's car sales nearly doubled, to 5,090, largely on the strength of the new Altima midsize sedan.
"We can't keep the Altima in stock," said Jim Vullock, sales manager for David McDavid Nissan-Oldsmobile in Houston. "Our January allocation is 30 cars. We've received about 20, and we're down to about 5." The Altima competes with the Honda Accord and Toyota Camry.

HEADLINE: U.S. Seeks To Reopen Japan Deal

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is looking for ways to undo a secret last-minute decision by the Bush Administration to approve a Japanese corporation's purchase of an American company that makes computer equipment, Federal officials said today.
The case, involving a unit of the Applied Magnetics Corporation of Goleta, Calif., is the first foreign investment issue to face the Clinton Administration, and is a top priority of the White House's new National Economic Council, according to Congressional and executive branch officials. President Clinton today formally created the council, which is meant to complement the National Security Council and will review questions of national economic security.
 
The Bush Legacy
 The Bush Administration encouraged foreign investment in the United States and approved almost all of the applications submitted to it by foreign businesses seeking to buy American high-technology companies. A notable exception came last summer, when the Administration barred the LTV Corporation from selling its missile division to Thomson-CSF of France. 
 While President Clinton has said little on the issue, some Democratic members of Congress have been pressing for years to curb such sales, contending that foreigners are buying American inventions cheaply and then producing them overseas.
Last Tuesday, on its final full day in office, the Bush Administration secretly ruled that Applied Magnetics could sell its optical products division to Nakamichi Peripherals Inc. of Japan, said the officials, who insisted on anonymity. The division is the only American company producing the main component for computer laser disk drives in the United States, and it has just developed a new generation of laser disk drive technology.
 
Missile-Guidance Device
 The Defense Department has recently completed the testing of the new gear in the guidance system of the Patriot missile. The new generation of equipment results in faster and more durable laser disk drives and could improve the missile's performance against other missiles, like the Iraqi Scud. After the Persian Gulf war, controversy arose over the effectiveness and accuracy of the Patriot against the Scud.
"This technology is about the best there is," said Bruce E. Thompson, the chairman of Mountain Optech Inc., which is based in Boulder, Colo., and assembles military laser disk drives that use Applied Magnetics components together with special shock absorbers and insulation. "You just can't break it under very harsh conditions," he said. The high acceleration of a missile launching requires very sturdy electronic equipment.
The Bush Administration's decision, made by an interagency committee on foreign investment that is headed by the Treasury Department, is already beginning to stir criticism in Congress. Representative Cardiss Collins, Democrat of Illinois, sent a letter to the Treasury Department today protesting that Congress had not been informed about the ruling and asking that the decision be reconsidered.
Ms. Collins heads the Energy and Commerce Committee's Subcommittee on Commerce, Consumer Protection and Competitiveness, which oversees Federal policy on foreign investment.
People with a detailed knowledge of the case said the staff of the National Economics Council began seeking to reopen the case immediately after President Clinton took office last Wednesday, even before formal creation of the agency, which is headed by Robert Rubin.
Federal law on the sale of American companies to foreigners allows such a reopening only if the Government finds a "material discrepancy" between the truth and information provided by participants in the transaction during the initial review of the case.
A material discrepancy is defined in the legislation as either inaccurate information or the omission of relevant information. The Treasury Department and the council are now reviewing whether Applied Magnetics provided all relevant information about the military applications of its product, officials said.
The Treasury Department declined to comment on the case, citing a Federal law that bars disclosure of information about foreign investment cases unless the companies involved have already publicly discussed the case.
Applied Magnetics announced last Tuesday that it had signed a letter of intent to sell the laser disk division, but it did not disclose the buyer. Andrew M. Kearns, the director of investor relations at Applied Magnetics, declined to comment further today on the sale, citing routine legal restrictions associated with the company's planned sale soon of four million additional shares of stock.
The company's shares closed at $12.65 today, down 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Laser disk drives resemble phonographs, in that the disk spins around while encoded information is read from it. A small laser replaces the stylus of the phonograph.
Typically, laser disk drives move the laser and all of its associated equipment across the surface of the disk. But Applied Magnetics has developed a new technique in which the laser is mounted at the edge of the disk and shines a beam into a tiny lens that moves around the disk and reflects the beam downward, reading the information, Mr. Thompson said.
Because the tiny lens is so much smaller and less bulky than the laser, it can move around the disk faster and the whole disk drive is quicker and more durable, he said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rally Drops Long Bond Yield to 6-Year Low

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to its lowest level in six years yesterday in a bond-market rally touched off by comments of Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bensten over the weekend that raised hopes of deficit reduction.
Appearing Sunday on NBC News's "Meet the Press," Mr. Bentsen said the Clinton Administration was likely to propose increased taxes on energy consumption. He suggested that a broad-based tax on energy was the leading option. 
 Yesterday, President Clinton told reporters he thought Mr. Bensten had done a good job on television. The President did not back away from the notion of a consumption tax, but he added, "No decision has been made."
The rally in bonds had a positive effect on the stock market, where the Dow Jones industrial average gained 39.39 points, to 3,292.20. [D10.]
Traders said yesterday's bond market rally was also fueled by speculation that the Government would shift more borrowing to shorter maturities, which would shrink the supply of long-term bonds. That pushed long-term prices up yesterday, they said.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 14/32 , to 1055/32 , pushing its yield down to 7.20 percent by late in the day. That was the lowest yield since Aug. 26, 1986, when it was 7.19 percent. A rise of one point is equivalent to $10 for every $1,000 of bonds held.
In when-issued trading, the two-year note to be auctioned today was trading at a price to yield 4.25 percent, down from 4.29 percent on Friday. The five-year note to be auctioned tomorrow was trading in the when-issued market at a price to yield 5.67 percent.
William H. Pike, head of United States Government trading at Chemical Bank Securities, said the market was definitely reacting to the Treasury Secretary's comments. He said the comments added to rising hopes that the Administration would develop concrete plans to reduce the deficit.
Analysts at MMS International, a research firm, noted that although Mr. Bentsen had said he wanted to work with the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates low and perhaps bring them down, they did not expect the Fed to cut rates in exchange for promises of cuts in the deficit. They said that with signs indicating a strengthening economy and a fiscal-stimulus package forthcoming from the Administration, the Fed was expected to hold rates steady.
Traders said the market also reacted yesterday to reports of only moderate growth in the rate of domestic vehicle sales in mid-January. The release today of the January consumer confidence survey could add to the market's bullishness, traders say. Confidence in the economy soared after the Presidential election and through the holiday season, but the market has been sensitive to recent signs of a pullback, particularly in expectations.
Technical analysts noted yesterday that the Commodity Research Bureau's index, comprising 21 basic raw materials, broke below 200 for the first time since early November, adding to the bullish market tone.
They said the index had been driven down largely by agricultural components, while the energy component was up sharply, with oil the chief culprit. But the decline in the total index reinforced market perceptions that inflation was not currently a concern.
 
Corporate Bonds
 The rally in Treasuries provided grounds for higher corporate bond prices. Relatively low interest rates and strong investor demand continued to provide an excellent climate for new corporate bond issues as corporate treasurers move to refinance debt that was sold when interest rates were higher.
Three banks issued $500 million of notes yesterday: Society National, the PNC Financial Corporation, and Continental Bank N.A. Other corporations accounted for $300 million in new fixed-income debt, and federally chartered agencies like Freddie Mac accounted for $130 million.
Underwriters see a heavy backlog of companies waiting to issue debt in the corporate bond market. The Public Service Electric and Gas Company of New Jersey plans to price $250 million of first and refunding mortgage bonds today through competitive bidding.
High-yield corporate bonds also traded firmer yesterday. "Things had a better tone all around," one high-yield trader said.

HEADLINE: Clinton Says He Has Made No Decision on Energy Tax

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
As lawmakers and industry officials responded unenthusiastically to suggestions of a new energy tax, President Clinton said today that he had not yet decided whether to support the idea.
Mr. Clinton said that he had not selected any of several proposals to reduce the Federal budget deficit. "We have a lot of options under consideration, but no decision has been made," he said as he signed an order establishing a National Economic Council. 
 Aides said that Mr. Clinton's comments were not meant to suggest backpedaling on an energy tax. But after the tepid reaction to Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen's suggestion on Sunday that the nation needed some sort of energy tax, Administration officials know they are walking through a minefield in search of deficit-cutting programs.
Many senators said a broad-based energy tax would hurt several regions, while public-interest groups criticized the idea because it would hit the middle class hardest. Environmentalists were among the few groups to welcome the suggestion.
Facing annual deficits of more than $300 billion, Mr. Bentsen said on Sunday that a tax on coal, oil and other forms of energy would not only cut the budget deficit, but would also conserve energy, reduce oil imports and cut the nation's trade deficit. He said the Administration was looking at a wide range of consumption taxes.
"As a pollution proposal, a broad-based energy tax makes a lot of sense," said Roger C. Dower, director of climate, energy and pollution studies at the World Resources Institute.
Although many lawmakers said they were eager to cooperate with the new President, several seemed wary of supporting an energy tax, fearing the public response.
Senator David L. Boren, an Oklahoma Democrat, said such a tax would hurt his energy-producing state and harm efforts to trim the deficit. "If we start dividing the country by region, putting heavier tax burdens on some regions of the country than others, I don't think we'll succeed," he said.
Some Republican senators vehemently attacked the proposal. "At the very moment the economy is beginning to move, we're talking about heaping on huge tax increases," said William V. Roth, Jr., the Delaware Republican who sits on the Senate Finance Committee.
 
Approval Could Be Won
 But Congressional leaders said Mr. Clinton could probably win approval of such an energy tax if he heavily lobbied legislators. According to calculations by the Congressional Budget Office, a 5 percent tax on energy would collect $18 billion a year. For a household that spends $100 a month on utilities and $80 a month on gasoline, a 5 percent tax on energy would cost $9 a month.
The loudest cries against an energy tax came from heavy industries, like steel and aluminum, which feared that such a levy would cripple them against foreign competition by increasing the cost of production.
Charles J. DiBona, president of the American Petroleum Institute, the oil industry's lobbying group, said a broad energy tax "will hurt the economy short term and long term and will have a disproportionate effect on us compared with other countries."
 
Patience Is Urged
 Administration officials cautioned today that it would be premature to focus on any one tax proposal, asserting that people should wait for the President's overall deficit-reduction plan to see how well the sacrifice is spread around.
Administration officials said they were studying several energy tax options, including a gasoline tax and an oil-import fee. A gasoline tax would hit families in the West hardest because they drive long distances, while New England would be hurt worst by an oil-import fee because much of its energy comes from imported oil. Energy experts said a broad energy tax would hurt the Midwest most because it gets much of its energy from coal and utilities that burn coal, which might face the highest tax increases.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off Across the Board As Foreign Rates Stay High

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined in an across-the-board selloff yesterday touched off by worry over high foreign interest rates.
Gold prices rose modestly after declining in Europe. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $328.80 a troy ounce, up 20 cents from Friday. The Republic National Bank said gold added 30 cents an ounce, to a late bid price of $328.80. 
 The dollar declined overseas, and heavy selling continued in domestic markets. The dollar was off sharply against several key currencies, particularly the Japanese yen and the German mark.
While there was no specific fresh news to influence trading, the dollar was hindered by "changing perceptions of interest rate differentials," said John McCarthy, foreign exchange manager at the ABN-AMRO Bank.
It has become increasingly apparent to traders that overseas "interest rates are not going to narrow in favor of the dollar as some would have hoped," he said.
 
Expected a Rate Cut
 Dealers had expected both Japanese and German monetary officials to trim their interest rates. The Japanese lowered one rate last week, but it had little effect in the marketplace, and officials of the Bundesbank have been insisting that they will not lower rates despite a weakening German economy.
Lower interest rates abroad make dollar-denominated securities more attractive in comparison, thereby increasing investors' need for the United States currency.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 125.05 yen, down 0.10 yen from Friday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 123.25 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 123.45 yen, down from 125.10 yen on Friday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.5589, from $1.5345 late Friday. In New York it cost $1.5565 to buy one pound, more expensive than Friday's $1.5305.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.5675 German marks, down from 1.5905; 1.4465 Swiss francs, down from 1.4580; 5.3305 French francs, down from 5.3800; 1,452.50 Italian lire, down from 1,463.25, and 1.2790 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2808.

SECTION: Section C; Page 16; Column 1; Cultural Desk; Word and Image Page

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Groping for the Future as the Modern Age Ends

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

 BODY:

The End of the 20th Century
 And the End of the Modern Age
 By John Lukacs
291 pages. Ticknor & Fields. $21.95.
 The year 1989, when the Berlin Wall came tumbling down and Eastern Europe emerged from the shadow of the Soviet Union, not only marked the end of the 20th century but also the waning of a great historical epoch, the passing of the Modern Age, which witnessed the rise of liberalism, humanism and bourgeois culture throughout the Western world. So argues the historian John Lukacs in his provocative new book. 
 The 20th century was a short one, he says, having begun in 1914 with World War I and having ended well short of the millennium. It was a century indelibly shaped by the legacy of two world wars, a century whose central developments (from the Russian revolution to the collapse of the old colonial empires to the emergence of a balance of power between the United States and the Soviet Union) were direct consequences of those two pivotal wars. Today, Mr. Lukacs says, the consequences of those wars no longer dominate the historical landscape as they used to; an uneasy new era lies ahead.
Unlike its predecessor, Mr. Lukacs predicts, the 21st century will not be an American one, the decline of American power reflecting, in his view, both specific shifts in the country's fortunes and the fading of "the age of superpowers, superstates" in general. The gradual retreat of American influence in Europe, coupled with the more spectacular collapse of Communism, he adds, will leave "a large vacuum of power in the heartland of the world." In his view, this vacuum will not be filled by a "United Europe," a chimerical vision that will fail to materialize in any meaningful way, but will "most likely be filled" by a resurgent Germany, which will probably exert more and more influence on small countries from the Baltics to Croatia.
A Hungarian-born scholar who fled Budapest in 1945, Mr. Lukacs has written a dozen other books, and "The End of the 20th Century and the End of the Modern Age" draws heavily at times on ideas laid out in previous works like "The Duel: 10 May-31 July, the 80-Day Struggle Between Churchill and Hitler," "A New History of the Cold War" and "The Great Powers and Eastern Europe." His book also echoes William Pfaff's impressive study, "Barbarian Sentiments: How the American Century Ends" (1989), in several respects, most notably in its focus on Europe as a locus for change and in its emphasis on nationalism as an influential and potentially dangerous force.
As Mr. Lukacs sees it, nationalism -- that is, the love of "the myth of a 'people,' justifying everything" -- was the principal factor in this century's two world wars, and nationalism continues to be the world's most potent political force. Nationalism destroyed the Hapsburg Empire and monarchy, and nationalism helped end the Soviet domination of Eastern Europe. Hitler, in Mr. Lukacs's opinion, was not a racist but an extreme nationalist, and Stalin, too, understood nationalism only too well.
"Populist nationalism," Mr. Lukacs writes, "as distinct from the now almost extinct variety of the liberal nationalisms of the 19th century, is a modern and democratic phenomenon. Populist nationalists are self-conscious rather than self-confident, extroverted, essentially aggressive and humorless, suspicious of other people within the same nation who do not seem to agree with some of their populist and nationalist ideology. Hence they assign them to the status of minorities, suggesting -- and at times emphasizing -- that such minorities do not and cannot belong within the authentic body of the national people."
Given the rise of this new kind of nationalism, what does Mr. Lukacs foresee for the 21st century? A proliferation of small states or statelets, perhaps "a bubbling new Levantine world, a subcivilization ruled by brigands and traders -- another reversion to something that existed before the Modern Age." Although he suggests that the era of great revolutions and great wars is very likely over, he also notes that new questions are raised by the "growing evidence of a New Barbarism all around us."
"When life is endangered," he writes, "when everyday life may be punctuated by instant and incalculable attacks of savagery, by tribal battles or by mob riots, no less dangerous than were wars that we still remember or can imagine -- is that way of life preferable to an era when wars, with all of their dangers and horrors, were confined to definite periods of time, with a marked beginning and end, and when a definite distinction between armies and civilians corresponded to the definite distinction between war and peace? The answer to this question is not yet. History does not repeat itself. The new barbarians are not like the barbarians of 1,600 years ago (well, the latter had at least some virtues, whereas the present ones . . . at least, not yet); and the United States and/ or the Western world at the end of the 20th century is not really like the Roman Empire."
Certainly readers will not agree with all of Mr. Lukacs's predictions and assessments. His aristocratic suspicion of democracy and egalitarianism, his arbitrary dismissal of Communism's consequences, his tendency to overemphasize the intangibles of a country's national "character" and ancient historical imperatives -- all are subject to debate. For instance, his suggestion that a spiritual "Russian sense of guilt" played a significant role in the breakup of the Soviet empire seems overly romantic, even naive; it fails to take into account the fierce economic and political realities that existed and continue to exist in that part of the world.
There are other limitations to "The End of the 20th Century" as well. Mr. Lukacs virtually ignores developments in Asia, Africa, Latin America and the Middle East, and he pays no attention at all to shifts in America's international role, galvanized by recent developments like the Persian Gulf war.
Because of such shortcomings, Mr. Lukacs's book fails to offer a comprehensive or thoroughly persuasive portrait of "the end of the 20th century" (much less "the end of the Modern Age"). Still, the volume is well written and well argued, and it makes for stimulating reading, the sort of reading that sends one rushing to the bookstore in search of other books on related subjects.

HEADLINE: ON PRO FOOTBALL;
A Vision That Goes Beyond 100 Yards

BYLINE: By Thomas George

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Solomon Wilcots offered the most memorable line about the riots in the Overtown section of Miami that jolted the National Football League and its annual January bash, this one Super Bowl XXIII in 1989 that featured the San Francisco 49ers and the Cincinnati Bengals. Wilcots, now a Pittsburgh Steelers safety but then with the Bengals, said: "We went to the movies to see 'Mississippi Burning.' We came out and we saw Miami burning."
The riots began after a Cuban-American police officer was charged with fatally shooting a black motorcyclist in a predominantly black section of Miami a few days before the game. The N.F.L. spun on its heels in the days that followed, bombarded with questions. 
 What responsibility does the league have to the communities that it uses to be host to its big show? Sure, more than $120 million is generated for host cities from simply having a Super Bowl, but how do the inner cities directly benefit? Is the Super Bowl simply an event of bold economics and prime entertainment for the privileged?
After the civil strife in Miami, the league tarnished its image even further by awarding the city of Phoenix and the state of Arizona the 1993 Super Bowl even though the state was divided over the failure to adopt Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday as a holiday. The N.F.L. owners' decision was a personal affront to many and particularly to the black athletes who constitute 65 percent of the league's players.
Of course, the decision was eventually reversed, which brought this year's Super Bowl to the Rose Bowl and to Pasadena, Calif., instead. But at the time of the first vote, only one N.F.L. owner, Norman Braman of the Philadelphia Eagles, stood up and spoke out about potential boycotts and the possibility of a need to rescind the '93 Phoenix bid.
The other owners -- and N.F.L. Commissioner Paul Tagliabue, too -- either could not undertand what the fuss was about or simply, initially, refused to fully address it.
My, the N.F.L. has come a long way.
Starting in Miami, after the riots, the league began offering minority scholarships for youths in Super Bowl cities and developed a program to insure that minority businesses large and small would gain a share of the enormous Super Bowl economic pie. Now the league has made a gigantic leap with its N.F.L./Y.E.T (Youth Education Town) idea, a $1 million, multifaceted educational and recreational facility being built in South-Central Los Angeles.
This facility speaks to the heart of problems particulary in the Compton/Watts area where it will be built, an area that has gained worldwide attention since the riots in South-Central Los Angeles after the Rodney King verdict last April. The facility will give something back to the area where 104 N.F.L. players past and present grew up, including two from this year's Super Bowl, receiver James Lofton of the Buffalo Bills and safety James Washington of the Dallas Cowboys.
The facility will include four primary arenas -- library, classroom, physical conditioning room and Astroturf recreational field. The goal is for its completion between May 1 and April 1. Many businesses have offered a helping hand; Sports Illustrated has offered to coordinate the acquisition of books and creation of educational programs, book donors include Random House and the Trumpet Club/ Bantam-Doubleday Dell Publishing, and Sony has offered 50 mini-disk electronic encyclopedias.
Everyone from quarterback Vince Evans of the Los Angeles Raiders to the Football Hall of Famer John Mackey to Roy Roberts, the executive director of the Watts/Willowbrook Boys and Girls Club, has given time and input. Country singer Garth Brooks will donate the proceeds from two concerts here this weekend.
But the driving force behind the project is Reggie Williams, the former Bengals linebacker, former Cincinnati city councilman and former general manager of the New York/ New Jersey Knights of the now-defunct World League of American Football.
"I was on the city council in Cincinnati and a Bengal getting ready for the game when the riots in Miami broke," Williams said. "You could see the fires burning from our hotel. After the motorcyclist was killed, the police closed off the area and let an implosion take place. Well, this program will tear down those type of blockades. We're going in and we're trying to make a difference."
Williams was hired by the N.F.L. last fall as director of community affairs for Super Bowl XXVII.
"The first thing I did was come to Los Angeles in October and November and spend a few days just listening," Williams said. "Commissioner Tagliabue made a commitment for us to identify a community project in connection with the Super Bowl and the Rebuild L.A. Project. He made a commitment and backed it up. Listening to the people here was important. But really, all you had to do was drive through Compton and you could see the many problems on the many faces."
And one trip to the Watts/Willowbrook facility was all Williams needed to crystallize his idea.
There he saw a run-down, tired facility that was a refuge to more than 1,000 youths. The ceilings were full of holes. The basketball courts were full of long, ugly holes, some covered with gray masking tape, others just left bare. No showers. A trailer that served as an educational center was dark and ugly brown outside with few resources inside. And yet there was immense pride in the work being done there by Roberts and his assistants.
"I felt like maybe I have lived a spoiled life, but still, it was hard to believe," Williams said. "The standards had to be raised. What more basic promotion of self-esteem is there to have a facility that at least includes showers and an emphasis on personal hygiene?"
Williams knew what needed to be done. He began marshaling forces. He met some resistance.
"The politics of putting together something this massive calls for perserverance, and Mr. Williams had it," said Roberts, who has worked at the Watts/Willowbrook facility for 18 years, who grew up in a housing project in South-Central L.A. and who has lived in the area for 43 of his 49 years. "I don't know if it would have happened without Mr. Williams. He is leaving a legacy here. So is the N.F.L."
N.F.L. players, especially from the Raiders and the Rams, will be asked to visit the center and work with youths. This facility cannot solve all of the deep, sweeping problems of South-Central Los Angeles, but it makes a tremendous effort where effort is needed most -- among youth.
Williams makes special mention of former Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall, who died Sunday. Marshall's impetus that sparked the Brown v. Board of Education decision in 1954, which ended the "separate but equal" system of segregation in American schools, came in the year in which Williams was born.
"He always played a unique role in my life," Williams said. "He paved the way and issued a challenge for me. I'm trying to do the same with these youth. In a small way, a door is open for opportunity. The hope and the expectation is that the N.F.L/ Y.E.T facility will not be a goal unto itself but a catalyst for creative ways to assist youth. We tell them to stay in school and get an education, but this is a vehicle that goes beyond the advice. It puts deeds behind the words. The youth must act and seize the opportunity."
Will they?
"I don't think very much is going to change," said Amos Harris, an 18-year-old who lives five minutes from the facility and who worked at the center setting up the sound system for the N.F.L. news conference today that was to announce the facility plans. "Some people have changed, but not a whole lot has changed. But I have to look at it in the way that every little thing that is done here is good. I've never heard of the N.F.L. doing anything like this. It's a great start. They should continue."
One final thought. The site on which the facility will be built is part of a shopping center that serves as a nerve center for the area. In fact, the new facility is being built on ground where stores were burned to ashes during the L.A. riots.
This is how ashes can, indeed, be turned into beauty.

Darrell Henley of the Rams, left, stands alongside a member of a Hispanic gang during visit by N.F.L. players to Toberman Settlement House in Los Angeles yesterday. (Associated Press)

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 3; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Gay Couples Also Need Economic Benefits

 BODY:
To the Editor:
We appreciate your coverage of Mayor David N. Dinkins's announcement of executive orders to allow domestic partners in New York City to register their relationship with the city clerk, which confers certain noneconomic benefits (news article, Jan. 8). Yet we are dismayed that you omit mention of the suit filed the same day by a group of city employees demanding precisely what the executive orders lack. 
 The Coalition of Lesbian and Gay City Employees, four named city employees and four pseudonymous complainants, filed a complaint with the the city's Commission on Human Rights. We seek full spousal benefits for all full-time city employees living in domestic partnerships, namely the same health, dental, retirement and death benefits conferred on the spouses of our heterosexual counterparts. This is the first suit by city employees to demand the full spectrum of economic benefits.
For the thousands of lesbian and gay city employees with uninsured partners, these economic benefits matter most. The executive orders permit bereavement leave, family leave without pay, visitation rights in municipal hospitals and correctional facilities, and provide that a registered domestic partnership is evidence of family for occupying or succeeding to rights in city housing.
Although these measures are welcome, they are noneconomic.
Without health benefits, domestic partnership registration for many is simply too risky. Indeed, based on experiences with employment discrimination, many lesbian and gay employees fear retaliation for declaring their domestic partnerships, notwithstanding the confidentiality provisions. However, if registration included nondiscriminatory qualification for benefits, more city employees would be motivated to take that step.
Contrary to the Mayor's position, nothing prevents the city from providing full health benefits now. Other employers, such as Seattle, Montefiore Hospital, the Lotus Corporation and The Village Voice already offer such benefits to the domestic partners of employees. To deny full spousal benefits to lesbian and gay employees is to deny equal pay for equal work.
 
JULIE MERTUS
VICTORIA METAXAS
CHRISTOPHER WOLFE
New York, Jan. 11, 1993
 
The writers are in the Coalition of Lesbian and Gay City Employees.

HEADLINE: Gay Couples Also Need Economic Benefits;
Undermining Marriage

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Time will tell whether or not Stanford University and the University of Chicago have yielded unwisely to the political correctness ideology in giving gay partners the same benefits as married couples. 
 As one who became a college president in 1951 and served as president of the American Association of Presidents of Independent Colleges and Universities (1969-72), I offer the perspective of an educational philosophy now sidelined, but not without success in supporting the American experiment in self-government.
Until World War II the colleges and universities of America had rules and customs that reflected the common beliefs about what is a good society. Among the many givens of campus life in those days were regulations that prohibited students from being in the dormitories of the opposite sex overnight. These proprietary rules, as they were called, placed the full majesty of the intellectual community on record as favoring marriage and the ideal of premarital chastity as critically important features of American civilization.
In this era of the triumph of sexual liberation, lawmakers and policy makers focus on the sexually active generation and relegate children and grandparents to the status of encumbrances. The new policies of Chicago and Stanford follow the pattern and drive one more nail in the coffin of marriage as a civilizational norm.
Since it is now beyond dispute that a child raised in a family with a father and a mother has a substantially better chance than other children do for emotional stability, success in school and employment, and for avoiding delinquency and suicide, one has to wonder if these two universities know which direction is forward.
 
JOHN A. HOWARD
Rockford, Ill., Jan. 11, 1992
 
The writer is a counselor with the Rockford Institute.

HEADLINE: Gay Couples Also Need Economic Benefits;
Clinton Should Proceed

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Gays in the Military: Cancel Reagan's Ban" (Op-Ed, Jan. 14), James T. Bush appears to draw a distinction between declaring one's homosexuality and engaging in homosexual acts. Such a distinction promotes a double standard between heterosexuality and homosexuality. 
 Our society permits, even encourages heterosexuals to participate in sexual activity when both parties are consenting adults. To allow members of the armed services to state they are homosexual without fear of disciplinary action, while continuing to prohibit them from exercising their sexuality by engaging in consensual homosexual activity, is hypocritical.
President Clinton should stand behind his campaign promise to sign an executive order overturning the 1982 ban on gays in the armed services. Only such a high-profile act will send the message that discrimination has no place in our Armed Forces. Mr. Clinton's order should also revise military regulations to provide equal treatment for all servicemen and women, regardless of sexual orientation.
 
WILLIAM ANDREW LAURENCE
San Francisco, Jan. 14, 1993

SECTION: Section B; Page 6; Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 135 words

HEADLINE: John Corbin Eddison, Development Expert, 73

 BODY:
John Corbin Eddison, an expert on economic development who was a former director of Near East Affairs for the United States Agency for International Development, died Friday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 73 years old and lived in Lexington, Mass.
He died of lung disease, said his wife, the former Elizabeth Owsley Bole. 
 Mr. Eddison was with the agency from 1963 to 1970, serving as deputy director of its mission in La Paz, Bolivia, and then in Washington as its deputy director of aid for Central America before becoming its Near East affairs director.
Mr. Eddison was born in Manhattan, grew up in Ardsley, N.Y.
Other survivors include a son, Jonathan B. Eddison of Los Angeles; two daughters, Elizabeth O. Eddison of Minneapolis and Martha Sieniewicz of Cambridge.

HEADLINE: River Life Through U.S. Broadly Degraded

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
TWO decades of Federal controls have sharply reduced the vast outflows of sewage and industrial chemicals into America's rivers and streams, yet the life they contain may be in deeper trouble than ever.
The main threat now comes not from pollution but from humans' physical and ecological transformation of rivers and the land through which they flow. The result, scientists say, is that the nation's running waters are getting biologically poorer all the time and that entire riverine ecosystems have become highly imperiled. 
 Dams disrupt temperature and nutrient patterns on which organisms depend. Countless river and stream channels have been straightened, eliminating the meandering course on which rivers depend for their ecological variety. Repeated diversions of water from a river's flood plain can decimate populations of fish that spawn there. Sediments from farming run into streams and suffocate many small forms of aquatic life. Vacationers who cut down trees to improve the view in front of summer homes may erode stream banks. The stream then carries more sediment and becomes wider, shallower and warmer, making the water unfit for many vital organisms.
"If you take a drive out into pretty, rolling farm country, nobody thinks of the farming activity as habitat destruction," says Dr. J. David Allan, a freshwater ecologist at the University of Michigan. "But the transformation of the landscape by agriculture is taking its toll" on life in rivers and streams, as are urban and suburban development and the spread of exotic, disruptive species of aquatic life.
The transformation, says Dr. Allan, is far more destructive to aquatic life than are spills of oil or toxic chemicals. For all the one-time harm they may cause, these spills have relatively little long-term impact. And because the transformation is so much a part of deeply entrenched patterns of land and water use, it is also far harder to deal with.
Dr. Allan lays out the threat to riverine organisms and ecosystems in an article in the current issue of the journal BioScience.
A 1990 study by Larry Master of the Nature Conservancy found that in North America, 28 percent of amphibian species and subspecies, 34 percent of fishes, 65 percent of crayfish and 73 percent of mussels were imperiled in degrees ranging from rare to extinct. The comparable figures were 13 percent for terrestrial mammals, 11 percent for birds and 14 percent for land reptiles.
In the West, where dams and the introduction of exotic species are common, the situation is particularly acute. Of 30 species of native fish in Arizona, 25 are listed as threatened or endangered, according to Dr. W. L. Minckley, a zoologist at Arizona State University.
The biotic impoverishment goes beyond the loss of individual species, however. Many rivers, Dr. Allan wrote, contain few or no endangered species, yet there are so few representatives of each species present that the ecosystem's functioning is impaired. Scientists do not know at what precise point this thinning of life causes an ecosystem to disintegrate. But "it's like an airplane wing," said Dr. John Cairns Jr., an environmental biologist at Virginia Polytechnic Institute, explaining, "if you keep pulling rivets out, the wing is going to go."
Among other benefits, riverine ecosystems create breeding grounds for commercial fisheries, carry nutrients to them and support multimillion-dollar recreational activities. In concert with wetlands, they regulate the flow of water, releasing it more slowly in flood times so that more will be left for dry times.
Few if any major river systems are unaffected by the threat to ecological integrity.
Sediment from farm fields, for instance, has clouded the mighty Mississippi, making it more hostile to many organisms. Levees prevent the sediments from settling out naturally on the Mississippi Delta. Instead, they are channeled directly to the continental shelf. This contributes to a sinking of the land in southern Louisiana and releases so many river-borne nutrients into the Gulf of Mexico that plankton growth is stimulated. The plankton use up oxygen when they decay and die, and scientists fear this oxygen depletion may harm Gulf fisheries.
 
Loss of Native Fish
 The Colorado River south of Lake Mojave has been so altered by disruption of water flow and the introduction of exotic fish species, Dr. Minckley said, that it has become the first major river in North America with no native fish left.
Dams on the Columbia River have so interfered with salmon migrations that one variety of Columbia salmon has been listed by the Government as endangered. Another has been declared threatened, and five more have been proposed for listing.
All three of these watercourses appear on a 1992 list of North America's 10 most endangered rivers compiled by American Rivers, a Washington-based conservation organization. Others include the Alsek and Tatshenshini river system in Alaska and Canada, the Great Whale River in Quebec, the Everglades, the American River in California and the Penobscot in Maine.
The list is rounded out by the Beaverkill and the Willowemoc, legendary Catskill trout streams where American fly fishing was born, and Montana's Blackfoot, the putative setting of the current hit movie, "A River Runs Through It."
Habitat in lower stretches of the Beaverkill-Willowemoc system is threatened by developers' cutting of streamside vegetation. The Blackfoot has become so degraded by timber cutting, agriculture, water diversions and mining activities that the movie makers were forced to move to another location.
 
'Four Horsemen' of Destruction
 Kevin Coyle, the president of American Rivers, describes "the four horsemen of river destruction" as dams, diversion of water, alteration of channels and land development.
Dams trap nutrients and keep them from flowing downstream. Perhaps more devastating, they alter the temperature of downstream water, making it either too cold or too warm and thus annihilating whole populations of insects vital to the riverine food web. One dam might not be so bad, but many dams on the same river, as is common in the West, repeatedly interrupt the river's natural functioning.
Diversion of water for human use, also widespread in the West, has simply dried up many rivers and streams for much of the year, with the result that their ecosystems are, in Mr. Coyle's words, "ghosts of what they used to be."
The straightening, diking and redirection of river channels, common across the country to control floods and convert flood plains to cropland, housing and highways, reduce the variety of habitats critical to biological diversity.
Land development often denudes stream and river banks of vegetation, eliminating the vital transition between the river and the uplands. Draining land for farming or development causes water to flow more rapidly into the river channel than it naturally would. This leaves less water to percolate into the river in drier times.
If the river channel has been straightened as well, water draining from the land moves more efficiently, producing more powerful floods. These carry the increased sediments from farming and development farther, choking organisms and ecosystems well downstream.
On top of all this, legions of exotic species have been introduced into running waters. Some, like the zebra mussel slowly spreading across the country, have appeared by accident. Others, like fish imported to provide sport or to clean vegetation from the waters, have been introduced on purpose. Together, Dr. Allan said, they have significantly reduced biological diversity through predation, alteration of habitat, introduction of diseases or parasites and interbreeding with native organisms.
 
Tinkering With Nature
 Such ecological tinkering can unexpectedly cascade through the water, onto the land and into the economy as well. In one instance, fishery managers in Montana introduced opossum shrimp into Flathead Lake and its associated river systems, hoping the shrimp would provide forage for kokanee salmon that were the basis of a thriving tourist industry.
Instead, the shrimp consumed zooplankton that were the staples of the kokanee diet. The kokanee population collapsed. Bald eagles and grizzly bears that once congregated at the rivers to feed on salmon disappeared, as did tourists who had come to see them.
Once invasive species have established themselves, said Dr. Allan, it may be impossible to eliminate them. The other main causes of biological impoverishment seem only a little less intractable. Even so, Dr. Allan, Mr. Coyle and others say much can be done.
 
Strategy Is Proposed
 American Rivers advocates a three-pronged strategy: saving the headwaters of the major rivers, which for the most part are already publicly owned; protecting and restoring riparian zones by replanting green strips along rivers; and working with governments to regulate water discharges from dams so they disrupt ecosystems less. Federally controlled dams are also being examined for their environmental effects as their hydroelectric licenses come up for renewal.
A number of scattered efforts to restore rivers and streams are being undertaken. Restorationists have become expert at restoring streams for game fish like trout, Dr. Allan noted. What is needed now, he said, is a comparable effort to restore habitat for the full panoply of riverine organisms.
An ambitious effort along these lines involves the Kissimmee River in Florida. To control flooding, the Army Corps of Engineers basically turned the twisting, 103-mile-long river into a straight canal, largely destroying the riverine-riparian ecosystem. Now, after a successful demonstration project, the State of Florida and the corps hope to restore the river's twists and turns -- and its ecosystem.
Broader restoration of this sort is still in its infancy. But as fragile as riverine ecosystems are, Dr. Allan points out, they are also remarkably resilient. They tend to repair themselves once the causes of their impoverishment are removed.
So, he says, all is not lost.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 28, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Science Times on Tuesday about environmental stresses on rivers and streams omitted a source of the material. The chart was adapted from work by Dr. James R. Karr, now director of the Institute for Environmental Studies at the University of Washington in Seattle.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Trees along an eroding bank falling into Willowemoc Creek near Roscoe, N.Y. As such banks erode, the river becomes wider and shallower and its water becomes too warm during the hot summer months. (Kris Lee) (pg. C7)
 
Diagram: "Flowing waters, dynamic ecosystem"
As rivers and streams meander, overflow their banks and create shortlived oxbow lakes, they fashion a patchwork of plant and animal habitats, both aquatic and terrestrial. Altering their courses over time, they achieve a long-term rhythmic balance among current, shore and floodplain that adds up to a single, indivisible ecosystem.
 
Eddies, riffles and pools
Patches of small environments occur in the riverine-riparian system as a result of differences in temperature, water velocity and dissolved nutrients. Organisms become specialists, adapted to life in shallow riffles with swift water, deep pools or warmer streambeds.
 
Stresses spread throughout the system
Changes in the channel, banks and water quality disrupt the finely meshed details of the aquatic ecology, endangering the health and fertility of many species. If a streambed silts up or a channel is widened, the water chemistry, temperature, depth and movement are all modified. Farming and overgrazing lead to destructive erosion of banks and runoff into the streams.
 
Silting up of streams diminishes aquatic life
Fine particles that remain suspended in water reduce sunlight and plant productivity, with a ripple effects all along the food chain. Predatory fish require good visibility to hunt.
 
(Source: "Restoration of Aquatic Ecosystems: Science, Technology, and Public Policy" [National Resource Council]) (pg. C1)
 
Chart: "Stresses on the Aquatic Environment of Rivers and Streams"
 Five major classes of factors that affect the river environments of living things and how human activities affect them.

Energy Source
The type and amount of organic material entering a stream from the riverside, versus primary production in the stream; seasonal patterns.
 
Water Quality
Temperature, turbidity, dissolved oxygen and nutrients, natural and synthetic chemicals, heavy metals and toxic substances, acidity.
 
Habitat Quality
Spawning, nursery and hiding places; substrate type; water depth and velocity; diversity (pools, riffles, woody debris).
 
Water Flow
The volume of water and the timing of floods and low flows.
 
Interactions of Living Things
Competition, predation, disease and parasitism.
 
CHANGES THAT RESULT FROM HUMAN-INDUCED ALTERATIONS:
Coarse particles of organic matter decrease; silt and fine particles increase; algal production increases.
More extreme temperatures; more suspended solids, nutrients and turbidity; altered daily cycle of dissolved oxygen.
Destabilization of substrate and banks by erosion and increased sediment; less habitat variation and vegetation; more uniform water depth; less habitat area.
Changes in flow extremes, including velocity and frequency; fewer protected sites; reduced diversity of flow in microhabitats.
Increases in fish disease and hybridization; alterations in reproduction, riverbed structure, decompositon rates and timing; disruption of seasonal rythms; shifts in community assembly and species abundance.
 
(Adapted from "Restoration of Aquatic Ecosystems: Science, Technology, and Public Policy" (National Research Council) (pg. C7)

HEADLINE: Israel Faces New U.N. Pressure Over Deportations

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Accused of allowing the United Nations to adopt a double standard in its dealings with recalcitrant nations, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali called today for the Security Council to take "whatever measures are necessary" to make Israel obey the Council's demand to re-admit 400 deported Palestinians.
Mr. Boutros-Ghali's recommendation led immediately to a call for sanctions against Israel by the Palestine Liberation Organization, which circulated a draft Security Council resolution to ban Israel from human rights meetings and to prevent foreign companies from doing business with some Israeli enterprises in the occupied territories. 
 The P.L.O.'s draft, which is likely to receive considerable backing, seemed to set the United Nations on a collision course with the Clinton Administration, which fears the crisis will derail the Mideast peace talks but wants it resolved by diplomacy.
 
History of U.S. Vetoes
 The United States has always exercised its veto on the Security Council to block sanctions against Israel, but has sometimes joined in votes condemning Israeli actions or abstained.
The Administration today indicated its readiness to block sanctions again, but such a veto would open Washington to charges that it seeks United Nations punishment against countries like Iraq, Libya and Yugoslavia for defying Security Council orders while shielding Israel from similar treatment.
A United States veto would also end a two-and-a-half-year period when no vetoes have been cast. The last veto was cast on May 31, 1990, when the Bush Administration blocked a resolution it considered unfair to Israel.
Israel angrily rejected the Secretary General's recommendation and, hoping to buy time, urged all parties to do nothing until after the Israeli High Court decides whether the deportations were legal. That ruling is expected later this week. [Page A8.]
The United States also asked for more time. The State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, said, "We believe there is an opportunity to resolve the issue through active diplomacy. We would like to see those efforts exhausted before the Security Council considers taking action."
Mr. Boucher said the Administration "wouldn't see any constructive purpose in a Security Council debate" on sanctions. He noted the impending court ruling and said Washington's "top priority" was to secure "the advancement of the Middle East peace talks."
 
Accusation by Israel
 Israel edged closer to a confrontation with the United Nations when Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin accused Mr. Boutros-Ghali, an Egyptian Christian, of employing a double standard by allegedly ignoring the "extremist Islamic terrorism" that made the deportations necessary.
Other Israeli officials reacted strongly to a separate proposal by Mr. Boutros-Ghali for the United Nations to start monitoring Israel's treatment of the 1.8 million Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza, saying monitoring was unnecessary because Israel has responsibility for the Palestinians under international law.
The head of the Palestinian delegation to the Middle East peace talks, Haidar Abdel-Shafi, praised the Secretary General's report, saying it was "high time that the U.N. asserts its authority" and that it would be shameful and ridiculous if Washington were to use its veto to block tough measures against the Israelis.
In his report to the Security Council, the Secretary General said his Middle East mediator, Chinmaya Gharakhan of India, had failed to persuade Israel to take back the deportees, who have now spent more than a month in a makeshift camp in a no man's land in southern Lebanon. The Lebanese Government says the deportees are Israel's responsibility.
 
Interpreting His Responsibility
 Thus, Mr. Boutros-Ghali said, "I would be failing in my duty if I did not recommend to the Security Council that it should take whatever measures are required to insure that its unanimous decision, as set out in Resolution 799 (1992), is respected." The resolution orders Israel to take back the deportees.
The Secretary General said his mediator also rejected Israeli claims that the Council's criticism of the deportations was damaging the Mideast talks.
The Secretary General's recommendation was seen by diplomats here as an open invitation to the P.L.O. and its Arab supporters to demand mandatory sanctions against Israel, and the P.L.O. promptly circulated its draft.
 
What the P.L.O. Wants
 The resolution would bar Israel from attending any meeting organized by the United Nations or any member state devoted to human rights issues or the legal instruments that govern them. This would prevent Israel from being represented at the world conference on human rights that the United Nations plans in June in Vienna.
The draft resolution would also prohibit all "trade and financial dealings" with Israeli establishments involved in the activities in the occupied territories that violate the Fourth Geneva Convention of 1949, which establishes the rights of civilians caught in occupied areas. This means, for example, that foreign companies could not supply Israel with goods used in the construction or maintenance of Israeli settlements in the territories; the Geneva Convention prohibits changing the ethnic composition of occupied territories.
The draft resolution also threatens unspecified "further measures" if Israel fails to comply with Resolution 799, which was adopted unanimously by the Council on Dec. 18. The draft calls for the Council to meet on Feb. 9 to review Israel's response.
 
Britain Opposes Sanctions
 The British Government joined Washington in saying it opposes any move to impose sanctions on Israel, arguing that this would only lead to a United States veto. But the 12 European Community countries are expected to tell the Israeli Foreign Minister, Shimon Peres, when he meets with them on Monday that Israel's request for closer economic ties with the Community will be put on hold until the problem of the deportees is resolved.
Some Western diplomats also criticized the P.L.O.'s plan to ban Israel from attending human rights meetings, arguing that the point of such meetings is to shame countries into improving their behavior by confronting them publicly with evidence of abuses.
But many countries on the Security Council are worried by the accusations that some are applying a double standard. In order to maintain credibility, many diplomats say, the Council must at least try to punish Israel for defying its orders, even if the United States vetoes the resolution.
This feeling is particularly strong among the seven developing countries with seats on the Council. These include three Muslim states, an unusually high number. They are Morocco, Pakistan and Djibouti.
