HEADLINE: 3 Aircraft Companies Announce Big Job Cutbacks as Orders Fall

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Squeezed by fewer orders for military aircraft and commercial jet airliners, three major aerospace companies announced cutbacks yesterday that will result in layoffs of thousands of workers in coming months, with Connecticut and Washington State losing most of the jobs.
Pratt & Whitney, the jet engine manufacturer with headquarters in Hartford, said that 6,700 jobs at its Connecticut plants would be eliminated during the next 24 months, including 1,800 this week. 
 The Boeing Company, the world's largest aircraft manufacturer, said it would cut back production of every model of jet airliner that the company makes -- from jumbo jets to 737's. Analysts said this could result in as many as 30,000 lost jobs through layoffs, attrition and retirement.
 
1,500 Jobs at McDonnell
 And the McDonnell Douglas Corporation announced that 1,500 white-collar jobs would be eliminated at its St. Louis headquarters. On Monday, the company had said that 8,700 jobs, or 10 percent of its remaining work force, would soon disappear, most of them production jobs at its California factories that make commercial airliners.
Responding to Pratt & Whitney's announcement, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. asked the Clinton Administration to reregulate the airline industry to end the air fare wars that have weakened the industry. [Page B1.]
"God almighty, I wish the Federal Government would get off the dime," the Governor said in calling for a restoration of the regulations that until the late 1970's gave the Federal Government the power to set air fares and distribute routes among the airlines.
The latest announcements of job cutbacks came just 24 hours after Sears, Roebuck & Company announced plans to reorganize, eliminating its famous catalogue, 113 stores and 50,000 jobs.
The flood of new job cutbacks could weaken the economic recovery that appeared to be gaining strength in last year's fourth quarter -- renewing pressure on President Clinton to try to stimulate the economy through job-creating public works projects.
Boeing was not precise about its layoffs, declining to say how many jobs might have to be eliminated as production slides to 340 new aircraft this year from 441 in 1992. But analysts estimated that the company's payroll of 130,000 employees would probably be trimmed by 30,000 people in coming months. Most of the layoffs will be in the Seattle area, where Boeing has its headquarters and has most of its factories, and in Wichita, Kan., where it also has plants.
"I had been anticipating some more cuts, but not of this order of magnitude and not this soon," said Bill Whitlow, a Boeing analyst with Pacific Crest Securities in Seattle.
The latest layoffs and job eliminations are part of a broad-gauged shrinking of the aircraft manufacturing industry, which has declined from 1.3 million jobs in 1990 to 1 million today and probably 700,000 by mid-decade, said Wolfgang Demisch, an analyst with UBS Securities.
"We're about halfway there right now," he said. "And currently we are at the fastest rate of aerospace industry job cuts."
Boeing, like McDonnell Douglas, had already trimmed staff, forced to do so by fare discounts and sagging travel that has weakened airlines here and abroad. As a result, many airlines have canceled or delayed orders that had been placed for new jetliners, among them such industry giants as American Airlines, which announced yesterday that it had reached agreement with Boeing to delay delivery of eight airliners worth $500 million. They were to have been ready starting late this year.
 
Optimistic on Long Term
 The aircraft companies put the best light they could on the new cutbacks. Dean Thorton, president of Boeing's Commercial Plane Group, said that while "the present reality is sobering," the company "remained optimistic about the longer-term prospects."
Similarly, Barbara Anderson, a McDonnell Douglas spokeswoman, predicted better days ahead. "We think this will be a pivotal year for the company in that it will establish our financial strength and viability," Ms. Anderson said, according to The Associated Press.
Only Pratt & Whitney, a division of United Technologies, with six factories in Connecticut, a state still suffering from hard times, sounded gloomy.
"Last year, Pratt & Whitney lost approximately $500 million -- these losses cannot continue," said Karl J. Krapek, the company's president, in a letter to employees. "Our goal is to make ourselves recession proof."
The stock prices of the three companies suffered yesterday. McDonnell Douglas shares fell $3.375, to $63.50; Boeing fell $1.375, to $35.50, and United Technologies slipped 12.5 cents, to $47.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Military Cutbacks Cited
 While the companies stressed the weak economy, some Defense Department officials said that many of the aerospace industry's job cuts in recent months were a result of cutbacks in the manufacture of military aircraft, although actual dollars spent by the Pentagon for aircraft had barely fallen.
"The unit costs of new planes are rising through the roof because of inefficiencies at the manufacturers," said A. Ernest Fitzgerald, a Defense Department analyst. These inefficiencies inevitably infect the commercial divisions of the aircraft manufacturers, he said, helping to force production cutbacks as costs rise beyond what the airlines can afford.
Whatever the reasons, Boeing announced that fourth-quarter earnings before an accounting charge for retiree health benefits fell 7 percent, to $377 million, or $1.11 a share, from $403 million, or $1.17 a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue fell 3 percent from the 1991 fourth quarter, to $7.5 billion.
For all of 1992, Boeing said that net income before the accounting charge rose 4 percent, to $1.64 billion, or $4.81 a share, from $1.57 billion, or $4.56 a share, in 1991. Revenue increased by 3 percent, to $30.18 billion.

HEADLINE: Job-Stimulus Plan Begins to Take Shape

 BODY:
Aides to President Clinton said that he would probably propose $15 billion to $20 billion in new Federal spending this year to stimulate employment.
The likelihood of such a proposal was confirmed by Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, who acknowledged that the figure was a modest one, given the context of a $6 trillion economy. 
 But he insisted that it would have an important psychological impact, sending "a very clear signal that we have got to get the growth back."
It would also be a signal to the financial markets that the new Administration intends to be restrained in spending on jobs, so that the deficit is not seriously worsened or inflation spurred.
Both Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and the White House budget director, Leon E. Panetta, have urged restraint in the development of any stimulus package, and their advice seems to have won the day.
Article, page A15.

HEADLINE: Asking 'What Can I Do?' And Giving to Neediest

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
New Yorkers sometimes feel that to survive in their city, they must steel themselves to the poverty that spills onto the sidewalks. Perhaps they force themselves to tune out pleas for spare change or to ignore a haggard woman sleeping in a box near their apartments. But every so often an experience may pierce that armor.
At that point, when they no longer can turn away, they might ask: "What can I do?" For some, the answer is to contribute to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which rescues thousands of people every year who might otherwise spend their days suffering and devoid of hope. 
 "I sent one check earlier this year -- never as much as I'd like," wrote a Manhattan woman who asked that her name not be used. "Then I saw a very presentable, clean older lady searching in a Dumpster outside a supermarket. I didn't have much with me to help her then, but it haunts me." The woman gave $75 as her second donation to the Neediest Cases.
Alan H. Vorchheimer of Manhattan gave $600, explaining that he and his wife, Leslie J. Lane, were dedicating their donation to the homeless. "My wife sees a homeless woman on the subway each day on her way to work," Mr. Vorchheimer wrote. "Hopefully, our gift can make these peoples' lives a little less hurtful."
 
'Look of Total Despair'
 With her check for $1,100, Pilar Crespi of Manhattan sent a note describing how sad she felt when she walked past people living on the streets. "I will never get used to the sight of the many homeless wandering around this city with a look of total despair," she wrote.
And Jane Bender of Manhattan gave $35. "As a social worker, I see the ravages that poverty, homelessness, drug abuse and illness cause and thus hope I can help a little," she wrote.
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund supports seven charities that are coming to the aid of newly unemployed people whose lives have been thrown into turmoil because of the recession. The Times pays the fund's expenses, so all contributions go directly to the charities. This year's campaign, the 81st, ends on Feb. 28.
Jane and Bill Stubenbord of Manhattan gave $100 to the Neediest Cases in honor of their two daughters, who volunteer in homeless shelters in New York and San Francisco. And Rose M. Lucas of Flushing, Queens, sent a letter explaining that she tried to think of ways to end homelessness.
"I see so many pathetic things that no one seems to be able to handle," she wrote. "I often wonder where are the friends and relatives of the homeless. If a homeless person has seven friends and each one takes him or her in for one night until other arrangements can be made, that would get the person off the street."
"I wonder," she added, "if anything can help."

HEADLINE: Dinkins Tells Legislators Of Burdens

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 26

 BODY:
With more assertiveness than in past visits to Albany, Mayor David N. Dinkins today charged the state with shifting its financial problems onto the city in recent years, and pleaded for "a change of posture in Albany."
The Mayor, who plans to unveil his proposal for filling a $2.1 billion budget gap on Friday, said the city had absorbed "an astonishing $1.1 billion in shifted costs since 1990." 
 Speaking at a hearing on the state budget held by the Assembly Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee, Mr. Dinkins asked legislators to reverse that trend by refusing to pass any budget that does not include a plan for the state to assume Medicaid costs currently paid by local governments.
Mr. Dinkins minced few words in blaming the Legislature and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo for imposing both budget cuts and tax increases that he said have had a disproportionate impact on the city.
 
'Deficit Shifting'
 "Time and again the state has asked local governments to carry a heavy fiscal load," Mr. Dinkins said. "And after we have done so, we have been asked to carry even more."
Mr. Dinkins and his aides provided only partial substantiation for the Mayor's calculation of $1.1 billion in shifted costs. They said the number included reductions in unrestricted state aid for local governments, cuts in probation spending, caps placed on state reimbursement for foster care and other social-service programs, cuts in school transportation spending and programs for handicapped preschoolers, and cuts in state aid to the City University of New York.
Cuomo administration aides were quick to dispute Mr. Dinkins's arithmetic and to charge that he omitted mention of state initiatives that had saved the city money, including Medicaid cuts and fiscal reforms that have reduced debt payments.
Mr. Cuomo canceled a meeting and news conference with Mr. Dinkins scheduled to follow the Mayor's appearance at the hearing. The Governor's press secretary, Anne W. Crowley, said Mr. Cuomo had to attend to other business and had not even heard about Mr. Dinkins's remarks when he scrapped the meeting.
The argument that the state has shifted costs to local governments during the recession is not a new one, either for Mr. Dinkins or for county executives. Just as Mr. Cuomo has complained that the Federal Government has shifted an undue burden to the states, local officials have maintained that the state has passed the burden to cities and counties.
But what was new today was Mr. Dinkins's tone. While he spoke in the formal idiom that defines his political persona -- "one has to look at whence cometh," he said at one point -- his message carried the indignation often shown during budget hearings by his predecessor, Edward I. Koch.
The change may have less to do with any personal transformation than with election-year politics. In a year when he faces a tough campaign against both Democrats and Republicans, Mr. Dinkins is saddled with a budget shortfall that his aides said is now $2.1 billion.
Until today the Dinkins administration had projected the gap to be $1.6 billion, but that figure did not reflect the cost of a recent labor settlement with municipal unions or the impact of declining property tax revenues.
When Mr. Dinkins proposes his budget on Friday, he will seek about $600 million in help from the state.
The issue that the Mayor chose to focus on today was taking over Medicaid. Mr. Cuomo first suggested the takeover in the fall of 1991, proposing that the state would assume all local Medicaid costs by the year 2000 in exchange for the revenues generated by the city's personal income tax and up to 1 percentage point of the sales tax in counties outside the city.
The plan has been greeted warily by the Republicans who control the State Senate. They have proposed an alternative that would require deeper cuts in Medicaid but would not call for the state to take taxing authority from local governments.

HEADLINE: Russian Sensitivities;
As Choices Become Harder, Moscow Grows Skeptical About U.S. Policies

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 26

 BODY:
For Russia the conflicts in Iraq and Yugoslavia have posed an increasingly wrenching choice between traditional allies and a longing for a new partnership with Washington and the West.
It is a predicament that has stoked a bitter political struggle at home. Abroad it has made Moscow increasingly sensitive to Washington's intentions and methods abroad and has set the stage for an open dispute over any increase of force against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq or the Serbs in Bosnia and Herzegovina. 
 Russia's smoldering annoyance with United States policy broke into the open on Monday, when President Boris N. Yeltsin accused Washington of a tendency to "dictate terms" in regions like Iraq and Yugoslavia and expressed the hope that President Clinton would be more open to a dialogue.
Mr. Yeltsin's comments seemed not only to reflect frustration at being taken for granted by purported "partners" in Washington, about whose strikes on Iraq he learned only from news reports, but also irritation over the ammunition that his many political foes have derived from the air strikes on Iraq and the ostracism of the Serbs.
Mr. Yeltsin said Russia would seek to maintain a "balance of political interests," hinting that he may be moving away from the staunchly pro-Western foreign policy championed by the liberal Foreign Minister, Andrei Kozyrev.
 
New Sharing of Roles
 That impression was strengthened today, when Mr. Yeltsin signed a decree assigning coordination of foreign policy to the Security Council, which includes military and security officials in addition to the Foreign Minister. Three months ago Mr. Yeltsin assigned the leadership role in foreign policy to the Foreign Ministry.
According to Russian officials and Western diplomats, however, the actions were probably not so much a turn against Washington as they were more of the vacillations that have marked Russia's foreign relations as a result of the bitter institutional and political struggles over what place Russia should seek in the post-Communist world.
The vacillations have not been limited to Russia. The United States and the West also have yet to sort out the complexities of a world suddenly wrenched from the rigid discipline of two power centers.
If the collapse of the Soviet Union initially seemed to promise a "new world order" supervised in partnership by East and West, the reality has been an eruption of pent-up feuds and a multiplication of new challenges. Yugoslavia would never have indulged in internal feuds as long as it feared for its tenuous neutrality between East and West, and the United States would not have dared bomb Iraq as long as it was in the Soviet sphere of influence.
 
'New Thinking' by Gorbachev
 It was also inevitable that the loss of influence and power would be bitterly resisted by those who took pride or drew sustenance from Soviet might like generals, Communist stalwarts and military contractors.
The struggle began long before the collapse of the Soviet Union, when President Mikhail S. Gorbachev proclaimed a "new thinking" in foreign policy and pulled Moscow away from the arms race, East Europe and Afghanistan. Already die-hard Communists inveighed against what they perceived as surrender to the ideological foe.
In the first action against Iraq two years ago, Mr. Gorbachev took an ambivalent stance, backing the American-led alliance while sending a personal ally on an independent and ultimately futile mediating mission.
With the disintegration of the Soviet state, Mr. Yeltsin proclaimed principles that went beyond Mr. Gorbachev's, seeking rapid integration into the institutions of the "civilized" world, partnership with the United States and a military doctrine of "minimum sufficiency." He named as Foreign Minister Mr. Kozyrev, who sought from the outset to link Russia's foreign policy to Washington and the West.
 
New Muddle Injected
 But instead of uniting behind the new policy, Russia fell into an even angrier debate. The rise of 14 neighbors out of the former Soviet republics, all confused, bankrupt and ambitious, injected a new foreign-policy muddle that neither Moscow nor any of the other republics has sorted out.
Beyond the new cordon, there were equally perplexing and often humiliating questions. Was Russia the successor to Soviet superpower and strategic interests or was it simply a bankrupt landmass saddled with a defunct empire's missiles? Was it moving toward rapid integration in the democratic, market-oriented West or was it fated to remain aside, a vast land ever balanced between East and West but part of neither? What was Russia's "national interest" in the new world? Was it necessary or useful to maintain strategic parity with the United States?
There were other questions. In the absence of Communist control, who ran foreign policy? Furious turf battles broke out almost from the outset. The Foreign Ministry, the Parliament, Mr. Yeltsin's aides, the military and other institutions plunged into the fray, accusing one another of surrendering Russia's interests, of plotting fascist coups and of kowtowing to America.
It was inevitable that Yugoslavia and Iraq, and relations with the United States, would become major battlegrounds.
 
The Washington Romp
 It was not so much that Russia's "national patriots" were enflamed by sympathy for their fellow Orthodox Slavs in the Balkans or for a wily former arms client in the Middle East. It was more the sense of humiliation in the spectacle of Moscow's currying favor with the West while Washington was romping around the world without any regard for Moscow's traditional ties or sensitivites.
Not only the hard-liners were irritated. A proud man who put great stock in having Russia treated as a great power, Mr. Yeltsin also gave hints before this week of his resentment. Many mainstream politicians and academics joined in urging a more conservative foreign policy than Mr. Kozyrev was espousing, especially when it became evident that the United States was not rushing to embrace Russia or to shower it with investment and aid.
In the Parliament and in the press, the polemics often became frenzied. Last month Mr. Kozyrev gave an extraordinary speech to a stunned international forum in Stockholm in which he compiled the demands of the hard-liners into what he pretended was his own position.
The Parliament, for its part, has assailed Mr. Kozyrev at every opportunity. On the far right, the newspaper Den has mercilessly criticized Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Kozyrev and their "occupation regime."
In its current issue Den published what it said was a transcript of private conversations between President Bush and Mr. Yeltsin at their meeting in Moscow on Jan. 3 under the headline "Your Commands Have Been Fulfilled, Mr. Bush." Among the passages that the newspaper underlined as especially onerous was one in which Mr. Yeltsin said to Mr. Bush, "You asked that we keep Kozyrev in place, and we met your request."
In the political center, meanwhile, the notion is taking hold that in foreign policy, as in politics and economics, Russia will have to sort out its own priorities and problems before it can expect to join the "civilized world." It will also have to be more cautious, as the United States and the West determine their courses.
At the low-key start of a USA-Russia Foundation to promote understanding, the director, Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, once Mr. Gorbachev's partner in perestroika, declared that it was for Russia to sort out whether its national interests lay with the United States, with Europe or in a balance between East and West. For the present, he said, "we need to watch carefully the development of the new administration in the U.S."

HEADLINE: Israel Rejects U.N. Chief's Proposals on Deportees

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Israel, edging closer to a confrontation with the United Nations, today angrily rejected Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali's recommendation for Security Council measures to force the return of roughly 400 Palestinians deported to Lebanon six weeks ago.
Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, responding to Mr. Boutros-Ghali's move, accused the Secretary General of employing a double standard by "completely ignoring extremist Islamic terrorism" that he said had made the deportations necessary. 
 Other senior officials reacted sharply to a proposal by Mr. Boutros-Ghali for United Nations' monitoring Israel's treatment of the 1.8 million Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. That was not needed, the Foreign Ministry said, because under international law, responsibility for the Palestinians' "safety, peace and welfare" fell to Israel as the ruling power in the territories.
 Although the Rabin Government struck a combative stance, it was clear that it had lost ground in its fight to head off sanctions for violating Security Council Resolution 799. Approved unanimously on Dec. 18, it demands the return of the hundreds of expelled Islamic fundamentalists and sympathizers.
 
Report on Monday
 Hoping to buy time, the Government has also urged all parties to do nothing until after the High Court of Justice here decides whether the deportations were legal, a ruling that is expected this week. Israeli newspapers have speculated about possible compromises that would shorten the announced exile of up to two years, but all actions have been delayed until the court acts.
Mr. Boutros-Ghali, who gave a report of his findings to the Council late Monday night, did not recommend specific measures against Israel. But some officials here expect the next move to be a United Nations timetable to return the Palestinians from their tent camp in southern Lebanon. The move may be accompanied, they say, by a threat of sanctions, which Israel has never had to face despite having flouted many Council resolutions.
As in the past, the Israelis are counting on the United States to stand by them, even though the United States, too, had voted for Resolution 799, which called the deportations a breach of international law, specifically the Fourth Geneva Convention of 1949.
The Israelis were encouraged today when the American Ambassador, William C. Harrop, said in a radio interview that it was "most unlikely that the United States would want to see sanctions" imposed. But Mr. Harrop quickly added: "We've not used our veto for two years. We don't want to do that, either."
 
Reluctance to Exercise Veto
 The Ambassador said the Clinton Administration wished "to continue a very close relationship with Israel."
Mr. Rabin echoed those sentiments, telling a parliamentary committee: "Until now, no American Administration has allowed sanctions against the State of Israel. I hope this will continue."
From Mr. Harrop's remarks, it seems that Washington wants the deportation crisis to be resolved before it is forced to choose between voting against Israel and exercising its veto in the Council, an action that has gone out of fashion as the United Nations has become an important vehicle for American foreign policy.
Mr. Boutros-Ghali's report caught the Israelis somewhat off guard. Not that it was a complete surprise, especially after three missions by United Nations emissaries had failed to budge Mr. Rabin from his positions that the expulsions stand and that to bring the exiles back now would be to hand a victory to his primary target, the Hamas group of militant fundamentalists.
The Secretary General warned that the Israeli refusal challenged the Security Council's authority. And he seemed to endorse the arguments of Arab states and some other countries that a double standard had been created in the way resolutions against Iraq were enforced, but not those against Israel.
In the last few days Israel has turned the double-standard argument around, saying that it is the victim, because the United Nations and other international bodies have solely condemned the deportations, and not the Hamas violence that led to them, including the killing of Israeli servicemen in December.
"They are completely ignoring extremist Islamic terrorism, completely ignoring the aim of this terrorism to bring about the end of the peace process," Mr. Rabin said. "The report is an example of double standards." The demand that the Security Council adopt new measures, he said, was almost unprecedented.
Foreign Minister Shimon Peres said, "If the United Nations wants to control Israel, it must answer how they're going to control the dangers which are facing Israel." Mr. Peres repeated warnings that stern action against Israel could imperil the peace talks by forcing the Arabs into added hard-line positions. But Mr. Boutros-Ghali's report quoted a United Nations emissary, Chinmaya Gharekhan, as having said Israel would be responsible if the talks broke down.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, above, accused Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali of employing a double standard by "completely ignoring extremist Islamic terrorism" that he said had made the deportations necessary. He flew yesterday to Northern Israel. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Chrysler stock is on the rise despite threat of dilution.

BYLINE: By Doron P. Levin

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
THE Chrysler Corporation's rebound has been nowhere more evident than in the vitality of its common stock. The shares rose steadily in the last week despite the auto maker's decision to try to raise perhaps as much as $1.5 billion by offering 40 million new shares.
Although the new common stock would cause a 12 percent dilution for current holders of Chrysler stock, and after an initial drop in price following the announcement, the shares closed yesterday at $40 each, up 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. That compares with $36 before the announcement on Jan.11. 
 From Main Street to Wall Street, Chrysler is being applauded as an ugly duckling-turned-swan. After years of producing mediocre cars, a period when the mini-van was Chrysler's mainstay, a parade of hits has suddenly arrived: the Jeep Grand Cherokee sport-utility vehicle, the L/H midsize sedans and the new Dodge Ram pickup, which isn't in production yet but attracted effusive praise from reviewers at the North American International Auto Show early this month.
According to Zack's Investment Research, among 19 analysts, 11 rated Chrysler a strong or moderately strong buy, 7 were neutral and only one recommended selling.
For investors, the relevant question is: Can Chrysler shares go much higher? Automotive analysts won't discuss this question for the record, since most brokerage firms are part of -- or wish to be included in -- the syndicate that will sell Chrysler's new shares within a few weeks.
 However, trading by the auto maker's top officers, which is reported publicly under Federal securities law, shows that Chrysler officers were invariably sellers as the stock climbed from $20 to $30 a share during the summer and fall.
That could show that officers believe the company's fortunes have peaked. David Coleman of the Vicker's Stock Research Corporation in Washington, D.C., calls insider selling "a reliable indicator that share prices are peaking or leveling off."
However, because of Chrysler's poor financial performance "executives haven't had bonuses in three years," said Arthur C. Liebler, Chrysler's vice president for public relations, who was among the sellers. He said most of the sales were connected to exercise of executive stock options, which previously were "under water" because Chrysler's share price was low.
In any case, most financial analysts have been watching the reception of Chrysler's new models, recognizing the company's limited exposure in the deteriorating European market, factoring in the slowly strengthening economy and raising their estimates of 1993 earnings.
Still, Chrysler faces risks. First is the state of the economy and economic components like employment and personal income, whose weakness could choke off the slow but steady recovery in automotive demand since October.
Second is the auto maker's financial condition, which is better than it has been for several years but is still weak. The credit rating agencies expect Chrysler to use some of the proceeds from the stock offering to cut back its $4 billion unfunded pension liability.
Finally, because so much is riding on the L/H sedans, Chrysler must avoid any problems like those that occurred early in 1991 with the Ultradrive transmission, resulting in a warning against Chrysler vehicles from Consumers Union. The L/H already has experienced some minor glitches, like the failure to install antilock brakes in some cars in which the equipment was ordered and paid for by customers.

HEADLINE: $15 Billion Jobs Effort Is Called Likely

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration, confronting a new round of huge layoffs in some leading American industries, said today that the President was likely to propose $15 billion to $20 billion in additional Federal spending this year to stimulate job growth.
Since the election Mr. Clinton's economic advisers have been debating how much new spending and what tax credits they should propose to create jobs and how that increased spending should be coupled with longer-term measures to shrink the budget deficit. 
 In the campaign Mr. Clinton and his advisers talked about a stimulus in the range of $20 billion to $30 billion. But since the election there has been pressure from some quarters to raise that figure and, from others, to lower it.
Some of the more liberal economists close to Mr. Clinton, like the Nobel laureate James Tobin, have advocated $60 billion in increased spending. Other advisers, pointing to signs of recovery and estimates of bigger deficits than expected, have suggested reducing the stimulus or foregoing it altogether.
Mr. Clinton himself has been very careful not to tip his hand. But in the most clear indication yet of the shape of the new Administration's economic package, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said in an interview on the ABC News program "Good Morning America" today that there would probably be a stimulus package and that it would probably be "in the range of $15 billion to $20 billion."
Mr. Reich acknowledged that this was a rather paltry figure in the context of a $6 trillion economy, but he insisted that it would have an important psychological impact, sending "a very clear signal that we have got to get the growth back."
It would also be a signal to the financial markets, though, that the new Democratic Administration intends to be restrained in spending on jobs, so that the deficit is not seriously aggravated or inflation spurred in ways that could frighten the bond markets.
Both Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and the budget director, Leon E. Panetta, have urged a modest stimulus package, and their advice seems to have won the day. The package will probably consist of accelerated Government spending on highway, rail and fiber-optic projects, plus investment tax credits for companies spending on new equipment.
 
No Jobs, No Recovery
 "On the job front, we still have a problem, and we can't have a genuine recovery, a real booming, buoyant recovery, until we get those jobs back, so we may have to have a little bit of a stimulus," Mr. Reich said. "But in the longer term, that is, beginning next year right on through 1997, we are going to have to tackle the budget deficit and also public investment. Those are the twin deficits that President Clinton has promised the American public we are going to tackle, and we will be tackling them."
Mr. Reich's remarks, which appeared to be calculated to see how Wall Street and businesses react to the modest stimulus numbers, were immediately reinforced at the noon briefing by George Stephanopoulos, the White House Communications director.
He confirmed that the Administration would offer a stimulus package, but he said it was likely to be even a little higher than the figures mentioned by the Labor Secretary. Mr. Stephanopoulos said the full package would be outlined by Mr. Clinton in his State of the Union Message on Feb. 17.
A senior Administration economic official said Mr. Clinton was opting for a modest stimulus, as opposed to either a large one or none at all, for three main reasons.
First, he said, is the fact that while the economy now appears to be recovering to some degree on its own, without any additional Government help, it is a "jobless recovery." Unemployment, which was at 7.3 percent in December, has actually gone up as the recession has ended. This state of affairs was underscored this week when a string of corporate titans, including Sears, I.B.M., Boeing and United Technologies, all announced large-scale layoffs for 1993.
The second reason, the official said, was a fear that even the current recovery is more of a "feel good" recovery. Consumers have increased their spending in the hope that the new President will turn the economy around, but it is money taken from their savings, not from higher incomes. This increase in spending could turn out to be short-lived unless industry starts investing more money in new plants or equipment and creating large numbers of jobs.
The third reason was called insurance. Even if there is only a 25 percent to 30 percent chance of the economy slipping back into recession, the official said, $20 billion in additional Government spending right now, even at the cost of a higher deficit, is a small price to pay to insure against that.
In addition, the official observed, the financial markets have come to expect some sort of stimulus, and if the Administration retreated from that idea entirely it could create a lot of negative expectations.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, speaking of the Administration's economic proposals, said that there would probably be a stimulus package and that it would probably be "in the range of $15 billion to $20 billion." Mr. Reich testified yesterday before a House subcommittee on education and labor. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Clinton Choice for Latin Post Stirs Feud Between 2 Groups

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Early indications that the Clinton Administration was moving to select a Cuban-American lawyer for the State Department's senior Latin America post have provoked a bitter fight between two constituencies the Clinton Administration had hoped to please with the nomination: Cuban-Americans and blacks.
For the last week, the formal nomination of Mario L. Baeza, a Wall Street lawyer who has specialized in privatization in Latin America, has been held up by the protests of conservative Miami-based Cuban-American groups, backed by influential Democratic lawmakers, who say they suspect Mr. Baeza of softness toward the Government of Fidel Castro. 
 After having reportedly been the only person interviewed for the job of Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, the candidacy of Mr. Baeza, a Cuban-born American who is black, collided with the strenuous objections of Cuban-American lobbyists, supported by members of Congress from New Jersey and Florida.
 
Name Dropped From List
 On the eve of Mr. Clinton's inauguration, Mr. Baeza's candidacy appeared doomed when his name was crossed out on a list sent to Congress of Clinton Administration appointees to senior State Department positions. The Bush Administration's appointee, Bernard W. Aronson, remains on the job.
But in the last several days a defense of Mr. Baeza has been mounted by black lawmakers who have expressed resentment for the treatment of the 42-year-old lawyer. Members of the Congressional Black Caucus, which has written the Clinton Administration in support of Mr. Baeza's candidacy, have angrily denounced assertions that the lawyer is a sympathizer of Mr. Castro.
"We have to appeal to the Clinton Administration to explain to us why this guy is not acceptable," Rep. Charles B. Rangel said. "If there is some flaw in his credentials, tell us. If not, put the nomination forward and let the man be heard."
Opponents of Mr. Baeza's candidacy have cited a half-day trip to Cuba he took last July to participate in a seminar on Cuba's fledgling efforts to privatize parts of its economy as evidence of Mr. Baeza's softness toward Havana.
"According to participants, he spoke openly about promoting American investment in Cuba," said Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey.
Mr. Baeza has declined to speak directly about his candidacy, but on Monday, he denied the allegations.
"My purpose in attending that meeting was seeing how soon Castro is going to fall, what are the consequences and whether the privatizations there involving Spain, Italy and France had had any success," he said. The seminar was attended by executives from many United States corporations.
Since Mr. Baeza's name was scratched from the list of nominees sent to Congress, Clinton Administration officials have declined to speak about him. But Administration officials say that attention has turned to another candidate for the job, Sally Shelton Colby. Mrs. Colby, who is white, is a specialist in Latin American affairs and a former ambassador to the Eastern Caribbean under the Carter Administration.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Drug Giants Show Gains In Earnings

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Two large drug companies, Merck and Warner-Lambert, announced double-digit earnings growth yesterday, but investors seemed preoccupied with national trends that may limit future pharmaceutical profits. Drug stock prices have been declining on reports that the Clinton Administration expects to produce a national health-care program by May.
Trying to stave off price controls, Merck and eight other drug companies -- not including Warner-Lambert -- have promised to limit their increases to the general inflation rate. Industry executives told the Clinton transition team that drugs should be included in a standard health package for American families. But some companies remain wary of proposals that might involve deep discounts for elderly Medicare patients, who buy 40 percent of prescription drugs. 
 Merck & Company, based in White House Station, N.J., said earnings rose 17 percent, to $618.9 million, in the fourth quarter of 1992, before noncash accounting charges. After the charges, earnings in the quarter were up 15 percent, compared with the comparable period a year earlier.
 
 
Full-Year Earnings
 Profit for all of 1992 was down by 6 percent, after the charges, which recognized future health-care and disability costs and made a change in tax accounting. It was Merck's first decline in 12-month earnings since it was hit by unfavorable foreign exchange developments in 1981.
Merck sales increased 12 percent in the quarter, to $2.6 billion, from $2.31 billion in the 1991 period. Earnings per share were 53 cents, up from 46 cents.
The company told analysts that earnings would rise by 14 percent to 16 percent in 1993, down slightly from last year's 17 percent growth. Neil B. Sweig at Capital Institutional Services in New York said the costs of promoting Proscar, Merck's new prostate treatment, might be $150 million by December. But he said Proscar could have $250 million in 1993 sales, up from $55 million last year.
 
Warner-Lambert
 The Warner-Lambert Company, based in Morris Plains, N.J., which had made similar accounting changes in 1991, said earnings in the quarter increased 14 percent, to $138 million, excluding the one-time charges a year earlier. Sales were a record $1.47 billion.
Quarterly earnings per share rose 13 percent, to $1.02, compared with 90 cents in the final three months of 1991.
Warner-Lambert said sales increased 11 percent, to a record $5.6 billion for all of last year.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Northern Telecom's Earnings Increase 23%

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Partly by taking business away from A.T.& T. and other telecommunications rivals, Northern Telecom of Canada was able to report a 23 percent gain in fourth-quarter earnings, to $255.6 million, or $1.02 a share. Quarterly revenue rose 10 percent, to $2.54 billion, from $2.306 billion a year ago. All figures are in United States dollars.
"We've been gaining market share from many of our competitors," Paul G. Stern, Northern Telecom's chairman and chief executive, said . 
 For years, Northern Telecom had been an also-ran in the sale of telecommunications equipment to the world's telephone companies. Its rival equipment manufacturer, A.T.& T., dominated North America; Alcatel of France and Siemens of Germany led Europe; Nippon Telegraph and Telephone and its longtime suppliers had locked up Japan.
But as the company helped pioneer new versions of switching equipment, the huge computers that route millions of telephone calls a day, its business has prospered. Northern Telecom is the leading supplier of fully digital telephone switches.
Sales of such equipment began to take off as the world's telephone carriers, especially those of the United States, switched to digital machines.
Increasing privatization also helped. In the United States, carriers like MCI, rivals to American Telephone and Telegraph, made it a practice of buying non-A.T.& T. equipment. In Europe, because A.T.& T.'s main business is selling long-distance telephone calls in competition with European carriers, these phone companies have also tended to buy from non-A.T.& T. vendors.
As a result, Northern Telecom has prospered despite a dour world economy. Four years ago, the company's business outside North America was only 8 percent; today, the proportion is 25 percent.
Northern Telecom said that some business was drummed up with discounts. "Although competitive pricing pressures in our central office switching business led to lower gross profit margins," the company said in a statement, "we were able to offset this with cost controls."

HEADLINE: Data Show Region's Slump Among the Worst in the U.S.

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
With their economies battered by some of the worst construction slumps in the nation and the loss of thousands of armaments jobs, Connecticut, New Jersey and New York have been among the slowest states to recover from the recession, according to figures released today by the Commerce Department.
The statistics for total personal income showed Connecticut making the poorest showing in the region, with 3.2 percent growth over the 18 months that the nation was pulling out of the recession. 
 That placed the state 48th nationally; only Florida and Hawaii fared worse, and officials attributed their low numbers to major storms late last year.
Avice Meehan, a spokeswoman for Connecticut's Governor, Lowell P. Weicker Jr., said the numbers squared with their expectations. "I don't know if it would take a rocket scientist to predict that this was the case," she said.
New York ranked 39th nationally, with 3.9 percent growth in personal income, while New Jersey was 41st with 3.8 percent.
 
Slower Than Annual Rates
 Nationally, incomes grew at an annual rate of 4.4 percent from the first quarter of 1991, the low point of the recession, through last September, when figures showed that the recovery was fully under way.
Nationwide, prices rose at an annual rate of 3.2 percent during the six-quarter recovery period.
Personal income is the income received by people from all sources before the deduction of income taxes and other taxes. Therefore, it is a reliable and highly accurate gauge of an economy's performance. Federal and state governments use the figures to forecast income and to help develop their budgets.
Montana led the nation with a 7.3 percent growth rate in personal income.
The New England region, which includes Connecticut, and the Mideast region, which includes New York and New Jersey, were rated at the bottom in income growth at 4.0 and 3.6 percent respectively.
 
Problems Facing Connecticut
 Connecticut's problems are two-fold, the report said.
It is in one of the regions hardest hit by the recession -- which Federal officials say began in July 1990 and ended eight months later in March 1991. And cutbacks in military spending forced thousands of layoffs by some of the state's biggest employers, including a new round today at Pratt & Whitney.
In per-capita income, Connecticut, New Jersey and New York are among the wealthiest states in the nation. The annual per-capita income figures, determined by dividing a state's total personal income by the total population, are expected to be released in April. In recent years, Connecticut and New Jersey have finished first and second in per-capita income, masking the economic turmoil evident in today's report.
"They are affluent states, but that does not mean that there is no poverty," said Ms. Meehan, Governor Weicker's spokeswoman. "No single number tells an entire story."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
I.B.M. TO REPLACE ITS TOP EXECUTIVE

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
I.B.M. announced yesterday that it was starting a search to replace its chief executive, John F. Akers, within three months. The company also cut its dividend payments to shareholders for the first time in its 79-year history, reducing the quarterly payout to 54 cents from $1.21.
The moves, coming just a week after the International Business Machines Corporation reported the largest yearly loss in corporate history, are a recognition of the deep troubles at the world's largest computer company and its need for new leadership. 
 The pressure on Mr. Akers had been mounting for months, with large institutional shareholders became increasingly outspoken as they watched I.B.M.'s share price drop to half what it had been in the summer. Business magazines including Business Week, Fortune and The Economist called on Mr. Akers to step down. Rumors about his departure swirled daily within I.B.M.
 
Some Elements of Surprise
 Still, the timing of the announcement surprised many analysts and its details were a well-kept secret, especially for a company that has a sizable cottage industry of people who follow it, including many former I.B.M. executives. The plan for Mr. Akers to step down came together fairly quickly, although he had discussed it for weeks with a few board members, according to one outside director.
A small group of executives worked on the particulars over the weekend, and Mr. Akers formally presented the plan to the 18-member board on Monday during a two-day board meeting at I.B.M.'s former headquarters building in Manhattan, at 590 Madison Avenue.
There was "spirited debate" at the meeting, James E. Burke, an outside director and a retired chairman of Johnson & Johnson, said in an interview. But that debate, he added, was mainly about details of the proposal, which he declined to discuss, not about whether Mr. Akers should go.
"The basic decision was his, and it was made in consultation with the board," Mr. Burke said. "This wasn't a board room coup or anything like that."
Most analysts say that given recent events, Mr. Akers would have had to step down, with only the timing in question. "Akers recognized reality," said Dan Mandresh, an analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company. "There's no way he could have withstood the pressure for long."
The transition plan calls for a new chief executive to be named within 90 days. Mr. Akers will remain as chairman and chief executive during the selection process. But the choice will be made by a committee of outside directors, headed by Mr. Burke.
After a new chief executive is selected, Mr. Akers could stay on as chairman, a company spokesman said. But analysts and management experts say that seems unlikely because the board approved other changes yesterday that essentially clears out the top management team that Mr. Akers has headed.
Jack D. Kuehler, the president, will move out of that position to become a vice chairman and remain on the board. Frank A. Metz Jr., a senior vice president and chief financial officer, will resign in February. He will be replaced by Paul J. Rizzo, a one-time rival of Mr. Akers for the chief executive slot, who was called back to I.B.M. last month from his post as the dean of the University of North Carolina's graduate school of business.
 
Once a Model Company
 Mr. Akers, 59, became I.B.M.'s chief executive in 1985 at a time when the company dominated the world computer industry and its management was viewed as a business-school model of excellence. But its prowess and its image have deteriorated considerably. It has struggled, often unsuccessfully, to keep up with the pace of innovation in the fast-changing computer industry.
The company has particularly lagged in adjusting to the shift by its corporate customers away from big mainframe computers, I.B.M.'s traditional strength, and toward less expensive but increasingly powerful small machines, personal computers and work stations. Consequently, it saw more and more business slip away to personal computer makers like Apple, Compaq and Dell, and work station producers like Sun Microsystems and Hewlett-Packard.
Mr. Akers came from the mainframe marketing side of the business, and critics say he and his team were slow to recognize the changes in the industry. Still, Mr. Akers did oversee a drastic streamlining of the company, cutting the work force from more than 400,000 people to 300,000 by the end of last year. He also tried to make the company more flexible and quick on its feet with a sweeping overhaul in late 1991, dividing the company into 13 businesses.
Yet the changes, though dramatic by I.B.M. standards, have not proved enough to stop the company's slippage. Last week, I.B.M. reported a loss in 1992 of $4.97 billion, though much of that was from huge accounting charges related to the efforts to cut the work force and streamline operations. Its stock price has fallen from about $100 a share in the summer to $48.875 yesterday, up 12.5 cents for the day.
"I.B.M. recognized some time ago the need for genuine change, and it just couldn't make it happen," said Jon Katzenbach, a director of McKinsey & Company. "It's a classic example of how difficult it is to change the practices and behavior in huge organizations."
The choice of Mr. Akers's replacement will be crucial for I.B.M.'s future. The board's nominating and executive compensation committee, headed by Mr. Burke, is just beginning that process and it says it will consider both I.B.M. insiders and people from outside the company.
Management experts say that the board must either choose an outsider or some younger member of the I.B.M. management corps who is not steeped in company traditions, a bit of a maverick.
"To come back, I.B.M. has to change its culture," said John Kotter, a professor at the Harvard Business School. "And the only way to do that is with truly new leadership, someone not wedded to the old ways."
In a statement and in an internal memo to company employees, Mr. Akers seemed to concede that point. In both, he stressed the achievements during his eight-year tenure, notably the reorganizing and streamlining of the company. Yet, he said in his statement, "It is the right time in I.B.M.'s business transformation to identify new leadership."
Under normal circumstances, Mr. Akers, who turned 59 last month, would have retired a year from now at age 60, the traditional retirement point for I.B.M. executives. Like any other retiree, he will receive benefits based on his salary and years of service. According to the company's proxy statement last year, that will be about $1.2 million a year.
Even with that, he has been dealt a double financial blow from the slide in I.B.M.'s stock price. The value of his personal holdings has declined and most of his stock options are probably worthless, since they become valuable only when the stock price rises."

HEADLINE: Canada Seeks an Exemption As U.S. Prepares Steel Duties

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
As the Commerce Department put the finishing touches on preliminary new steel import tariffs, Canadian officials said today that they were attempting to win an exemption for Canadian steel from the Clinton Administration.
Michael Wilson, Canada's Trade Minister, has called Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, to discuss ways to strike a separate deal, the Canadian officials said. The United States is expected to announce tariffs on up to 20 countries, including Canada, on Wednesday. 
 High-profile trade cases like the steel industry's current one are often settled through special deals, as foreign governments bring diplomatic pressure to bear on behalf of their industries. The result is usually a limit on the volume of imports or a minimum price for imports. Such deals deprive the Federal Government of tax revenues but provide some assistance for domestic producers and are less likely to generate consumer anger or a trade war.
 
A Complex Process
 Though the Commerce Department is widely viewed as simply ruling in favor of tariffs or against them, in reality its decision often has little to do with tariffs.
Washington trade experts and the Canadian officials said that Commerce Department civil servants would decide the level of tariffs based on complicated computer models of pricing practices, so that the rulings would not provide any indication of the Clinton Administration's trade policy. Federal trade law specifies the economic variables used in the model, but the civil servants have some discretion in whether they choose the importer's statistics for these variables or the domestic industry's statistics.
Political appointees can strongly influence the outcome of the computer models by ordering the civil servants who operate the computers to make certain choices about which statistics are used. But Mr. Brown, a former lawyer and lobbyist, has not yet assembled a team of subordinates with the experience in trade cases to make such decisions.
The Clinton Administration will have a chance to put its stamp on the steel case in June, when Federal law requires it to complete a review of the preliminary tariffs and decide whether to make them permanent. The preliminary tariffs can be paid by posting a bond that is forfeited if the tariffs become permanent.
 
Canada's Reasoning
 The Canadian officials said that their industry deserved separate treatment because of its close integration with American producers.
The domestic steel industry has forced the Commerce Department to review whether tariffs are necessary by filing a series of legal complaints at the department last summer. The complaints charged that foreign countries were violating Federal law by subsidizing steel shipments to the United States and by selling flat-rolled and plate steel in the United States for less than they charged in their home markets.
The Commerce Department levied preliminary import tariffs averaging 12.5 percent in November in response to the subsidy cases, and is expected to levy preliminary tariffs averaging up to 25 percent on Wednesday in the underpricing cases.
The domestic auto industry is preparing similar cases charging that foreign auto makers sell cars in the United States for less than they charge in their home markets. Such cases are commonly filed when industries think that the economy is improving because the cases require an ailing domestic industry to prove that imports are a significant cause of its troubles.

HEADLINE: The Gloom Deepens As Layoffs Increase;
More Job Losses at Pratt & Whitney

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 26

 BODY:
Pratt & Whitney's decision to shrink its Connecticut work force by one-third during the next two years promises to ricochet through an economy already battered by deep cuts in military spending and layoffs in the insurance industry. It will also mow down, at least for now, the hope for recovery from one of the worst local recessions in the nation, economists said.
But what has dampened spirits even more is that Pratt & Whitney, the state's largest private employer, had been seen as a leader among military contractors in reducing its dependence on Government contracts.
 
Away From the Military
 As military orders for jet engines declined with the end of the cold war, falling from a high of 800 a year in the early 1980's to 80 this year, Pratt & Whitney had sought to insulate itself by relying more heavily on sales to airlines. Dependence on the Pentagon fell from 50 percent of all sales through the last few decades to only 30 percent last year. 
 A steep drop in orders from the airlines has now dashed that plan, and with it the hopes of thousands of workers and their families.
Twice last year the company had announced layoff and reorganization plans that it said would solve its problems. Of the 6,700 job cuts announced today, 1,800 were included in those earlier plans and will take effect at the end of this month.
From the plant gate here to the State Capitol in Hartford, where Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. called for reregulating the airline industry to forestall further job losses, it was a day of anxieties, and suspicions that worse might still be ahead.
"Within the next two to three years, are we going to hear that they have to still cut more?" said Andrew D. Romegialli, a spokesman for the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, which represents 10,105 Pratt & Whitney workers.
Mr. Romegialli said that while the falloff in commercial orders was real, the company also had a hidden agenda to move jobs out of the United States and into cheaper foreign labor markets. "They should just be up front and tell everybody what's happening," he said.
Edward J. Deak, an economist at Fairfield University, said he was troubled by the announcement for two reasons: first, because he believes it will push back into late 1993 or 1994 the modest economic rebound he had forecast for Connecticut, and second, because the layoffs -- unlike corporate reorganization plans aimed at cutting middle management -- are being driven by a shrinking business.
"This is not a series of labor-force cutbacks forced by efficiency," he said. "What we're seeing is a decline in the demand for the products: engines, engine parts. We've got a different kind of animal here and probably in some ways a more serious problem."
Governor Weicker, who said he was briefed by company officials on Monday night and again this morning, said he thought that the region's entire aerospace industry was threatened.
"This is an aerospace-industry problem, and make no mistake about it, it's a statewide problem," Mr. Weicker said. "You're not just talking Pratt. You're talking the hundreds of subcontractors, and they're the greatest concern to me, throughout the state of Connecticut that are dependent on a healthy aerospace industry."
Pratt & Whitney, a division of Hartford-based United Technologies Corporation, has operations in East Hartford, Cheshire, Middletown, North Haven, Southington and Rocky Hill.
Outside the plant in North Haven, today's announcement deepened the malaise and uncertainty created by earlier layoffs. Many former Pratt workers said they could not find jobs that came close to paying as much as Pratt & Whitney. Many expressed hopes that they still might be called back to work at the plant.
"I've got two kids and a house," said one laid-off worker who is 35 years old and had worked at Pratt & Whitney for nine years. "I am looking for work, but if they offer you something for $5 or $6 an hour, you have to tell them no. You have to look for at least $10 an hour, something you have a chance to grow with. It's depressing, having to go out and start all over."
He said he would have been willing to take a pay cut to keep his job.
"These layoffs could have been avoided if they'd made a shorter work week or had furloughs. The company should have asked the employees, 'What can we do?' I think the company is putting profits before people. They're losing a lot of good help."
Claude Hanson, the bartender at Wallabies Cafe on Washington Avenue, said his daytime business is down since the layoffs last year.
"People don't have the money to spend anymore," he said. "We've served sandwiches here, but now the workers are bringing their lunches in with them instead of going out. Every package store from the North Haven Green all the way up to Wallingford has lost business because of Pratt."
Frank Porto, who owns Aircraft Package Store, directly across the street from Pratt & Whitney's North Haven entrance, said: "We're all holding on for dear life. On Washington Avenue, one deli has closed and two gas stations. When layoffs happen, everybody suffers. The Pratt guys who are still there, they are not jubilant anymore. Any moment they could walk in and find a notice on the bulletin board or a foreman might come up and say to them, 'Look, you've had it.'
At the headquarters of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, Local 707, near the plant's entrance, laid-off workers studied the bulletin board, which listed the names of employees who had recently been laid off. "I've been looking, but nobody pays," said one of the men, who until his October layoff had been making $13 an hour at Pratt & Whitney. "Somebody wants to pay you $8 or $9, you can't live on that, not in this state."
Nancy Waters, business agent for the union, said the mood in the plant and the union hall was "disheartening."
She said, "When people hear that the company is downsizing by another 6,700 people, they don't know where all those people will come from."

HEADLINE: Congress to Tell Greenspan To Keep Interest Rates Low

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
With economic growth finally picking up and short-term interest rates at their lowest level in three decades, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, might expect to be hugged when he testifies before Congress on Wednesday and Thursday.
He would be wiser to expect to be mugged. 
 Angry at the slowness with which the central bank has cut interest rates, Congressional lawmakers say they will warn Mr. Greenspan to keep rates low now so as not to block President Clinton's attempt to engineer a strong recovery.
Federal Reserve officials "say they're worried about inflation, but at the moment the more pressing issue is jobs and economic growth," said Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, a Maryland Democrat who is vice chairman of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.
"Any notion that they would raise interest rates would be completely inappropriate," he said. "My own view is they should ease monetary policy further."
 
Blocking for Clinton
 By throwing some elbows at the Fed, Democrats in Congress appear to be running interference for President Clinton and possibly saving him the trouble of having to do some Fed-bashing of his own.
For his part, Mr. Greenspan is expected to sound an accommodating note when he appears Wednesday before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress and Thursday before the Senate Budget Committee.
Judging from interviews with other central bank officials, Mr. Greenspan is expected to say the Fed can live with a small, one-year increase in deficit spending in the $20 billion range.
George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, said today that "it's very likely there will be a stimulus package." Appearing on ABC's "Good Morning America," Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said the stimulus package would probably be "in the range of $15 billion to $20 billion."
But the Fed chairman will probably caution Mr. Clinton against too much stimulus. Fed officials fear that inflation could be reignited if there is a large stimulus package, perhaps $60 billion, and if it kicks in six months from now when growth might be stronger.
Mr. Greenspan and other Fed officials appear ready to go along with a modest stimulus package because they worry that economic growth does not have a strong foundation. Federal Reserve governors say the slowdowns in Europe and Japan could undermine the nation's recovery by hurting American exports. And they worry that the debt burdens weighing on American businesses and households are slowing growth, although those burdens are less strong than the 50-mile-an-hour tailwind that Mr. Greenspan described last year.
Jim Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, angrily criticized the Fed today for cutting interest rates too slowly in recent years and causing the recovery from recession to be so anemic. "Over the past three years, the Federal Reserve Board wore its monetary policy like a hair shirt." he said.
Mr. Sasser added that as deficit reduction takes center stage "it is critical that we get assurances from the Federal Reserve that the White House and Congress will not be left dangling and twisting in the wind." In Congressional testimony today, Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, seconded that view, saying an easier monetary policy would be needed to offset the recessionary effects of cutting the deficit.
 
How Much Growth?
 When Mr. Greenspan testifies, he is expected to say once again that the Fed is seriously considering whether to lower its targets for money supply growth. In the past, he asserted that this would be a mere technical move that would reduce the target for M-2 -- the most closely watched measure of the money supply -- because less money growth appears to be needed to produce a desired level of economic growth. The current range for M-2 growth is 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent.
Mr. Sasser and Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas and chairman of the House Banking Comittee, have attacked this proposal, saying that if the central bank cuts its money supply targets, that could cause the Fed to raise interest rates sooner than with higher targets. Most economists say that when a central bank reduces its monetary targets, it is also setting lower goals for inflation.
Fed officials appear to be paying more attention to Congressional criticisms this year than last year, fearing that Congressional proposals to reduce the Fed's independence have a better chance of passing under President Clinton than under President Bush.
Mr. Sarbanes is sponsoring a bill that would strip the Federal Reserve's regional bank presidents of their right to vote on the central bank's main policy-setting committee. The 12 regional bank presidents are not nominated by the President, but are selected by bankers and business executives.
Mr. Gonzalez is sponsoring a bill calling for the President to nominate the regional bank presidents and the Senate to confirm them.

HEADLINE: U.S. Suspends Dredging Permit for Newark Bay

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, Jan. 26

 BODY:
A permit allowing port officials to begin dredging container-ship berths in Newark Bay, a project vital to the survival of waterfront commerce in New York Harbor, was abruptly suspended this month by one Federal agency, only a week after it had been approved by another.
The issue is dioxin contamination in dredged sediment: how much is too much and how can it be disposed of? Until the agencies resolve their differences, officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, who have been poised to begin dredging for almost three years, remain mired in frustration. So are many others -- fishermen, environmentalists and officials at other ports -- who see Newark Bay as a test case that could determine how dioxin, a cancer-causing industrial byproduct easily absorbed by fish and wildlife, can be safely dredged and disposed of. 
 The Port Authority, which is the first major port to confront the problem since scientists became aware of it here in the mid-1980's, contends that it has carried out every test and complied with every request of every Government agency during a prolonged hearing process, only to watch its berths in Elizabeth and Newark become so seriously clogged with sediment that some vessels have been forced to call elsewhere.
 
'Sort of the Guinea Pigs'
 "We are sort of the guinea pigs," said Lillian C. Liburdi, director of the port department for the Port Authority. "We're the first port required to go through this process. This delayed us significantly. Ships have chosen to call at other ports first, so a vessel can come in lighter. Some lines are saying that ships are not going out full. It's not a good competitive situation."
Normally, the authority would dredge each year, scooping out silt accumulations of six inches or more and keeping berths at depths of up to 42 feet to accommodate the enormous container ships that are a mainstay of the long-suffering shipping business that has only now begun to stabilize around the container industry.
In the mid-1980's, however, scientists became aware of the presence of dioxin in bay crabs, just down the Passaic River from the shuttered Diamond Shamrock plant that once manufactured the defoliant Agent Orange. When the time came for the port agency to renew its annual dredging request, the familiar search for such poisons as mercury, cadmium and PCB's had been augmented with a need to find out about a fresh and mysterious marine problem: dioxin.
Because testing for dioxin, its effects on ocean life and the development of a program for disposing of contaminated sediment were all relatively new issues, the Port Authority's dredging application, otherwise routine, became a test case that has been watched closely by other ports and scientists everywhere. Even now, the Environmental Protection Agency in Washington is trying to determine how serious a threat dioxin poses to humans, animals and the environment in general. A policy statement, perhaps with new standards for its presence in the environment, is expected in the spring.
 
Permit From Corps
 Eventually, the Port Authority got the go-ahead from the Army Corps of Engineers. But the permit issued by the Corps on Jan. 6 was put on hold by the E.P.A. on Jan. 13. A spokesman for the E.P.A., Herman Phillips, said that the agency had acted because the permit allowed for dredging of far more material than the amount in the original request, made in May 1990.
"Normally, we do act in tandem," he said of the Corps and the E.P.A. "But we had O.K.'d a different set of numbers than what was in the actual permit." The agency asked for additional data on the amount of sediment to be removed, and fresh statistics were delivered to the E.P.A. today.
If the E.P.A. is satisfied with the new figures, a permit could be issued within days. Or the agency could ask for more dioxin testing, delaying the dredging project indefinitely.
While dredging has been blocked for the moment, environmentalists are still calling for more information and more testing before hundreds of thousands of cubic yards of sediment are dug up and carried on barges to a site known as the Mud Dump, a disposal site in 90 feet of water about six miles east of Sandy Hook, N.J.
 
Another Round of Tests?
 The disputed dredging permit calls for removal of up to 500,000 cubic yards of material, not the 200,000 originally requested. If the Port Authority's latest soundings show that the dredged amount will be about the same or registers only a modest increase, the E.P.A. could conceivably grant the permit. But a much larger amount of sediment could set off yet another round of tests for dioxin, and a further delay. Of the 62 berths in Elizabeth and Newark, 29 were to be dredged under the permit being sought. The cost of dredging and dumping would be $5 million.
Not to allow the dumping at all would be unthinkable, said Ms. Liburdi of the Port Authority.
"We really don't have an alternative except for ocean disposal," she said. There are no land sites large enough or impermeable enough for hundreds of thousands of cubic yards of muck.
"Remediation technology would be impossible," she said. "There isn't any technology to handle the Port Authority's volume." The only other known option, building an artificial island, would cost $500 million to $1 billion, she said.
 
Alarm Over Review Process
 Environmentalists and fishermen have watched and participated in the review process with alarm, concerned not only about the standard chosen for gauging contamination but for the way the sediment would be disposed of.
Sarah L. Clark, a staff scientist with the Environmental Defense Fund in New York, said she was disappointed with what she called the inability of government agencies to work together.
She said she was not convinced that enough testing had been done on dioxin and marine life to determine whether the sediment could safely be dumped at sea. The test used worms to determine the amount of dioxin absorbed by marine life and the dioxin standard was the same as the New York State standard for dioxin in fish. That standard is 10 parts per trillion.
She also expressed concern with plans for capping the Mud Dump in the Atlantic. Under the plan, clean fill would be poured over the muck, essentially pinning the dioxin in place.
But this will not happen, she said, until all the dredged material is dumped there. "We're not satisfied there won't be exposure to marine organisms."
"This is likely to be the first time that a large dredging project will be permitted, knowing that dioxin is in the sediment," she said. "And if this permit is allowed to go forward under present conditions it will set the stage for hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of cubic yards of material to be disposed of at dump sites. That's a grave concern considering the natural resources and the economics that are at stake."

HEADLINE: 2 Candidates for Governor to Pay Back Taxes for Aliens

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Saying they want to move ahead with their campaigns, two Republicans who hope to be governor announced today that they have agreed to pay back taxes for hiring illegal aliens.
Christine Todd Whitman said her payments would total $22,694 for Social Security and unemployment taxes to the Federal Government and the state of New Jersey for employing two undocumented workers for three and a half years to take care of her children. 
 She said $14,467 was paid today to the Internal Revenue Service. A check for $8,227 will be delivered to state tax officials on Wednesday, she said. Campaign officials said penalties and interest would be paid when they are determined by the tax agencies.
The second candidate, W. Cary Edwards, a former state attorney general, said he intends to make a payment totaling $2,820 to cover Social Security and state and Federal unemployment insurance taxes for employing a Portuguese woman without residency status as a housekeeper for about 18 months.
 
Additional Fines
 Both candidates could face additional fines from the Immigration and Naturalization Service if they are found guilty of breaking Federal law. John Gershkoff, who heads the New Jersey region's investigations unit for the immigration service, said today that the Whitman and Edwards cases were being reviewed.
Mrs. Whitman and Mr. Edwards disclosed their employment of illegal aliens on Friday following the furor over President Clinton's nomination of Zoe Baird as attorney general. Ms. Baird, who admitted that she and her husband employed illegal aliens to care for their son, withdrew her nomination.
Mrs. Whitman, who plans to announce formally her candidacy for governor on Wednesday, said she hoped the payment would "put these matters behind me." But she acknowledged that she did not believe the issue would go away.
"It's always going to be there, and it will be part of how people view me," Mrs. Whitman said. "But there are other things, such as the issues of the campaign. I expect this will be fully aired again, and I am willing to discuss it."
Mr. Edwards, whose admission of hiring an illegal alien came four hours after Mrs. Whitman's disclosure, said he would make the $2,820 payment "in order to get on with the issues of the campaign."
