HEADLINE: Bank Rates Slide a Bit Across U.S.

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Yields offered on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit for the week beginning today dipped slightly, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, a Florida-based newsletter.
In the New York metropolitan region, commercial banks adjusted yields on short-term C.D.'s while savings banks lowered money market account yields. Elsewhere in the nation, the declines were most evident in money market accounts. 
 At the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, average discount rates declined modestly. Many traders and investors view results of Treasury auctions as harbingers of future deposit rates.
The average rate at auction yesterday was 2.98 percent, down from 3.03 percent last week. The weekly decline was the fourth in a row. The six-month bill, meanwhile, edged down to 3.09 percent from 3.13 percent.
"The direction of rates in the next few weeks depends on whether President Clinton and Congress can coax the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates a notch in exchange for deficit reduction," said Robert K. Heady, The Bank Rate Monitor's publisher. "Lower rates would help pump up the economy, but they would also drive low savings yields even lower."
 
New York Accounts Fall
 In the New York area, money market accounts are down one basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point, to an average of 2.69 percent. The decline began seven weeks ago. The average yield for three-month certificates of deposit also fell one basis point, to 2.78 percent, while the average yield on a six-month certificate edged down two basis points, to 2.96 percent.
Commercial banks continued to make the steepest cuts in three-month certificates of deposit, shaving the average yield 3 basis points, to 2.68 percent. Savings banks cut their money market accounts 2 basis points, to 2.83 percent. In some of the biggest changes for New York institutions, the Republic National Bank lowered its six-month C.D. 11 basis points, to 2.94 percent, and its three-month accounts one-tenth of a basis point, to 2.79 percent, while Crossland Savings cut its money-market account 10 basis points, to 2.65 percent.
Around the country, yields at 20 large commercial banks also slipped. The average money market account dropped 2 basis points, to 2.66 percent, and the average six-month C.D. dropped one basis point, to 3 percent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Forget the Theories, Japan Puts Chaos to Work

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 26

 BODY:
In research laboratories around the world, chaos theory, a young scientific field that seeks to find order amid seemingly random behavior, is providing fundamental insights into the behavior of the weather, the inner workings of the human body and the ebb and flow of wildlife populations. In Japan, chaos theory is also being used to make a kerosene heater.
While new technology in the United States has often been developed for military or space efforts, Japan does not have a strong military program and so relies on consumer products to lead the way. 
 The Sanyo Electric Company's heater, introduced last year, lets the temperature and the speed of the fan fluctuate. It attests to the enthusiastic practicality with which Japanese companies are rushing to apply chaos theory, even as researchers in the United States study how the theory might be used in everything from medical care to forecasting financial markets.
The contrast is not new. About a decade ago, for example, researchers developed metal alloys that could return to their former shape after heating. The United States used them in fighter planes; the Japanese used them to make air-conditioner louvers and eyeglass frames. The United States used special ceramics to make tiles to protect the space shuttle from heat as it re-entered the atmosphere; the Japanese made ceramic scissors and ballpoint pens.
Now, Japan is looking to create customer orders from chaos. "I've given talks in Japan where all the electronics companies have been present," said Peter Davis, a chaos researcher at the ATR Institute, a research center in Kyoto that is partly financed by the Japanese Government. "You certainly don't get that kind of interest from manufacturers in other countries."
The rush to employ hot new technologies in Japan is partly a marketing response to the Japanese consumer's appetite for the latest gadgets. But there is a more fundamental economic motivation at work. The rapid adoption of technology has been a key to Japan's industrial success, with the simple applications helping to hone the technology and finance the development of more complex applications. The solar-powered calculator, for instance, helped speed the development of photovoltaic cells that now provide electricity to homes and factories.
Still, there are some who think the rush to simple applications can detract from basic long-term research. "Japanese engineers easily flow to superficial applications," said Kazuyuki Aihara, an associate professor of electronic engineering at Tokyo Denki University. "In the case of chaos, it is very profound, so we should study the fundamental theories."
 
Successor to 'Fuzzy Logic'
 A few years ago, the technological fad was fuzzy logic, a technique for making computers more adaptable that had been invented but virtually ignored in the United States. Japanese companies quickly produced fuzzy washing machines, fuzzy vacuum cleaners and fuzzy rice cookers that adjusted their operations to the condition of the substance being cleaned or cooked.
Now chaos is all the rage. Chaos theory is based on the idea that seemingly random behavior, like the turbulence in a river, the behavior of the stock market or the fluctuations of animal populations from year to year, might actually be caused by some simple underlying mechanisms. Understanding these mechanisms might allow for prediction of now unpredictable phenomena and, possibly, better control of them.
As yet, the Japanese have no Government-backed research program in chaos engineering, as the application of chaos theory is sometimes called. But two committees, made up of university and industry scientists, are devoted to comparing notes on chaos. And this fall, Toyota will sponsor a conference with the theme "Toward the Harnessing of Chaos."
Applied-chaos theory can be divided into two broad areas. One involves using mathematical tools to analyze seemingly chaotic behavior in a search for patterns.
Stock market prediction is one obvious application, though many experts say it is far from clear that chaos theory will work here. Still, Hitachi has begun selling software that uses some mathematical techniques of chaos theory to help forecast market moves. Similar work is under way in the United States.
Yutaka Takeuchi, a researcher at Toshiba, is trying to analyze oscillating signals from a nuclear plant's monitors to detect conditions under which nuclear reactions might become unstable.
Computer Convenience, a company in Fukuoka, has developed a device that uses chaos theory to try to diagnose mental health by measuring the pulse in the capillaries of a finger. The seemingly random fluctuations are diagrammed by a computer.
The device's developers, led by Takashi Tahara, a doctor at the Hizen National Mental Hospital, and Ichiro Tsuda, professor of computer science at the Kyushu Institute of Technology, say there is a clear difference between the patterns produced by a healthy, relaxed person and those from someone who is mentally ill or under stress.
The other class of applications involves deliberately creating a state of chaos and then corralling it into some practical purpose. The Sanyo kerosene heater belongs to this category.
The typical kerosene heater, a popular appliance in Japan, where central heating is not common, burns the kerosene and blows a constant stream of hot air, using a thermostat to try to maintain a constant temperature. The Sanyo heater, by contrast, allows the temperature to fluctuate a bit. The company says this saves fuel and increases comfort.
An even simpler application, though it did not actually use the mathematical techniques of chaos theory, was an air-conditioner introduced a few years ago by Matsushita. Instead of a steady stream of cool air, the air strength fluctuated in a manner mimicking the variations of natural wind, providing what the company said was a more comfortable way of cooling.
Another area of keen interest for chaos researchers is computers. Many companies are developing computers known as neural networks that seek to mimic the behavior of the neurons in the brain and that can learn by trial and error. Work by Professor Aihara and others has shown that human neurons exhibit some chaotic behavior. Introducing chaotic fluctuations in neural networks might improve their performance, he said.
To encourage applications, the New Japan Radio Corporation is selling what it says is the world's first chaos chip, which generates various chaotic signals. True to form, several Japanese stereo companies have expressed interest in using the chip to generate chaotic images and light patterns to accompany music.
Takeshi Yamakawa, a professor at the Kyushu Institute of Technology and the developer of the chip's technology, sees such frivolity as a matter of course. "The practical applications," he said, "will be focused on amusement."

A technician, at right, analyzed the charts, which the company says give clues to a person's mental state. (Photographs by Computer Convenience) (pg. D5)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
COUCH potatoes might have closed their eyes to a surprising development: the programs they watch are becoming somewhat less cluttered with commercials. That's because advertisers and their agencies are cooling to 15-second spots, once the fastest-growing phenomenon on television since Roseanne Arnold.
According to an annual analysis by the Network Television Association, 15-second commercials accounted for just 31.8 percent of all spots that ran during the 1991-92 season on programming broadcast by its members. That marked a sharp decline from a peak achieved as recently as the 1988-89 season, when 37.7 percent of all commercials on ABC, CBS and NBC were 15 seconds long. 
 Indeed, last season's figure was the lowest for 15's, as they are known in the industry, since they began a meteoric rise in popularity in the mid-1980's. At one time, it seemed they might even supplant 30-second spots as the industry standard, in much the same way that 30's superceded 60-second commercials in the 1970's.
"The numbers are dramatic," Peter Chrisanthopoulos, president and chief executive at the N.T.A. in New York, said yesterday. "A drop from 37.7 to 31.8 in just three seasons is significant."
Fifteen-second spots, which began appearing on network television during the 1983-84 season, were developed in response to the soaring cost of commercial air time. They are sold for about half the price of 30-second commercials, though sometimes premiums are charged.
At first, the networks sold them only in a "split 30" format, meaning an advertiser had to buy two 15-second spots that ran consecutively. Later, that stipulation was relaxed so that free-standing short spots -- stand-alone 15's, in industry parlance -- were also made available. Even so, the networks have placed limits on the frequency of 15-second spots, unlike their longer siblings.
Some advertisers have used the 15-second format creatively, producing so-called book-end spots or to-be-continued spots. Viewers, for example, watch a 15-second spot in which an actor, grimacing almost convincingly, complains about a headache and decides to take an Excedrin tablet. That spot is followed by one or two 30-second spots for unrelated products. Then the actor returns in a second 15-second spot, proclaiming that Excedrin has vanquished his pain.
Speaking of pain relief, as 15-second commercials fade in popularity, viewers should be less bothered by separate commercial interruptions, a problem referred to as clutter. The rise of 15's was a gamble. Advertisers hoped the savings achieved by paying for 15 seconds of air time, rather than 30, would offset whatever alienation might occur among viewers who felt beset by increasing clutter.
"No one knows at what point the clutter has a substantial negative impact on the medium," said David Marans, senior vice president of media research at J. Walter Thompson U.S.A. in New York.
"But a preponderance of evidence from many research studies over the years," he added, "has demonstrated there seems to be a definite relationship, and a negative one, between increased clutter and commercial effectiveness. Our concern is the effectiveness of the TV medium -- to not kill the goose the laid the golden egg."
Mr. Chrisanthopoulos called the shift from 15-second commercials "good news" for advertisers because "if there are fewer of them, there's a more favorable environment created." He said the networks feared that the increase in 15's would hurt the medium, but were willing to offer them "to accommodate the demands of the marketplace."
That marketplace has, of course, changed substantially in recent years. The weakness in the economy softened the demand for commercial time. That, in turn, broke the 1980's pattern of commercial prices ratcheting ever higher, a primary reason that 15-second spots were spawned.
Mr. Chrisanthopoulos said he expected "the downward trend in 15's will continue somewhat, but I don't see them disappearing."
"They're here to stay," he added, "but they will not be the dominant format used by advertisers."
In the 1991-92 season, according to the association's analysis of Arbitron Media Watch data, as 15-second commercials fell to 31.8 percent of all sports from 33.6 percent in 1990-91, 30-second commercials rose to 62.9 percent, from 62.5 percent. There was also a slight increase in the once-mighty 60-second format, to 2 percent, up from 1.6 percent.
More information about clutter is expected on Feb. 9, when the American Association of Advertising Agencies and the Association of National Advertisers are scheduled to release the next installment of their periodic Commercial Monitoring Study. The study, prepared by Thompson, is expected to report decreases in clutter, particularly during prime-time network programming.

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

 BODY:
THE last vintage chart to appear in this space, on May 22, 1991, documented one of the more memorable periods in wine history. From 1981, the first vintage covered, through 1990, which had not yet been bottled, it was a period of unrivaled prosperity and success in most of the major wine regions of the world.
Most vintage charts -- and the people who follow them -- are primarily concerned with Bordeaux, and for Bordeaux the good times began much earlier. After the mysterious 1975 vintage, which still has not matured and, alas, probably never will, there has been an abundance of fine harvests and good wine. 
 The 1977, 1980, 1984 and 1987 vintages were all given relatively low ratings in their time, but except for 1984, all of them provided good, early-maturing wines at affordable prices.
Even 1984, which has been eliminated from this year's chart, provided a few decent wines. In France, the '84's still turn up on restaurant lists and are much beloved by caterers who pour them at weddings where people are curious about the bride's age, not the wine's.
This year's chart includes both 1990, whose anticipated success is now a fact, and 1991, which was not impressive in Bordeaux. The 1990 Bordeaux marked the third consecutive year of great wines from its region. The 1991's were mediocre but sold at relatively high prices. The 1992's, not charted here, are also expected to fall considerably below the highest standards. Heavy, unrelenting rains at harvest time seriously affected quality.
The talk is that 1992 will equal or slightly surpass 1987, the last problem vintage. The fact is that 1987 was not a bad year; it just did not match 1985 or 1986, or the three years that succeeded it. The 1987's, which still can be found in most areas, are still attractive wines to drink. And they are attractively priced.
It can't be emphasized enough that a good year in one part of the world is not necessarily a good year somewhere else. While 1991 and 1992 were not great years in Bordeaux, 1991 was a superb vintage in Beaujolais and both years were excellent in most parts of California.
The vintages are given a rating from 1 to 10, with letters indicating the drinkability of the wine. But bear in mind that even within a vintage, wine will differ from vineyard to vineyard, from cellar to cellar and even from bottle to bottle. A hard, tannic wine from St. Estephe in Bordeaux should need five more years' aging than the equivalent wine from St.-Emilion, which is also in the Bordeaux region.
Most of the romance surrounding very old wine is spurious. Most wine, even the very best, peaks after about 10 to 15 years. Some may improve for decades; most will not. Thus, the chart cannot explain how a wine of a lesser year may taste better right now than a famous wine that needs 10 years to mature.
Champagne has no drinkability rating on the chart because it is, or is supposed to be, ready to drink when sold; the winemakers do the aging for you, sometimes for as long as eight years. Once, Champagne hardly rated space on any vintage chart because it was almost entirely nonvintage wine, blended from wines of different harvests.
But vintaged Champagne is popular at the moment and it is possible that some houses are declaring vintages for purely economic reasons. There are no official vintage years. The ratings are given for those years when a sufficient number of producers have declared a vintage to make a rating meaningful.
As in the past, the chart offers no Beaujolais ratings earlier than the three most recent harvests. If well kept, the 10 so-called cru Beaujolais, such as Fleurie, Moulin-a-Vent and Morgon, will last for five years or more. But it is unwise to buy or order in a restaurant any Beaujolias more than two years old. It is a wine to be drunk young.
A word of advice: the 1991 vintage of Beaujolais will soon be giving way to the 1992's. The new vintage will be good but not as good as 1991. It might be worth snapping up some of the remaining 1991's if you can find them.
A vintage chart is only the vaguest of guides to good wine. Its advice on Bordeaux, for example, relates almost exclusively to the expensive classified growths, the most famous chateaux. Each year, Bordeaux produces millions of gallons of simple, delicious wine that is meant to be drunk young.
Similarly, the chart cannot easily take into account the poor weather in the southern Rhone in 1991. It was a disaster for Chateauneuf-du-Pape but a good year farther north at Hermitage and the Cote Rotie. The rating is an unsatisfactory compromise for the rater.
The California ratings refer mostly to the northern coastal counties of Napa, Sonoma and Mendocino. California stretches 1,500 miles, from the Oregon border to Mexico. No chart could cover all its wine regions.
Some day, perhaps, there will be a truly comprehensive wine vintage chart, one where it will be possible to look up the 1989 vintage in Hungary; the 1985 vintage in Mendoza, in Argentina, and the 1990 harvest in Temecula, Calif., near San Diego. It will be a rather large chart; it might even be called an encyclopedia.
 
TASTINGS
Jordan Vineyards Cabernet Sauvignon, 1988; Alexander Valley, California; about $25.
 
If there were one word that summarized Jordan cabernets, it would have to be accessibility. Almost from the first vintage, back in 1976, Jordan wines have been rich, flavorful, fragrant and ready to drink when they were released. Given those criteria, the 1988 offers no surprises; it just happens to be a delicious wine. With his spectacular winery overlooking the Alexander Valley in Sonoma County and his great advance press, Tom Jordan would have to have been a miracle worker to have lived up to all the expectations. Instead he produced a quality wine that became an instant success and that has remained fairly high on the charts ever since. Some critics fault the wine, saying it lacks subtlety and ageability. The fact is that not every good wine needs to be subtle or to possess the ability to age. There is nothing wrong with having all that good taste right up front. And as for aging, it may be too soon to tell.

HEADLINE: Brooklyn Philharmonic Reaches Pact

 BODY:
The Brooklyn Philharmonic, one of the nine orchestras affected by the strike of freelance musicians, which began on Saturday, reached a separate tentative agreement yesterday with Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, the union representing the players. The orchestra's musicians are meeting today to vote on the new three-year contract.
The orchestra's management, anticipating ratification, announced that it would perform its concerts on Friday and Saturday evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. 
 Maurice Edwards, the orchestra's artistic director, said the new contract gave the orchestra's players annual raises of 4 percent and proportional increases in health benefits. Mr. Edwards said that unlike the eight other orchestras in the Orchestra Managers of New York, the Brooklyn Philharmonic already has a side agreement covering tenure and peer review, which are among the sticking points in the negotiations.
"The Brooklyn Philharmonic joined the consortium to negotiate the economic issues," said Joseph Rosenthal, the lawyer representing the managers. "When the main point of contention turned out to be peer review, which they already have, they asked to withdraw and we did not object."
Mr. Rosenthal said that he expected the remaining eight orchestras to continue negotiating as a consortium.

HEADLINE: Metropolitan Diary

BYLINE: By Ron Alexander

 BODY:

DEAR DIARY:
I was on my way to work, heading uptown on Avenue of the Americas. At 52d Street, I stepped off the curb to cross just as a truck was making a sharp turn in front of me. I stopped to let the truck pass but did not step back on the curb.
Suddenly from behind me, I heard someone shout, "Hey, look out! Watch it!" I jumped back on the sidewalk and turned around to see who my protector was. 
 It turned out to be two rather large ladies. I was about to thank them for alerting me, when one turned to the other and said, "That's all I need first thing in the morning, somebody getting splattered all over my coat!" -- JULIA LIZZUL

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Dear Diary:
Despite incessant hints, no one presented me with "The Complete Beatles Chronicle" for Christmas. So the other evening, I walked over to the Barnes & Noble near Rockefeller Center. There, the following dialogue ensued.
Me: Where are your books on the Beatles?
Clerk: Look under the Rolling Stones.
Surely this signifies the end of civilization as we know it? -- JAMES SMITH

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
NOCTURNE
 
 I love to wake up in the dark of night
 surrounded by silence,
 the edges softened by moonlight slipping
 through cracks in the curtains.

 I love prowling the house
 while the town 'round me sleeps,
 curling up in an overstuffed chair,
 sipping cinnamon tea and catching
 the last five minutes of
 "Casablanca" on the TV.

 I love easing open
 the door to my son's room,
 seeing him sleep in a tangle of sheets.

 I love to wake up in the dark of the night
 seeing the clock reading quarter to four,
 knowing that I can sleep two hours more.

 I love to wake up in the dark of the night
 and I love knowing I can go back to bed.
 ALICE LAURANCE

She: Oh.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Letter from a thrifty New Yorker:
"As a currently unemployed advertising account executive, much of my time is spent on the telephone. Today, for example, while dropping my resume off at countless personnel offices, I managed to stop at no less than 30 pay phones for what is arguably the city's finest freebie, directory assistance.
"Considering that such assistance is 45 cents a call when dialed from home, my savings for the day totaled $13.50. I celebrated with a $5 cab ride from my last appointment to my front door. Net income for the day: a whopping $8.50. That's more than I was able to save when I was working."

Dear Diary:
The other day I started thinking about the time when signs announcing "Tea Leaves Read Gratis" dotted Manhattan's midtown landscape. It was the middle of the 1930's, we were in the midst of the Depression, and having tea leaves read was an inexpensive escape from reality.
I had missed my train back to Bridgeport -- I used to visit New York to see the French films of the day -- and with 59 minutes to spare until the next train, I walked along 42d Street. Seeing a sign -- "Gypsy Tea Room" -- near Fifth Avenue above Russell Stover Chocolates, I climbed a flight of stairs to a nondescript room and sat at a very small table.
My tea leaf reader was a man who looked to be in his 40's. He began by telling me my first name and went on to say that if pushed too far, I was capable of displaying a sharp tongue. (True.) He told me that I lived in a house surrounded by trees (also true) and described my living room, including the unusual window arrangement. He also described the office where I worked, including the placement of my desk.
He said that on the following day, a friend named Rose would fall from a horse and sustain fairly serious injuries. (Most of my friends rode, and three were named Rose.) It happened.
The last thing the reader told me: several people in my office would lose their jobs, but I would be kept on at a reduced salary. It happened.
I caught the next train to Bridgeport and never sought to have my tea leaves read again. -- ANN RAPOPORT

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
A Real Live Health-Care Drama

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
Many a lawyer must be an actor manque. But Prof. Arthur Miller of the Harvard Law School is demonstrably not to the manque born. His thespiantic talents have been displayed in many upscale television discussions, and now, in "Who Shall Be Healed?," he has the hit of his performing career.
As the moderator and provocateur of tonight's "Fred Friendly Seminar," Mr. Miller takes the role of Homer Smith, a computer manager for a company in what he calls "the wonderful community of Appleville," somewhere in the middle of the United States. As the hour progresses, Smith's troubles accumulate. First, he can't accept a better job because the new company, a small one, does not provide health benefits. Then he comes down with severe headaches and his group-health doctor discourages him from being examined by magnetic resonance imaging because of the cost. And then his wife has trouble getting the best oncologist in town to treat her breast cancer. 
 "I realize," he admonishes the panelists who have been cooly discussing the need to keep costs down, "to you doctors, my apprehension about the tumor doesn't mean a damn thing. My wife's peace of mind and her ability to bond with the doctor doesn't mean a damn thing." Hath not a law professor passions?
Mr. Miller, whose only prop is a plastic-foam cup for waving, mixes his prosecutorial fervor with pathos, his indignation with incredulity. He is constantly on the move; if there were more scenery than the big table for the doctors and former government officials, the nurse, the hospital director, the businessman, the academic, the insurance specialist and the others who make up the symposium, he would assuredly shred it. His script and emotings are all in the service of bringing home the workings and misworkings of America's present health-care arrangements.
Dr. Arnold S. Relman, editor emeritus of the New England Journal of Medicine, needs no magnetic resonance imager to diagnose the cause of health-cost inflation: the person who receives the services does not pay for them. Prof. Alain Enthoven of Stanford University, a prominent exponent of "managed health care," agrees: "Today everybody has a personal interest in spending more money, or at least no interest in spending less money, because it's all paid for by a third party."
Demurring from the call by Rhoda Karpatkin, head of Consumers Union, for a version of the Canadian system, where the Government pays the bill, they and others on the panel favor some form of health maintenance organization that concentrates on preventive care and has incentives to keep costs down.
In the hour's testiest moment, Joseph A. Califano Jr., a former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, demands that Robert Laszewski, the panel's insurance representative, end his industry's "shilling for doctors, hospitals, medical equipment manufacturers and pharmaceutical companies." Mr. Califano, a practiced scene stealer, predicts early death for both Ms. Karpatkin's and Mr. Enthoven's favorite plans. Experience tells him that lobbyists for big political contributors will kill any proposed change that threatens their financial health.
Such, this pertinent program concludes, is the sort of reality confronting the new Administration as it goes about trying to live up to the campaign promise to keep down health costs (which are moving speedily toward a trillion dollars a year) while providing care for everyone. Maybe Hillary Rodham Clinton should hire Professor Miller, give him a cup and let him do his stuff for Congress.

Who Shall Be Healed?
PBS, tonight at 10 (Channel 13 in New York)

A panel discussion produced by Richard Kilberg for WNET/New York and Socratic Seminars in association with Columbia University; Stuart Sucherman, executive producer; Arthur Miller, moderator.

HEADLINE: The Urgency of Aiding Russia

 BODY:
President Clinton has appointed a fresh team to handle the nation's most important foreign challenge: to help a disintegrating Russia move to democracy and markets without threatening the safety of its neighbors. Now the team needs to inject new urgency into an economic aid program that languished under his predecessor.
Russia is on the brink of disaster. The Yeltsin Government has lost control of the central bank, which has poured billions of excess rubles into dead factories. The result is inflation near 50 percent a month -- hyperinflation -- which if allowed to persist will virtually guarantee economic chaos and political breakdown. It was, after all, hyperinflation that helped bring forth Hitler. 
 Russia can still be saved. Indeed, it has started to heal itself. The Yeltsin Government is pushing privatization of state-owned enterprises. And last week it tried to put reform back on track by demanding tighter monetary policy and revoking a misguided decree to reimpose price controls. But the political battle over how fast and how far to push reform rages on. Western aid can buttress the reformers.
By yesterday's appointment of Thomas Pickering, an experienced Foreign Service officer, to be his ambassador to Russia, Mr. Clinton has given diplomatic strength to his policy. And by choosing Strobe Talbott, a columnist for Time magazine who is a close friend, to serve as ambassador at large, he has shown his personal stake in Russian policy.
Lawrence Summers, chief economist at the World Bank, takes over responsibility for international economic policy at the Treasury Department. And Toby Gati, an expert on the Soviet Union, will spearhead Russian policy at the National Security Council.
Each of these appointees backs substantial Western aid to support the struggling economic and political reforms under way in Russia.
The Russians will have to do the major work of reform. But no country -- including West Germany after World War II and, more recently, Mexico -- has successfully undergone economic transformation without substantial external help.
In April the West promised Russia a $24 billion aid package. But it delivered virtually nothing. An invigorated effort is now called for. Russia needs Western money to create a safety net for the unemployed and elderly, to promote the growth of small business and to stabilize the value of the ruble so that it can open its borders to trade. It also needs Western money to import desperately needed food and medical supplies during the chaotic transition to a freer economy.
The package would still cost about $24 billion, only $3 billion of which would come from the U.S. The rest would come from the European Community and international lending institutions like the World Bank. But the West won't move until the Clinton Administration takes charge.
That won't be easy. Congress is reluctant to pony up funds for Russia while domestic needs cry out for help. It is Mr. Clinton's responsibility to explain the long-run consequences of letting Russia collapse from Western neglect. The few billions a Western aid package would cost may go to waste. But it would be a grievous miscalculation not to take the small risk.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Baird Stands in Part for All Working Mothers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Sins of Zoe Baird," Anna Quindlen's excellent Jan. 20 column, doesn't go far enough. The blame placing in which the Senate indulged over Ms. Baird's child-care arrangements demonstrates a fundamental paradox. No one says she was right to ignore the law. But the issue is more profound than Ms. Baird's failure to pay the appropriate taxes. 
 Americans mythologize the concept of a happy childhood, yet our society provides no acceptable institutional child-care arrangements. A mother with a career like Zoe Baird and countless others is put in the untenable position of having to forgo the results of hard work -- a choice that few men have to make -- or to provide often heart-rending, makeshift child-care arrangements.
Too often these arrangements involve recent immigrants, unskilled, ignorant of English, but of good character and with a love of and care for children. How many second-generation, English-speaking women who can work in an office would even consider a housekeeper-governess position? In my experience, few.
The moralistic reaction to Zoe Baird's predicament reflects the low esteem given to child-rearing, which our society identifies with women. None of the articles I have read fault Ms. Baird's husband, Paul Gewirtz, for his role. Apparently, no one expected him to refrain from teaching constitutional law at Yale or to shoulder the arrangements!
Ms. Baird and Professor Gewirtz had options many others do not have because of income. But none of the law firms or corporations for which Ms. Baird worked so effectively provided satisfactory child-care arrangements that would have obviated the necessity of private, in-home help and would have allowed mother and child to be together at times during the day. We still regard the workplace as "masculine" -- all business -- and the home as "feminine," and the lines between are rigidly drawn. This rigidity is the source of Ms. Baird's 1990 dilemma.
Before the women's movement changed our perceptions, severe judgments were made about women opting for the career role. However, by closing our eyes to the need for child care and support for the parental function, we continue to penalize women (and children) for making those choices. That is the moral paradox in the Baird case.
I write from personal experience. I am a partner in a national law firm; my children are in college. But I have been divorced with custody of my two daughters since 1978; one was then 7, the other 3. Their schools let out at 3 P.M. and noon, respectively. Like any new associate in a law firm, I had to work long hours. I could do so only by hiring full-time help -- Mexican, Colombian and finally Barbadian. Their wishes on Social Security prevailed; I was entirely at their mercy.
No law firm at that time offered child-care arrangements. Flexibility permitting work at home was unusual and in the law, impractical. I could have taken a leave of absence, but economic need made that impossible. I did not want to leave my daughters for 10 hours a day, every day, but since it was necessary, I had to know they were cared for by trustworthy employees.
When will we admit our blindness to the needs of children for their parents and a flexible work style that adapts to those needs; our callous assignment of the burdens of making arrangements to women, and our unwillingness to finance decent, alternatives to bootleg domestic arrangements?
 
CAROLE E. HANDLER
Los Angeles, Jan. 20, 1993

HEADLINE: Aspin Overhauls Pentagon to Bolster Policy Role

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
In a sweeping overhaul of the Defense Department intended to strengthen the Pentagon's involvement in foreign and domestic policy, Secretary Les Aspin is creating posts on human rights, arms proliferation and the conversion of military industries.
Among the least traditional of Mr. Aspin's choices for the new jobs is Morton H. Halperin, a former official in the Johnson and Nixon Administrations who fought a lengthy legal battle with Henry A. Kissinger over wiretapping and who was director of the Washington office of the American Civil Liberties Union. Mr. Halperin is Mr. Aspin's choice for Assistant Defense Secretary for Democracy and Human Rights. 
 In reorganizing the Pentagon, Mr. Aspin is forming a 1990's group of the "best and the brightest" to deal with the new agenda of foreign policy issues, drawing on specialists from the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University and the Rand Corporation, as well as present and former Government officials.
Altogether, Mr. Aspin's plan and personnel choices are intended to forge a new approach and structure for dealing with the national security problems that the United States is facing with the end of the cold war. These include the possibility that democratic reforms in Russia might fail, the spread of weapons of mass destruction, the surge in ethnic strife around the world and the need to retrain workers in the arms industry at home.
In developing his plan, Mr. Aspin is emphasizing diplomatic and military steps to prevent crises before they arise instead of responding to them after they erupt. A senior aide to Mr. Aspin described the plan as an effort to create an "operational design that matches the times."
But some critics assert that Mr. Aspin's plan is a power play to strengthen the Pentagon's hand on foreign policy at the expense of the State Department. They assert that the plan may divert the Pentagon's energies from its primary task of overseeing the shrinking of the military and maintaining and equipping the reduced forces.
 
Bureaucratic Politics
 "It is driven more by the bureaucratic politics of competing with the State Department than dealing with the essential functions of the Defense Department," said Zalmay M. Khalilzad, the Pentagon's head of policy planning in the Bush Administration. "It is ironic that at the time we are going to cut back the forces, the number of senior management officials in the policy domain is increasing."
Under Mr. Aspin's plan, the traditional civilian Pentagon functions will be handled by four branches: weapons acquisition, personnel and readiness, the office of the Pentagon comptroller and an office of national security policy.
The weapons acquisition branch is to be headed by John M. Deutch, a former Under Secretary at the Energy Department, and a professor and a former provost at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
The personnel and readiness branch will oversee the military reserves, health affairs and the military readiness of the forces. The Pentagon comptroller will serve as the chief financial officer. These two appointments have not been disclosed.
The policy branch is to be headed by Frank G. Wisner, a former Ambassador to Egypt and top State Department official. He will assume the post of Under Secretary of Defense for Policy, and his main deputy will be Walter B. Slocombe, an expert on arms control and nuclear forces who was a senior Pentagon official in the Carter Administration.
It is the policy branch that is being reshaped to deal with the new set of issues. The post of Assistant Defense Secretary for Democracy and Human Rights will address military assistance to foreign governments, the training of foreign military forces, American policy on peacekeeping and humanitarian operations undertaken by the military.
The position will give the Pentagon a high-level mechanism for considering human rights criteria in determining the extent of military cooperation with other countries.
Mr. Halperin, who served in the Pentagon and on the National Security Council staff, became known for his lawsuit against Mr. Kissinger. He accusing Mr. Kissinger of authorizing a wiretap of his home when Mr. Halperin worked for Mr. Kissinger when the latter was President Richard M. Nixon's national security adviser. This chapter left over from the Watergate scandal was closed in November, when Mr. Kissinger wrote a letter of apology and Mr. Halperin dropped the suit.
Another new post is that of Assistant Defense Secretary for Nuclear Security and Counter Proliferation. That official would be in charge of arms control, efforts to stem the spread of weapons of mass destruction and eliminate nuclear weapons in the former Soviet republicas, and policy on nuclear forces and anti-missile defenses.
The position is to be filled by Ashton B. Carter, director for the Center for Science and International Affairs at the Kennedy School of Government.
Mr. Carter has a doctorate in theoretical physics from Oxford University and has written on a wide variety of national security issues. During the Reagan Administration, he was a critic of the President's plan to build a space-based anti-missile system. More recently, he has devoted much of his energies to plans to remove nuclear weapons from the former Soviet republics and prevent those weapons from falling into the wrong hands.
 
Elevating Policy Planning
 A new Assistant Defense Secretary for Economic and Environmental Security will deal with converting military industries to civilian production and retraining workers.
The traditional Pentagon job of policy planning is to be raised in status. Graham Allison, the former dean of the Kennedy school and the advocate of the "grand bargain" plan to send billions of dollars of aid to Russia, is to be an Assistant Defense Secretary for Plans and Policy, addressing long-term strategy.
Edward L. Warner, a Rand Corporation expert on the Russian military and on arms control, is to be the Assistant Defense Secretary for Strategy and Resources under Mr. Aspin's plan. Mr. Warner will be responsible for preparing the classified Defense Policy Guidance, which is used to guide the military services in preparing budget plans. He will also play an important role in devising a new structure for the armed forces as Pentagon spending declines.

HEADLINE: Subway in Los Angeles To Open in Modest Step

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 27

 BODY:
Years of debate, delay and construction turn into reality on Saturday when trains begin to roll under Los Angeles in a subway so different from others that passengers will pay their fares on the honor system.
Many in Los Angeles thought it would never happen, and skeptics call the project a boondoggle. But the opening will be a milestone for this sprawling city whose very name suggests cars and clogged freeways. 
 It is a modest start, just 4.4 miles of tunnels linking five stations across downtown. Two sleek Italian-made trains running in opposite directions will carry riders on the seven-minute trip between Union Station and MacArthur Park just west of downtown.
The Metro Red Line, as it is called, would hardly make New Yorkers feel at home. The stations are bright and airy and are filled with dramatic art; the automated trains glide by almost silently. Turnstile jumping has been eliminated, in one sense, by the doing away with turnstiles, though the police will spot check for tickets.
Transit officials said they concluded that the cost of building a fare-collection system would be higher than the amount likely to be lost to cheaters. They said comparisons with New York, where fare-evasion is rampant on the 469-station system, were inappropriate because the Los Angeles system was such a small and closely monitored one. Moreover, many of the subway passengers here are expected to be transfers from commuter rail lines and therefore entitled to ride the Red Line free.
There will be no barriers to the train platforms, a concept borrowed from European and Canadian systems. Sharon K. Papa, chief of police for the transit district, said officers planned to check about one of every four riders for valid tickets. Such a system has been in use on a small above-ground section of the overall rail system for two years, and the rate of noncompliance has been less than one-half of 1 percent.
On a first offense, violators will be removed from the train and given a lesson in how to buy a ticket from a machine in the station. Repeat violators could be fined up to $250.
 
'Freeway of the Future'
 To Los Angeles's visionaries, the opening will be a turning point for a far-flung checkerboard region, where it is difficult to find an urban core and the automobile serves as the chaotic instrument of personal independence.
"We have made public policy that for the next 30 years we are not going to add any more freeways," said Neil Peterson, executive director of the Los Angeles County Transportation Commission, which oversees the subway project. "The freeway of the future is the rail system, tied in with tremendously expanded car-pooling and bikeways."
Transit officials have plans for a 22.7-mile subway system that will be the backbone of a 400-mile commuter rail system and expanded bus service. Such a system would give this area a transit system that would be larger than any other in the country, except New York City's.
Backers hope the system will alter helter-skelter development while reducing traffic congestion and smog. It is projected to cost $78 billion over the next 30 years and is the largest public works program in the United States today.
"The most important question is how this affects development patterns and does it encourage the kind of social and economic behavior we want," said Mark Pisano, executive director of the Southern California Association of Governments, a regional planning organization.
 
Critics Call It Outdated
 But skeptics argue that the rail project is a 20th-century solution to 21st-century urban needs and a huge waste of scarce dollars. They contend that buses and vans offer cheaper and more flexible transportation in a region with so many centers.
"Rail was an appropriate technology at one time, but now we have cities that are spread out massively, and most people do not live or work near a rail line," said Peter Gordon, associate dean for academic affairs at the School of Urban and Regional Planning at the University of Southern California. "It doesn't compete with the convenience of the automobile, and everybody knows that."
Mr. Gordon said the decision to build the subway was a political one tied to creating jobs.
But no such negative voices are likely to rise Saturday when Mayor Tom Bradley and other leaders gather to dedicate the Red Line on the mezzanine of the Pershing Square station amid the dazzling neon art of Stephen Antonakos. The overall system, operated by the Southern California Rapid Transit District, is projected to create 1.4 million jobs over the next three decades. The first segment cost $1.4 billion to build.
The Red Line connects with two surface rail lines that opened recently, the Blue Line that carries commuters 22 miles from Long Beach to downtown Los Angeles, and Metrolink, three train lines from Ventura County, San Bernardino County and the Santa Clarita Valley to Union Station in Los Angeles. The subway will operate from 5 A.M. until 7 P.M. at the start and will be free for the first two months, after which the honor fare system goes into effect.
Under construction or planned are extensions of the subway to Hollywood and on to the San Fernando Valley, and another line that would run out Wilshire Boulevard, then toward West Los Angeles by a route not yet decided. A line to the southeast is also under consideration. In all, by the year 2001, plans call for 20 stations and 22.7 miles of subway at a cost of $5.3 billion in Federal, state and local money.
 
Part of a Vast Network
 The subway is the centerpiece of a vast system, to cost $183 billion over 30 years. It would also include more freeway lanes for car pools and expanded bus service, bikeways and park-and-ride sites. By 2010, the transportation commission estimates that 25 percent of Los Angeles County residents and 29 percent of the county's jobs will be within a half mile of a rail line.
Even so, no one claims that mass transit will replace more than a fraction of the automobile traffic. Today only about 6 percent of Southern Californians use mass transit to get to work, and the number is declining, according to the association of governments.
Mr. Peterson, the head of the transportation commission, said he hoped the figure for Los Angeles County could be raised to 20 percent, or 500,000 commuters a day, in 30 years. (New York City subways and buses, record 4.8 million fares on a typical weekday and carry 49 percent of city's residents to work. In Boston, 65 percent of the trips to downtown are on public transit.)
"We are trying to attract a portion of the population out of their own automobiles," Mr. Peterson said. "This is a very big geographic area. We are not able to use trains everywhere. The subway is just one step toward a transportation system that works in this day and age."
Skeptics doubt the rail system here will attract the expected ridership. They cite studies by Don H. Pickrell, an economist with the National Transportation Systems Center in Cambridge, Mass., that found the forecasts used to justify rail projects in Washington; Miami; Buffalo; Portland, Ore.; Sacramento, Calif., and other cities had grossly overestimated the ridership.
Among the chief critics is Martin Wachs, a former New Yorker who is professor of urban planning at the School of Architecture and Urban Planning at the University of California at Los Angeles. In New York, where subway service began 88 years ago, people "take it for granted the subway is a good thing," he said. "But L.A. has much lower population densities. Less than 5 percent of the employment is downtown. A subway is simply too expensive and will serve too few people."
Professor Wachs supports mass transit, but favors buses and vans, which he says can get closer to most people than rail lines.
Mr. Peterson counters that buses are not the answer for heavily traveled corridors like Wilshire Boulevard, where they can hardly move through traffic today. As for ridership forecasts, he said the two rail lines operating now had healthy patronage, with 36,000 a day on the Blue Line and nearly 4,000 on the three Metrolink suburban lines. Ridership forecasts for the Red Line are 7,800 passengers a day at the start with 12,000 by the end of the year and 350,000 after 30 years.
And he said that complaints about the huge cost of subway construction were shortsighted. "We are building something to last forever," Mr. Peterson said. "Who today wonders whether New York's initial investment in its subway was worth it? That was the best investment New York ever made."

HEADLINE: Guatemalan Chief Pushes for Accord With Rebels

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN

DATELINE: GUATEMALA, Jan. 27

 BODY:
Convinced that the remnants of a guerrilla war damage Guatemala's image abroad and slow its economic development, President Jorge Serrano has begun an intense effort to get a peace accord or a cease-fire in the next few months.
"The truth is that although the conflict affects few people, it is affecting the reputation of the country," he said in an interview in the presidential palace on Tuesday. 
 The initial reaction of the insurgents, the Guatemalan National Revolutionary Union, was tentative approval of the basic points, but the exiled guerrilla leaders also introduced what Mr. Serrano said were new demands: the purge and reduction of the army. He said he was waiting for a further response from them that he hoped would be more flexible.
The President said that the conflict, whose roots go back more than three decades, involves very little actual combat today and that the armed guerrillas number fewer than 500.
"It's an enemy that doesn't appear," he said. "There are no battle lines, the guerrillas don't dominate any territory and are concentrated in the most remote areas of the country. The visible leadership lives in Mexico."
But he said the absence of a peace accord provided the excuse for human rights abuses -- most attributed to the Guatemalan Army or civil defense patrols -- and for the bombings of power stations, bridges and other infrastructure by the guerrillas.
Arguing that the insurgents achieve most of their successes in international forums and among supporters in Europe, the United States and Mexico, he said the conflict had become "5 percent military, 10 to 15 percent national politics, and 80 percent international."
Mr. Serrano, who has made the search for a peace accord a top priority since his election two years ago, first announced his initiative here two weeks ago, then went to New York last week to present it at the United Nations.
He proposed leapfrogging ahead in the intermittent negotiations under way since April 1991, with both sides committing themselves to a 90-day period of nonstop talks.
If a definitive accord could not be reached in that time, he proposed that both sides agree to declare cease-fires and that the guerrillas concentrate their forces in designated safety zones in the Guatemalan highlands, where United Nations forces would be asked "to guarantee that there is no provocation by the army."
He said the 90 days could begin as soon as the Government and insurgent leaders signed a human rights accord, which has already been negotiated. He said he was ready to sign the rights agreement and to accept international verification of it, if the guerrillas accepted the rest of his package.
 
A Visit to New York
 The seriousness of Mr. Serrano's peace effort was somewhat undercut here in recent days by press attention and public tittering over the visit he made, while in New York, to a restaurant and bar that features topless dancers. A freelance cameraman taped Mr. Serrano as he left the establishment, Stringfellows, and made it available to the Spanish-language television network, Univision, which broadcast it.
The President said he knew nothing about the place before his party arrived there. He said the group, which included the Defense Minister and the President's two college-age sons, went out in search of food one night and went to Stringfellows at the suggestion of Guatemala's delegate to the United Nations.
Mr. Serrano said that he decided to leave as soon as he saw the inside of the place but that his security people had asked him to wait until the rest of his party had arrived in separate cars. He said he had spent less than an hour there.
The President said that while he would never have intentionally taken his sons there, what they saw "was nothing more than any kid can see on television today."
He also said he had been to shows in Paris with his wife that were "probably more risque -- at the Folies-Bergere and the Moulin Rouge."

HEADLINE: Labor Secretary Says Extension Of Jobless Benefits Is on the Table

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
In the face of huge layoffs at companies like Sears Roebuck, Boeing and Pratt & Whitney, the Clinton Administration is preparing to extend the unemployment benefits of the 1.7 million Americans now receiving them, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said today.
"I think that's likely," Mr. Reich said in an interview. "It's on the table. The President has not made a decision. But it seems to me that given the sluggish rate of job creation and persistently high unemployment numbers, it seems that emergency unemployment compensation will be extended and that the President will seek to do that." 
 Mr. Reich said the Administration was also considering extending the benefits of workers who had been without work so long that they had exhausted up to 59 weeks of regular benefits and extensions. A Labor Department official said 256,000 workers fell into that group.
Mr. Reich also reaffirmed two of Mr. Clinton's campaign promises: to raise the Federal minimum wage of $4.25 an hour and to prohibit employers from hiring permanent replacements for workers who strike. The striker-replacement issue is the highest priority for many labor unions this year.
 
Expectations on Spending
 Mr. Reich also elaborated on his disclosure Tuesday that the President favored spending about $20 billion to stimulate the economy. And for the first time he described how the Administration might distribute that spending: a third might be used for public works, like building roads and bridges; a third for job training and education, and a third to induce companies in invest in machinery and equipment to increase production. The last part represents the money the Government would lose by granting industry a 10 percent tax credit to make the investments.
In several appearances this week on television news programs and before Congress, Mr. Reich has been speaking harshly of many companies where, he says, workers are treated as costs rather than assets. This morning on the NBC program "Today," he called many recent large-scale layoffs in industry "a management failure."
He said the bill on family and medical leave was one of many "sticks" the Administration would use to try to persuade companies to treat workers more humanely. That bill was vetoed by President George Bush, but it is swiftly moving through Congress again. The Labor Secretary added that better treatment of workers would also be sought by stricter enforcement of health and safety regulations and laws regulating other working conditions.
 
Layoffs Spur Fuel Plans
 But Mr. Reich said he wanted to enlist "enlightened" management leaders, including those who allowed their employees family and medical leave without Government pressure, to work with him and organized labor in encouraging managers of other companies to treat employees as assets.
The Administration's interest in extending unemployment benefits, a possibility that Mr. Reich also mentioned on the "Today" program, was spurred by the latest announcements of layoffs. Despite the economy's continuing growth, Mr. Reich said the layoffs were evidence that "we're not out of the woods." He said, "Until you get jobs back, you don't have a genuine recovery."
After months of opposition by the Bush Administration, Congress enacted an extension of unemployment benefits in November 1991. After losing jobs involuntarily, workers normally receive up to 26 weeks of benefits, typically one-third to one-half of their prior wages. In its 1991 action, Congress granted them another 26 to 33 weeks of pay, depending on the level of unemployment in their states.
Congress later renewed the extension program twice. But workers were allowed no more than 59 weeks of benefits, so many who have been unable to find jobs for more than a year have now exhausted their benefits. Mr. Reich said the Administration was considering granting benefits to these people as well as to other workers who had lost jobs more recently.
 
Disagreement by Economists
 Economists are divided over the wisdom of extending coverage again at this time. Some say the added spending will be counterproductive, driving up the budget deficit at a time when the economy may be generating more new jobs on its own.
But others said that the last recession was unique because it drove many workers out of jobs permanently as companies closed or found ways to rely on fewer workers. They say the extended benefits will allow those workers more time to seek training for new kinds of work.
"All the forecasters are still talking about continued slow job growth," said Jeff Faux, president of the Economic Policy Institute, a research group with ties to organized labor. "We're dealing with a job problem that makes this recovery unique."
Mr. Reich reiterated Mr. Clinton's campaign promise to raise the minimum wage by indexing it to the rate of inflation or letting it rise in line with increases in consumer prices, just as Social Security benefits do now. But he said that he first favored a straight increase in the wage, then indexing it from that point on. Mr. Reich said that he was speaking for himself and that the White House had not yet settled on a minimum-wage proposal.
Legislation to enact an increase is some months off, he said, because forcing an increase now may hurt companies that are still working their way out of the recession and discourage them from hiring as many people as they might otherwise. "Maybe you want to wait a little bit until the job situation improves," he said.

HEADLINE: Executive Brief: THE WHITE HOUSE;
Young Staff's First Steps Are Right Back in Time

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
The staff members at the Clinton White House were still flush with victory from the campaign and recovering from a week of inaugural parties when they moved into their new digs last week. Then they saw the typewriters.
Most of the young staff had been reared on easy-touch computer keyboards, satellite dishes, voice mail and fax machines. They were horrified. 
 "This is the White House," said Dee Dee Myers, the press secretary. "It is a beautiful building, less posh than people would suspect and certainly with less space. But technologically, it's somewhere between Roosevelt and Truman."
At the Presidential campaign headquarters in Little Rock, Ark., Bill Clinton's aides could push one button and watch their candidate on satellite or pick up their phones and listen to him giving a live speech. News-service machines hummed on every floor, and the computers had three levels of electronic mail through which aides could communicate with each other and process requests from constituents.
To understand the culture shock, note this: One of former President George Bush's first tasks on retiring to Houston last week was to learn how to operate a computer, nearly a year after a first lesson in the White House was scheduled and then canceled.
Call the change generational. Call it cultural. The people at the White House are calling it "techno-shock."
"There is no technology at the White House," moaned a Presidential assistant as he left the Executive Mansion one night this week on his way to a working dinner.
Complaints about the White House by new occupants are a tradition dating from the 19th century. And most of the White House employees who are coping with adjustment hesitate to be quoted by name for fear that their criticism might be construed as kicking the Republicans when they're down.
"It's not nice to beat on them anymore, because we've already beat them," said one of these officials, who insisted on anonymity. But he added that by his computer-era standards the previous White House staff was "grossly inefficient."
Phone lines to the executive offices have been clogged for days, and one aide said he was shocked to discover that there were 65 phone systems feeding into the White House.
When senior aides want the latest news-service report, they have to hustle downstairs to the situation room in the basement of the West Wing, a paneled room that is a secure military command center full of classified material.
"The Republicans always said they wanted to run things like a business," said Paul Begala, a campaign consultant who will continue to help President Clinton under contract to the Democratic National Committee. "Instead, they were running it like Bartleby the scrivener."
The cost of preparing the White House for the 21st century might be prohibitive, and any changes would have to take into account the building's historical significance.
But White House officials said this was a hurdle that would be overcome.
"The first few days was complete techno-shock," Ms. Myers said. "But now we've had some therapy and are working through it."
 
Readying Work Space For the New First Aide
 At the West Wing, which houses the President's offices, workers are painting and hanging new drapes in the new second-floor offices of Hillary Rodham Clinton, the senior, unpaid domestic policy adviser who is also married to the President.
Mrs. Clinton's base will be the office that was last occupied by Janet G. Mullins, the aide to James A. Baker 3d who has emerged as a central figure in the investigation of Republican participation in the illegal search of Mr. Clinton's passport files.
A spokeswoman for Mrs. Clinton said she was unaware of the office's previous occupant.
Mrs. Clinton, a successful lawyer when she was in private practice, will be near the southwest corner office of the White House counsel, Bernard W. Nussbaum, and a few doors down from Carol Rascoe, the President's paid domestic policy adviser. Mrs. Clinton's chief of staff, Maggie Williams, will move into an office used by a deputy White House counsel under Mr. Bush.
Mrs. Clinton's office, not one of the floor's cushier spaces, is being outfitted with new electrical outlets to accommodate a fax machine and a coffee maker. The bulk of her support staff will remain in the traditional East Wing offices of the First Lady.
 
From Cuba and Manila Bay To Caucuses in Des Moines
 Other changes on Pennsylvania Avenue: The White House's new tenants plan to re-create a highly successful and widely chronicled campaign tactic by opening a political "war room" on the first floor of the ornate 19th-century Old Executive Office Building.
The war room back in Little Rock served as a crisis clearinghouse, and it was there that political consultants posted the famous Clinton campaign mantra: "It's the economy, stupid."
The new version will be in the map room used in the McKinley Administration as a base of operations for the Spanish-American War. No word yet on a slogan for the wall.
Outfitted with televisions and fax machines, the room is expected to be less reliant on cutting-edge technology than the White House areas will become.
"The war room is more of a state of mind than a state of technology," said one White House official.

HEADLINE: Big Business in Turmoil

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
When the takeover raiders finally left the stage at the end of the 1980's, things were supposed to calm down in corporate America. But the steady stream of surprising announcements this week, from the departure of chief executives at I.B.M. and Westinghouse to the layoffs at Sears, Boeing and McDonnell Douglas, underlines the continuing turmoil in America's corporate economy.
This time, instead of high-rolling financiers, the instability is being fueled by fast-changing markets. To be sure, there are a mix of forces at work at these name-brand corporations, including a sluggish economy, shifts in technology, new rivals, restive shareholders and suddenly uppity boards of directors. 
 "These cutbacks are largely the result of an intensification of competitive forces, so that companies can no longer make piecemeal changes," said Michael Porter, a professor at the Harvard Business School. "And most of the management changes are part of the same phenomenon. These are companies that didn't move quickly enough in the past."
For the Clinton Administration, the relentless attrition at big companies raises questions about the health of the economy and what policies to pursue. "Icon after icon in the American economy is falling," said Lester Thurow, an economist and the dean of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's graduate school of management. "That has got to hurt the economy by demoralizing workers and consumers."
Secretary of Labor Robert B. Reich expressed a similar concern yesterday. In an interview on the NBC News program "Today," he noted some signs of strength in the economy, but added, "The employment picture is still very, very bad."
The consequences of the turmoil on so many factory floors and in executive suites are likely to extend well beyond the current economic cycle. Though it began years ago, the shrinkage of big companies now seems to be accelerating. That trend will affect the way companies are governed and how workers are treated in the future. Since World War II it has been large corporations that have set the standards for corporate management and labor relations.
Now, the notion that a person stays with a single company for decades, remaining loyal and receiving job security and ample benefits in return, is essentially a big-company concept that may be dying. In a fast-changing economy, where more and more companies try to remain small and nimble while farming out tasks to subcontractors, this old model of company-worker relations is far less prevalent.
"It becomes much harder in the modern world to guarantee things to employees for years and years," said Daniel Mitchell, a professor at the University of California at Los Angeles's graduate school of management. "That's okay for younger people, who no longer build their lives around stability. But that transition is very painful for someone who is 50 and has just lost a job at a company like I.B.M."
 
Domestic Competition
 In the past, when economists and business school professors spoke of competition, it was all but inevitably preceded by the word foreign, which usually meant Japanese. Today, the big companies being battered are more typically the victims of efficient American rivals, with novel approaches to their industries or innovative uses of technology.
Sears, Roebuck & Company, for example, has not kept up with retailers like Wal-Mart, Home Depot and others, in using computers to track sales, trim inventory and reduce costs. For its part, I.B.M. has been slow to adjust to the shift away from big mainframes toward increasingly powerful but less costly personal computers and work stations.
The companies that have created or successfully exploited shifts in technology, like the Microsoft Corporation, the dominant producer of operating software for personal computers, are producing jobs and wealth while the old-line firms are shrinking. By one estimate, the more than 2,200 people who have become millionaires -- on paper, at least -- by simply working for Microsoft and holding its stock outnumber the people who were made instant millionaires on Wall Street during the takeover boom of the mid-80's.
Whether the companies emerging as the new stars of corporate America will add jobs as quickly as some old-line giants are shearing them is doubtful. But a certain amount of turmoil is part of the cycle of renewal that is inevitable and ultimately healthy in a market economy, though undeniably painful for the workers affected.
All cutbacks are not necessarily a signal of management failure or proof that a company is locked in a cycle of inevitable decline. For example, analysts praised the Boeing Company's management for moving fairly quickly to cut back production of commercial jets in response to lower demand, a contraction that may eliminate as many as 30,000 jobs. And companies like I.B.M. are genuinely trying to change in order to regain their competitiveness, although their success is by no means certain.
 
Investor Pressure
 In the 80's, it was the threat of being taken over by a corporate raider that generated the pressure to change a company's strategy or its management team. But anti-takeover laws in some 35 states and reduced lending for corporate acquisitions has removed that threat for now.
Instead, the pressure for change is coming from large institutional shareholders, like pension funds and mutual funds, that lean on the outside directors on corporate boards. It was outside directors that played a prominent role in the top management changes at General Motors, I.B.M., Westinghouse and elsewhere.
"We're going to see more of that," said John Nash, president of the National Association of Corporate Directors, in Washington. "The board has always had the power to make these changes in theory, but now directors' feet are being held to the fire by the institutional investors."
Michael Jensen, a professor at the Harvard Business School, sees the active roles taken by big investors as the 90's version of the capital markets' trying to exercise some control over corporate America, serving as a kind of natural policeman over entrenched managements. In his view, it was corporate management excesses that created the opportunities for raiders in the 80's.
"Corporate changes are always driven by market forces," Mr. Jensen said. "It's just a question of whether the pressure comes from the capital markets or the product markets."
