HEADLINE: U.S. Imposes Heavy Tariffs On Steel From 19 Countries

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
In a victory for American steelmakers, the Commerce Department imposed steep, temporary tariffs today on steel imports from 19 countries, after determining that foreign companies were illegally selling steel in the United States for less than they did at home.
Today's rulings were the first big trade decisions under the Clinton Administration, although they were made by career civil servants following trade regulations rather than by Clinton appointees. 
 In a statement today, Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown approached the issue gingerly. The rulings were not necessarily an indication of the Administration's trade policies, he said, but he added that "the Administration fully supports the rights of the domestic industry to obtain relief from unfair trade practices under U.S. laws."
 
Foreign Steelmakers Protest
 Foreign steelmakers protested today's decisions, but had already reduced steel shipments to the United States in anticipation. Industry officials said, however, that they did not foresee a shortage because of large inventories and overcapacity. But as foreign competition weakens, domestic steel prices have already begun to rise, and could eventually result in slightly higher prices for cars, refrigerators and other products made from steel.
The preliminary tariffs take effect immediately and the Commerce Department will set final tariffs, which may be higher or lower, by late spring. But before the tariffs become permanent, domestic steelmakers must also persuade the International Trade Commission, an independent United States agency, that steel imports are a significant cause of the industry's woes. Imports equal roughly a sixth of the United States market, which is also the amount of unused production capacity of the struggling American industry.
Domestic and foreign steel industry officials predicted that there would be tremendous pressure from foreign governments on the Clinton Administration to replace the tariffs with tonnage limits on steel imports. Foreign producers prefer the limits instead of tariffs because limits that restrict the supply of steel tend to raise prices, whereas producers pay tariffs themselves.
Tonnage restrictions, in place for nine years, expired in March and the Bush Administration refused to renew them, contending that tariffs would be better for world trade.
Today's rulings were in response to legal petitions by domestic steelmakers, which have been improving their productivity but have continued to lose money in a weak economy, especially as new factories open that recycle steel from scrap.
Foreign officials were quick to protest today's decisions. "This action is unwarranted and wholly disproportionate," said Sir Leon Brittan, the European Community's Commissioner for External Economic Affairs. Steel from 7 of the community's 12 member countries came under today's rulings.
The Ministry of International Trade and Industry in Japan said in a statement today that the American steel industry's problems were the result of domestic troubles rather than foreign competition. While the ministry did not provide any examples of these troubles, the American industry has been burdened with high pension and retiree health care costs, and has lagged its foreign competitors in developing cheaper ways to produce better-quality steel.
A senior Japanese official who insisted on anonymity said on Tuesday that while President Clinton was perceived in Japan as a supporter of free trade, aggressive remarks about trade policy by his Cabinet officials might be wrongly encouraging industries here to take advantage of American trade laws to seek tariffs on their competitors. The auto industry is preparing similar cases against imported cars.
The rulings cover $2.6 billion a year worth of imported flat-rolled and plate steel, which hold a sixth of the United States market for these products. The preliminary tariffs averaged 27 percent, while ranging from three-hundredths of a percent for plate steel from one Canadian steelmaker to 27 percent for corrosion-resistant flat steel from Japan and 109 percent for plate steel from Britain.
The tariffs imposed today are in addition to preliminary tariffs averaging 12.5 percent that the Commerce Department imposed last November on steel from 12 countries that were deemed to be subsidizing their domestic steel industries. The rule of thumb in the steel industry is that, at current price levels, a 15 percent tariff will price foreign steel out of the market.
"It's obvious that most imports will be suspended," said Yoshitaka Fujitani, the president of NKK America, the United States arm of the Tokyo-based NKK Corporation.
But the average level of tariffs disguises the fact that low tariffs were imposed on steel from Germany, Belgium and Canada; these countries may continue shipments.
The preliminary tariffs may be paid in cash or, more commonly, by posting a bond equal to the value of the tariffs owed. If the case is not settled, the next step will be for the Commerce Department to review the preliminary tariffs and set a final level of tariffs, which may be higher or lower, by late spring.
But before the tariffs become permanent, domestic steelmakers must also persuade the International Trade Commission of their case this summer. The commission is independent of Congress and the Administration and is composed of three Democrats and three Republicans.
If the commission rules against the domestic industry then the tariffs are canceled and all bonds are returned. The commission's rulings are commonly appealed to the courts.
If the tariffs today were calculated fairly then they are appropriate and legal, said William Cline, a free-trade economist at the Institute for International Economics. The world steel market is plagued by overcapacity and subsidized production by foreign, state-owned steel companies.
But Federal law for calculating the tariffs tends to favor the domestic industry, and the imposition of high tariffs today could result in overwhelming foreign pressure on the Clinton Administration to revive the old system of assigning different slices of the United States market to foreign countries, Mr. Cline added. Tariffs produce tax revenues, but are more likely to anger consumers and bring on trade wars.
William Lane, the trade specialist for Caterpillar Inc., a tractor producer and large steel user based in Peoria, Ill., said that the company did not object to the tariffs because it had long-term contracts with American producers already. But the company would object to market share deals, he said, adding that such pacts are, "nothing more than a plea bargain, where you allow the accused to participate in a price-fixing scheme."
The tariffs may never reach the final stage at the Commerce Department, as foreign governments begin lobbying the Administration for separate deals, which may include quantity limits on steel imports or minimum prices for them. Canadian officials said on Tuesday that Michael Wilson, Canada's trade minister, had tried in the last several days to persuade the Clinton Administration to make an exception for Canadian steel, which is closely integrated with the American industry.
"If you look at past history, no case involving a significant amount of trade has ever gone to finals -- this will be the first if it does," said Nicholas C. Tolerico, a former Commerce Department steel import administrator who is now the director of Federal relations of the LTV Corporation, a domestic steelmaker.
Mr. Fujitani said that the American tariffs poisoned the atmosphere for negotiations. "Nobody wants to negotiate with a counterpart who has a sword behind him and pretends to be friendly," he said.
Besides Britain, Canada and Japan, the other countries cited are Argentina, Australia, Austria, Belgium, Brazil, Finland, France, Germany, Italy, South Korea, Mexico, the Netherlands, Poland, Romania, Spain and Sweden.

HEADLINE: Blanche Bernstein, 80, Official Who Criticized Welfare System

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Dr. Blanche Bernstein, a prominent welfare expert and former government official whose criticisms of the welfare system provoked stormy policy debates, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 80 and lived in Manhattan.
She died of lung cancer, said Barbara Rulnick, a niece. 
 Dr. Bernstein argued that the welfare system's major failing is in fostering continued dependency for people receiving aid, instead of guiding them off the welfare rolls to independence.
"Reduction of dependency is the greatest unmet need in social policy today," she once said. "We have not gotten to the heart of the problem."
Her pronouncements often stirred opposition from other officials, experts and advocates. Some accused her of being unsympathetic to poor people and minorities, which she denied.
Supporters said her aim was to help the truly needy while paring cheaters and ineligible recipients from welfare and reducing erroneous overpayments.
 
High-Ranking Welfare Posts
 In 1978-79 she headed the nation's largest local welfare agency when she served as the city's Human Resources Administrator, with more than a million residents receiving aid. Mayor Edward I. Koch appointed and praised her as "terrific."
But during her term more than 100,000 people were pared from the welfare rolls. After she came under fire from a number of black officials, Mr. Koch named a deputy with superseding power over her, and she resigned. The Mayor's action was widely interpreted as a concession to soothe his frayed minority relations.
Dr. Bernstein also served as the State Social Services Department's deputy commissioner for income maintenance from 1975-77, under Gov. Hugh L. Carey. She was in charge of public assistance, food stamps and welfare job programs.
Later she recounted her battles and explained her policies in "The Politics of Welfare: The New York City Experience" (Abt, 1982), which Fortune magazine called "wonderfully instructive."
An economist, Dr. Bernstein earlier held policy posts in the State Department, worked for charities, was an educator and researched a wide array of social problems.
Among the issues she studied were foster care, the effect of welfare on family stability, obstacles to drug treatment for addicts, impoverished Jews, day care, obstacles to employment for welfare recipients, mental health care, welfare spending, family budgets and prenatal care.
 
Director at New School
 Dr. Bernstein focused increasingly on the growing and entwined problems of teen-age mothers, single-parent families, poor education, school dropout and unemployment. Unless society "breaks the cycle of dependency and poverty," she said, "we are in danger of creating a permanent underclass."
On leaving government in 1979, she became the director of the Social Policy Research Institute at the New School for Social Research. The institute studied welfare, housing, health care, child neglect and abuse and services for the aged.
After retiring from the New School, she remained in education as a trustee of the City University of New York.
Dr. Bernstein was born in New York City. She graduated from Hunter College and received a master's degree and a doctorate in economics at Columbia.
Her survivors include a brother, Hilliard, of Manhattan.

HEADLINE: White House Memo;
Timing Awry, Clinton Trips Into a Brawl

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
Acknowledging that they underestimated the opposition in Congress and the Pentagon to homosexuals in the military, White House aides say the struggle has left President Clinton in an awkward test of wills on an issue that neither he nor gay-rights organizations had made a high priority.
As a result, at a moment when he is more interested in dealing with his economic agenda, Mr. Clinton has little choice but to expend precious political capital with Congress in pushing ahead on his campaign promise to end the military's ban on homosexuals. 
 Although the White House scrambled today to seek compromise with lawmakers, aides to Mr. Clinton made clear that he would not back down from his goal of reversing the ban and thus avoid being attacked either for breaking another campaign pledge or for abandoning his gay constituency.
But the course of events left some of Mr. Clinton's strongest supporters conceding that he miscalculated the political repercussions of his pledge from the start. Many argued that the President could have had an easier time if he had dealt with the ban last week, when he issued orders on abortion and other matters.
 
Wasting a Powerful Argument
 "If he had done it last week, it would have been one of five things," said Representative Patricia Schroeder, a Colorado Democrat who sought to build Congressional support for Mr. Clinton's position. "There would have been some screaming about it, but not this media feeding frenzy."
She also said White House aides should have more convincingly argued to Congress that this was not only a civil rights issue but one of national security. "They didn't emphasize that it doesn't make sense for people who are handling the top secrets of the nation to be exposed to blackmail," she said.
Although the extent of public opposition to homosexuals in the military is impossible to judge accurately, there has been a far louder outcry in the past several days on the issue than there was during the campaign.
Mr. Clinton's move should have come as no surprise either to the military or to Congress: ending the ban was firmly and consistently listed as a campaign pledge, even if heraised the issue only sporadically on the trail.
 
A String of Misjudgments
 While gay organizations have long demanded that homosexuals be admitted into the military, their political efforts during the campaign were concentrated on raising money to fight the AIDS epidemic and on broader efforts to protect homosexuals against discrimination in housing and the workplace.
"I think it's something that we almost backed into," Mr. Clinton said when asked in an interview in August about his positions on matters important to gay Americans. While he said his proposal on homosexuals in the military would "frighten some Americans," he predicted that "if the American people will hear me out I have what I consider to be a basic, common-sense view of this."
What Mr. Clinton clearly did not anticipate then was that some people would try to expand his comments into a referendum on whether homosexuality is acceptable in America.
Nor did he appear to anticipate the eagerness with which Republican lawmakers seized on the issue to give him a political fight early in his Administration.
 
Powell as Antagonist
 Even more important, Mr. Clinton's advisers said, the President did not anticipate the depth of outrage among Democrats in Congress and the Joint Chiefs of Staff over an issue that to them was in many ways symbolic and, on its face, less complicated than practical matters like improving the economy. But the matter became so contentious that at a time of international crises, it dominated Mr. Clinton's first meeting with the Joint Chiefs.
In particular, said David Mixner, an adviser to Mr. Clinton on gay issues during the campaign, the new Administration never expected that the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs, Gen. Colin L. Powell, would oppose the ban with such intensity, though his position has long been known.
"His failure to exert moral leadership has allowed this issue to grow into what it has grown into," Mr. Mixner said of General Powell. In the long term, he said, "I don't think it's going to hurt Clinton politically; people will respect that he kept to his word, stuck to his guns, standing up for unpopular issues. Isn't that a little bit of what Ross Perot was all about?"
But many gay-rights advocates complained that Mr. Clinton was naive in believing he could change people's minds on such a controversial issue, and they contended that he could have limited the debate by moving more quickly and forcefully.
 
'It's Killing Us'
 "This is an organized effort by the religious right to slap Clinton around in the first 10 days," said William W. Waybourn, executive director of the Gay and Lesbian Victory Fund, a political action committee. "They've been beating it to death for the last 72 hours. It's killing us."
Marvin Liebman, a conservative who is a gay-rights advocate, said Mr. Clinton should have signed an executive order last week. "Clinton caused it to become an explosive political issue by inaction," he said. "The more you let these characters talk -- the military men like to flex their muscles -- the more trouble you're going to get with it. He's being pushed around by the military."
Mr. Mixner disagreed. "No politician," he said, "has used up more political capital on behalf of our community in the history of the country."

HEADLINE: Westinghouse Chief Steps Down

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
Paul E. Lego, the 62-year-old engineer who presided over the collapse of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's finance subsidiary, announced yesterday that he was retiring after two and a half years as the corporation's chairman and chief executive.
The company's directors declined to name an immediate replacement and said it might look outside the company for one. But Richard M. Morrow, a member of the board and the retired chairman of the Amoco Corporation, was installed as the nonexecutive chairman. Gary M. Clark, head of the company's special operations group, was chosen president and acting chief executive and given a seat on the board. 
 Mr. Lego's decision to step down was but the latest in a series changes at the top of major American corporations. Just Tuesday, the International Business Machines Corporation announced that John F. Akers would soon step down as chief executive.
 
 
New Era
 And in recent months, Robert C. Stempel of the General Motors Corporation, Kenneth H. Olson of the Digital Equipment Corporation and Joseph (Rod) Canion of Compaq Computer have been ousted by directors.
The departures are indications, for one thing, of a new era in corporate governance, in which powerful institutional investors are putting pressure on long-passive boards to remove chief executives who do not meet their standards of financial performance. Other forces are at work, too, of course, such as the disappointing economic recovery and changing domestic and foreign markets.
At Westinghouse, Mr. Morrow said the board would commence searching for a permanent chief executive, pointedly saying that candidates outside the company would be considered along with Mr. Clark and other current Westinghouse executives. Westinghouse has traditionally promoted from within. Mr. Morrow said the board had not yet decided whether a new chief executive would be given the chairman's title as well.
 
 
Dividend Cuts
 As announced last fall, the board cut the common stock dividend 44 percent, to 10 cents a share from 18 cents. Last January, the dividend was reduced from 35 cents a share.
In trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, Westinghouse's share price gained 25 cents, to $14.
Mr. Lego, like Mr. Akers and the other chief executives under fire, was unable to reverse enormous losses. Whereas Mr. Akers's troubles lay in the rapidly changing nature of the computer business, Mr. Lego's were the legacy of a lending spree in the 1980's by Westinghouse Financial Services. The unit invested heavily in real estate, leveraged buyout securities and junk bonds, many of which have declined sharply in value.
As a result the company had to take a series of charges against earnings that produced losses of $1.096 billion in 1991 and $1.18 billion last year. In November, bowing to pressure from institutional investors, the company announced that it was getting out of financial services and would sell some of its profitable businesses to pay for the losses incurred by the unit.
The actions, which are scheduled to be carried out over a two-year period, will shrink the company by about one-third, to about $8 billion in sales from $12 billion.
At a news conference yesterday, Mr. Lego insisted that he had decided independently to retire and had not been asked to depart by directors. But he conceded that they had made no effort to persuade him to stay.
Analysts said whether he had decided to retire on his own or responded to signals from the board, Mr. Lego was affected by the recent willingness of large institutional shareholders to press for the ouster of chief executives of poorly performing companies.
"It is clear that Paul Lego is another casualty of the Westinghouse Financial Services problem," Kemp Fuller Jr., a vice president of RAS Securities, said. "He joins John Akers, Bob Stempel at G.M. and Ed Hennessy at Allied-Signal." Allied-Signal, in addition to the others, failed to satisfy investors that it was taking effective action to improve financial performance.
Analysts said Mr. Lego's departure was a positive development for the company, since Mr. Clark would be able to focus more on running Westinghouse's remaining businesses. The decision to name Mr. Morrow, an outside director, as chairman signals that the board intends to be more actively involved in evaluating management decisions, they said.
It was quite clear that Mr. Lego lost the power to designate his successor. Although he talked about "Gary Clark and his team" being in place to execute plans that Mr. Lego had made, Mr. Morrow made it clear in a separate statement that the board intended to look elsewhere for management talent as well. "Certainly Mr. Clark is a candidate," he said. But he said the board would evaluate "candidates outside the corporation."
 
 
'Full Support'
 Mr. Morrow said the board did not have a timetable for selecting a new chief executive, but expected to actively conduct a search. In the meantime, he said Mr. Clark had "the full support of the board."
Mr. Lego said Westinghouse decided to liquidate the financial services operation itself after negotiations to sell the portfolio to the GE Capital Corporation broke down last year. He said both sides agreed on the price, but could not agree on when Westinghouse's responsibility for the assets, some of which require additional lending, would end.
"It was like selling a hotel and then six months later asbestos is discovered," he said. "Who is responsible? It was that kind of thing." Mr. Lego said the company would realize greater value by selling the finance unit's assets by itself, rather than selling them as a package to GE Capital. However, he said such a package sale "would have looked better from the outside."
Mr. Lego said last year that he was all but forced to announce the liquidation of financial services when a relatively small, $55 million write-off in the third quarter brought protests from investors and sent the stock price plunging. He said the softness of the real estate market made it likely that there would be continuing charges, so he decided to announce all the bad news at once.
 The problems in financial services have dogged Mr. Lego almost from the day he took over as chief executive in July 1990. He spoke yesterday about "the problems I inherited when I became chairman." But he declined to blame his predecessor, John C. Marous, for the risky loans that pumped up profits when they were made, but which turned into financial disaster when the economy slumped. "History is history," he said.
Mr. Lego is a native of Johnstown, Pa.. He earned bachelor's and master's degrees in electrical engineering from the University of Pittsburgh and spent his entire career at Westinghouse, which has its headquarters in Pittsburgh.
He was named president in 1987 and was designated at that time as the successor to Mr. Marous, since the latter was due to reach retirement age in three years. Both executives spent most of their careers in Westinghouse's manufacturing operations and had little experience with financial services.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Backs Plan Of Clinton

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
Giving his long-awaited blessing to the new Administration's program, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, told Congress today that he agreed with the "general thrust" of President Clinton's policies to speed growth with a modest short-term stimulus plan.
In his first public comments on the new Administration's plans, Mr. Greenspan said he did not believe the President's policies would overstimulate the economy, a move that could reignite inflation and push the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates to stop the economy from overheating. 
 Administration officials have been hungry for Mr. Greenspan's seal of approval because it would not only reassure financial markets but should also mean the Federal Reserve chairman will be in no rush to raise interest rates. On Tuesday, Administration officials said they were likely to increase deficit spending by about $20 billion this year to spur growth and create jobs.
 
Still Sees Problems
 Mr. Greenspan, often called the nation's most powerful economic policy maker, appeared to see room for some stimulus because he said there were still many problems preventing robust growth, including big corporate layoffs, consumer debt burdens and cuts in defense spending.
"Although a number of economic indicators are distinctly encouraging, this is not to say that we have clear sailing ahead," Mr. Greenspan told the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.
In a week when Pratt & Whitney, Sears, Roebuck and other large corporations have announced big layoffs, Mr. Greenspan said there was virtually no job growth during this recovery and forecast that corporations would continue large layoffs.
Noting that he had breakfast today with Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, Mr. Greenspan said he was heartened that the new Administration favored "maximum sustainable growth," a technical phrase that Federal Reserve officials use to mean growth that is not so fast that it will reignite inflation.
 
Stresses Common Ground
 Although Mr. Greenspan's remarks are often hard to decipher, he appeared to take pains to say that he saw eye-to-eye with the Administration on several issues.
"The general thrust of the policy of this Administration is not different from that which I expressed in my prepared remarks -- that is, to sustain maximum sustainable growth over the long run," he said. "What it is we do not want to do is get into the stop-go type of instabilities which have so characterized many of our periods in the past. I think neither we, nor President Clinton, would basically subscribe to that view."
 Several Clinton aides have voiced fears in recent weeks that the Federal Reserve might push up interest rates if growth picked up to well above its current rate of 3 percent. For their part, several Federal Reserve officials said privately that they had feared the Clinton Administration would embrace too large a stimulus plan of, say, $60 billion in increased deficit spending this year.
At today's hearing, the lawmakers welcomed Mr. Greenspan's cooperative tone, but several warned the central bank not to raise interest rates soon because that could crimp economic growth when job creation has been minuscule.
Representative David R. Obey, the Wisconsin Democrat who is the new chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, said, "It would be a sad irony indeed for the country to have voted to end the gridlock in economic policy between the Congress and the President only to find it replaced with a new gridlock between an Administration and Congress committed to stronger growth and a Federal Reserve restraining growth by keeping its foot on the monetary brakes."
 
Agreement on Deficit
 Mr. Greenspan appeared to give a subtle vote of confidence to Mr. Clinton's vague plans to cut the budget deficit. He noted that "the evidence that that President Clinton" has "very seriously focused on this long-term budget deficit has impacted" on financial markets and helped pull down long-term interest rates.
Cautious as always, Mr. Greenspan said that "economic activity has been increasing at a firmer pace of late," but he added that "we are still not out of the woods."
He was optimistic about inflation, noting that the underlying inflation rate, after excluding volatile changes in food and energy prices -- was 3.3 percent in 1992, a full percentage point below the 1991 rate.
Responding to a question from Mr. Obey, he said, "If you're asking me do I think that the inflation rate is likely to accelerate any time soon, the answer to that is, I will stipulate, probably not."
Mr. Greenspan said the cascade of large corporate layoffs could jeopardize the recent gains in consumer confidence. He added that further strong increases in consumer spending were "not very likely in the absence of a sustained pickup in income growth," which usually does not happen without job growth.

HEADLINE: Taxes on Household Employment

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
Although Zoe Baird ran into political trouble principally because she hired illegal aliens as household workers, her other offense -- not paying taxes on their earnings -- is an even more common practice.
Anyone who pays a household employee more than $50 in a quarter is required by law to arrange for payment of Social Security and Medicaid taxes, which are shared by the employer and the employee. And if a household worker earns more than $1,000 in a quarter (or about $80 a week), Federal and often state unemployment taxes are due as well. Federal income tax need not be withheld from the worker's pay, although some employers do withhold it. 
 Employers could hire an accountant to handle the work for a modest price. Or they could take a few hours to learn the system and, by marking the calendar, could complete the task within an hour or two every three months and a few additional hours at the end of the year.
A simpler filing process, which was included in broader tax legislation that was vetoed last year, is likely to be enacted this year. Under the existing system, employers of domestic workers are supposed to file quarterly forms by Monday because the normal deadline, Jan. 31, falls on Sunday. Employees are also supposed to have received their 1992 wage statements, showing the amounts earned and withheld, by Monday.
People who have not been complying with the law might be hard pressed to meet that deadline, but I.R.S. officials said that it is a good time to come into compliance. The agency is taking a gentle approach these days to those who seek help with compliance. Although penalties may be assessed for past transgressions, the agency will often arrange to spread out the payments.
Calls to the I.R.S. toll-free number for assistance or problem resolution (it's listed in most telephone directories under United States Government) usually get a polite reception.
People who employ illegal workers can still obey the tax law, and in the meantime help the worker apply for legal status.
The employer must fill out all the tax forms and deposit all the tax payments. If the employee has no Social Security number, "SSA 205(c)" should be written in any space where the number is requested. That's legal shorthand for saying that the worker is not allowed to have a Social Security number.
If you get letters asking about this matter, simply write that the worker is not eligible under the law for a Social Security number. The Government will either drop the matter or issue a number, which doesn't make it legal for the employee to work but keeps the computers happy. Because of privacy rules, such correspondence should not result in prosecution of the worker or the employer.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Paying At-Home Help"
Anybody who pays a household employee like a a babysitter, caretaker, cook, gardener or maid, more than $50 a quarter must report the payments to the Internal Revenue Service and pay certain taxes. You do not have to withhold Federal income taxes, although you may do so if the employee requests it. Here are some of the forms involved in meeting the employer's obligations.
 
Application for Employer Identification Number.
 
The indentification number is required by the IRS used by the employer whenever forms are completed.You can apply in writing, ask for a number by phone, or simply mark "none" on forms that ask the number. The I.R.S. will then assign a number and notify you of it. Other forms will then be sent automatically.
 
Application for a Social Security Card.
 
If your employee does not have a Social Security number, he or she must obtain one using this form.
 
Employer's Withholding Allowance Certificate.
 
If you agree to withhold income tax from an employee's paycheck, the employee must fill out this form so that you can calculate how much to withhold.
 
Advance Payment of Earned Income Credit.
 
If your employee has a child, earns less than $23,050 a year, and requests this benefit, a Federal program that aids the working poor, you must obtain this form from the employee and pay the credit in advance with each paycheck. Every payday you make the advance payment to the employee from the withheld taxes that you would otherwise pay the I.R.S. The payments are reported on form W-2 at year end.
 
Employer's Quarterly Tax Return for Household Employees.
 
This simple, eight-line form must be filed four times a year. On it you record the wages paid to the workers and the taxes paidfor Social Security, Medicare, and the income taxes, if you withhold income tax for the employee.
 
Employer's Annual Federal Unemployment Tax Return.
 
This is a tax paid by the empoyer to help fund unemployment compensation. Most household employers can use the short version of this form, 940-EZ. For small amounts, this tax can be paid annually, but if the amount owed by the employer is more than $100 at the end of any quarter, it must be deposited then. Most states also have an unemployment tax -- and separate state forms are required -- but payments to the state can be credited against those to the Federal government.
 
Wage and Tax Statement.
 
This form must be given to the employee by January 31. It summarizes all wages paid and taxes withheld in the prior year.
 
Transmittal of Income and Tax Statements. This tells this Social Security program what the worker earned.y March 1, this must be sent to the Social Security Administration along with Copy A of Form W-2.
 
To Receive tax forms and publications, call the Internal Revenue Service at the toll-free number found in the U.S. Government listings in most telephone directories. Ask for Publication 926, Employment Taxes for Housefhold Employers, and Publication 937, Employment Taxes and Information Returns.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Regulation Isn't Halting Loans, U.S. Aide Says

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
The Government's top auditor today warned Congress and the Clinton Administration not to hastily loosen banking regulations to spur lending and stimulate the economy.
In testimony rebutting some recent arguments by banking-industry leaders that excessive regulation was crimping lending, the Comptroller General, Charles A. Bowsher, told the Senate Banking Committee that "the current system of bank regulation as a whole does not undermine the economic incentive for a bank to make sound loans." 
 President Clinton and his economic advisers have spoken favorably of the idea of reviewing banking regulations to see if relaxing them would reduce credit restrictions affecting small business.
And banking-industry lobbyists are mounting a vigorous effort to change regulations they consider most burdensome, like ones that help regulators verify that banks are lending to clients in the communities where they take in deposits.
 
Bankers Who Don't Lend
 Critics say that recent regulations, including those required by the bank deposit insurance law enacted in 1991, make it difficult for bankers to justify commercial and industrial loans to some customers, while rewarding the banks for investing in Government securities.
Mr. Bowsher, who heads the General Accounting Office, was instrumental in advising Congress as it tightened regulations in the wake of the widespread failures of some banks and of many savings and loan institutions. He said today that it was unfair to blame the new laws for the difficulties that some borrowers are having in getting loans.
"Congress, the Administration and the financial regulators should exercise great caution in considering short-term measures to encourage more liberal lending practices by insured institutions," he said in a written report submitted to the Senate panel.
Many banks are reporting record earnings, largely because the difference between short-term and long-term interest rates allows them to profitably invest deposits in Government securities. That has made banks' total investments in Government securities higher than in commercial and industrial loans, the first such occurrence in 27 years.
Mr. Bowsher cautioned that many banks still held problem loans. And he argued that there were factors other than Federal regulation behind the heavy bank purchases of Treasury obligations in preference to making business loans.
First, he declared, is relatively low demand for commercial loans, something he said had been induced by the recession.
Second is the trend among corporate borrowers and banks to correct "the excessive reliance on debt in the 1980's."
Third are more demanding standards being applied to real estate loans, which he called an appropriate response to "the disastrous experiences of many banks and thrifts with this type of lending in the 1980's."
Finally, he cited the continuing loss of market share by banks in the face of competition from finance companies and other sources of credit.
Bankers depict the situation differently. Leland M. Stenehjem Jr., president of First International Bank of Fargo, N.D., said at a Washington news conference on Tuesday that "the regulatory burden is costing banks a bundle, and it is hampering our ability to lend."
Mr. Stenehjem was presenting a study commissioned by the Independent Bankers Association of America, which represents smaller community banks, that found that the nation's 9,600 community banks spend about $3.2 billion a year to comply with 13 Federal regulations. The cost, the group said, was equivalent to nearly a quarter of pretax income.
Some of the Senate panel members expressed sympathy for the bankers' views. Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, both berated Mr. Bowsher for not acknowledging what they said were serious problems with heavy regulation.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
A First Step Toward an 800-Seat Jet

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
The Boeing Company and the four leading European aerospace companies took the first step today toward jointly building a superjumbo airliner capable of carrying up to 800 passengers.
The five companies reached an agreement after several months of negotiation that calls for the European companies -- partners in the Airbus Industrie consortium, the world's No. 2 aircraft producer -- to conduct a one-year study with Boeing, the industry leader, of the demand among airlines for such a plane. 
 The trans-Atlantic joint venture, potentially the largest international deal by far in an industry rapidly seeking out global alliances, will also study the antitrust implications of the partnership, the technical problems of building an aircraft far bigger than the 400-passenger Boeing 747, and the ability of the companies to work together.
If the program goes ahead into full-scale development and production -- a decision the companies said would not be made for at least six months -- the new plane would probably come into service around the turn of the century. The main customers are likely to be airlines flying between the United States and Asia and between Europe and Asia.
 
Unlikely Partners
 Both Boeing and Airbus, which has grown rapidly in the last five years to supplant the McDonnell Douglas Corporation of St. Louis as the industry's No. 2, have been interested for years in building a huge new aircraft, although until recently they seemed unlikely to do it together.
Boeing and Airbus have been increasingly bitter rivals, with Boeing arguing that Airbus's success has been built on billions of dollars of subsidies from the Governments of France, Germany, Britain and Spain. The European companies are Aerospatiale of France, Deutsche Aerospace of Germany, British Aerospace and Construcciones Aeronauticas S.A. of Spain.
But Airbus and Boeing have been driven together on the superjumbo project by the immense costs involved. Developing such a plane could cost $10 billion or more, an amount that industry executives said no single company could afford, especially during a period of slack demand for new planes from recession-racked airlines. Boeing said on Tuesday that it would slash production of the 747 and its other planes because of a lack of new orders, cutbacks that will lead to an estimated 15,000 layoffs from the Seattle-based company.
The superjumbo program would be particularly risky because initial assessments by Boeing suggest that airlines would ultimately purchase no more than 600 of the planes, and perhaps as few as 300, small numbers given the necessary investment. By contrast, Boeing has sold nearly 1,200 747's and more than 3,000 of its smaller 737's.
"The limited potential market combined with the costs of developing a plane of unprecedented size makes it a riskier proposition than launching any other Boeing airplane," said John Hayhurst, a Boeing vice president who is in charge of the company's efforts to build a superjumbo. "Because of the limited market and because we think the market can only accommodate one airplane of that size, we thought it would be worthwhile to consider spreading the risk among a number of companies."
The study phase of the joint venture, which the companies said would involve only small expenditures, will be headed by Mr. Hayhurst and by Jurgen Thomas, the head of research and development at Deutsche Aerospace. The companies said they had made no decision on what ownership stakes they might take in the venture if it went forward. But analysts said the initial structure suggested that Boeing would like to own 50 percent, commensurate with its status as the industry leader, with the European companies splitting the remainder.
Boeing has close ties to the largest aircraft manufacturers in Japan, and has been discussing their involvement in a superjumbo jet for some time. Mr. Hayhurst said those discussions were continuing, and he said he would not rule out participation by Japan or by other nations in either the study phase or in any eventual production.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Is Mostly Higher In Relatively Light Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose in listless trading yesterday against all currencies but the Canadian dollar.
Gold prices fell in domestic and European markets after rising in Asia. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $329.90 a troy ounce, down $1.20 from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank said gold lost $1.40 an ounce, to a late bid price of $329.60. 
 The dollar gained in Europe and continued to advance when trading shifted to United States markets. But analysts said the dollar was confined to a relatively narrow range against most currencies and that trading was uneventful.
"There was a lot of technical trading," said Kevin Lawrie, a dealer with Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. "There's a lot of big positioning with fund managers, corporate dealers, and that's pushing the market rather than" interest rate differentials.
Mr. Lawrie said there was little reaction to the Congressional testimony yesterday by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan. Mr. Greenspan said he believed the long-awaited economic recovery was gaining strength but warned of a host of problems that remained unresolved.
 
Dollar at 124 Yen in Japan
 In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 124.00 Japanese yen, up 0.10 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, it rose to 124.10 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 124.10 yen, up from 123.55 yen on Tuesday.
The British pound continued to drop after Tuesday's surprise one-point cut in interest rates by the Bank of England.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.5145, from $1.5355 late Tuesday. In New York it cost $1.5105 to buy one pound, less expensive than Tuesday's $1.5380.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.5865 German marks, up from 1.5770; 1.4630 Swiss francs, up from 1.4530; 5.3700 French francs, up from 5.3310; 1,485.50 Italian lire, up from 1,450.00, and 1.2683 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2713.
Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $330.40 a troy ounce, from $330.95 bid late Tuesday. In Zurich, it fell to a closing bid of $330.30 from $331.00. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.91 to close at $331.06.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Market Fund Yields Were Mixed in Latest Week

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER

 BODY:
Yields on money-market funds were mixed in the latest week, reflecting a steady Federal monetary policy and the normal year-end effect on yields.
The average yield on tax-exempt funds rose, while the yield on taxable funds was unchanged. 
 According to IBC/Donoghue's Money Market Fund Report, assets of tax-exempt money funds fell by $2.4 billion, to $100.9 billion. The average number of days to maturity of securities held in tax-exempt fund portfolios was unchanged, at 55 days.
 
Tax-Exempt Yield: 1.87%
 The seven-day average compounded tax-exempt yield rose 14 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 1.87 percent. The simple yield rose 13 basis points, to 1.85 percent.
Over a 30-day period, the average compound and simple yields were both down 18 basis points, to 2.14 percent and 2.12 percent, respectively.
Not assuming state taxes, the taxable equivalent of the seven-day compounded tax-exempt yield of 1.87 percent is 2.60 percent for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket, while the equivalent for investors in the 31 percent tax bracket is about 2.71.
In its weekly survey of tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million, IBC/Donoghue's said that Dreyfus Basic Municipal was the best-performing fund, with a seven-day compounded return of 2.63 percent.
Walter S. Frank, chief economist for IBC/Donoghue's, said that the rise in tax-free yields reflected the outflow of assets from money funds.
"The yields have dropped so low that people are once again switching out of funds into higher-yielding long- term tax-exempt bonds." he said.
 
Taxable Fund Assets Up
 Meanwhile, yields in taxable money market funds were unchanged from last week, as assets increased by $6.4 billion, to $488.6 billion. The average number of days to maturity of securities held in taxable fund portfolios increased by one day, to 60 days.
The major reason for the assets increase was the continued return of institutional assets, which rose $9.2 billion last week. Meanwhile, noninstitutional fund assets fell by $2.8 billion from last week.
"It is normal for institutional investors to get back into taxable funds at this time of the year," Mr. Frank said. "But the public is switching to both bonds and stocks for higher yields."
Mr. Frank said that he expected rates to hold firm in the week ahead. "The immediate outlook is that yields have returned close to a level that we expect to hold for some time," he said.
 
Taxable Yield: 2.81%
 Both the seven-day compound and simple average rates for taxable funds were unchanged, at 2.81 percent and 2.77 percent, respectively. For 30-day average rates, both compound and simple rates fell one basis point, to 2.87 percent and 2.83 percent, respectively.
Olde Premium Plus Money Market Series, distributed by Olde Asset Management Inc. in Detroit, remained the top-yielding fund with assets over $100 million. But its yield this week slipped to 3.71 percent, down four basis points from 3.75 percent a week ago.
By comparison, the average bank money account was 2.74 percent, unchanged from last week, according to The Bank Rate Monitor.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
If cars become trucks, the middle class may bear the freight.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
WHILE Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen acknowledged this week that the White House was agonizing about a middle-class tax increase to pare the deficit, Mr. Bentsen was not advertising the fact that the Treasury could soon impose a new tax aimed squarely at the middle class with the stroke of a pen.
The catch: Most of the revenue would end up in the pockets of Detroit's auto makers, which are reportedly pressing on a variety of fronts for a helping hand from Uncle Sam. Well, make that catches. The tax -- actually a tariff on imported mini-vans and Jeep-like sport utility vehicles -- would further sour economic relations with Japan and distract from the "strategic" trade issues in high technology. 
 The levy, on the agenda of the first meeting of President Clinton's new National Economic Council, which will most likely be held in early February, would come innocently packaged as a Customs Service reclassification of some 200,000 imported "multipurpose vehicles," like Toyota's Previa mini-van and Mitsubishi's Montero, as trucks rather than passenger cars. The resulting increase in the duty to 25 percent, from 2.5 percent, would add thousands of dollars to the imports' sticker prices. More ominous, it would give Detroit's Big Three, which already have more than 80 percent of this market, a freer hand to raise prices.
This tale, no joke, began with the Great Chicken War of 1962. When West Germany tripled duties on imported poultry to please its European Common Market partners, America retaliated with a batch of tariffs that applied to all countries, but were really aimed at the Europeans. The bird battle was settled long ago, and most of the retaliatory tariffs have been rescinded by Presidential order. But the 25 percent light-truck tariff, initially aimed at Volkswagen, is still on the books. And it gives Detroit an edge against Japanese rivals who were innocent bystanders in the chicken war.
Irony has since been piled on irony. As a favor to American makers of mini-vans and sport utility vehicles, Congress initially classified these newly popular vehicles as trucks in order to exempt them from strict auto emissions and safety regulations. And while hardly anyone -- certainly not the ad agencies -- thinks of Dodge Caravans or Ford Explorers primarily as commercial cargo haulers, Detroit has been using the break it got on safety and emissions standards as a wedge to demand that the Treasury reclassify the almost entirely Japanese competition as high-tariff trucks.
The Bush White House offered an arbitrary concession to Detroit in 1989, applying the 25 percent truck rate only to sport utility vehicles with just two doors. But the issue arose again in the 1992 elections. In September, Congress barely defeated a bill to do for Detroit what George Bush would not. And in the last week of the campaign, with polls tightening in Michigan, Clinton-Gore strategists ran a television ad deriding President Bush for giving "the Japanese an unfair advantage over our trucks, and our workers."
This is not a policy question that generates a lot of head-scratching among mainstream economists. "There is no argument for a developed country to protect old-line producers of middle technology with a 25 percent tariff," declares Robert Crandall of the Brookings Institution.
Moreover, the 25 percent could mean real money for middle-class families, the sort that use their $15,000 mini-vans to cart around three tots, four bags of groceries and scads of old newspapers bound for recycling. Even "buying American" would not exempt consumers from the inflationary clout of the import reclassification. Citizens for a Sound Economy, a nonprofit Washington group that lobbies against economic regulation, used earlier academic studies of auto protectionism to project that Detroit would raise multipurpose vehicle prices by 40 cents for every extra dollar of tariff -- an average of $1,300.
Is the deal wired, as reports following President-elect Clinton's private Jan. 5 meeting with auto executives suggested? Maybe not. When pushed on the NBC News program "Meet the Press" on Jan. 17, Al Gore responded that "no commitment was made" at the auto meeting. And there are reasons to believe that Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the newly appointed chairwoman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, will oppose the change. Ms. Tyson, known as advocating "cautious activism" in trade policy, may want to take pains to differentiate the championing of American cutting-edge technologies from garden-variety protection of an influential industry undergoing hard times.
In the end, of course, the choice will be President Clinton's. His decision could say a lot about how he plans to cope with conflict between the old, blue-collar constituencies and the suburban pragmatists, who apparently voted Democratic this time because they were frustrated by stagnating living standards.
Mr. Clinton has long argued that globalization of the economy cannot be slowed, only better molded to American interests. That mold would be hard to fashion on the precedent of a long-forgotten food fight with Europe.

HEADLINE: U.S. Pay Gains in '92 Trailed Inflation Rate

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
Americans' pay failed to keep up with rising prices in 1992, the Government said this week. Including benefits, however, overall compensation did outpace inflation.
The Labor Department said its employment cost index showed that total compensation -- wages, salaries and benefits -- rose 3.5 percent last year, the smallest increase since the Government began computing the index in 1982. 
 In 1991, total compensation rose 4.3 percent.
While 1992 compensation surpassed the 2.9 percent rate of inflation, wages and salaries did not, edging up 2.7 percent. That, too, is the smallest advance since 1982.
Wages and salaries, which represent about 75 percent of worker compensation, rose 3.6 percent in 1991, outpacing the 3.1 percent inflation rate that year.

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%);

HEADLINE: Essay;
NATO on the Brink

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
Looking southward in 1876, Bismarck of Germany, borrowing a phrase from Frederick the Great, recoiled from Continental responsibility: "The Balkans are not worth the healthy bones of a single Pomeranian musketeer."
Many Americans today feel the same way. What the rapacious Serbs have been doing to the Bosnians is horrible, and what the Croats are now doing to the Bosnians as they get even with the Serbs is almost as bad -- but what do all these ancient hatreds have to do with us? 
 Our inclination is to translate Bismarck's isolation into Lyndon Johnsonese: "I don't have a dog in this fight."
But when television brings film of suffering into our homes, and rescue workers and journalists report rapine and genocide, Americans are moved to a more principled position. We say human-righteously: You Europeans ought to do something about the evil rampant on your own Continent.
So European leaders hold peace talks to legitimize current conquests. They loosely apply economic sanctions. They send in peacekeepers to provide humanitarian aid, treating the victims rather than confronting the perpetrators. The U.N. labors over imposition of meaningless flight restrictions.
Result: Aggression is rewarded and war spreads in the former Yugoslavia.
American public sentiment is now becoming prepared for another half-step: to allow the Bosnians to arm themselves and die for their country. We may even provide air cover and satellite intelligence for European troops, and threaten to bomb Serbian artillery now killing civilians.
Today, the essential American message to Europe seems to be: If you take the lead, we'll help, but our help has to be technological and not the sort that generates outcries of opposition.
This qualified offer to hold Europe's coat does not go over well with our allies. They much prefer that the superpower take the lead in the Balkans, which would give them political cover at home; barring that, they wish some hawkish Americans would stop talking about serious military response, because it may jeopardize the present conscience-salving treatment of the symptoms.
That's the state of play as the Clinton Administration takes its place at the world table. Here are three facts that face our new policy makers:
1. Collective security is no longer limited to defending national borders; a nascent understanding grows that ethnic minorities are entitled to international protection.
2. Europeans are capable of being shamed into taking action to enforce this new concept of collective security, but unless America does the active shaming, Europe's leaders will shrink from their responsibility.
3. America, if it is to have the standing to call for effective action, must be ready to share the risk. We should be prepared to help pose a threat on the ground as well as in the air -- perhaps as a symbolic part of a muscular NATO force that could be assembled in Macedonia, protecting that region as well as the ethnic Albanians who live in Serbia's Kosovo. This would not be a vulnerable contingent riding shotgun for the Red Cross; it would be a powerful deterrent ready to counterattack ethnic cleansers.
American public opinion is far from ready for this. Is President Clinton, so eager to begin domestic innovation, ready to begin preparing the ground for such a foreign commitment?
To do so, he must ask his aides: Why isn't the Pentagon working with allies to prepare a battle plan that might intimidate local aggressors into settlement without war? He must also ask France, Germany, Britain: Are the stable nations of Western Europe prepared to offer the carrot of economic incentives to the Balkans and to other impoverished peoples to the south and east?
We are entering the season that will decide whether NATO lives or dies. A misstep could cost lives; inaction will cost lives and an alliance. America cannot impose its ideals on its allies, but if the nations of Europe are unwilling to defend their innocents, those nations can hardly expect America to help defend their borders.

HEADLINE: Break the Billion-Dollar Congress

BYLINE: By Joseph A. Califano Jr.; Joseph A. Califano Jr., president of the Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University, was Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare from 1977 to 1979 and President Lyndon B. Johnson's assistant for domestic affairs from 1965 to 1969.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The members of Congress elected in November join the first national legislature that private interests have paid more than $1 billion to put in place. So long as they need private financing for future campaigns, these elected officials are not likely to slap the wrists of the hands that delivered the money, much less get into a bare-knuckled fight with their political action committees.
If President Clinton and the Democratic Congress are serious about ending gridlock, the first law to pass is not an economic package or national health plan. It is legislation to provide public financing and set limits on spending in Congressional races. 
 Private interests and PAC contributors have acquired veto power in key committees over proposals that threaten them. They spent $314 million for the 1992 House elections and $581 million on the 1988, 1990 and 1992 elections that produced the current Senate. Back-door support and money raised by political parties added at least $100 million last year alone.
So long as private money clogs the corridors of power, any economic package President Clinton gets from Congress will include the same payoffs to PAC's that the House and Senate stuffed into the 647-page tax bill George Bush vetoed last year.
Campaign finance reform is also the first hurdle for any health-care legislation. Lyndon Johnson was the only President with the political strength and savvy to drive major health reform through Congress. But he had to pay the private pipers to enact it.
In 1964 Johnson couldn't get the Senate Finance or House Ways and Means Committees to move his bill. Late that year he mustered the votes on the Senate floor to attach Medicare to a House bill raising Social Security benefits. But the House would not accept the Senate bill. So shortly before the 1964 election, he killed the Social Security increase. He wanted popular pressure for the increase to help get Medicare through the next Congress.
Johnson then won by the greatest landslide in U.S. history, carrying into office a two-to-one Democratic majority in the House. Yet to cobble together a House Ways and Means Committee majority for Medicare and Medicaid, Johnson had to abandon the authority his bill gave the Government to set medical reimbursement rates. He was compelled to agree to pay doctors "reasonable," "customary" and "prevailing" fees -- something commercial insurers had refused to do because it gave physicians power to raise their own fees.
Almost immediately, Johnson pressed to change the payment system. Without action, he predicted, health costs would be $100 billion by 1975. Pressured by industry lobbyists, Congress failed to act. By 1975, health care costs hit $133 billion.
Compare President Clinton's situation, even with the help of his wife, whom he named to head the health reform task force this week. Mr. Clinton won a mere 43 percent of the vote. He faces a more sophisticated industry of well-heeled insurers, doctors, hospitals, pharmaceutical and medical equipment companies, unions, H.M.O.'s and nursing homes. Health PAC's handed out an estimated $22 million in 1992 political contributions, evenly divided between Republicans and Democrats. And the President faces a complex financing system, an aging population and a technological revolution that require a far more intricate legislative fix.
Mr. Clinton has the benefit of demand for reform from citizens and businesses. A shrewd and tenacious politician, he has the best shot to reshape the health care system of any President since L.B.J. What a shame it will be if he fails to clear out the PAC mines before he sets foot on the legislative battlefield.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Avoiding Carter's Mistakes

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Bill Clinton may not know it -- and certainly won't like to hear it -- but much of what he has said about foreign policy echoes Jimmy Carter's campaign themes and policies. This coincidence merits the new President's attention -- for voters booted Mr. Carter after four years, in good part because of his troubles abroad.
The rhetorical similarities are startling. Both Democrats courted the liberal vote by stressing a new agenda in world affairs: promoting human rights and democracy, curbing the spread of nuclear and conventional arms, emphasizing centrality of international economics, promising cuts in military spending, etc. 
 Both appealed to conservatives by preaching toughness: the Georgia Governor slammed Henry Kissinger for being too soft on Moscow about human rights and strategic arms; the Arkansas Governor repeatedly suggested that he'd be even harder on foreign outlaws than President Bush.
The big difference, of course, is that Mr. Clinton does not have to worry about the cold war. Mr. Carter stumbled badly in trying to downplay the Soviet-American rivalry at the very peak of its crescendo.
Mr. Carter failed mainly because of confusion and weakness in his Soviet policy. He faltered elsewhere not because his ideas were wrong, but because he never packaged them strategically and coherently. He also flopped because he never understood the politics of foreign policy.
Mr. Carter's most evident flops -- doing little to deter crises in Iran and Afghanistan -- were no worse than those of his Republican successors. Ronald Reagan sent the Marines to Beirut to protect U.S. "vital interests," only to withdraw them without explanation after 241 troops were killed in a terrorist attack. Against common sense and his stated policy, he traded arms for hostages with Iran. And George Bush coddled Saddam Hussein, flattering him and giving him grain credits right up to the moment he invaded Kuwait.
Meanwhile, Mr. Carter's successes were about as impressive as the Republicans' over the next 12 years. Mr. Reagan "conquered" Grenada and ushered in the Gorbachev revolution. Mr. Bush "vanquished" Panama, helped ease the death of Communism and earned a genuine triumph building the Desert Storm coalition.
Mr. Carter pulled off the Panama Canal treaties, full ties with China, a strategic arms accord with the Soviet Union and the invaluable Camp David peace treaty between Israel and Egypt. He also concluded a major free trade agreement and pushed human rights and democracy to the top of the U.S. policy agenda.
Yet these accomplishments never loomed as large as they should have. They seemed isolated and ad hoc, unilluminated by a grand design. Nor did he prepare Americans or allies for failure by spotlighting dangers ahead or explaining how his strategy would accommodate setbacks.
Unlike Mr. Reagan, Mr. Carter did not understand the need to smother fiascos with bold new action. The day after the terrorist attack in Beirut, the Old Gipper invaded Grenada. Unlike Mr. Kissinger, Mr. Carter did not know how to ignore his failures and exaggerate his successes.
In particular, Mr. Carter's farsighted new agenda for world politics lacked an anchoring overall strategy, and thus looked both radical and incoherent. He never laid out how he would press unsavory allies on human rights without undermining their regimes. He tried to halt the proliferation of arms without first laying the necessary groundwork. He failed to show how his innovative policies fit together and profoundly affected people's lives.
Mr. Carter's disinclination to be tough and appear tough also proved self-destructive. The arbiters of "toughness" -- principally Republicans, media stars and foreign leaders -- quickly portrayed him as weak. That reputation invited everyone's challenge. Worst of all, Mr. Carter rarely exacted a price from his detractors at home or abroad.
Like Mr. Carter's, Mr. Clinton's instincts seem to be conciliatory. But he insists that he appreciates the value of toughness. Many of his allies wouldn't mind a demonstration volley against a political adversary.
Unlike Mr. Carter, Mr. Clinton always talks about something he calls "strategy." But it seems more like general themes followed by lists. A strategy explains why something needs to be done -- and how.

HEADLINE: We Have to Break Persian Gulf Oil Habit

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As an epilogue to Leslie H. Gelb's superb "Iraq Balancing Iran?" (column, Jan. 17), there is yet another cogent reason for decreasing, even abandoning, our dependence on Persian Gulf oil. 
 As unbelievable as it appears, several months ago when the spot price of oil oscillated between $20 and $21 a barrel, the real total price that it cost our country (now hold your breath) was $90 a barrel.
Just as the total price one pays for a mail-order catalogue purchase adds on postage and handling, the cost of maintaining our fleet in the Persian Gulf to insure safe passage must be prorated over every gallon we import.
This figure comes from the Center for Defense Information, which is headed by Rear Adm. Gene LaRoque of the United States Navy (retired) and staffed by other former top-level military personnel. Their expertise and patriotism are unquestioned.
Two of our closest allies, Japan and Germany, are much more dependent on Persian Gulf oil than we are. Their defense budgets over the years have been less than 1 percent of their gross domestic product. Ours have been five to six times greater. They are both creditor nations, while we have the unenviable distinction of being the largest debtor nation in the world.
Among the myriad problems confronting the Clinton Administration, the Department of Energy should make one of its top priorities a much more vigorous approach to conservation and alternate energy sources. Tens of billions of dollars are just begging to be saved to help reduce our deficit.
 
HERBERT BARCHOFF
New York, Jan. 17, 1993
The writer has served on the President's Council of Economic Advisers.

HEADLINE: AT HOME WITH -- Michael Lebron;
The Adman as Artist (Or Is It Vice Versa?)

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Michael A. Lebron wants to spend $100,000 of his own money to spread some of his most personal political beliefs across a 1,000-square-foot billboard at the mouth of Pennsylvania Station, in a piece of art that he has nurtured for more than two years. But he insists -- absolutely insists -- that he doesn't much care if anybody knows that he's the one behind it.
"I don't like to have my work personalized," said Mr. Lebron, 38, a freelance advertising art director, who for a decade has used the methods of Madison Avenue (and his credit cards and savings) to make political art in public spaces in New York and Washington. "I like to think of my work as being styleless, without any stylistic identity or trademark to it," he said. 
 If there is a trademark to Mr. Lebron's work, it may be that he wants to display it in places others don't want to let him use. In a case that went to trial yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan, he is suing Amtrak over its refusal to let him use the 103-foot billboard in the lobby of Pennsylvania Station, known as the Spectacular, to lambaste the controlling owners of the Coors Brewing Company for their support of conservative political causes.
So far, this work -- a striking parody of a Coors beer ad, with 20 photographic images blended by computer into a high-gloss whole -- exists only as a three-foot backlit mockup in the bedroom of Mr. Lebron's loft in a former pet-food warehouse on Cooper Square in the East Village. Yet, to hear him talk about it is to see it hanging high, greeting -- and, he seems to hope, unnerving -- tens of thousands of commuters a day.
But unlike Gladys Glover, the aspiring celebrity played by Judy Holliday in "It Should Happen to You," who plastered her name on a billboard at Columbus Circle just to be noticed, Mr. Lebron is no mere self-promoter. This compact polemicist, whose baby face, pony tail and granny glasses make him look like a cross between John Lennon and Radar O'Reilly of "M*A*S*H," does not even sign his work. He just copyrights it in the name of ATW (for "Against the Wall") Communications.
"I like to think that I create work in such a way that I use whatever visual and textual elements are necessary to communicate an idea," he said one evening last week in his large, sleekly arranged living room. "And to the extent that it's possible, to reduce my identity or personality as an artist."
"There's something," he said, then paused, "facile, I guess, about trying to say that 'Well, I'm not important,' because obviously I'm the one who's doing it and not somebody else. But my personality should not be the issue." The next day he called his visitor to say the word he'd been groping for was "disingenuous," not "facile."
Mr. Lebron (pronounced luh-BRUN) calls his work social realism for a "consumer, corporatist society" in which advertising is the medium of mass idealization. He says his goal is to recreate previously available information in more visually arresting forms. He is nothing if not serious, about his work and himself, though it takes him such a while to warm to both subjects that an interviewer at first worries he is too laconic for productive conversation.
"He's very serious," said Gloria Phares, one of his lawyers. "He loves to talk -- especially about himself. I think he has a sense of humor."
But, she added, "I don't think he has a sense of humor about this."
Mr. Lebron's mission requires an ordered life. He stresses that he works 12- and 13-hour days in advertising to finance his art. He shares his tidy lair with two cats and a woman he will identify only as Sylvia.
At the center of his current artistic vision is a silver beer can, wrapped in flame and hurtling like a missile, propelled out of the heedless, smiling faces of American consumers into a street of huddled Nicaraguan villagers, under the words: "Is it the right's beer now?" -- a reference to some Coors family members' support for the contra rebels who fought the Sandinista Government and a play on the company's lite-beer slogan, "It's the right beer now."
But whether this vision will be shared with the public remains to be seen. Mr. Lebron had a contract with Amtrak's leasing agent, but Amtrak has the final right of approval and late last month, the railroad told him its policy prohibited political ads on the Spectacular, which now celebrates Levi's "Loose Jeans."
Amtrak is a private corporation, but because it gets about 20 percent of its budget from the Federal Government, and its directors are appointed by the President, Mr. Lebron contends that its billboard is more like public property than private enterprise and that it therefore cannot give preference to the commercial speech of Levi's over the political speech of Lebron. Oral arguments were heard yesterday by Judge Pierre N. Leval, who presided at the trial of Gen. William C. Westmoreland's libel suit against CBS.
Mr. Lebron has a few notches on his own belt. In 1984, he won the right to display in the Washington subway posters that used a photomontage of Ronald Reagan and his economic advisers at a table, with the President smiling and pointing at a cluster of dispossessed citizens (actually Mr. Lebron's friends, who posed on his roof); the caption said, "Are you tired of the Jellybean Republic?"
His champions in that case included a three-judge Federal appeals court panel of sterling conservatives: Kenneth W. Starr, who became Solicitor General of the United States; Antonin Scalia, who went on to the Supreme Court, and Robert H. Bork, who wrote the opinion upholding Mr. Lebron's right to show the work -- a blow for free speech that was cited by many of Judge Bork's defenders in the unsuccessful fight to confirm his nomination to the Supreme Court.
The current case is considerably more complex and involves reams of records and financial ganglia growing out of the bankruptcy of the old Penn Central Railroad that led to Amtrak's control of the station. Amtrak spokesmen declined to comment on the case, citing a policy of not discussing pending litigation. But in court papers, its lawyers contend that Amtrak is a private entity, with no obligation to display political advertising. Moreover, they assert that Mr. Lebron showed the content of the ad to the leasing company only after he had already signed the contract because he was concerned that they might never have signed it had they known.
Even if Amtrak is forced to let Mr. Lebron display the work, he would undoubtedly face more objections from Coors, which might sue for trademark infringement or libel. John M. Meadows, Coors's director of community relations, said it was awaiting the outcome of the current case before deciding what to do.
Of Mr. Lebron's contention that the work is an allegory on American power and not an attack on Coors per se, he said, "Well, it certainly is an attack."
Mr. Lebron seems discomfited at belonging neither fully to the world of art nor to that of advertising. Even most avant-garde galleries are uninterested in his art. "The response," he said, "has mostly been that it's too utilitarian, or looks too much like advertising.
"Or maybe, they just think I'm a bad artist."
This visual anarchist grew up in rural New Jersey, the son of an export-traffic clerk. After graduating from Cooper Union in the mid-70's, he spent three years as a calligrapher, engraving corporate testimonials and certificates (where he was paid "like a monk in an abbey") before working his way into advertising art direction.
For the last eight years, he has freelanced, mostly working on ads for prescription pharmaceuticals, a discipline that requires copious research and documentation -- which helps explain why footnotes speckle the text of his Coors parody. He said he "just sort of fell into" this field, but that "with hindsight, it probably wasn't an accident."
"I was probably instinctually gravitating toward it, because I'd be hard pressed to imagine myself doing ads for, you know, dog food and that sort of thing," he said. "And then the work is pretty regular and stable and pays pretty well."
That is an important consideration, since he has no patron. If this project goes through, he said, he will have spent about $170,000 over the last decade, more than half of it on his current effort. The two-month rental of the billboard alone would cost $36,000, while, he said, his income varies but is less than $100,000 a year.
"It's fair to say that I make enough to be able to do this," he said. "It's just that instead of buying a condominium or sports car or whatever, I do this."
Though he has received government subsidies for some projects, he has not this time.
"Unlike Amtrak," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 29, 1993, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article in The Home Section yesterday about the artist Michael Lebron referred incorrectly in some editions to the cost of renting the large billboard in the lobby of Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan. The rental for two months is $36,000.
