HEADLINE: Texas Bank Sold by U.S. To Chemical

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
In an indication that the nation's banking industry and the Texas economy are returning to health, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said yesterday that it had sold the 20 banks of the failed First City Bancorporation of Texas for far more than expected, mostly to the Chemical Banking Corporation.
The F.D.I.C. had estimated that the Bank Insurance Fund would lose $500 million rescuing the banks, which the Government seized on Oct. 30.
But the bids were so much higher than expected that the deal will not cost the fund anything. Indeed, uninsured depositors and possibly First City shareholders will get more money than expected -- potentially as much as $60 million.
 
Terms of Transactions
 Chemical's Texas Commerce Bankshares unit will pay $346.8 million for First City's banks in Houston, Dallas and three other cities, which have a total of $4.4 billion in deposits and $6.6 billion in assets. Eleven other companies will pay $87.6 million for 15 banks in smaller Texas cities. 
 The cost to the banks making the acquisitions will be higher because they will have to cover some or all the cost of future losses from First City loans. The buyers will also have to put fresh capital -- roughly 5 percent of assets -- into the banks.
For the Dallas and Houston banks, the F.D.I.C. has agreed to cover 80 percent of the losses from $2.1 billion in commercial loans, up to $82 million, and 95 percent of losses above that. Marc J. Shapiro, president of Texas Commerce, said he expected the losses to run higher than the $82 million level.
The Federal agency has been using this sort of loss-sharing arrangement on sales of failed banks for about a year. Before that, it covered all loan losses, including on the sales of the other major Texas banks in trouble.
The Government was able to get banks to accept a higher percentage of the loan losses here, and to bid more than expected, because of the improving economy and also because of a broad network of banking-industry contacts, said Harrison Young, director of the F.D.I.C.'s resolutions division said.
"We were not a forced seller," Mr. Young said. "We were able to generate an enormous amount of competition. We worked very hard at it. The timing turnout to be fortuitous. A lot of people think that it's a great time to expand in Texas."
The amount paid for the Texas banks was far more than in any previous Government sale of a failed institution. Chemical's bid, for example, represents 7.8 percent of First City's deposits. The winning bidders for Southeast Bank in Miami and the Bank of New England both paid less than 1 percent of deposits.
Frank Anderson, an analyst with Stephens Inc. in Little Rock, remarked, "I can't remember a bank paying this high a premium -- even 3 or 4 percent is pretty rich."
Chemical says the deal will improve its profits within a year because it will be able to cut costs by eliminating 1,700 of First City's 3,700 jobs and closing 24 of 58 offices.
Chemical's bid reflected the fact that First City was the largest remaining independent bank in Texas and presented an opportunity for Texas Commerce, the third largest in the state, to increase its market share. "This is the last significant transaction in Texas," Mr. Shapiro said.
Moreover, with the economy improving there, First City's assets may not have been as hard to sell as the F.D.I.C. expected. Some investment bankers who examined the deal said the price Chemical paid, while high, was fair.
"No one ever overpaid the Government and I don't think First City is any different," said Gerald Smith of Salomon Brothers, who specializes in banks. He said that Texas Commerce Bankshares, already the largest bank in Houston and the third largest in Dallas, has the economies of scale to make First City profitable.
That Chemical was allowed to make this acquisition is a sign that regulators are pleased with the improvement in the bank's condition after its merger with Manufacturers Hanover in 1991, Mr. Smith said. "This is a signal that Chemical is back," he said. Last year Chemical improved its capital position and earned $1.1 billion.
The outcome of the sale means that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is likely to avoid the politically embarrassing action of having to rescue First City depositors a second time. In September 1987, the agency committed $970 million in assistance to an investor group headed by A. Robert Abboud. But amid continued loan losses, regulators ousted Mr. Abboud two years ago, and in October took control of the banking network.
Uninsured depositors with more than $100,000 in accounts at three of the First City bank units -- in Dallas, Austin and San Antonio -- could recover all their money as a result of the higher bids, Mr. Young said. The original terms set by the F.D.I.C. put the recoveries at 80 cents on the dollar. The F.D.I.C. said today that it would increase that by 10 cents on the dollar. Uninsured depositors at the Houston subsidiary, however, are still likely to suffer losses because of large real estate write-offs charged against assets there.
Mr. Young said the surplus from the sales would be distributed to creditors and shareholders of First City Bankshares, which is now in a Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 28, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Jan. 28 about the sale of the First City Bancorporation by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation misstated the circumstances of the dismissal of the bank's chairman, A. Robert Abboud, in 1991. He was dismissed by the bank's board, not by Government regulators.
